Marketing News TM


January 21, 1991


Nike's quarterly earnings up 58%


BYLINE: by the Associated Press


SECTION: Pg. 8


LENGTH: 159 words


DATELINE: Beaverton, Ore.


Nike Inc.'s second-quarter earnings were up 58% from the same period last year, chairman Philip Knight said.

The strong earnings report comes despite a nationwide boycott of Nike products called by Operation PUSH last August. 

Nike's net income for the three months ended Nov. 30 was $ 58 million, or 77 cents a share. During the same quarter last year, the company earned $ 37 million, or 49 cents per share.

Revenues for the second quarter increased 46% to $ 649 million from $ 446 million in the previous year.

"I think our numbers speak for themselves," said Nike spokeswoman Liz Dolan. Retailers were showing confidence in Nike despite the boycott and general fears of a recession, she said.

Nike said minorities compose 16% of its work force, up from 11% in January 1989. The company said it recruits at black colleges and has made many other efforts to help minorities.

Nike plans to add a minority member to its board by July.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 American Marketing Association

 

110 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


February 8, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


SPORTS BUSINESS;
Reebok ads have Nike considering suit


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 386 words


There are famous new voices in the ongoing jibes between Reebok and Nike.

In a new $ 20 million ad campaign for its Pump sneakers, Reebok airs six TV spots using athletes as spokesmen.

Both companies say it's the first time athlete endorsers have taken shots at the competition. It has also prompted Nike to consider legal action, says Nike ad manager Scott Bedbury, because ''after a callous attack, you can't sit on the sidelines.'' 

The Reebok ads implicitly tweak Nike endorsers. Consumers are meant to think of Nike's Michael Jordan when Reebok's Dominique Wilkins says, ''Michael, my man, if you want to fly first class,'' switch to Pumps. Reebok decathlete Dave Johnson says, ''I'm the man who knows cross-training,'' not Nike's Bo Jackson. Reebok's Boomer Esiason is more direct: ''Boomer knows something that Bo don't know.''

Nike's Bedbury says, ''It saddens us to see (endorsers) misused or abused. ... This doesn't bode well for the ad industry.''

Reebok marketing vice president David Ropes says the ads just reflect reality. ''Athletes' egos are so huge they needle each other. This banter is their professional jargon. Nike is just blowing smoke.''

Where there's smoke, there's publicity - and that helps both companies. ''In the world of competitive noise, both of us benefit,'' says Reebok's Ropes. ''We're battling for a share of consumers' minds.''
 
PUNCH PITCH: The World Boxing Council is considering selling licensed merchandise and might even try to improve its image through a consumer ad campaign. The WBC, a leading boxing sanctioning group, has hired the New York ad agency Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co. to publicize its pension programs and support of medical research. ... Arnold Schwarzenegger appears in free-market economist Milton Friedman's five-part TV series Free to Choose, starting Sunday on CNBC. ''I came from a socialistic country, Austria, (where) you can hear 18-year-old kids already talking about their pension. But me, I wanted more.'' ... ... Junior college quarterback John Kaleo, who signed Wednesday with University of Maryland, shows how sponsors can leave an impression. ''The Weed Eater Bowl,'' Kaleo told The (Baltimore) Sun, ''solidified my decision.'' Maryland tied Louisiana Tech 34-34 in the Poulan/Weed Eater Independence Bowl last December.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

112 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)


July 7, 1992 Tuesday Final Edition


Nike Inc. appeals court ruling


SOURCE: FROM ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. E5


LENGTH: 521 words


DATELINE: MADRID


Nike Inc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of Nike apparel in Spain, a company attorney said yesterday.

Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Oregon-based sports apparel company from using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

Nike Inc., whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, has planned to use the Olympics promotional campaign to launch a new line of sports clothes. 

If further legal actions fail -- and if the courts rule the injunction bars U.S. athletes from wearing Nike uniforms -- the firm stands to lose $20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide, according to company documents.

"We do not believe we've lost the battle by any means, much less the war," said John Faylor, Nike's European lawyer.

But the decision clearly left Nike at a disadvantage in its long-running dispute with Juan Amigo Freixas, the Barcelona lawyer who bought the Nike name from the original registrant, who briefly made socks during the 1930s.

Amigo has reportedly asked Nike for $30 million for rights to the brand, according to Faylor, who has called the Spaniard a "pirate."

Amigo refused to divulge his demands in a recent interview. He said the injunction would prevent Nike from carrying out its Olympics promotion.

Nike, however, claims the decision won't keep athletes from wearing its name when the Games open July 25.

The International Olympic Committee does not consider the uniforms to be a form of advertising or promotion, Faylor said in a telephone interview from Frankfurt.

The arguments against Nike could be strong, however.

In documents filed with the Constitutional Court and the U.S. Trade Representative, Nike itself raised the Olympics sponsorship issue to argue that retaining the injunction would cause irreparable damage to the company.

And since Nike paid millions to The Athletics Congress -- the governing body of U.S. track -- for the right to dress the athletes in Nike gear, the Spanish courts may not look kindly on the company's claim that its sponsorship was mere altruism.

"Nike's sponsorship of the U.S. track and field team during the 1992 Olympic Games is a central component of Nike's long-term international marketing strategy," Nike attorneys wrote the Washington-based U.S. Trade Representative in April.

The prospect of missing out on the Games is particularly painful since Reebok, a fierce competitor in shoes and apparel, is providing the uniforms that all U.S. athletes -- including Nike spokesman Michael Jordan -- will wear on the awards podium if they win medals.

In the meantime, Nike is hoping the Constitutional Court reverses itself -- quickly, with the Olympics less than three weeks away.

The Constitutional Court -- having spoken only on Nike's motion to lift the injunction -- has yet to rule on the validity of Amigo's 60-year-old trademark.


LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Metroland Media Group Ltd

 

114 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury


July 23, 1992 Thursday


LENGTH: 332 words


Legal rebuff to Nike's Games plans Madrid NIKE Incorporated has suffered a major setback in its trademark battle with a Spanish lawyer who has vowed to prevent the US track and field team from wearing Nike's name at the Barcelona Games.

With the Olympics set to open on Saturday and Nike counting on US athletes to show off its new clothing line, a Barcelona court refused to lift its order barring Nike from selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain.

The decision left the US company with few short-term options in its court wrangle with a lawyer, Mr Juan Amigo, who bought the Nike trademark in 1981 from a Barcelona sock company that registered it as a trademark 60 years ago. 

Nike has repeatedly insisted it would not negotiate with Amigo and his ally, the Barcelona clothing company Cidesport, which has asked around $US25 million ($A33.60 million) for rights to the trademark.

But the two sides are scheduled to meet in Madrid, with the encouragement of American diplomats, according to a US embassy spokesman, Mr Paul Saxton.

Nike paid a multi-million dollar sum to put its name on the US and Algerian teams in Barcelona.

Its case has been bolstered by the European Commission, which asked the Spanish government last month to convince the court to allow Nike to post a bond allowing the company to sell its apparel while awaiting a final decision.

The United States has also weighed in on Nike's behalf, placing Spain on a special trade "watch list" for what US officials consider slack trademark laws and enforcement.

The negotiations may be Nike's only chance of following through on its plan to put its name on the Olympic athletes.

Company lawyers say the uniforms are not "advertising", and therefore do not fall under the court order.

But Amigo and Cidesport insist the order bars the Olympic athletes from wearing the uniforms.

The injunction was upheld earlier this month by the Constitutional Tribunal, Spain's highest appeals court.

January 16, 1992, Thursday, DAILY: TORONTO EDITION


Nike athletes used steroids: book


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 39, SPORTS SHORTS


LENGTH: 80 words


DATELINE: Portland, OR


        Steroid use by Nike-sponsored athletes and widespread
under-the-table payments to amateur competitors are among the allegations in a new book about the athletic shoe and apparel giant. A statement from Nike Inc. corporate vice-president Liz Dolan admitted there was truth in some of the stories in the 660-page book - Swoosh, The Story of Nike and the Men Who Played There by Julie Strasser and Laurie Becklund - but added it's all ''ancient history.''

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


August 14, 1992, Friday


No lease yet


BYLINE: By Chris Burritt STAFF WRITERbusiness; sports; fashion; industry


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section F; Page 1


LENGTH: 146 words


Nike Inc. and Phipps haven't yet signed a lease. But several Phipps tenants said they anticipate a deal soon and that the Nike Town store could open next year. 

Officials of Phipps and Nike, the sporting goods giant based in Beaverton, Ore., declined comment Thursday.

Tenants, some of whom have talked to Nike officials, said the company likes Atlanta because it is a major sports center. The city is home of the Braves, Hawks and Falcons, and it will host the Super Bowl in 1994 and the Summer Olympics two years later.

Nabbing Nike Town would give bragging rights to Phipps over other Atlanta malls, including nearby rival Lenox Square. Phipps is in the midst of a $ 140 million renovation and expansion.

Tom Ross, Tiffany's vice president, said Nike Town would be a major draw and w ould boost traffic in Phipps, which has suffered poor traffic in recent years.

July 16, 1992, Thursday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION


Nike gets help


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 39, Sports Briefs


LENGTH: 71 words


The Spanish government has vowed to help Nike Inc. in the trademark dispute threatening to derail its multimillion-dollar Olympic ad campaign. Spanish officials promised to ask a Barcelona judge to allow Nike to post bond in the case, allowing it to sell and advertise its sports apparel in Spain while awaiting a final court decision. A Spanish businessman claims he owns the rights to the Nike trademark in Spain.

The Washington Post


July 7, 1992, Tuesday, Final Edition


OLYMPICS


From news services and staff reports


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE E2; FANFARE


LENGTH: 181 words


Nike Inc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of Nike apparel in Spain, a company attorney said.

Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore. -based sports apparel company from using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

If further legal actions fail -- and if the courts rule the injunction bars U.S. athletes from wearing Nike uniforms, the firm stands to lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide, according to company documents. ...

Daley Thompson will make a final attempt to qualify for a fifth Olympic Games decathlon Thursday and Friday at an arranged meet in London.

Thompson, the world record-holder and Olympic gold medalist in 1980 and 1988, must achieve the qualifying standard of 7,850 points at the Crystal Palace meet for a place on the British Olympic team.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

126 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


May 23, 1992, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


COMPANY NEWS: Promoting Racial Harmony;
Nike Plans Commercial That Features Spike Lee


BYLINE: Reuters


SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 3; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 267 words


DATELINE: BEAVERTON, Ore., May 22


Nike Inc. said today that it would begin showing next week a television commercial to promote racial harmony that features Spike Lee, the film maker.

Set in an outdoor basketball court called Spike's Urban Jungle Gym, the advertisement, directed by Mr. Lee, shows black and white basketball players giving reasons for not playing with one another. Mr. Lee steps in to say: "If we're going to live together, we've got to play together." 

The commercial, which also features Tim Hardaway, a Golden State Warriors player, was filmed at an outdoor basketball court in Los Angeles about two weeks before the riots that followed the verdict in the Rodney King case.

The filming was done in an area that later saw some of the worst disturbances. Mr. Lee said the commercial is a reworking of a scene from his 1989 film "Do The Right Thing."

 Nike was criticized last summer by a Chicago-based civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The group urged the sneaker maker to increase its hiring of blacks and called for a boycott by the black community.

Nike said at the time that 8.5 percent of the 4,500 employees in its headquarters here were black.

Eventually, however, the campaign petered out because Nike sneakers had become a virtual uniform for inner-city youths.

The company said in 1990 that 14 percent of its sales were to blacks.

 Nike said it plans to put on sale in August a line of sports apparel inspired by Mr. Lee's Urban Jungle Gym, including jackets, shirts and shorts with slogans like "The Mo' Colors, The Mo's Better" and "Live Together/Play Together."


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

127 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


January 31, 1991, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Nike's 2 Stars Appear In a New Campaign


BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ


SECTION: Section D; Page 19; Column 1; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 204 words


Spike Lee and Michael Jordan are back with Nike. This time, the two are starring in the company's $5 million "Stay in School" campaign.

One spot, which will begin nationally during the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game on Feb. 10, features Mr. Lee as his "Mars Blackmon" character, joking around with Mr. Jordan, the Chicago Bulls star. After a slightly intense discussion about the principles of gravity, they tell other kids in the classroom, "Don't be stupid; stay in school." 

"These spots are important to me because education is the key," Mr. Lee said in an interview. "Spike and Michael saying 'stay in school' is not the only answer, but it helps.

"Also, we tried to put humor in," the Brooklyn film maker said. "We're not trying to be too preachy."

Nike Inc. has been criticized in the past for using black athletes in its ads but having few of them in as corporate executives. Mr. Lee said some of the criticisms were valid.

But he said: "We have tried to work some of these things out. I wish a lot of other companies were as open minded as Nike. They want to do the right thing. No pun intended."

Nike's agency, Wieden & Kennedy, first matched Mr. Lee and Mr. Jordan in 1989.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


August 14, 1992, Friday


Phipps shooting for Nike sport store


BYLINE: By Chris Burritt STAFF WRITER


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section F; Page 1


LENGTH: 84 words


Phipps Plaza has the high fashion of Saks Fifth Avenue and the glitter of Tiffany's. 

Now it's going for a slam dunk with Nike Town.

The Buckhead mall is being eyed by Nike Town, one of America's funkiest retail concepts. It blends fantasy for wannabe jocks, high-tech glitz for the entertainment-minded and, yes, shoes and other merchandise.

A new Nike Town store in Chicago has a maple basketball court, where people can test sneakers. The first Nike Town opened in Portland, Ore., in 1990.

134 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Journal of Commerce


July 30, 1992, Thursday


NIKE OFF AND RUNNING WITH RECYCLABLE SHOES


BYLINE: The Seattle Times


SECTION: CHEM, Pg. 7A


LENGTH: 204 words


DATELINE: SEATTLE


 

American manufacturers sold some 388 million pairs of athletic shoes last year. Retailers saw $ 12.1 billion in estimated sales. Environmentalists see 776 million shoes made largely of plastic and other synthetic material heading straight for landfills. 

Now Nike Inc. of Beaverton, Ore., may forever change the footwear industry by being the first to offer, partially at least, recyclable and recycled neakers.

"Maybe at some point we'll have a system where shoes can be 100 percent recycled, where you never throw a pair away. You always take them back like bottles or other common recyclables," says Dusty Kidd of Nike.

The key to turning today's shoes into tomorrow's lies in a new Nike technology. The process grinds and pulverizes whole shoes into material for the outsoles of new shoes.

Nike's process can completely recycle every shoe the company makes except for cleated models. The machinery to draw metal out of rubber and fiber isn't here yet, but the technology is.

The first Nikes to contain recycled material will arrive in stores next spring. The shoe will be a new version of one of the company's best sellers, the Air Escape Low, a mid-priced outdoor cross trainer for men and women.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.

 

136 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


December 17, 1991, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


Nike Profit Rises by 6%


SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 4; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 169 words


DATELINE: BEAVERTON, Ore., Dec. 16 AP


Nike Inc.'s earnings rose 6 percent in the second quarter of the fiscal year, setting record levels for profits and sales, the athletic shoe manufacturer said today.

Earnings for the three months ended Nov. 30 totaled $61.5 million, or 80 cents a share. In the comparable period last year, Nike earned $58 million, or 77 cents a share. 

Revenues increased 15 percent, to $743.4 million.

European sales led the increase, with Germany up 73 percent, France up 63 percent, Italy up 138 percent and Spain up 83 percent.

United States athletic footwear revenues declined 2 percent, but domestic athletic apparel revenues were up 2 percent. Revenues from other brands owned by Nike rose 18 percent.

Nike said the domestic athletic footwear revenues were lower because retailers had been cautious in placing orders six months ago.

Although the increases were strong, they paled in comparison with those announced for the first quarter, when the Beaverton-based company reported earnings of $114 million.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

137 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


May 31, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Even washed-up Nikes have plenty of value


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 248 words


Memo to Nike: Potentially terrific - and cheap - new sneaker endorsers are just down the road from your Beaverton, Ore., headquarters.

Thousands of Nike shoes have begun washing up on Oregon beaches - the result of a May 1990 shipping accident that left 80,000 sneakers floating in the Pacific. Some beachcombers are stockpiling hundreds of shoes, claiming the shoes are fine - after clams and seaweed are removed. Swap meets let collectors find their sizes - and create matching pairs.

''The advertising possibilities are obvious,'' says Shirley Tarnasky, owner of 50 seagoing sneakers. ''Shoes that can float in the ocean for a year and not come apart at the seams just have to be good.''

So how about, say, a pickup basketball game between beachcombers to prove Nikes can take a lickin' and keep on tickin'? Laughs Nike's Liz Dolan: ''It's an (ad) idea we haven't really considered.''

But Nike's TV ads for the NBA playoffs are old standbys: replays of six resurrected Michael Jordan-Spike Lee spots.
 
A STEP UP: Walking passed swimming as the USA's No. 1 recreational sport in 1990, says a National Sporting Goods Association study. Total walkers: 71.4 million, up 72% since 1985. ... The World League of American Football's New York/New Jersey Knights average 15 kids a game at their free home-game child care. ... Inspired by Disney World, Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., urged a $ 300,000 federal study of using monorails to ease traffic congestion in national parks.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportstalk


SPORTS BUSINESS


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

143 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 10, 1991, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Good Nike earnings look like a shoo-in


BYLINE: Rhonda Richards


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 402 words


Like other companies, Nike Inc. has had some problems during the recession. But the nation's leading maker of athletic shoes appears to be landing on its feet.

Nike, which makes Air Jordan and other high-priced sports shoes, is expected to report results today for its fiscal year ended May 31. Tuesday, the company said it was comfortable with Wall Street estimates of $ 3.65 to $ 3.85 a share, vs. $ 3.21 last year. The stock jumped 2 3/8 to $ 41 1/4. 

''I don't think there'll be any surprises,'' says Kidder Peabody analyst Gary Jacobson . ''It's been able to hold its own in a difficult environment while others fade away.'' Nike said earlier that 1991 revenue had topped $ 3 billion - 36% higher than its $ 2.2 billion in 1990.

Nike faces challenges in 1992 because of increased competition and a growing trend away from expensive athletic shoes. Some analysts predict revenue growth will slow to 17%. Jacobson says he's looking for only 9% earnings growth to $ 4.15 a share - not the big double-digit growth investors saw in previous years.

Still, Jacobson and First Albany analyst Todd Berko say the company has bright prospects ahead internationally, where trends lag three years behind the USA. ''It's an incredibly well-managed company that's had an incredible string of successes the past few years,'' Berko says. ''The product development is still the strongest in the industry and they're still committing money to advertising.''
 
Valuable assets? Shares of Craig Corp. have been roaring higher since BusinessWeek reported Monday that some investors believe Craig is greatly undervalued. But at least one analyst takes exception to the article and recommends selling the Los Angeles-based real-estate and supermarket company. Craig shares, up 2 3/8 Monday, rose another 2 1/8 to $ 20 5/8 Tuesday - a 28% gain in two days.

BusinessWeek, citing unnamed money managers, said Craig's 50% stake in Stater Bros., a private California supermarket chain, and stakes in financial services company Citadel Holding and real-estate manager Reading Co. make Craig's assets worth about $ 30 a share. But H.D. Brous & Co. analyst Howard Rosencrans, one of the few analysts to follow the company, says the stock is fully valued at $ 15. He urges his clients to sell. He says 1991 sales slowed at Stater Bros. He says defense cuts and the poor real-estate market is hurting Craig's other interests.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Marketline

The Toronto Star


December 31, 1991, Tuesday, HOLIDAY EDITION


L.A. Gear, Nike settle lawsuits


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C7


LENGTH: 103 words


 

L.A. Gear Inc. and sneaker rival Nike Inc. have settled all federal lawsuits against each other without payment of any money, the Associated Press reports. 

Nike agreed to dismiss its claim in a Los Angeles court that L.A. Gear's Catapult technology infringes on Nike patents. Nike also agreed to drop a case filed in Portland, Ore. involving L.A. Gear's distribution deal in Spain, said L.A. Gear's Steve Stern.

As part of the settlement, L.A. Gear agreed to drop its Catapult countersuit accusing Nike of engaging in anti-competitive conduct. Both companies agreed to take no further legal action

L.A. Gear, Nike settle lawsuits

   L.A. Gear Inc. and sneaker rival Nike Inc. have settled all federal lawsuits against each other without payment of any money, the Associated Press reports. 

Nike agreed to dismiss its claim in a Los Angeles court that L.A. Gear's Catapult technology infringes on Nike patents. Nike also agreed to drop a case filed in Portland, Ore. involving L.A. Gear's distribution deal in Spain, said L.A. Gear's Steve Stern.

The Nikkei Weekly (Japan)


December 14, 1991


SECTION: FOREIGN JOURNAL; In Profile; Pg. 27


LENGTH: 261 words



MICHAEL DELL RATTA
Company: Nike Japan Corp.
Title: General manager, corporate planning office
Nationality: American
Hobbies: Mountain biking, photography

Ironically, Michael Della Ratta's pursuit of stress relief eventually brought him to Tokyo. While working at a consulting firm in Washington D.C. 11 years ago, he enrolled at a local Japanese martial arts school, to help work off every day stress. 

Hooked by aikido, he came to Japan to study the martial art for a year in Wakayama Prefecture, near Osaka. Dela Ratta said he was particularly impressed by aikido's great attention to form, or kata.

The characteristics of aikido may apply to Japanese business in general, he said. "The Japanese don't spent a lot of time analyzing. Instead, they concentrate more on forming internal modes of operation, so they can react to many different situations."

Since joining Nike in 1982, he has spent most of the last decade in Asia, including stints of China and Taiwan.

As general manager of Nike Japan Corp.'s corporate planning office since September, Della Ratta calls himself a "cultural bridge" between Nike Inc. of the U.S. and Nike Japan, a wholly owned subsidiary of Nissho Iwai Corp.

"What I try to do is get Nike Japan on the same timetable as the rest of Nike, which is very tough," he explained.

Della Ratta sees the changing lifestyles of Japan as beneficial to Nike. "Now Japanese people want to get outdoors more. They want to be running, mountain biking or surfing. So that's encouraging for our industry."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Picture, no caption

152 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


March 29, 1991, Friday, Late Edition - Final


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Nike Approach To Women


BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ


SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 2; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 161 words


Nike has employed an all- star roster of male athletes, including Bo Jackson and Michael Jordan, to lure men to its lines of athletic footwear. But what about women, who accounted for roughly 42 percent of all athletic shoes purchased in 1990?

"We feel our advertising has to be different for women," said Lisa DeNeffe, a Nike spokeswoman. "Women look up to other women, but they don't really have specific role models as much as men do. So we took a different approach." 

That approach is illustrated in an eight-page insert that Nike and its advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy, began placing in women's magazines earlier this month. Instead of sports stars, the ad relies on simple sentences in large black type that chronicle the stages in a woman's life from childhood to adulthood.

"You wanted to be a veterinarian," the ad states in a section devoted to childhood. "You wanted to be president. You wanted to be the president's veterinarian."


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

 

155 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


February 21, 1992 Friday


Nike gets behind Krabbe


LENGTH: 310 words


THE Nike sportswear company said today it would stand behind double world sprint champion Katrin Krabbe, suspended from athletics for four years for manipulating a dope test.

The German Athletic Federation (DLV) banned Krabbe, world 400m silver medallist Grit Breuer and 1987 double world sprint champion Silke Moeller on Saturday for four years after they returned identical urine samples at a random test at their training camp in South Africa. 

On Tuesday the sport nutrition firm Isostar, which sponsored Krabbe and Breuer, said it would scrap a two-year promotional deal worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.

But a Nike spokesman said the company would stand behind Krabbe and Breuer until it knew the full story.

"Both runners have been strong supporters of Nike and we've been strong supporters of them," Nike spokesman Dusty Kidd said. "We think they deserve continued support at least until this thing gets some resolution."

Kidd said Nike executives had reviewed all the information so far available and were not satisfied that any conclusive evidence had been presented regarding the drug tests.

"This particular situation suggests manipulation, but the question is, who did the manipulating?" Kidd said.

"Certainly we have reviewed the information we've got from Germany and we still feel that resolution is yet to be final. Until it is, it's not fair for the athletes not to get the support they need."The Oregon-based athletic footwear and sportswear company has had a contract with Krabbe, Breuer and their Neu Brandenberg running club since March 1990 and supplies equipment to the club.

Krabbe, who has argued that the tests were doctored by an outside party, has pledged to fight the suspension in the law courts and her manager has threatened a $7.95 million lawsuit against the DLV.

- REUTER

END OF STORY

Nike would not disclose how much it spent on the agreement.

On May 26, during NBC's coverage of the French Open, Nike will introduce a new spot featuring the tennis player Andre Agassi.

Basketball Star In Nike Spots


BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ


SECTION: Section D; Page 7; Column 4; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 110 words


David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs will resume his starring role next week in a series of spots for Nike parodying the television program "Mr. Rogers's Neighborhood."

In past spots, which Nike said had generated an unusual amount of fan mail, Mr. Robinson invited a diverse collection of guests, including his coach, Larry Brown, and the classical pianist Rudolf Firkusny, into his "neighborhood," which is a basketball court.

The new spots, which will support Nike's new Air Force 180 basketball shoes, feature, among others, Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers, an oft-disciplined player who will teach viewers his word for the day: "fined."

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 28, 1992, Wednesday


Nike planning a splashy store for Phipps Plaza Shop expected to open near Parisian in spring '93


BYLINE: By Robert Luke STAFF WRITERsales; business; consumers; atlanta


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section D; Page 1


LENGTH: 255 words


Nike Inc. announced plans Tuesday to bring its hot Nike Town retailing concept to Buckhead's Phipps Plaza next spring.

It is a "store" that has wowed shoppers in Chicago and Portland, Ore., where the only Nike Towns currently exist. There had been rumors among Phipps tenants for months that Nike Town was coming.

The 25,000-square-foot Atlanta store will have 60 full-time employees and be located on the first floor of the new Phipps Plaza wing that houses a Parisian department store.

"Our design concept for Nike Town incorporates sports, fitness, entertainment, history and product innovation, all in one," said Melinda Gable, a spokeswoman for the Beaverton, Ore., footwear maker.

Mixing Disneyland and MTV

Nike Town is like a mixture of Disneyland and MTV, with customers as the audience participating in a production.

Shoppers walk through doors to the center of a Hollywood-like town square that has videos and life-size sculptures of sports stars, such as Deion Sanders and Michael Jordan.

Sports sounds - the squeak of basketball shoes or the smacking of a tennis ball - accompany customers as they walk through each area of the store. Once customers make a selection, a high-tech delivery system speeds merchandise through clear plastic tubes from the stockroom to the customer.

"The Atlanta Nike Town will have the same town-square concept as the other stores, but will be more modular in design to accommodate future product lines and to serve as a focal point for community events," Ms. Gable said.


LOAD-DATE: October 31, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923050081


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

165 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


July 7, 1991, SUNDAY, LATE FIVE STAR Edition


NIKE'S NEXT MOVE IS TO WIN WOMEN


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5E


LENGTH: 322 words


 

BEAVERTON, Ore. - Nike Inc., the largest athletic apparel maker in the world, has built its business by speaking to men. If women were eavesdropping and understood the message - fine. Nike was happy to sell them smaller, pretty-color versions of its men's offerings. In the industry, these are known as ''take-down'' products. With that approach, it is little wonder that Nike's women's business has been only a trickle in the company's revenue stream. For the fiscal year ended May 31, it accounted for about 16 percent, or $480 million, of total revenues of $3 billion. By comparison, Reebok International Ltd., the other industry titan, does about half its $2.16 billion annual sales in women's products. But with the domestic men's market at its saturation point, Beaverton-based Nike has acquired a fascination with women rivaling that of an adolescent boy. ''Nike is a male brand,'' says Kate Bednarski, marketing manager of women's fitness shoes for Nike. ''But we're now committed to growing our business on the other side of the channel.'' The commitment comes in the form of new head-to-toe women's collections - designed by women for women - and a critically acclaimed advertising campaign that says ''Just do it'' in a distinctly feminine voice heretofore unheard from Nike. Analysts and industry obser vers are generally enthusiastic about Nike's potential in the domestic women's market. Overall, shoes alone in that market amount to about $3 billion annually if you figure in the whole spectrum from sneakers to highly engineered performance shoes. It's $2 billion if you toss out the shoes Nike types caustically refer to as ''foot coverings.'' Fitness apparel (other than footwear), a loosely defined category that includes about everything women don't wear to the office, is estimated at $16 billion a year; the sports-performance part of it that most interests Nike takes up about $2 billion.


LOAD-DATE: October 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

USA TODAY


July 8, 1992, Wednesday, INTERNATIONAL EDITION


STAYING HOME


BYLINE: Jack Carey; Mark Hayes


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 286 words


The New Mexico basketball program, unable to locate quality opponents overseas, has cancelled a planned August trip to Europe. The Lobos had scheduled games in Austria, France and Switzerland Aug. 10-24. However, a Cincinnati-based travel agency arranging the trip could not confirm enough games.
 
STRAW RETURNS: Darryl Strawberry, who missed 48 games with a herniated disk, was activated by the Los Angeles Dodgers between games of a doubleheader with the Montreal Expos. Pitcher Kip Gross, who was called up from the minors and won the opener 8-3, was optioned to Class AAA Albuquerque.
 
 NIKE NEWS: Nike, which has paid millions of dollars to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, says it is appealing a Spanish court ruling that bars the advertising or sale of Nike apparel in Spain. Spain's Constitutional Court last week upheld a lower court's order barring the sports company from using the Nike name on clothing bcecause a Spanish firm registered the trademark in 1932. Nike, whose shoes are not affected by the ruling, planned to use the Olympics to launch a line of sports clothes. Nike says it could lose $ 20 million in sales in Spain and much more worldwide if the ruling stands.
 
TYSON APPEAL: Mike Tyson's lawyers have requested copies of any contracts between the boxer's rape victim and her former civil lawyer for use in the appeals process. Alan M. Dershowitz, who is heading Tyson's appeal, said he is exploring ''appropriate legal grounds'' for his legal actions and needs the contracts from Marion Superior Court Judge Patricia Gifford. Tyson was convicted Feb. 10 of raping Desiree Washington last July.

TYPE: Sportsline


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

170 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 30, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Jordan cuts NBA out of apparel deal


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 238 words


Apparel bearing Michael Jordan's likeness won't be on sale in NBA arenas for long. You'll have to go to a store that sells Nike products. 

Jordan has asked the National Basketball Association to stop using his likeness on its licensed apparel. The Chicago Bulls star has that right, say NBA senior vice president Gary Bettman and NBA Players Association executive director Charles Grantham.

A player and the league can share revenues from NBA merchandise deals using a player's likeness - or a player can decline to involve the NBA in a product category in which he has an exclusive deal.

And Jordan decided to go solo with Nike in his apparel arrangement.
Nike, which does not sell its products in NBA arenas, says its annual sales of Jordan gear top $ 200 million.

But with the NBA no longer a partner in Jordan's apparel deal - the financial impact on the NBA and Jordan remains to be seen - fans won't be able to buy clothing items bearing both Jordan's image and the Bulls' logo. Nike doesn't use NBA logos on Jordan apparel.

Nike isn't gloating. ''It's between the NBA and Michael,'' says Nike's Liz Dolan. ''It has nothing to do with Nike.''

A recent survey by Sporting Goods Business said Jordan has more influence over consumer purchases than any other athlete. Proceeds from retail sales of NBA merchandise, which topped $ 1.1 billion last year and was led by Bulls gear, trickle down to all NBA teams.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: JORDAN: 'This isn't a state problem.'


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

173 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 22, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings of Nike Increased By 7.1% in the First Quarter


BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO


SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 5; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 474 words


Nike Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 7.1 percent, but heavy spending on advertising during the Olympics caused profits to fall below investors' expectations. Nike's stock price dropped $2 immediately after the earnings were released, but as the day progressed, it rebounded as investors focused on Nike's high level of orders for the spring. The shares closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $76.375, a gain of 75 cents.

Nike executives defended the heavy Olympic advertising spending, saying the results are already evident. "Our U.S. business was robust during the critical back-to-school season just completed, and worldwide futures orders for spring delivery were at record levels," said, Philip H. Knight, the chairman of Nike. The company sold one million pairs of $65 basketball shoes during the back-to-school season, making it the nation's best-selling shoe for the season. 

For the quarter ended Aug. 31, Nike, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., earned $122.5 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $114.4 million, or $1.50 a share, in the period last year. Nike was expected to earn $1.72 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research.
 
Sales Advanced by a Sharp 16%

 Nike's sales grew a robust 16 percent, to $1.09 billion, compared with $947 million last year.

Nike, which plans to spend $140 million on advertisements this year, said that one-third of those expenditures will take place in the first quarter.

Advertising and other administrative expenses "went through the roof," said Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody.

Still, Mr. Jacobson called the heavy promotional outlay a prudent investment. "The Olympics only come around once every four years," he said.

Nike executives also say there is a direct correlation between the heavy global advertising levels and the strong spring orders.

For September through January, 1993, Nike has orders for $1.36 billion of shoes, 27 percent higher than the orders for the corresponding period last year. The company said its January orders were the largest single-month total in the company's history.

"The most important number to look at is the futures number," said Josie Esquivel, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "It's really pretty astronomical in this type of environment," she said, referring to the sluggish demand for most consumer goods.

In a conference call with analysts, Nike said that it continued to gain market share in Germany at the expense of Adidas.

Mr. Knight of Nike said that despite the higher expenses Nike's earnings should grow by 15 percent for the fiscal year.

Nike told analysts that its business grew by 5 percent in the United States and by 49 percent in foreign markets.

In addition to sports shoes, Nike makes athletic clothes and Cole Haan dress shoes.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

174 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


March 17, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


NIKE EARNINGS


BYLINE: Donna Rosato


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 533 words


Sneaker giant Nike says earnings jumped 17% its latest quarter, but Nike stock stumbled 3 5/8 to $ 70 1/2 Monday. Though net income climbed to a record high, results were slightly below analysts' expecta
tions of $ 1.12 to $ 1.15 a share. Net income for the quarter ended Feb. 29 rose to $ 82.5 million, or $ 1.08 a share, from $ 70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue also hit a record $ 867 million from $ 802 million. Though analysts trimmed earnings estimates for the year, they recommended Nike for the long term. Chairman Philip Knight says investment abroad, where revenue rose 27% from a year earlier, is starting to pay off. 
 
 CIRCLE K PLAN: A group of international investors that in
cludes the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue has offered $ 425 million to buy Circle K, the USA's second-largest convenience-store chain. Circle K says its sale to CK Acquisitions could help it emerge from bankruptcy-court protection by the end of the year. Circle K filed for Chapter 11 in May 1990 and has lost more than $ 1 billion the past two years. In December, it said it will close 1,500 of its 3,700 stores, situated mostly in the South. Circle K's reorganization plan and any sale must be approved by the bankruptcy court. The parent of Circle K's chief rival 7-Eleven - Southland - was bought by Japanese investors in 1990 .
 
FedEx DEAL: Federal Express says it is ending its domestic European and intra-European services May 4. The company says it agreed to sell its domestic French operations to TNT Express Worldwide's TNT Chrono Service S.A. and is selling domestic U.K. operations to Securicor Omega Express Ltd. Terms of the deals weren't disclosed. Also, FedEx said it lost $ 193 million, or $ 3.58 a share, in its third quarter, which ended Feb. 29. The loss includes a $ 254 million charge to pay for the European restructuring. The company lost $ 106 million, or $ 1.98 a share, in the year-earlier quarter.
 
ANDERSEN SETTLEMENT: Arthur Andersen & Co., accused of helping

former savings-and-loan executive Charles Keating   in a bond-sales

 

scam, settled civil fraud claims for up to $ 30 million, Reuters says. Keating, Arthur Andersen and several other professional firms that worked for Lincoln Savings and its parent, American Continental, are targets of a $ 1.2 billion law suit brought by 17,000 investors. The investors claim salespeople at Lincoln tricked them into buying junk bonds, which became worthless when Lincoln was seized in 1989.

   CONTINENTAL BUYER?   A group of investors led by financier Charles

 

Hurwitz is close to an agreement to bail out financially troubled Continental Airlines, The Houston Post says. Hurwitz reportedly submitted a proposal to buy a majority stake in the airline, which has been in bankruptcy-court protection since December 1990. Continental filed a reorganization plan Feb. 6.
 
TREASURY AUCTION: The Treasury Department sold $ 11.4 billion in three- month bills at an average discount rate of 4.09%, up from 4.02% last week. Another $ 11.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.27%, up from 4.13% last week.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; color, Barbara Gundle
 
CUTLINE: KNIGHT: Investments paying off.


TYPE: Moneyline


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

179 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


February 19, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


SPORTS BUSINESS;
Nike pays price for big presence


BYLINE: Sal Ruibal


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 593 words


You can't escape the long arm of Nike.

It seems that every time you turn on the tube, flip a magazine page or gaze at a billboard, the Nike Inc. ''swoosh'' and a well-paid athlete are staring back at you.

Nike's advertising firepower has taken it to the top of the athletic shoe market, but those creative and often outlandish ads don't come cheap. In the first nine months of 1990, Nike spent $ 61.8 million for TV and radio air time, cable TV spots, newspaper and magazine pages and billboard space - up 79% from the same period in 1989. 

The numbers come from LNA/Arbitron Multi-Media Service and Advertising Age and don't include the cost of creating the ads and payments to celebrity endorsers.

No other sports company came close to Nike. No. 2 sports shoe-maker Reebok International spent $ 30.6 million in the first nine months of 1990, up 13%; Sports Illustrated spent $ 23.5 million (undoubtedly most on endless repetitions of its cable TV subscription ads featuring football phones, Michael Jordan videos, etc.), up 73% from 1989; and L.A. Gear spent $ 23.2 million, up a whopping 162%. No other sports companies cracked the top 200.

To put those numbers in perspective, look at how much the really big spenders put out in only nine months: AT&T spent $ 371.5 million and McDonald's $ 334.6 million.
 
LINKAGE: New LPGA Commissioner Charles Mechem isn't pulling many punches in his analysis of the tour. In a recent interview in Golfweek, Mecham said the LPGA suffers from a ''massive inferiority complex. I don't mean that critically of anybody, but I think the organizatiom is a lot stronger that it realizes it is.'' ... Golf icon and Senior PGA Tour member Don January is getting into the golf architectural business. His partners include son Tom and Craig Curry, formerly of Jack Nicklaus and Associates.
 
CHAIN GANG: Hybrid bikes aren't two-wheelers for biologists, but they are quickly moving up the evolutionary ladder. A cross between fat-tired mountain bikes and featherweight road racing bikes, hybrids are catching on with fitness fanatics and born-again cyclists. Some purists scoff, but the market loves them. According to Bicycling magazine, more than 100 of the 941 new bicycle models can be classified as hybrids, an increase of 30 products from last year's selection. The good news: The average price of a hybrid has decreased from $ 612 to $ 478. Last year's hot model was Schwinn's $ 300 Crisscross, rated a Best Buy by both Consumer Reports and Bicycle Guide. Road bike prices are up an average of 30%, while mountain bikes increased only 11%.
 
COLLECT CALLS: Some people think baseball memorabilia came of age when they stopped putting gum in baseball card packages. Another milestone: Sotheby's auction salon in New York is selling the collection of James C. Copeland, a California sporting goods retailer, March 22. Among the goodies: a rare Honus Wagner tobacco card that could bring $ 150,000, and a collection of 160 World Series press pins that could fetch $ 300,000. ... Score Inc. has created a ''hobby advisory board'' to learn how it can best serve dealers.
 
SHELL GAME: Next trip to the ballpark, tip your hat to the MVP - the Master Vendor of Peanuts, that is. Peanuts have been a big part of baseball for more than 100 years, according to the National Peanut Month Committee. More than $ 10 million is shelled out for peanuts at ballparks every year. The MVPs will be named in March and the lucky vendors will get a trophy, a button and a free trip to spring training in Florida.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

180 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


May 13, 1991 Monday


NEWS BULLETINS Nike outpaces Klein


BYLINE: GAM


LENGTH: 123 words


DATELINE: New York NY


NEW YORK
Shoemaker Nike Inc. nosed out fragrance maker Calvin Klein as sponsor of
the most popular print advertising campaign of 1990, a consumer survey
shows. 

Nike moved up from fourth place in the 1989 survey, while Calvin Klein
fell from the top spot for the first time in four years, according to
results in the survey from the research firm Video Storyboard Tests Inc.

Video Storyboard Tests interviewed 24,000 people over the course of
1990 for its latest survey, asking them to recall the newspaper and
magazine ads that they found to be the most outstanding they had seen
recently.

Other top ads: Camel cigarettes, Revlon cosmetics, Absolut vodka,
Infiniti cars, Marlboro cigarettes, Guess apparel, Ford vehicles, and
Maybelline cosmetics.

184 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


June 18, 1992, Thursday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION


Nike facing Olympian battle


BYLINE: Michael M. Phillips Associated Press


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 43


LENGTH: 597 words


DATELINE: Madrid, Spain


Spanish trademark laws are threatening to turn Nike's sponsorship of the U.S. Olympic track-and-field team into a multi-million-dollar fiasco.

 Nike Inc. is in the midst of a court battle with a Spanish attorney who owns the Nike name in Spain - first registered here 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker.

With the Olympics less than six weeks away and Nike planning to plaster its disputed name on U.S. athletes' uniforms, the company and the attorney, Juan Amigo Freixas, are playing a game of courtroom chicken. Whoever swerves first is likely to lose tens of millions of dollars. 

Pressure is building on both sides: Nike, an American sports shoe and apparel giant based in Beaverton, Ore., wants to clear up the matter before the July 25 opening ceremony. Amigo, who says the athletes can't use the Nike name without his permission, knows his payoff will shrink after the games end.

Amigo ''should be aware that it would result in a very unpleasant embarrassment for the Kingdom of Spain,'' said John Faylor, Nike's European counsel. ''Juan Amigo is a pirate, as we see him, who's using the . . . trademark to blackmail Nike into a negotiating position and Nike refuses to submit to those kinds of tactics.''

At stake are the profits Nike hoped to reap when it paid a handsome sum - the company won't say how much - to hitch its name to the U.S. athletes.

 Nike documents put potential sales losses at US$20 million in Spain alone and many times that amount worldwide.

To make matters worse for Nike, competitor Reebok's logo will be on the sweatsuit of every American who steps to the winner's podium in Barcelona, including Nike spokesman Michael Jordan, should the U.S. basketball team take a medal.

At the heart of the dispute are Spain's idiosyncratic commercial laws, which have generated an array of cases involving foreign firms that entered the Spanish market only to find someone else already owned their brands.

Trademark laws here long permitted anyone to register and renew a name simply by paying a fee, even if they never produced anything.

The statutes were changed in 1988 to permit easier challenges to inactive trademarks, but registrants still aren't required to prove they have an ongoing business or product when filing an application.

''Trademark piracy is practically the national sport in Spain,'' Faylor said by telephone from Frankfurt.

''Nike has been one of the many trademark companies that have experienced harassment.''

Is it piracy? Or just smart business?

''They can think what they want,'' Amigo said from Barcelona. ''If the Olympics hadn't come to Spain, Nike would never have landed here because they wouldn't know where Spain was.''

Amigo bought the Nike name from the original owner, who produced knitted wear during the 1936-39 Spanish Civil War and kept the trademark - a photographic negative of the headless Winged Victory of Samothrace statue in the Louvre Museum - long after production ceased.

The registration applies only to sports apparel, not shoes - but it's the U.S. track team's shirts and shorts that will be most visible to television cameras.

In July 1990, Nike was issued a registration for its name and ''swoosh'' symbol, but two Spanish courts upheld Amigo's earlier trademark. The Constitutional Court is now considering Nike's appeal.

At one point, Amigo asked Nike for US$30 million for rights to the brand, Fraylor said. Amigo refused to divulge any figures.

''He's trying to basically take advantage of what he has,'' said the U.S. official.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jordan teamed up with Bugs Bunny for Nike Super Bowl ads in January, but there's a chance he won't be able to wear Nike logos at the Barcelona Olympics.


TYPE: COLUMN


Copyright 1992 Financial Post Ltd.

 

186 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 9, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


COMPANY NEWS;
Nike Earnings at Record; L.A. Gear Posts Deficit


BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER,  Special to The New York Times


SECTION: Section D; Page 3; Column 3; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 458 words


DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 8


Two makers of athletic shoes and sports wear reported widely divergent financial results today. Nike Inc. of Beaverton, Ore., reported its fifth consecutive year of record revenues and earnings, while L.A. Gear Inc. of Los Angeles reported a loss for its second quarter.

Both companies' stock moved sharply on the news. Nike shares jumped more than 10 percent, closing at $66.375, up $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. And L.A. Gear slid more than 13 percent, closing at $10.625, off $1.625. 

Philip H. Knight, Nike's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the company was well positioned to continue its growth.

"A 17 percent increase in future orders for the next six months sets the stage for another record year in 1993," Mr. Knight said. "This increase reflects U.S. retailers' continued success with Nike products in an otherwise difficult retail environment." He added that Nike was also strong in Europe.

L.A. Gear said its loss stemmed partly from the cost of settling three separate consolidated shareholder suits, as well as a loss from continuing operations.

"The company's new management is continuing its efforts during this transition year to redirect the company, both operationally and financially," said Stanley P. Gold, L.A. Gear's chairman and chief executive.

Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Nike

For the fourth quarter, which ended May 31, Nike said it earned $70.7 million, or 92 cents a share, up 20.6 percent from $58.6 million, or 76 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues rose 17.9 percent, to $847.6 million, from $719.0 million in the fourth quarter of the 1991 fiscal year.

For the year, Nike had earnings of $329.2 million, or $4.30 a share, up 14.7 percent from $287.0 million, or $3.77 a share, in the 1991 fiscal year. Revenues rose 13.7 percent, to $3.41 billion, from $3 billion in the previous year.

"The Olympic Games will further showcase Nike's products and athletes to a truly global audience," Mr. Knight said. "Seven of the 12 U.S.A. Basketball Team players and 66 of the 129 track and field qualifiers are Nike athletes."
 
L.A. Gear

For its second quarter, which ended May 31, L.A. Gear had a deficit of $24.4 million, up substantially from a loss of $4 million in the period a year ago. Sales fell 36.9 percent, to $104.7 million, from $166 million in the second quarter of the 1991 fiscal year.

The loss for the quarter reflects a $13.87 million after-tax charge for the settlement of the shareholder suits. The company attributed the decline in earnings to a drop in the number of shoes sold worldwide. The company said that pricing pressure on its old product line will reduce gross margins for the balance of the year.


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

189 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


August 8, 1992, Saturday


The Diary


BYLINE: By HENRY WINTER


SECTION: WEEKEND SPORT PAGE; Page 45 


LENGTH: 1109 words


 NIKE AND THE BARE ESSENTIALS

THE sportswear firm, Nike (Greek for victory), has not enjoyed the best of times at the Olympics. Michael Johnson, subject of a large advertising campaign by Nike, flopped in the 200 metres, while another Nike star, Sergei Bubka, failed to reach the qualifying heights in the pole vault. At least Nike will not be upstaged by rivals Reebok tonight. Reebok has a deal with the United States Olympic Committee to provide tracksuits for all US medal-winners to be worn on the podium. This agreement has caused problems for six of the ''dream team'', including Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley, who are contracted to Nike for seven-figure sums. Eventually a compromise was reached. So if - or rather when - Jordan, Barkley and Co win gold tonight, the medal ceremony should be fun. Apart from the sight of the chosen dignitary straining to place medals around the necks of near 7ft-tall athletes, some of the basketballers will be revealing some chest. The reason for the unzipped tracksuit tops? So the collars can fold down and conceal the Reebok logo.

NAME the one football video that is available in the club boardroom, but not in the club shop? ''Dion Dublin - the goals''. This tape was sent to every leading club by John Beck, Cambridge United's manager. It worked. Manchester United forked out pounds 1m for Dublin's services. What next? ''Vinnie Jones - the tackles''? 

CLEAR OBJECTIVE

A daunting task for batsmen - clearing the Lord's pavilion - has been turned into a competition. A cheque for pounds 1,000 is the reward for any cricketer who carries the beautiful old building, a feat achieved once, by Albert Trott (via a chimney pot) for the MCC against the Australians in 1899. The Cricket Lore Challenge, organised by the cricket magazine, is open until 1999, the centenary of Trott's achievement. Many have tried to emulate Trott's feat, players like Keith Miller, Kim Hughes, Wasim Akram and Mike Llewellyn. Llewellyn came closest, in the 1977 Gillette Cup final for Glamorgan against Middlesex, when he hoisted a delivery from John Emburey - it rose high enough but caught the top of the north tower.

WE ALL know Olympic medals bring their rewards. Fame for all, fortune for a few. And some new friends for Shannon Miller. The 15-year-old gymnast who is returning home to Edmond, Oklahoma, with three medals has aroused a lot of interest. ''Young men are calling from all over the country trying to get her phone number,'' an Edmond civic official said. ''One little guy from Denver has probably called seven or eight times today. He says it's a real emergency.''

RACING'S RICHES

The glamour of the turf . . . prizes at Ngong Racecourse, Nairobi, are a bit different from those at Kentucky and Epsom. A bucket pump was the top reward in the first race; race three offered a backpack sprayer; race four, a maize hand shredder; race five, a wheel barrow; and the concluding feature race of the evening promised a milk churn.

WHETHER FORECASTS

To commemorate what they call the ''dawning of a new age'', those wags at the football fanzine, When Saturday Comes, have produced a souvenir poster of the ''all-singing, all-dancing Premier League''. It features a predictions' chart, a vital excercise for any fan. The questions are not your normal ''pick the cup winners'' routine. Far from it. Take Arsenal . . . ''Name the number of central defenders bought between August and December'' followed by a box for your guess. Blackburn's is on a similar theme: ''Number of forwards bought during season''. The conundrum for Chelsea supporters: ''First month in which David Mellor is spotted at Stamford Bridge''. Southampton's involves ''final position in Fair Play League''.

A HEALTHY dose of pre-season delirium has also infected Shoot! To promote their Charity Shield competition, Shoot! ran a picture from last season of a Liverpool-Leeds United match. The scene? David Batty upending Steve McManaman. Cruel.

IMPORT QUANDARY

A quick look at the new Celtic line- up makes worrying news for their UEFA campaign, given the tight restrictions on imported talent. At No 1 they have a South African, while the 12 others in the squad comprise seven from France, two from Australia, plus three from Italy. The line-up from Paradise is, of course, the new Celtic wine- list, the top bottle being the ''Celtic Champagne'' attractively priced at pounds 15.95. Other footballing essentials in the Parkhead catalogue include a hamper (''with red and white Celtic house wine''), tartan dungarees, an exclusive mountain bike (which would last three seconds outside Ibrox, covered as it is with Celtic emblems), cameras, telephones, binoculars, decanters. Oh, and football kit.

DIVIDED LOYALTIES

Sachin Tendulkar, Yorkshire's Indian tyro, has come up with a variation on the dilemma of county v country - he may be playing for his county against his country next week in a pyjama series in Sheffield. The Tykes have insisted that Tendulkar, who made his first Championship century this week, represent them if both they and India reach the final of the Flamingo Land Floodlit Trophy at Don Valley Stadium on Thursday. Tendulkar turns out for his county against Durham in the first semi-final on Tuesday and then for his country against Lancashire the following night. ''No one can recall a similar situation in a tournament,'' Don Robinson, the promoter, said, ''so Sachin might qualify for a mention in the Guinness Book of Records.''

TAKING THE BISCUIT

THE Olympics have become so commercial, with everyone from fizzy-drink manufacturers to Wolverhampton butchers involved, that when the men's 100 metres was referred to as the Blue Riband event, some confusion was understandable. Overheard in a crowded room was a vexed voice . . . ''is this race sponsored by the biscuit-makers?''.

SPOKEN WORD

The Chris Boardman limerick competition provoked some patriotic responses after the British cyclist's gold medal-winning ride. Joanna Rimmer, of Newcastle-upon-Tyne, wins a bottle of Aberlour Malt Whisky for the following . . .

Who was our first gold award man?

A chap with the name of Chris Boardman.

With a hat like Darth Vader

This great Lotus raider

Did as well as a Briton abroad can.

What rhymes with Sally Gunnell? Entries to Sports Diary Limerick, The Independent, 40 City Road, London EC1Y 2DB.

PS

No let-up in the rivalry between broadcasters. After Sky had been beaten by LWT in the Tennents five-a-side tournament at Earls Court, an extra-terrestrial spokesman muttered: ''First time we've lost out to them at football.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Independent Print Ltd

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


September 8, 1991, Sunday


Players' pleas led to switch to Nike shoes


BYLINE: By David Davidson Staff writergeorgia/tech; football; salaries; leaders


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION F; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 388 words


Apparently sacrificing personal financial reward, Georgia Tech football coach Bobby Ross outfitted his 1990 national championship squad with the Nike shoes his players preferred, taking a $ 37,000 cut from his previous contract with Pony.

The strained relationship between Ross and Pony was evident in a letter to him from the company's national marketing manager for football, Randy Beverly, dated Nov. 6, 1989. It noted that a number of Tech players were wearing shoes made by other companies, saying that "could be perceived as a material breach of contract." It also stated: "I would like to assume that this is a temporary slip on your part and that you will ensure that in future games the players will wear the appropriate footwear." 

On March 26, 1990, Ross signed a contract with Nike.

"I don't even know what it says," Ross said of his contract with Nike, which paid him only $ 6,000 last season. "I used to get some money from Pony, but the kids wanted Nike shoes, so we changed."

Ross's remuneration from Nike is paid strictly on an incentive basis:

- $ 1,000 for winning a conference championship.

- $ 5,000 for winning a national championship.

Ross also receives $ 2,000 (retail value) in Nike merchandise.

Nike provides 50 pairs of shoes for Tech players, and others must be purchased at a rate of three pairs for the price of two. Nike provides 100 free pairs if Tech goes to a bowl game.

Under Ross's contract with Pony, Tech received 400 pairs of shoes in 1987 and 300 pairs in both 1988 and 1989.

Also, each of 12 assistants and six other persons designated by Ross receives $ 500 in Nike merchandise, and Ross receives 400 T-shirts to distribute to youngsters at his summer camp.

Ross was paid a $ 25,000 base stipend by Pony for the 1989 season, which included the following incentives:

- $ 1,000 for each national network television game, $ 500 for each regional game.

- $ 2,000 for a Jan. 1 bowl appearance, or $ 1,000 for a non-New Year's Day bowl.

- $ 500 for a Top 20 finish, $ 1,000 for a Top 10 finish, $ 5,000 for a national championship.

- $ 1,000 for an ACC title.

- $ 5,000 for being named national coach of the year.

Ross would have gotten $ 4,000 from Pony for Tech's televised games this season. There is no TV incentive in his Nike contract.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

WALL STREET JOURNAL


May 18, 1992, Monday


NIKE'S 4TH-PERIOD NET WILL BE ON LOW END OF ANALYSTS FIGURES


SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 5


LENGTH: 33 words



Nike Inc says earnings for fourth fiscal quarter and for year will fall at lower end of analysts' estimates, resulting in decline in Nike stock for second consecutive day (S)


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: WSJ


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company: Abstracts

 

202 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 9, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Just doing it: Nike stock jumps 6 5/8


BYLINE: Linda Dono Reeves; Pat Guy


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 389 words


Separate company reports pumped up Nike stock Wednesday while cramping comeback efforts of L.A. Gear.

Nike says it has increased its share of the U.S. athletic-shoe and clothing market to 31%. The stock market approved: Nike class B shares jumped 6 3/8 to $ 66 1/8. 

L.A. Gear's ongoing losses - $ 24.4 million in the second quarter, ended May 31 - caused it to postpone an Aug. 28 dividend payment on its preferred stock. Shares of the athletic-clothing and shoe manufacturer dropped 1 5/8 to $ 10 5/8.

''L.A. Gear shouldn't be a big surprise,'' says Gary M. Jacobson, Kidder Peabody shoe analyst. ''Nineteen ninety-two is a transitional year for L.A. Gear.''

But a transitional year is better than the alternative. If it weren't for the restructuring and new management, L.A. Gear would be in bankruptcy proceedings now, Jacobson notes. Instead, L.A. Gear has settled shareholder lawsuits and government problems, is discounting old inventory and is repositioning as a casual clothier and shoemaker.

''Just Do It'' Nike is continuing its cross-training by gaining market share both domestically and internationally.

''Nike has built a very firm foundation,'' says Kevin Silverman , analyst at Kemper Securities. Its strong association with pro athletes and its investment in research and development are paying off. But he sees L.A. Gear as a company playing off fashion and suffering from fading fads.

Both analysts like Nike, saying it is a bargain even after Wednesday's run- up. They are divided on L.A. Gear. ''I think the market is overlooking the turnaround value of L.A. Gear,'' Jacobson says. ''I think the stock is a steal.''
 
CBS's earnings rise: Thanks mostly to a greater demand for television network advertising, CBS reported a 37% rise in net income per share for the second quarter. Net income was $ 70.1 million, or $ 4.53 per share, vs. $ 50.6 million , or $ 3.31 per share, a year earlier . The network's quarterly revenue rose 10% to $ 781 million from $ 710 million . The stock edged down 7/8 to $ 195 1/2.

Also helping the earnings, says CBS Chairman Laurence Tisch: CBS's rise from third to first place in prime-time network ratings. Plus, it aired the two semifinal games of the NCAA men's basketball tournament during the quarter. Last year, the games aired in the first quarter.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Marketline


USA TODAY'S MARKET SCOREBOARD; STREET TALK


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

LAWSUIT FILED AGAINST NIKE CLAIMS PATENT INFRINGEMENT

Wolverine World Wide Inc files suit against Nike Inc on charges that Nike infringed on athletic-shoe patent for elastic inner sock (S)

206 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 1, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Nike ready to squeeze more ad time out of Bo


BYLINE: Sal Ruibal


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 184 words


 Nike is making advertising lemonade out of Bo Jackson's lemon of an injury, by emphasizing his rehabilitation work.

The shoemaker's new TV ad opens with Bo at the center of the ''Bo Show,'' a Busby Berkeley-style musical with frenetic dancers (in sequined Raiders and White Sox uniforms). As a big band lays down a funky beat, tuxedoed Bo sings Nike's new catchphrase, ''Bo knows it's got that Air thing.''

But Bo stops the show to proclaim that he's ''an athlete, not an actor.'' He literally crawls out of the TV and gets to work on his rehab program: swimming, spinning on a stationary bike and weight training.

The show goes on, however, with George Foreman as the star. He leads the dancers in a new verse, ''George knows it's got that Air thing.''

The ad is directed by Joe Pytka, who is responsible for the original ''Bo Knows'' ads. The first installment is due July 9 during baseball's All-Star Game. Other versions of the ''Bo Show'' will run later this summer and feature a new lineup of guest hosts: Wayne Gretzky, Jerry Rice, Darryl Strawberry, Randall Cunningham and Eric Davis.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w
 
CUTLINE: MAY I CUT IN?: Boxer George Foreman offers to take Bo Jackson's place during Nike's new cross-training commercial.


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

211 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 8, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;
Connors: The Shoes


SECTION: Section 8; Page 13; Column 5; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 174 words


JIMMY CONNORS is up to his ankles in a shoe controversy.

Connors, who at age 39 defied the odds by winning reaching the semifinals at the United States Open, has endorsed Converse shoes for so long that the company named a line of tennis shoes for him. Yet at the Open he has played in Nikes.

What's the story here? 

Well, LIZ DOLAN, a Nike spokeswoman, said Connors approached a Nike representative a few months ago at the Wimbledon championships and said he was having problems with his feet in longer matches and thought that shoes were a factor.

"He told us he would wear our shoes for free if he could get a pair that were really comfortable," Dolan said by telephone from Nike headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.

A Converse spokeswoman, HELENE FLETCHER, said she was authorized only to read a statement that noted Connors was playing "possibly the best tennis of his career."

"Converse has enjoyed a longstanding relationship with Jimmy and plans to continue working with him in the years to come," the statement said. (AP)


LOAD-DATE: September 8, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

 

212 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


July 22, 1992


OLYMPIC GAMES: NIKE IN FRANTIC BATTLE TO SAVE ITS NAME


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 18


LENGTH: 297 words


 

TIME is running out for Nike in its trademark battle with a Spanish lawyer who has vowed to prevent the United States track and field team from wearing the company's kit in the Barcelona Games.

With the Olympics opening on Saturday, a Barcelona court refused to lift its order barring Nike from selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain. 

The decision left the company with few short-term options in its wrangle with the attorney Juan Amigo, who bought the Nike trademark in 1981 from a Barcelona sock company that registered it as a trademark in the 1930s.

 Nike had insisted it would not negotiate with Amigo and his ally, the Barcelona clothing company Cidesport - a former Nike distributor - who have asked $ 20-30 million ( pounds 11-16 million) for rights to the trademark. Now, in increasing desperation and exhorted by American diplomats, the two sides are scheduled to meet in Madrid today.

The Oregon-based company paid a multi-million-dollar figure to put its name on the US and Algerian teams in Barcelona. It expected the promotional campaign to generate $ 20 million in sales in Spain alone.

 Nike was awarded its own trademark in Spain in 1990 and company officials say they are still confident the Spanish courts will eventually rule the trademark valid.

But, although the European Commission asked the Spanish government last month to persuade the court to allow Nike to post a bond allowing the company to sell its apparel while awaiting a final decision, the injunction was upheld this month by the Constitutional Tribunal, Spain's highest appeals court.

 Nike says the uniforms are not "advertising", so do not fall under the court order. The trademark dispute does not affect Nike's sports shoes or its "swoosh" symbol.


LOAD-DATE: May 7, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Guardian Newspapers Limited

 

216 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


June 20, 1992, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


COMPANY NEWS;
NIKE AGREES TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF SPORTS CAPS


BYLINE: AP


SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 1; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 119 words


Nike Inc. signed a letter of intent to acquire the Sports Specialties Corporation, a distributor of licensed headwear based in Irvine, Calif., from the Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. Terms of the acquisition, which the companies expect to close within 60 days, were not disclosed. 

Sports Specialties, which pioneered the sale of licensed sports merchandise and distributes caps decorated with logos of professional and college sports teams, is expected to have sales of $70 million this year. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., said Sports Specialties would be operated as a subsidiary. Robert Warsaw, chief executive officer of Sports Specialties, and James Warsaw, president, will remain with the company.

219 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 2, 1992, Tuesday


Nike defends ads


BYLINE: By Jeffry Scott


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section B; Page 2


LENGTH: 125 words


Whether it's corporate philosophy or advertising, Nike Inc. takes the same approach: Just Do It.

New research shows that black role models such as Magic Johnson and Jesse Jackson may be no more persuasive than President Bush in reaching young urban blacks. But Nike still thinks its latest Spike Lee ads are worth it.

In the $ 800,000 campaign that broke last week, the black filmmaker pitches racial harmony along with sneakers.

"If we're gonna live together, we've gotta play together," Mr. Lee said in the ad.

Nike spokesman Dusty Kidd said the effectiveness of a campaign "is always difficult to measure." But that's not a concern of the company.

"It's important to at least make an attempt to get your point of view across," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

221 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


April 16, 1991, Tuesday


Converse sidesteps shoe wars, goes back to basics in new ads


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION B; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 199 words


While Nike and Reebok continue stomping each other for supremacy in the athletic shoe market, Converse has snuck in with a refreshing new back-to-the-basics marketing campaign.

Once the king of canvas, Converse Inc. had been reduced to also-ran status in the sneaker market after the meteoric leap of No. 1 Nike Inc. and No. 2 Reebok International Ltd. 

Reebok, with its current "Pump Up, and Air Out" campaign, and British Knights's new spots featuring rapper M.C. Hammer jeering, "Your mother wears Nikes!" both bash market leader Nike.

In a decidedly contrarian approach to the fray, no-nonsense Converse has come up with an "It's what's inside that counts" promotion that features more shoes than celebrity endorsers.

The campaign's sports pros - Larry Bird, Jimmy Connors and Bernard King - play off the brand's 83-year history with folksy conversations, such as Mr. Connors's that starts like this: "My mother learned to play tennis from her mother . . . " The $ 22 million campaign, launched this month, is Converse's biggest ever.

"We didn't want to join the finger-pointing match against Nike," said Gordon Tucker, Converse senior vice president of marketing.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
