222 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


March 21, 1991 Thursday


Nike stock tumbles for the third day Higher profit still disappoints investors


BYLINE: REUT


LENGTH: 315 words


DATELINE: BEAVERTON, Ore.


Reuters News Agency
BEAVERTON, Ore.
 Nike Inc., the largest U.S. marketer of athletic shoes, reported third-
quarter earnings jumped 12 per cent but the performance has disappointed
Wall Street this week and Nike's stock price tumbled. 

The Beaverton-based sneaker maker - whose earnings were restrained by
advertising and interest costs - earned $70.7-million (U.S.) in the
quarter ended Feb. 28, or 93 cents a share, up from $63.1-million or 83
cents a year earlier.

On the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, its stock tumbled $2.50 to
finish at $47.50 in active trading after the earnings report. The shares
fell another $1.75 on Tuesday and 50 cents yesterday, to close at $45.25.

Nike's share earnings were at the low end of Wall Street forecasts,
which ranged from 90 cents to $1.05, according to a survey of 13 analysts
by Lynch Jones & Ryan Inc. The average forecast was 97 cents a share.

In its earnings report, Nike said revenue shot up 39 per cent in the
third quarter to $802.2-million from $577.9-million a year earlier.

Separately, the once high-flying sneaker maker L.A. Gear Inc. said it
had reached agreement with its banks to restructure loan agreements.

Last month the No. 3 maker of athletic shoes reported a $7.1-million
loss for the fourth quarter, technically throwing L.A. Gear into default
with the banks.

Los Angeles-based L.A. Gear said its agreement with bank lenders, led
by BankAmerica Corp. of San Francisco, waives the sneaker maker from a
technical default it had anticipated. The company has said it expects a
first-quarter loss.

The company said total bank credit will be cut, at its request, to
$300-million from $360-million, with a limit of $250-million for
borrowings and $70-million for letters of credit. The sublimit for letters
of credit would fall to $50-million later in the year. The agreement is
subject to final documentation, expected to be completed by the end of
March.

225 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 14, 1992, Thursday


Nike to let Sanders be like Mike


BYLINE: By I.J. Rosenberg STAFF WRITERpersonalities; contracts; baseball; finances; advertisment; atlanta/braves


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 1


LENGTH: 271 words


Barry Bonds is arguably the best player in baseball, but before Wednesday's game the Pittsburgh outfielder seemed a little envious of Deion Sanders's new multi-year deal with Nike.

He told his good friend and two-sport star, "I'll just take $ 100 and some shoes." 

Sanders will get much more than that after signing on earlier in the day with the shoe giant that has helped make mega-stars of Michael Jordan and Bo Jackson.

Neither Nike nor Sanders's agent, Eugene Parker, would discuss financial terms of the multi-year deal. But Sanders said several weeks ago that the contract was worth more than his contract with the Falcons, which is $ 750,000 a season.

"It's going to be a lot of fun," Sanders, who did not have any major endorsements before the Nike deal, said Wednesday. "We're going to do some commercials and I'm just going to be myself."

Nike spokeswoman Lisa Deneffe said Sanders will be used to endorse the cross-trainer shoe and other fitness products.

"Deion will definitely be very visible," she said. "We feel he can bring a lot to us."

His first commercial will air sometime around the baseball All-Star Game in July, and part of it will be shot in New York on May 28, a Braves off-day.

What will it be about?

"We won't give that away," said Deneffe. Said Sanders, "I can't say anything. It's going to be a surprise. Maybe I'll do some dancing."

Meanwhile, Parker said there has been little discussion with the Braves about a contract extension which would take Sanders through the baseball season. His client's current contract ends July 31, when he is supposed to report to the Falcons.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

227 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Sun Herald (Sydney, Australia)


July 26, 1992 Sunday  
Late Edition


BUSH'S THREAT IN GAMES SQUABBLE;
BARCELONA NOTEBOOK


BYLINE: ALEX MITCHELL


SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 30


LENGTH: 1245 words


THE threat of war hangs over the 25th Olympic Games in Barcelona. A trade war, in fact. Nike, the US sports shoe manufacturer, has found to its chagrin that becoming an official patron of the Games buys no favours in Spain.

A Barcelona judge has ruled the multinational company may not advertise or distribute its products in Spain. The case was brought by the Catalan firm of Cidesport, a family company which has held rights of the Nike trademark in Spain since 1932.

Now President George Bush's office has intervened, through international trade spokeswoman Carla Hill, to register its anger with Spain's Ministry of Trade and Industry.

The US has now put Spain firmly on the list of countries which could suffer reprisals if it continues to impose protective measures against the company which is based in Portland, Oregon (which Bush hopes to carry in November's Presidential election.) 

Sergei Bubka, and Michael Jordan are among the American firms' best-known sponsored athletes. Undeterred, Nike says its leading athletes will wear its products because they are not for sale in Spain.

Lawyers for Spanish Nike say the police are entitled to enforce compliance with the law - thereby raising the spectacle of the US men's relay team running barefoot |

With commercial sponsorship of athletes reaching grotesque levels at these Games, it's unlikely either Nike will back down.

TERRORIST FEAR

THE Games have occasioned the biggest police exercise in Spain since the rule of fascist dictator Franco. More than 30,000 policemen are keeping watch from helicopters, tanks, motorbikes, patrol cars and unmarked vehicles.

Some security men are even in the harbour and off the coast in navy submarines.

Operations are being directed from a $1 million purpose-built bunker, centre of a closed-circuit video network filming the stadium and tracks, the Olympic village and the city's main streets.

The main fear is a headline-grabbing military operation by members of ETA, the ultra-nationalist group seeking independence for the Basque country in northern Spain.

With many ETA activists in jail in both France and Spain, Barcelonans are praying for a trouble-free Olympics.

In the hot seat is Interior Minister Jose Luis Corcuera who boasted in Parliament that recent arrests probably left only one active ETA commando unit in Spain. That's fine, Jose, but where is it?

After two years of efforts to reach a truce, the Spanish Government evidently felt strong enough to maintain an official silence in the face of a recent truce offer from ETA leaders.

Last week two Basque political parties, Herri Batasuna and Eusko Alkartasuna, signed a joint pact and wrote to Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and French President Francois Mitterrand demanding recognition of the Basques' right to self-determination.

If ETA and the Basques behave during the Games, the Spanish Government has let it be known, ever so unofficially, that it will make some "tactical, conciliatory gestures" to the Basque nation.

TOUCHY SUBJECT

IT is not Basque terrorists but the regional government of Catalonia(capital Barcelona) which is causing most embarrassment to Spanish authorities.

Jordi Pujol, head of Catalonia's Council, has outraged Madrid by campaigning in the European press for recognition of Catalonia. One full-page advertisement declared Catalonia was "a country within Spain which has been able to bring the Olympics to its capital, Barcelona".

Pujol's campaign has led to an outcry from the Madrid Government which points out that the central government has borne more than 50 per cent of the cost.

In his visit last week to the Olympic village where his son, Felipe, is a member of Spain's yachting team, King Juan Carlos made no direct reference to the controversy. But he did remark that the Games were "of transcendental importance in the history of Spain".

Pujol, unrepentant, accused Spain's ruling Socialist Party of"criminalising Catalan nationalism". The lofty ideals of the Olympics are unlikely to heal the breach.

A hardy contingent of sports fans from Australia have fallen at the first Olympic hurdle - the language barrier.

"Jeez, mate," complained one Aussie, "it's hard to get around over here. No-one speaks Australian."

It reminded me of the old bloke from Coogee who went on a world tour soon after retiring. Back at the bowling club eight weeks' later someone asked him how it had gone.

"It was OK," he said grudgingly, "except there were too many New Australians."

HUMAN FAILURE

WHILE the Games are in the stadiums, Barcelona's Science Museum is not to be outdone. It is staging an exhibition of sports simulation which enables visitors to experience the thrill of the grand slalom or the pole vault, for example, without actually moving.

As well, the exhibition features comparisons between human athletic records and the achievements of the animal kingdom. This shows that no animal has jumped as high as the kangaroo (3.3 metres); that only Sergei Bubka, with his 6.13m pole vault, has jumped higher than a dolphin, and that Arnold Schwarzenegger swinging on a rope exerts a force of 100kg, less than one-third of that achieved by your average chimpanzee.

I wonder if our Science Museum could mount a similar exercise comparing the intelligence of animals and, say, politicians. Just a thought.

HOTSHOTS

THE hidden factor of these Games may well prove to be the heat. It is sweltering. Temperatures over the past week have swung between 30 to 38 degrees.

Spain's own Olympic football team has been suffering. Being blow-wave Iberians, a sports psychologist, Dr Jesus Garcia Barrero, was called in to help cool them down. My tip is that the sun-parched Moroccans, Algerians, Ethiopians and Kenyans will star in the track events. Give the Icelanders and Finns a miss this year.

DAYLIGHT ROBBERY

IT comes as no surprise to learn that the Spaniards gave us the word pirata which we translate as pirate. I visited an official money-changing office which carried a table in the window offering 178 pesetas for each Pound 1 sterling. I changed Pound 50 and discovered to my horror I had received only 161 pesetas per Pound .

When I protested I was insolently told the higher rate was only for transactions worth 500,000 pesetas or more. I got my money back but only after a furious row involving a threat to call the police.

Barcelona's restaurateurs have also gone mad. As of last week their eateries became - officially - the highest priced in all of Spain. Their bonanza may be shortlived. One hotel chain owner predicted in El Mundo last week that half of the city's restaurants will fold after the three-week Games

HARD YAKKA |

IN Seville, the Australian Consul ate is housed in the British Institute. Yes, folks, the British are the landlords and we are the humble tenants.

And the office keeps strict British colonial hours - open Monday to Friday, 10am to noon.

CASTRO'S VISIT EMBARRASSES THE HOST

BARCELONA is plastered with posters greeting Cuba's President, Fidel Castro.

He arrives today with 20 other Latin American heads of state for the Iberio-American summit opening in Madrid on Thursday. "Cuba, with you more than ever," say the street posters.

Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, a fawning friend of Uncle Sam, is doing his best to play down Castro's historic visit.

While left-wing mayors and regional leaders are queueing for a photo opportunity with the honcho from Havana, USA-style socialist Gonzalez will beat Ben Johnson sprinting in the other direction.

Perhaps wind-assisted.


LOAD-DATE: July 21, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

229 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


August 6, 1992 Thursday


Nike says trade boot is on the other foot


SECTION: HERALD BUSINESS; Pg. 49


LENGTH: 219 words


TWO of the world's biggest suppliers of sports equipment - Nike and Adidas - have warned the US Government that trade retaliation against China would seriously hurt their Hong Kong operations.

 Nike, the world's largest producer of sports shoes, said if punitive tariffs were imposed Nike would have to sharply raise prices or shut down its entire operation in China. 

Such action would undermine its regional headquarters in Hong Kong, where there would be thousands of job losses, the company said.

 Nike has urged the US Trade Representative to target China's state-run shoe factories instead of those operated by private enterprises.

Adidas, another industry giant, said all of its financing, purchases and shipping for Adidas merchandise manufactured in China was done through businesses in Hong Kong, which would be hard hit by US trade retaliation.

For example, a company such as Yue Yuen Industrial Ltd, the large sports shoe maker which listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange in June, could see its business seriously wounded.

But the powerful American Textile Manufacturers Institute (ATMI) has demanded that the US impose punitive tariffs on key Chinese exports to match dollar-for-dollar the losses suffered by the US from China's trade barriers.

Sth CHINA MORNING POST

END OF STORY

231 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


July 14, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


DIGEST


BYLINE: CITIZEN; CITIZEN NEWS SERVICES


SECTION: SPORTS; SPORTS DIGEST; Pg. E6


 

OLYMPICS

Nike says OK

Nike Inc. said Monday its trademark problem in Spain won't affect the ability of national teams to wear Nike-produced uniforms in the Olympic Games. "Despite repeated press reports that link our trademark case to Olympic uniforms, there is no connection legally," said Lindsay Stewart, Nike vice-president and corporate counsel. He said the uniforms bearing the Nike logo comply with International Olympic Committee regulations that restrict advertising. "The courts in Spainhave ruled we may not sell apparel or advertise our apparel until our trademark case is settled," Stewart said. The company will provide the national uniforms to the track and field teams of the United States, Nigeria, Algeria, Paraguay and the Bahamas. 

SWIMMING

Local medal haul

Paced by Hannah Buchanan, Shelly Price and Shannon Marklew, Nepean-Kanata Barracudas rose from 22nd place a year earlier to seventh in provincial swim team age-group rankings as they turned in a solid effort at the Ontario Long Course Age-Group championships in Etobicoke. Buchan, 10, who had earned under-10 high point honors at the recent Eastern Ontario championships at the Nepean Sportsplex, earned silver medals in the 200 and 400 freestyle; Price, 12, took silver in the 200 breaststroke and Marklew, 13, bronze in the 200 metre butterfly. Gloucester-Ottawa Swim Club's J.M. Mills, 12, broke the existing Ontario record of 1 minute, 7.92 seconds in the 100 backstroke with a 1:07.74 clocking but finished behind Windsor's Greg Meisner who swam the distance in 1:06.03, provincial and Canadian records. Mills also missed a Canadian record in the 50 freestyle as he swam 26.30. The national mark is 26.20. Mills added a second silver in the 100 freestyle and a bronze in the 100 butterfly. GO teammate Stephanie Zarins took gold in the 200 breaststroke and Gord Veldman of Ernestown earned gold in the 200 backstroke. Julie Gravelle, 12, of GO won three silver and two bronze; Jean Ooi, 14, of Ernestown a silver; Perth's Kelly Crampton a bronze and the Cornwall 4x50 freestyle relay squad of Erin Berard, Corina MacRae, Harveen Soodan and Andrea Bedard the 11-12 girls relay bronze.

(Citizen staff and news services.)

The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


December 19, 1992, Saturday, WEEKLY EDITION


Nike profits jump


BYLINE: Financial Times of London and Financial Post news services


SECTION: SECTION 4, THE MARKETS; Pg. 26, International Company News


LENGTH: 98 words


 Nike Inc. posted a 23% increase in profits for its latest quarter Friday and said worldwide orders continue to be strong. The leader in athletic footwear said it earned a record US$76 million (US98 cents a share) in the quarter that ended Nov. 30, compared with US$61.5 million (US80 cents) a year earlier. Revenues rose to US$875.8 million from US$743.4 million. For the first half of its fiscal year, Nike earnings have jumped to US$198.6 million (US$2.58) from US$176 million (US$2.30) in last year's first half. Revenues have risen to US$1.98 billion from US$1.69 billion.

234 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


November 20, 1992, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Jordan, league fashion a compromise


BYLINE: Peter Vecsey


SECTION: SPORTS; BASKETBALL COMMENTARY; Pg. 4C


LENGTH: 824 words


DATELINE: NEW YORK


A yearlong dispute regarding the use of Michael Jordan's likeness on NBA sportswear has been resolved in principle - without litigation or arbitration - to the satisfaction of His Airness, Nike and the league.

But, according to Doug Stamms, Nike's marketing attorney, ''The ink is not dry yet.''

Deputy commissioner Russell Granik is comfortable, though. He says Nike, Jordan and the NBA are ''finding a way to live together and prosper.'' 

The three parties worked out their differences as they applied to the Olympics and have now dealt with broader issues pertaining to league merchandising.

For whatever it's worth (David Stern is on call to caddy for Michael), the league has retained the right to market Jordan's likeness.

Had it not, the NBA probably would've substituted Mirage hotel and casino owner Steve Wynn.
 
MAGIC FORMULA: Nobody says it better than columnist Dan Shaughnessy. For example, in Tuesday's Boston Globe, he noted, ''Magic Johnson has said the same things so many times that even Arsenio will have a hard time pretending he's hearing the stuff for the first time.''

Then again, Magic has said so many things so many different ways, the truth is often ignored in the process.

Out of one side of his mouth, Magic fingered the Cavaliers for allegedly backing off him because of a bandaged scratch on his arm, a premise Craig Ehlo and Cleveland teammates labeled absurd.

Out of the other side, Magic tried to lay guilt trips on Suns owner Jerry Colangelo and Karl Malone for voicing concerns regarding the risk of playing against Johnson, who's infected with the AIDS virus. According to Magic's warped logic, their ulterior motive was to ice the competition.

To be perfectly blunt, Magic's assertion that Malone's comments influenced his decision is sheer twisted wreckage.

Immediately following his final retirement, he was quoted extensively as saying he didn't even know what Malone said until 36 hours after his decision. Shortly thereafter, he created a more convenient story line.

In the last couple weeks, I figure Magic has been fawned over by the national media roughly a dozen times in his effort to sell his book to people who'll buy anything and to document his world-class athleticism for womanizing.

Not once has an interviewer refuted Magic on the Malone discrepancy or other bogus contentions. Not once has one challenged his preposterous Cavaliers theory. Not once has anyone questioned his supposed concern for others as a factor in his retirement, when, in reality, the only person he ever really has been concerned about is himself.
 
CLIFF NOTES: As far as I know, Cliff Robinson is the only player in the league who plays three frontcourt positions every night and defends them all with honor. Occasionally, he must even clamp down on a particularly hot off guard.

Each season, the 6-9 Trail Blazers' minutes, blocks, steals, rebounds, scoring, (turnovers), field goal and free throw percentages improve. Yet his lack of recognition is constant.

Each season, Robinson plays in every exhibition, every regular-season game (251 and counting) and every playoff game (58) and doesn't fool around in any of 'em. Yet his durability, versatility and competitive spirit are largely ignored.

Each season, the Blazers have advanced well into the playoffs, and Robinson's role has increased. Yet each time ballots are cast for best sixth man, most improved or best defensive player, he's one step removed from an afterthought.

How can that be? It must be because Cliff has such a hard last name to remember compared to vote getters such as Sarunas Marciulionis, Detlef Schrempf and Dan Majerle.
 
WONDERLAND: That's not all I'm wondering about today:

- I mean, is Larry Bird working in Boston's front or back office?

- Shouldn't the Nets be thinking of getting Vernon ''Can't we all just get along?'' Maxwell to enhance their chemistry?

- Think Clifford Ray gets visibly excited about a comeback each time he reads a Warriors box score? How about Martha Raye?

- Does the Hornets' Allan Bristow entertain any plans of getting into coaching this season?

- Will the Hornets' Johnny Newman's field goal attempts dip to fewer than 15 a game now that he has broken his shooting hand?

- Have the Hornets really replaced Newman with David Wingate? Who's his agent, Marion Barry?

- Since the Celtics obviously have to do something (signing first- rounder Jon Barry to a fair contract is too easy), I wonder who'll be the lucky unrestricted free agent VP Dave Gavitt falls in love with but won't pursue? Who will Gavitt trade for, then ignore because he expects to get paid? Who will Gavitt claim off waivers, then release before his first per diem check is due?

Charles Barkley wanted to take his little girl to see Malcolm X but felt it was too violent, reports column castigator Frank Drucker. ''So he's waiting for Spike Lee to make the sequel, Malcolm PG.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

235 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


October 5, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Nike values versatility


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 83 words


Deion Sanders finds that it pays to play two sports.

Sander's three-year endorsement contract with Nike calls for him to earn $ 1 million a year as long as he plays both baseball and football. If Sanders, an outfielder for the Atlanta Braves and cornerback for the Falcons, decides to play only one sport, the contract's value drops to $ 100,000.

Nike also has an option to drop the contract completely if Sanders chooses one sport, according to The (Atlanta) Journal-Constitution.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

240 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 3, 1992, Saturday


BASEBALL: THE BRAVES Nike deal worth $ 1 million a year, making Sanders a $ 4 million man


BYLINE: By Len Pasquarelli STAFF WRITERsports; business; contracts; advertising; atlanta/braves; atlanta/falcons


SECTION: SPORTS; Section D; Page 7


LENGTH: 382 words


If his contract to endorse Nike athletic shoes and apparel has any bearing on Deion Sanders's future, the dual sports star is likely to continue juggling his football and baseball careers for the next few years.

The three-year deal signed this summer calls for Sanders to receive about $ 1 million annually from the athletic shoe manufacturer, provided the Falcons cornerback/Braves outfielder plays at least a half-season in each of the two sports, according to an attorney who reviewed the contract for Nike.

Sanders also receives a bonus based on the sales volume of the model of shoe he wears in each sport. 

The penalty if Sanders were to give up either sport is a stiff one, dropping the contract's value to about $ 100,000. Nike also maintains an option to terminate the contract should Sanders decide to play one sport.

Sanders's deal with Nike will likely push his sports-related earnings for 1992 close to the $ 4 million mark.

His contract with the Braves, extended through the regular season, will pay him $ 972,000 and offers Sanders the opportunity to add another $ 100,000 or more in postseason bonuses.

Sanders's new one-year "supplemental contract" with the Falcons calls for about $ 2 million. However, he figures to forfeit between $ 400,000 and $ 500,000 in penalties for missing the club's first regular- season game and one or two midseason games while he joins the Braves for baseball's postseason.

Sanders's attorney, Eugene Parker, could not be reached for comment. Lisa DeNeffe, public relations manager for Nike, declined to comment on the contract.

DeNeffe did say the company was "tremendously excited" by the early results of Sanders's endorsement deal.

"It's definitely a good fit for Nike," said DeNeffe. "We've done the one [commercial] spot so far and, based on our consumer hotline, it's had great response. We're definitely looking forward to furthering our relationship with Deion."

DeNeffe said a second commercial featuring Sanders would debut around the Christmas holidays but declined to offer details.

Reports have indicated Sanders and comic Dennis Leary, who appears in the first commercial, will discuss why Santa Claus is not generally portrayed as a black man.

Staff writer I.J. Rosenberg also contributed to this report.


LOAD-DATE: October 7, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922810097


GRAPHIC: color photo RAN ON D-1: $ 4 million man Deion Sanders has a $ 1 million endorsement deal with Nike.Deion Sanders's deal with Nike likely will push his sports-related earnings for 1992 close to the $ 4 million mark. But there are considerable losses if he doesn't play both football and baseball.


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

242 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 3, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Praise for Nike, Milk-Bone, revival ads


BYLINE: Stuart Elliot


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 8B


LENGTH: 747 words


For advertisers, 1990 was a strange year. Early on, the outlook was rosy. Ads glowed with glasnost to celebrate historic changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But by fall, ads addressed more somber topics - a souring economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. USA TODAY's Stuart Elliott looks back in this review of best and worst ads of 1990:
 
 Nike hits again: Nike just might be the most creative advertiser of 1990. The best of the best was ''Bo's family reunion.'' Few thought Nike could top its ''Bo knows'' spots, among the best ads of 1989. But this wildly imaginative TV ad presented 15 versions of superstar Bo Jackson, excelling in every sport from football and baseball to horse racing and golf. 

Other highlights:

- ''Announcers,'' a TV ad that parodies football, sportscasters and Nike's own ads.

- Two more TV ads in the Mars Blackmon series directed by Spike Lee and co-starring Lee and basketball titan Michael Jordan. They drew more praise than Lee got for his movie Mo' Better Blues.

- A new campaign called ''Rock 'n' roll tennis.'' One TV ad paired Andre Agassi and the year's most unlikely pitchstars - the Red Hot Chili Peppers, a cult punk-rock band.

Not every ad clicked. Someday, Mr. Rogers is going to spank Nike for the ''Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood'' ads with David Robinson. Can you say, ''Cease and desist''? Agency: Wieden & Kennedy Inc.
 
In the pink: Year 2 of Energizer's series of E.B. ads surpassed the fun of Year 1, when Energizer also made the Best Ads list. Just when viewers least expected it, along came the pink rabbit to march through ads that mock other ads. Targets in '90: ads for air fresheners, long-distance telephone service, soft drinks and hemorrhoid remedies.

Most hilarious: an ad that simultaneously made fun of foreign films and coming attractions. It took the form of a preview for a make-believe movie called Dance with Your Feet. To complete the illusion, the ad ran in movie theaters as well as on TV. Agency: Chiat/Day/
Mojo Inc.
 
Politically speaking: For everyone who despairs over mud-slinging political ads, hope surfaced in Minnesota's U.S. Senate race. Deftly humorous TV ads for long-shot challenger Paul Wellstone were a big reason that he upset the two-term Republican incumbent, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz.

One ad, ''Looking for Rudy,'' was based on the comic documentary Roger & Me. The ad followed Wellstone as he searched in vain for Boschwitz so they could debate.

Another ad, ''Fast-paced Paul,'' presented Wellstone cramming all his positions into a single 30-second spot. The rapid spiel was necessary, the ad explained, because Wellstone couldn't match Boschwitz's ad budget. Agency: North Woods Advertising, adman Bill Hillsman's free-lance shop.
 
Doggone clever: A TV ad for Milk-Bone dog treats put smiles on the faces of viewers by putting a smile on the face of a dog. The ad likened new Milk- Bone tartar-control products to toothpaste. The inspired video image that closed the sale: a bull mastiff sporting an enormous ear-to-ear grin. The silly sight was made possible by special effects that superimposed a human mouth onto the dog's mouth. Agency: FCB/Leber Katz Partners.
 
These ads fly: The growing glut of car ads in '90 made it hard for any pitch to stand out. Kudos to Chrysler's Eagle line for ads that manage to stand out and be outstanding.

The ads all are in the same style: As an announcer asks a car buyer why he or she purchased a 1991 Eagle model, there's a wry twist to a familiar joke.

Sample: A man says Eagle Talon ''rated higher in overall quality of workmanship than cars like Ford Probe and Honda CRX.'' Says the announcer, actor Orson Bean: ''I'd like to see a breakdown of all the competition.'' The man replies, ''Now, let's not get spiteful.'' Agency: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising.
 
Comebacks: A hot trend that began in '88 - revival ads - reached fever pitch. To get the attention of baby-boom consumers, advertisers brought back familiar characters, slogans and jingles of the '50s, '60s and '70s.

A warm Welcome Back to: Punchy, Hawaiian Punch's punch-drinking cartoon kid; Coca-Cola Classic's reunited hilltop choir; Nipper the RCA dog, joined by a junior puppy partner; a cartoon baby named Horton whose first words are ''Ruffles have r-r-r-r-idges''; and Joe DiMaggio back at bat for Mr. Coffee.

Agencies: N W Ayer, McCann-Ericson, Ammirati & Puris, DDB Needham Worldwide, Meldrum & Fewsmith Advertising.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, Rob Brown, USA TODAY; PHOTO; color (2)
 
CUTLINE: BO JACKSON: Star of Nike's imaginative ad. CUTLINE: MULTI-BOs: Nike ad features 15 versions of athlete Bo Jackson. CUTLINE: E.B. RIDES AGAIN: Energizer spoofs ads for long distance.


Ribbon Label; 1990'S BEST AND WORST ADS; 2


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

245 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


March 10, 1991, Sunday, Final Edition


Boycott or Not, Nike Sales Push Upward;
Jackson's Troubled Operation No Match for Thompson, Lee and Jordan


Bill Brubaker


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A19


LENGTH: 516 words


Inside a suite in New York City's Grand Hyatt hotel, three of America's most celebrated black sports and entertainment figures were trying to make peace with Operation PUSH, the Chicago-based civil rights organization. Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson was there. So was actor/filmmaker Spike Lee. And Chicago Bulls all-star guard Michael Jordan. 

The three celebrities gathered on a Sunday evening last September as paid representatives of Nike Inc., the world's largest athletic shoe and apparel company. Their mission: End the boycott PUSH had called against Nike to protest its minority hiring and business practices.

The meeting was scheduled after Nike Chairman Phil Knight failed to satisfy PUSH during a widely publicized session in August on the Georgetown campus. "It was John Thompson's idea," Knight said of the New York meeting. "I was complaining to John that we weren't getting anywhere in negotiations. John's line to me was, 'You think too much like a white man. Let me go negotiate with them.' "

But the negotiations failed -- and the two sides haven't met since. Now, as the largely unsuccessful boycott continues, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who founded PUSH, refers to Nike's black endorsers as "shoe salesmen" who seem more interested in making money than "fighting for equal opportunity."

PUSH officials complain that Nike -- though its annual retail sales to black consumers total hundreds of millions of dollars -- has no high-ranking black executives and does no business with black-owned banks and advertising agencies. According to Nike, 320 (7.5 percent) of its 4,243 U.S.-based employees are black. Blacks account for about 4 percent of the population of metropolitan Portland, Ore., where Nike is based.

Nike has announced it will hire a minority vice president this year and name a minority to its board of directors by 1992. Knight said the appointments probably will be black. "If we were perfect, we would've gotten that taken care of sooner," he said, adding that Nike was formed in 1972 as a small, "too male and too white" company.

Thompson, a $ 200,000-plus-a-year Nike consultant, said no organization has a right to tell another how to do business. Jackson responded in a recent interview: "That detachment from ethical responsibility, that detachment from racial justice, as opposed to personal aggrandizement, is not in the best tradition of fighting for equal opportunity."

The boycott has had little apparent effect on Nike, whose earnings soared 58 percent last September, October and November over the corresponding period in 1989. Jackson said the PUSH boycott will continue until Nike negotiates "a joint plan for economic justice." The boycott may be difficult to sustain: PUSH, citing economic troubles, recently laid off its entire 12-person national staff.

Thompson gently poked fun at Jackson last fall, giving him a pair of Nike sneakers for his 49th birthday. "When Jesse opened the box, he broke out laughing," Thompson recalled. But now Jackson isn't smiling. "Those sneakers," he said, "they're still in the box."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: THE SNEAKER PHENOMENON, Part 1 of 2


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, AFTER AN AUGUST 1990 NEWS CONFERENCE, THOMPSON, RIGHT, AND JACKSON CONFERRED ABOUT OPERATION PUSH'S BOYCOTT OF NIKE TO PROTEST ITS MINORITY HIRING AND BUSINESS PRACTICES. CAROL GUZY; PHOTO


TYPE: SERIES


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

248 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


April 25, 1992, Saturday


BUSINESS REPORT: ON RETAILING Saucony chases Nike, Reebok


BYLINE: By Sonia Murray


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section B; Page 2


LENGTH: 94 words


In the end, what's good for the sole is what counts. 

While athletic-wear giants Nike and Reebok account for about half of the running shoes sold in this country, the May issue of Consumer Reports plugs lesser-known and less-costly Saucony Jazz 3000.

The Saucony shoes rated higher than Nike and Reebok models in recent tests conducted by the magazine's athletic equipment experts.

However, the magazine did recommend Nike Air 180 and Avia ARC 2040MZ for men. For women, New Balance W997 and the Reebok Running Pump also impressed the in-house testers.


LOAD-DATE: April 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

The Advertiser


December 14, 1991 Saturday


The top ten


LENGTH: 77 words


Stepping out in the latest sports shoes is not cheap, as this list of the 10 most expensive shoes proves. 

1. Nike Air Force 180 High $329.

2. Rockport Hiking Boot $295.

3. Rockport Hiking Shoe $279.

4. Reebok Court Victory Pump $259.

5. Reebok SXT Pump $249.

6. Nike Air Jordon 7 $239.

7. LA Gear Catapult $229.

8. Nike Air-Tech Challenge $229.

9. Nike Air 180 running shoes $229.

10. Nike Air Max $199.

254 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 31, 1992, Friday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS OLYMPIC GAMES Olympic sidelines News and notes from around the Games Nike: Wearing Reebok OK


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 4


LENGTH: 292 words


Liz Dolan, Nike's vice president of corporate communications, says five minutes on the medal stand won't make anyone think Michael Jordan or any other Nike clients represent Reebok.

"You'd have to have been living in a cave to think that," Dolan said. "In Michael's case, he'd wear [the official uniform] for five minutes; he'll wear our shoes his entire career. There's no risk that anyone will think he's affiliated with anyone but Nike."

That's why, Dolan said, Nike is encouraging all of its Olympic medal- winners to wear the official medal-ceremony uniform, which is a Reebok product. Reebok's contract is believed to be worth about $ 4 million.

Jordan has said "there is no way in the world I am wearing a suit that's made by Reebok," but he also has hedged slightly, saying he'll decide "when the time comes." USA press chief Mike Moran has said that any medal winner who does not comply will not be permitted on the awards stand, and that no athlete ever has refused to wear the official uniform. In the previous two Olympics, Levi Strauss held the contract.

The Dream Team's Nike clients also include David Robinson, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and assistant coach P.J. Carlesimo.

Bureaucracy wins

Sprinting star Bruno Marie-Rose has been excluded from the 100-meter race at the Olympics because French organizers forgot to register him. Marie-Rose, a member of the team that set a world record in the 400-meter relay in 1990, was told Thursday he was excluded from the 100 because of the error by French track officials. "It's so stupid, so idiotic," he said. Serge Bord, who already plans to step down as head of France's track team after the Games, assumed responsibility for the mistake.


LOAD-DATE: August 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922190247


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

256 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


February 22, 1991 Friday


ANGIE REWARDS COACH'S FAITH


LENGTH: 279 words


LEN McKENDRY has sprung one of the surprises of the season by recommending temperamental Heidelberg winger Angie Goutzioulis to national coach Eddie Thomson.

Goutzioulis has earned three weeks of suspension from bookings and landed an extra week after being sent off early in the game against Wollongong City. 

But McKendry retained his belief in the player's ability and was rewarded when the player turned on a match-winning performance against Marconi on Sunday.

Goutzioulis' performance earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.The weekly winner receives a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280. The end of season winner collects $2000 cash from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award. Round 20. Votes. Apia v Woll Mac: 3 Blagojevic (al), 2 Kay (wm), 1 Hughes (al). Heidelberg v Marconi: 3 Goutzioulis (h), 2 Catlin (m), 1 Brattan (h). Preston Mak v Adelaide: 2 Parton (pm), 2 Ivanovic (ac), 1 A.Vidmar (ac), 1 Spink (pm). Sunshine v South Melb: 3 Micheil (sm), 2 Palatsides (sm), 1 Keogh (sgc). St Geo v Melb Cro: 2 Harper (stg), 1 Milosevic (mc), 1 Biskic (mc), 1 Davidson (mc), 1 Marth (mc). Syd Cro v Syd Oly: 3 Franken (scr), 1 Kupresak (scr), 1 Stanton (scr), 1 Bernal (so). Woll City v Melita: 2 Callanan (me), 2 Gimenez (me), 2 Kuc (wc).

Leaders: 17 Clarkson, Filan. 16 P.Okon. 15 Petersen. 14 Franken, 13 Blagojevic, Bundalo, Kuc, Petkovic.12 Biskic, Ivanovic, Stubbins. 11 Gimenez, Jackson, Kindtner, Kupresak, Lowe, McCulloch. Phillips, Spink, Tsolakis, 10 Katholos, Nowicki, A.Vidmar. Wade. 9 Catlin, Davidson, Durakovic, Gray, Krslovic, Stewart, T.Vidmar. P.Wilson.

JOURNAL-CODE: DHS

258 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


May 18, 1991, Saturday, SATURDAY EDITION


Nike finds sports fans like artsy commercials


BYLINE: By Dianne Allen Special to The Star


SECTION: WEEKEND; Pg. H6


LENGTH: 717 words


 

It's enough to make a TV sports fan choke on his beer. There he is innocently watching his basketball or baseball game expecting it to be interrupted by commercials, sure, but jock-style commercials aimed at jock-style guys.

Suddenly he's bombarded by incredible images that flash by his eyes.

Images of a sci-fi creature emerging from a pod as humanoid, a cartoon daredevil bouncing inside a giant running shoe, or an animated runner, escaping from his own burning scrapbook image. 

Fifteen-second and 30-second mini art films created and directed by some of the world's most talented filmmakers (including Canada's David Cronenburg) and commissioned by Nike, to advertise its new 180 air-cushioned running shoe.

Are these commercials art? Or commercial art? Or just commercial? And what are they doing on jock TV?

The campaign was born last year when Nike asked its ad agency, Wieden & Kennedy, to come up with a campaign for the 180 that could run internationally. (The 180 was the first Nike athletic shoe to be introduced everywhere in the world at once.)

The problem was how to communicate to people who speak different languages and idolize different sports heroes, sports heroes being Nike's traditional creative approach.

The creative folk at the agency solved the problem by suggesting Nike commission filmmakers from different parts of the world to express what the 180 meant to them.

The new 50 per cent larger air cushion was to be the main focus, with no spoken words, just music and sound effects.

The resulting commercials were surprising, even to Nike. Originally scheduled to launch in North America on the Superbowl, the spots were held back.

Another commercial was hurriedly put together, using Nike's traditional sports hero approach, and featuring triathalon champ Mark Allen. The jocks were safe from art for a time.

But when the artsy ads got good reaction in Europe, Nike's president, Phil Knight, decided to try them out at home. And according to Nike, they've worked.

Could it be that people who are ready to shell out $ 150 for a running shoe ($ 169.99 in Canada, $ 192 with tax) are also ready for art in their running shoe commercials?

The artistic approach has some opponents, however. It prompted one columnist to criticize Nike's print version of this campaign as a self-motivated form of corporate sponsorship of the arts.

But, in fact, the campaign is nothing of the sort. It was motivated by the need to find a practical solution to a problem, that of creating international advertising. And in the process, filmmakers were given the kind of artistic freedom seldom granted to commercial illustrators or directors.

They were also given exposure to a world-wide audience that would likely never have heard of them otherwise. Not a bad trade.

If you haven't seen the Nike 180 commercials, you still have a chance until June. David Cronenburg's sci-fi thriller, and Dutch animator Evert de Beijer's giant running shoe are still airing on CTV during Blue Jays games.

*

Mooooove Over, Cancows: That singing cow is back in the news again. It seems the bronze Bessie award-winning crooner for HP Sauce is one more example of an American performer appearing in a Canadian commercial.

Yes, that lounge-cow is from Arizona, born and bred.

According to writer Bill Martin, creator of the HP commercial, ad agency Bozell Palmer Bonner would have cast a Canadian cow, but the weather in November was too cold for the shoot. They cast this particular cow because she looked like a Canadian cow, and had no ear-notches or curly horns.

As one of 26,000 cows in the herd, how did she get the part?

Says Martin: "She probably didn't move away as fast as the other cows when they came to take Polaroids."

She didn't have to know how to sing either. In close-up, the singing cow was actually a puppet, and the voice was Canadian musician Tim Tickner.

By the way, fans of this commercial can look forward to a follow-up in September, starring a chicken and a pig named Wilbur, pitching four new sauces from HP. They're Americans too.

The duo won't be singing, but you can bet the commercial will be fun and sophisticated.

Meanwhile, rumor has it the cow has signed up an agent and will be appearing in Vegas next month.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: HP sauce's barnyard commercial


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

259 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


May 18, 1991, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION


Nike finds sports fans like artsy commercials


BYLINE: By Dianne Allen Special to The Star


SECTION: WEEKEND; Pg. H6


LENGTH: 718 words


 
   It's enough to make a TV sports fan choke on his beer. There he is innocently watching his basketball or baseball game expecting it to be interrupted by commercials, sure, but jock-style commercials aimed at jock-style guys.

Suddenly he's bombarded by incredible images that flash by his eyes.

Images of a sci-fi creature emerging from a pod as humanoid, a cartoon daredevil bouncing inside a giant running shoe, or an animated runner, escaping from his own burning scrapbook image. 

Fifteen-second and 30-second mini art films created and directed by some of the world's most talented filmmakers (including Canada's David Cronenburg) and commissioned by Nike, to advertise its new 180 air-cushioned running shoe.

Are these commercials art? Or commercial art? Or just commercial? And what are they doing on jock TV?

The campaign was born last year when Nike asked its ad agency, Wieden & Kennedy, to come up with a campaign for the 180 that could run internationally. (The 180 was the first Nike athletic shoe to be introduced everywhere in the world at once.)

The problem was how to communicate to people who speak different languages and idolize different sports heroes, sports heroes being Nike's traditional creative approach.

The creative folk at the agency solved the problem by suggesting Nike commission filmmakers from different parts of the world to express what the 180 meant to them.

The new 50 per cent larger air cushion was to be the main focus, with no spoken words, just music and sound effects.

The resulting commercials were surprising, even to Nike. Originally scheduled to launch in North America on the Superbowl, the spots were held back.

Another commercial was hurriedly put together, using Nike's traditional sports hero approach, and featuring triathalon champ Mark Allen. The jocks were safe from art for a time.

But when the artsy ads got good reaction in Europe, Nike's president, Phil Knight, decided to try them out at home. And according to Nike, they've worked.

Could it be that people who are ready to shell out $150 for a running shoe ($169.99 in Canada, $192 with tax) are also ready for art in their running shoe commercials?

The artistic approach has some opponents, however. It prompted one columnist to criticize Nike's print version of this campaign as a self-motivated form of corporate sponsorship of the arts.

But, in fact, the campaign is nothing of the sort. It was motivated by the need to find a practical solution to a problem, that of creating international advertising. And in the process, filmmakers were given the kind of artistic freedom seldom granted to commercial illustrators or directors.

They were also given exposure to a world-wide audience that would likely never have heard of them otherwise. Not a bad trade.

If you haven't seen the Nike 180 commercials, you still have a chance until June. David Cronenburg's sci-fi thriller, and Dutch animator Evert de Beijer's giant running shoe are still airing on CTV during Blue Jays games.

*

Mooooove Over, Cancows: That singing cow is back in the news again. It seems the bronze Bessie award-winning crooner for HP Sauce is one more example of an American performer appearing in a Canadian commercial.

Yes, that lounge-cow is from Arizona, born and bred.

According to writer Bill Martin, creator of the HP commercial, ad agency Bozell Palmer Bonner would have cast a Canadian cow, but the weather in November was too cold for the shoot. They cast this particular cow because she looked like a Canadian cow, and had no ear-notches or curly horns.

As one of 26,000 cows in the herd, how did she get the part?

Says Martin: "She probably didn't move away as fast as the other cows when they came to take Polaroids."

She didn't have to know how to sing either. In close-up, the singing cow was actually a puppet, and the voice was Canadian musician Tim Tickner.

By the way, fans of this commercial can look forward to a follow-up in September, starring a chicken and a pig named Wilbur, pitching four new sauces from HP. They're Americans too.

The duo won't be singing, but you can bet the commercial will be fun and sophisticated.

Meanwhile, rumor has it the cow has signed up an agent and will be appearing in Vegas next month.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

262 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


March 19, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Weaker earnings trip Nike shares


BYLINE: James Kim; Rhonda Richards


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 385 words


Shares of Nike Inc. ran into trouble Monday, when the Beaverton, Ore.- based athletic-shoe maker reported weaker-than-expected earnings. Nike stock sank 2 1/2 to $ 47 1/2

The nation's largest maker of athletic shoes reported earnings of 93 cents per share for the quarter ending Feb. 28 - a 12% jump from 83 cents. Analysts had been expecting the company to earn about 97 cents. ''The results were a little disappointing,'' says Gary Jacobson, analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. ''It appears that Nike is losing momentum.'' 

The company cited higher expenses related to the introduction of new products such as the Air 180 running shoe. Expenses rose to 22.7% of revenue from 19.9%. Revenue in the period rose 39% to $ 802 million. Nike said it plans to continue its ''aggressive'' marketing campaigns.

Nike inventories rose 121% in the period, suggesting sales are slowing dramatically, notes Mike Shea, analyst at Black & Co. Overall orders rose 12%, led by apparel (up 17%) and overseas footwear (up 43%). But domestic shoe orders, which account for more than 60% of sales, were flat. ''That's a red flag,'' Shea says, adding that he recommends selling the stock if you own it.

Meanwhile, the nation's No. 3 athletic-shoe maker, L.A. Gear, had better news. It restructured loan agreements with major lenders. L.A. Gear shares rose 1 to $ 13 1/2. Last month, the Los Angeles-based athletic-shoe maker reported a fourth-quarter loss of 35 cents a share, vs. net income of 58 cents the year before.
 
Thumbs down: Warner-Lambert Inc. shares dipped 1 7/8 to $ 72 1/2 after its Alzheimer's drug, Cognex, failed to win approval from a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee. The FDA said the drug was no more effective than a sugar pill. Alex. Brown & Co. lowered its rating to a sell from neutral. Shearson Lehman Bros. lowered its rating to underperform from outperform.

''The drug was highly touted and an important and major factor in many people's thinking about the fundamental outlook for Warner-Lambert,'' says Alex. Brown analyst Richard Stover. Analysts project that Cognex, if approved, would eventually generate more than $ 500 million in yearly revenue.

Company officials and some analysts insist the drug will get FDA approval by 1993.

- James Kim and Rhonda Richards


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Street Talk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

265 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


May 23, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Operation PUSH hails Thompson appointment


BYLINE: Sal Ruibal


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 226 words


 Nike Inc.'s newest director already has a job assignment.

Monday, Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson was named to Nike's board of directors. Tuesday, he joined the personnel committee, which oversees actions involving Nike employees. Directors are required to serve on a committee.

Last year, Operation PUSH, a Chicago-based civil rights group, alleged that the athletic shoe and apparel company denied blacks adequate employment and business opportunities and called for a boycott of Nike products.

The Rev. Willie Barrow, vice chairman of PUSH's board of directors, says Thompson's appointment is a victory.

''Since we sat down with them, they're now doing many of the things we had on the drawing board,'' he says. ''We've awakened their responsibility to the black community. I congratulate them.''

Not so fast, says Nike spokeswoman Liz Dolan.

''The boycott has not affected us at all by objective measures,'' she says. ''Sales are up dramatically and we have the same level of support from suppliers and retailers.

''(The boycott) has sensitized us to some issues, so now we are much more open about making announcements about what we are doing instead of just quietly doing them.''

Nike directors are paid a fee of $ 10,000 a year and $ 2,000 for every board meeting they attend. Board meetings are held bimonthly.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

268 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


May 11, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION


McColgan sets world best in Nike


BYLINE: Dick Patrick


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 279 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Liz McColgan, who has had more colds than impressive races recently, got well Sunday at the Nike Women's Race. The great Scot broke the world best for 8 kilometers (4.97 miles) by 14 seconds. Her time of 24 minutes, 48 seconds was worth a $ 25,000 bonus from Clairol, plus the $ 5,000 first prize.

Lynn Jennings, who set a world-best 25: 02 here last year, was second (25: 08) and Judi St. Hilaire third (25: 09).

''When I'm on song, it's going to take a very, very special person to beat me,'' said McColgan, who last year won the World Championships 10,000 meters and the New York City Marathon. ''I'm very confident of my ability.''

But McColgan, 28, who has an 18-month-old daughter, was apprehensive on Mother's Day. She was 41st in her last U.S. race, the World Cross Country Championships in March, which Jennings won for the third consecutive time.

McColgan blamed overtraining, which led to a cold and two subsequent illnesses. ''I had something to prove to myself and everyone else,'' she said.

After passing 2 miles in 9: 47 Sunday, she began pulling away from Jennings and eased up at the finish. ''I reckon I could have run 24: 32 if I had run through,'' she said. ''I really wanted a good race to say, 'Hey, I'm back to my old self.' ''

McColgan, who owns a home in Gainesville, Fla., is the favorite for the 10,000 meters at the Olympics. She will run the Cleveland Revco 10K next Sunday and the Advil Mini-Marathon May 30 in New York.

''She's incredible,'' Jennings said. ''She's the best in the world

at keeping up a five-minute (a mile) pace.   It was a terrific

 

experience. It's exactly what Barcelona will be like.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, Porter Binks, USA TODAY; PHOTO; b/w, Porter Binks, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: LIZ MCCOLGAN: Offers Barcelona preview. CUTLINE: LOOK OF A CHAMPION: Liz McColgan's world record in Nike race was worth a $ 25,000 bonus.


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

271 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


May 21, 1991, Tuesday, City Edition


New PBS show will promote reading


SOURCE: New York Times; Associated Press


SECTION: FLORIDIAN; Pg. 7D


LENGTH: 535 words


 

Children's Television Workshop, the educational production company responsible for bringing Sesame Street to public television, has announced that it would begin work on an ambitious new series intended to improve children's reading and writing skills.
 
    The series, called The Ghostwriter, is scheduled to begin on PBS stations in the fall of 1992. The target audience will be children 7 to 10 years old. 
 
    Children's Television Workshop announced the beginning of production after receiving a commitment for a $ 5-million grant from Nike Inc., the maker of athletic shoes. Nana Griller, the assistant director of information at Children's Television Workshop, said the Nike grant was the largest single corporate donation ever made to a children's television show.
 
    The show's overall budget will be $ 20-million for 48 episodes, with about $ 8.8-million coming from PBS and Children's Television Workshop, and the rest from other foundation and government sources.
 
    Richard K. Donahue, president of Nike, said the company would also help promote the project. He said that could mean guest appearances by some of the athletes, including Michael Jordan, Bo Jackson and David Robinson, who have endorsed Nike products.
 
    Nike decided to be the sole corporate backer of the series as part of a larger program aimed at advocating education for inner-city children, Donahue said.
 
    He said the company's commitment in this area had been longstanding and was not related to recent criticism for urging children to buy expensive athletic shoes, a charge he called a "canard."
 
    The executive producer of The Ghostwriter is Elizabeth Nealon, formerly vice president of MTV International.
 
    The show's stylistic approach will incorporate visual and musical techniques borrowed from MTV, Ms. Griller said.
 
    The format will use graphics to make reading the print on screen more entertaining.
 
    The stories will center on six children, three girls and three boys, and their interaction with an unseen ghost who can communicate with them only through writing.
 
    Children's Television Workshop will also publish an accompanying magazine and teachers' materials, as well as computer games using the series' characters.
"China Beach' returning in June for seven weeks
Associated Press

 
   LOS ANGELES The Vietnam War series China Beach will return to temporary active duty next month, network officials announced last week.
 
    The Emmy-winning series was suspended in December, but ABC had promised to air the seven remaining episodes made for the 1990-91 season.
 
    The episodes will air for seven weeks, beginning June 4, in the coveted prime time slot of thirtysomething.
 
    The network move follows a lobbying campaign by executive producer John Sacret Young, who urged thousands of supporters to write protest letters to ABC executives.
 
    The series has been placed on hiatus twice and pushed to new time slots three times during a four-year run on ABC.
 
    The future of China Beach is not yet known. ABC will announce its fall schedule this week.

USA TODAY


August 26, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Nike consultant joins sports marketing firm


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 220 words


Sonny Vaccaro has left Nike Inc., where he worked as a roving basketball consultant, to become chairman of DIC Sports Marketing, a division of DIC Enterprises. The Burbank, Calif. -based company specializes in producing animated TV shows, such as The Real Ghostbusters and Super Mario 3.

During Vaccaro's association with Nike, he helped sign college coaches John Thompson (Georgetown), Jerry Tarkanian (Nevada-Las Vegas), Bobby Cremins (Georgia Tech) and Jim Valvano (N.C. State) to lucrative shoe contracts. Vaccaro produced the Dapper Dan High School All-Star basketball games and helped run Nike's summer basketball/tutoring camps.

There have been allegations of conflict of interest and suggestions that the coaches' association with Vaccaro helped them enroll the best young basketball talent.

Vaccaro told USA TODAY that his new job should put to rest such allegations.

Vaccaro will work on sports- and TV-related projects for DIC, the first of which is the Sept. 17 NBC broadcast of the Comic Relief celebrity special presented in Chicago by Michael Jordan last month. Proceeds from the show are earmarked for charities to aid children and the homeless.

DIC also has been preparing a Saturday morning cartoon featuring
Jordan, Wayne Gretzky and Bo Jackson that is expected to premiere this fall.

TYPE: Sportstalk

The New York Times


August 20, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Nike Ends Deal with Krabbe


BYLINE: AP


SECTION: Section B; Page 14; Column 1; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 134 words


Nike broke off its sponsorship deal with KATRIN KRABBE, the world sprint champion from Germany who is expected to receive a four-year ban after failing a drug test.

The sportswear company also abandoned a similar deal with GRIT BREUER, Krabbe's teammate, who also tested positive for a banned substance. 

Krabbe, the 100- and 200-meter world champion, and Breuer, the 400-meter European champion and world silver medalist, tested positive for Clenbuterol, a muscle-building substance.

Krabbe, in an interview published yesterday by the German magazine, Super Illu, said the athletes did not know that Clenbuterol was on the list of banned drugs.

THOMAS SPRINGSTEIN, coach of the two athletes, has admitted giving the drug to the two sprinters. His contract with Nike has also been canceled.

283 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 22, 1992, Wednesday


BUSINESS REPORT: ON MINORITIES Deion's apparel benched for now


BYLINE: By Shelia M. Poolebusiness; minorities; personalities; advertising; children; appointments


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section D; Page 2


LENGTH: 515 words


Deion Sanders's "Prime Time" line of clothes is being sidelined - for now.

Public relations agent Jerry Davis said Mr. Sanders's multiyear contract with Nike means that the fleet-footed star has to wear Nike apparel and shoes.

"We have to wait and see what Nike decides to do," says Mr. Davis. 

Could it be that Nike wants to introduce a Deion-inspired line of athletic wear of its own?

Mr. Davis won't say, but industry watchers say that they wouldn't be surprised if a Prime Time shoe or warm-up suit is in the works.

Until then, however, people who have Prime Time clothes may consider themselves lucky because no more orders are being taken, said Mr. Davis.

"So whoever has it may have a collector's item," he said.

Even without promoting Prime Time, Mr. Sanders is pretty busy.

His other irons in the fire include:

A recently aired national commercial for Nike.

Possibly franchising the hair salon business he owns with Falcons teammate Jamie Dukes.

A potential deal with NFL Properties for trading cards.

The Falcons offering him an extra $ 1 million to report to training camp early.

And the Braves attempting to sign him for the rest of the season.

L.A. link

It began as computer talk - messages flashed back and forth across an electronic bulletin board during the Los Angeles riots.

Some who participated were content to assign blame for the violence. But Beverly Thomas, a resident of the Crenshaw neighborhood, wasn't. She wanted to dispel some of the stereotypes and help rebuild the affected areas.

"We're going to make change," she typed. "Either come in with us or get out of the way."

Ms. Thomas was surprised by the offers of aid she received.

Today, the 40-year-old computer consultant is helping develop a computerized bulletin board that matches people in the riot-torn area who need help with those willing to give it.

Via her keyboard, Ms. Thomas, whose handle is Kaiju, has lined up about 30 accountants, bankers and entrepreneurs. They've helped about 20 merchants fill out loan applications.

Her work doesn't end there.

Ms. Thomas, who has a master's degree in business from California State University, is also considering formation of an investment pool to capitalize business start-ups.

"I want to see our community stand on its own economically," she said.

Black Chamber

Thinking of starting a new business? A group of Atlanta professionals and entrepreneurs wants to help.

Plans are under way for the Sweet Auburn Black Chamber of Commerce, which would help develop and market black businesses, said Lea O'Neal, a member of the chamber planning committee. She is also president of Black Atlanta Transplants.

One planned chamber component is a six-week program for child entrepreneurs.

The chamber will accept members in the fall.

People . . .

Larry K. Barnhill has been named director of operations for the Gwinnett Civic and Cultural Center, scheduled to open in November. Previously, Mr. Barnhill was director of operations for Pyramid Arena in Memphis, Tenn.

Compiled from staff, news service and published reports.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922060114

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


April 29, 1992, Wednesday


BASEBALL: THE BRAVES Nike knows Deion: Shoe deal in works


BYLINE: By I.J. Rosenberg STAFF WRITERsports; baseball; football; personalities; fashion


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 6


LENGTH: 264 words


Is Deion Sanders the next Bo Jackson?

Nike may think so. With Jackson, the baseball/football star the shoe company currently has under contract, facing an uncertain future because of hip-replacement surgery, Nike is trying to negotiate a multiyear deal with Sanders, the Braves outfielder and Falcons cornerback. 

Both Sanders and his agent, Eugene Parker, acknowledge a deal may be close, but neither will discuss specifics.

Dusty Kidd, the public relations director for Nike Inc., would comment only in general. "It would be dangerous to compare Bo Jackson to any other athlete," he said. "It's sort of like Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen. One is vastly more recognized than the other. Every athlete has their own identity.

"Deion's market has never been tested," he said. "For a while last year I don't think people really thought of him as a two-sport player because he had spent most of his time in the minors in baseball. But the way he has started has changed people's mind s,and people have this romance with players who participate in two sports."

Sanders, asked the range of money a Nike deal might reach, said, "It's more than my football contract." Sanders is coming up on the last year of his four-year deal with the Falcons, which will pay him $ 750,000.

Sanders does not have any major endorsements, but Parker said equipment maker Mizuno, among others, has talked to his client.

Parker also said Nike approached Sanders before the baseball season started, and Sanders's fast start would appear to give him some negotiating leverage with the shoe giant.

The Washington Post


March 10, 1991, Sunday, Final Edition


The Evolution of a Shoe


Bill Brubaker


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A19


LENGTH: 334 words


During the NBA All-Star Game telecast last month, Nike introduced the seventh edition of its best-selling Air Jordan basketball shoe. Nike executives described the evolution of the 1991 Air Jordan during recent interviews at their nine-building, 570,000-square-foot headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.:

" FEBRUARY 1989: Nike designer Tinker Hatfield flew to Chicago for a meeting with Chicago Bulls guard Michael Jordan. They agreed that the '91 shoe would be lighter with a snugger fit. 

" FEBRUARY 1990: Jordan examined drawings of the shoe with Nike executives in Santa Monica, Calif. The shoe was too heavy; Jordan suggested removing some leather from its tip.

" MARCH 1990: A rough prototype Air Jordan was shipped with technical specifications to the Fong Chuan Rubber Enterprise factory in Taiwan. Nike sneakers are manufactured in the Far East because U.S. labor costs are "no longer competitive," company chairman Phil Knight said.

" AUGUST 1990: Production began with materials imported from Germany, Australia, Japan, Argentina and the United States. As many as 150 assembly-line workers were involved in stitching the shoe's perforated leather upper. Each pair took about two days to make.

" NOVEMBER 1990: About 170,000 pairs of sneakers were ready to be shipped. Cost to manufacture, box, crate and deliver one pair of Air Jordans to a port in Taiwan: $ 29.65.

" JANUARY 1991: The shoes arrived in Nike distribution centers in Memphis, Portland, Ore. and Greenland, N.H.

" FEB. 4, 1991: Retail stores received their first shipments. Dealers' cost for each pair: $ 68.75.

" FEB. 10, 1991: Nike introduced its lightest-ever Air Jordan -- a size nine weighs 15 1/2 ounces. A 30-second commercial featured singer Little Richard in the role of a "genie in the lamp" who granted Mars Blackmon (the Spike Lee character) one wish. Did Blackmon want $ 1 million? No. A new car? No. He only wanted a pair of . . . what else?

Nike's suggested retail price for the Air Jordan: $ 125.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: THE SNEAKER PHENOMENON, Part 1 of 2


TYPE: SERIES


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

290 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


January 30, 1992, Thursday, AM


Jordan tells NBA it can't sell clothes bearing his image


BYLINE: (AP)


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. C8


LENGTH: 278 words


DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.


 
   PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - Basketball superstar Michael Jordan, in an unprecedented move, has cost the NBA millions of dollars by forbidding it from selling apparel bearing his image, giving Nike Inc. those rights exclusively. 

Jordan, 28, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first NBA championship last year, is among the most charismatic - and profitable - personalities in the league.

While the NBA no longer may sell Michael Jordan T-shirts, you'll find all the Jordan wear you want at Nike, which already rakes in about $200 million a year on Jordan's image.

The company's Air Jordan basketball shoes, named for Jordan's gravity-defying on-court performance, are among its best sellers.

Jordan has been on the Nike payroll since 1984. He will earn $21.2 million this year for hawking products ranging from Nike shoes to Wheaties cereal to Gatorade sports drink, according to published reports.

Industry sources said Nike, the world's largest marketer of athletic shoes and clothing, persuaded Jordan to end his apparel licensing involvement with the NBA.

"Nike, with Jordan under its wing, is strong-arming the NBA," Jeff Atkinson, editor of Sports Trend magazine in Atlanta, said.

But Nike spokesman Dusty Kidd denied the company had any part in the decision. "It's strictly between Michael and the league," Kidd said.

Seth Sylvan, who manages licensing for the NBA, said the league made $1.1 billion last year from the sale of licensed products. But he downplayed the effect of Jordan's decision.

"We're still in the business of licensing our logos and players," he said.

Souvenirs other than apparel are not affected.


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: MICHAEL JORDANbasketball; advertising


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

USA TODAY


September 9, 1992, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Godzilla meets Barkley on MTV


BYLINE: Martha T. Moore


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 187 words


At least he gets top billing. Godzilla, the Tokyo titan, takes on Charles Barkley, the bull of Barcelona, on tonight's MTV Music Awards. But since the battle is an ad for Nike and the monster is bare-clawed, guess who wins.

''Have you ever thought about wearing shoes?'' Barkley asks after sending the prehistoric predator crashing through skyscrapers.

Though Barkley bests the beast, Nike sees the pair as evenly matched in personality. They're both ''sort of a bad guy but also sort of a sympathetic hero,'' says spokesman Dusty Kidd. While Godzilla lurches around the city, ''Charles has some cartoonlike characteristics, being very outspoken and playing in an exaggerated way.''

Agency Wieden & Kennedy made the ad to run in Japan, but Nike liked it enough to import it. Teaser ads have been running since baseball's All-Star Game in July.

Barkley (6-foot-5, 252 pounds) was animated in an earlier Nike ad, and Godzilla (328 feet, 60,000 tons) has pitched Dr Pepper and Konica, says his agent, Hank Saperstein of UPA Productions. His 19th film, Godzilla vs. Mothra, will open in the USA next spring.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, color
 
CUTLINE: MONSTER MATCH: Guess who wins the 30-second battle?

293 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


January 1, 1991, Tuesday


BUSINESS REPORT: ON ADVERTISING; Mr. Robinson makes amends


BYLINE: By Jeffry Scott Staff writeradvertising; business; personalities; finances


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION F; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 778 words


Ever since Nike miffed some parents this fall with its commercial of "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood" - which featured NBA star David Robinson saying "Can you say kick some butt'?" - the nation's No. 1 athletic shoe company has been making amends. It has been casting Mr. Robinson in less ambiguous, heroic roles.

A month ago, he appeared in a commercial playing piano with a 78- year-old concert pianist. Now Mr. Robinson is being plastered all over America (except Atlanta) on 1,200 public service billboards in 20 markets. He's urging kids to stay in school. 

The billboard shows Mr. Robinson hoisting a stack of books. A basketball sits on top of them. Beside the photo is a huge headline that reads: "Don't Be Stoopid. Stay In School. Nike."

The ads are the lastest in the series of Nike "Stay In School" promotions that the company says are intended to "reach the youth of America in a positive way about achievement and excellence as it relates to both education and athletics." Another ad, featuring another NBA star, Michael Jordan, and actor/director Spike Lee aired over the weekend.

Nike, and other expensive athletic shoe makers, such as Reebok, have stepped up their public service activities in the last year as they've come under pressure by minority and public interest groups concerned about the popularity of the shoes among inner-city youths and resulting crimes.; Hold the ads

The 1960's are considered the Golden Age of Advertising. That's when Americans delighted in watching commercials such as Alka-Seltzer's hall- of-fame "No matter what shape your stomach's in" ads, which featured bouncy music and shots of every shape of human stomach imaginable - from a belly dancer, to a fat guy working a jackhammer, to a woman arguing with a chubby man on the street while poking him in the stomach with a pointed finger.

In those golden days, less than half of America (43 percent) wanted television without commercials, according to a Columbia University study. Thirty years later, the university reports, almost two-thirds of America (67 percent) wants its TV, hold the ads.

"The novelty value of commercials a quarter-century ago kept this percentage (of people who want commercial-free TV) down," reports Video Storyboard Tests Commercial Break newsletter. "But the novelty has all since evaporated and viewer complaints about commercial clutter have progressively grown. Older age groups, in particular, have a higher preference for television without commercials."

Even more disturbing to advertisers, reports the newsletter, more than half of America (54 percent) is willing to pay "a small amount yearly" for TV without commercials, whereas in 1960 less than one in four (24 percent) said they'd pay for commercial-free TV.

The goods news for advertisers: The percentage of people who say they frequently welcome a commercial break (36 percent) has not changed in 30 years; and, while more people want fewer, or no commercials, today more viewers (57 percent, up from 43 percent) believe "some commercials are so good that they are more entertaining than the programs."; Back again

True to the title of his book, "Against Gravity," adman Ed McCabe has quit Miami advertisng agency Beber Silverstein & Partners, and returned to New York, after only eight months on a quest to build the Miami agency into a powerhouse like his first shop, New York agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Mr. McCabe - variously described during his 30- year career as brilliant, cryptic and abusive - said he'd been toying with the idea of leaving Beber for a few months.

"I found myself facing the opportunity to do things my own way, and I had to take it," he told Adweek magazine.

The magazine reports most of Miami's advertising community won't miss him, because it wasn't terribly bowled over by McCabe in the first place. Though he's the youngest copywriter ever to be installed in the Advertising Hall of Fame (at age 35), he wasn't the rain maker he was expected to be. "The copywriter produced only a few scattered showers," the magazine reports.

Mr. McCabe, who could not be reached for comment, is opening his own New York shop, McCabe & Co., and reportedly is pursuing the $ 40-million Volvo account which his first agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves, was forced to resign last month over a faked commercial scandal that rocked the industry.; Quickly

Jim Osterman has been named the new editor of Adweek magazine's Southeastern edition, replacing Martha Nolan, who left to pursue freelance writing. Mr. Osterman joined the magazine in 1984 as a reporter and rose to managing editor in 1988.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photo: mug of David Robinson


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

297 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 31, 1992, Friday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS Olympic sidelines News and notes from around the Games Nike: Wearing Reebok OK


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 4


LENGTH: 318 words


Liz Dolan, Nike's vice president of corporate communications, says five minutes on the medal stand won't make anyone think Michael Jordan or any other Nike clients represent Reebok.

"You'd have to have been living in a cave to think that," said Ms. Dolan. "In Michael's case, he'd wear [the official uniform] for five minutes; he'll wear our shoes his entire career. There's no risk that anyone will think he's affiliated with anyone but Nike." 

That's why, Ms. Dolan said, Nike is encouraging all of its Olympic medal-winners to wear the official medal-ceremony uniform, which is a Reebok product. Reebok's contract is believed to be worth about $ 4 million.

Jordan has said "there is no way in the world I am wearing a suit that's made by Reebok," but he also has hedged slightly, saying he'll decide "when the time comes." USA press chief Mike Moran has said that any medal winner who does not comply will not be permitted on the awards stand, and that no athlete ever has refused to wear the official uniform. In the previous two Olympics, Levi Strauss held the contract.

The Dream Team's Nike clients also include David Robinson, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and assistant coach P.J. Carlesimo.

Albania's swim 'team' Frank Lescas was thrilled about his far-fetched journey from Pennsylvania to Albania as that country's entire Olympic swimming team. Until he saw the practice pool. There was no water in it. "People sometimes don't have running water in the house," he said. "How can I expect them to put gallons and gallons of water in a 50-meter pool?" Lescas, a sprinter from suburban Philadelphia who never had been in Albania, will be a 21-year- old senior at La Salle in September. He wasn't good enough to make the U.S. team. Lescas continued his swim training at home, then arrived in Albania on July 10 in preparation for his trip to Barcelona.


LOAD-DATE: August 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922190248


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution
