COURIER-MAIL


June 1, 1991 Saturday


SNEAKERS CAUGHT IN THE RIPPLES


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: AAPINTNEWS


LENGTH: 154 words


Sneakers caught in the ripples NEW YORK: Beachcombers along Oregon's north coast are finding new treasures from the sea _ hundreds of Nike sport shoes washing ashore a year after a cargo ship mishap. Since April 2, Burke and Lisa Pond have found more than 140 Nike shoes on beaches between the mouth of the Columbia River and Gearhart. Steve McLoed, who until recently had never owned a Nike shoe, now boasts about 70. Shirley Tarnasky has found 50 Nikes near her oceanfront home in Rockaway Beach. But the shoes are not coming ashore in pairs, prompting Tarnasky to form the Sneaker Society to promote sneaker swaps at which people can trade to create matching pairs. Nike transportation manager Rich Hastings said yesterday that the shoes were from five boxcar-size containers that fell from a Seattle-bound cargo ship in the Pacific Ocean in May last year. About 40,000 pairs of Nikes were lost. Associated Press


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: CML


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

301 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Business Times (Singapore)


Made in the USA lobby running after Nike


November 5, 1992


Foundation launching nasty ad drive to shame major companies into bringing manufacturing back to US

THE Made in the USA foundation is launching a nasty ad campaign against major US companies that manufacture products overseas -and Nike is the first target.

The foundation has scrapped its original plan for more than US$ 50 million (S$ 81 million) "Buy American" campaign and instead will try to shame major marketers, such as Nike, into bringing some of their manufacturing back home.

According to the trade magazine Advertising Age, the non-profit lobbying group has US$ 1 million set aside for the Nike effort and plans to break the ads in 20 major market daily newspapers soon, as well as in union publications.

Several papers have been approached, but the media buy has not been made. 

Made in USA had been encountering "some resistance" from newspapers in running the ad, said chairman Joel D Joseph. However, he declined to name the newspapers.

"We presume they are refusing because Nike is a big advertiser," he said.

The ads urge consumers to send their "old dirty, smelly, worn-out Nikes" to chairman Philip Knight to "send Nike a message" to "come back home to the United States and start making shoes here once again".

Oregon-based Nike both sources and manufactures components of its shoes in the US but final assembly is generally done in the Far East.

The ad, which was created in-house, urges consumers to tell Mr Knight they will not buy another pair of Nikes until the company commits itself to building a US manufacturing plant.

The anti-Nike ad follows an Oct 1 letter to Mr Knight from Mr Joseph, who asked Nike to manufacture its top-of-the-line shoes in the US, since Mr Joseph contends they can be made here profitably. Nike said it had no apologies for its manufacturing practices.

"We are the No. 1 company in the business so we're willing to take the shot," said Dusty Kidd, public relations manager at Nike. "We would hope that those who criticise us would be better informed."

Mr Kidd said 1,200 of Nike's US workforce of 6,500 people were involved in manufacturing. "We have more manufacturing workers in the US than any other athletic footwear company," he said. Nike said it did not directly employ any workers in the Far East but employed contractors there that undertook the manufacturing.

"Any factory we use is required to meet their government's standards for minimum wage," Mr Kidd said. He added that it was unlikely that Nike would start any counter-advertising.

Explaining why Made in the USA was going for this "take your gloves off" approach instead of a general "Buy American" effort, Mr Joseph said: "I think we can get more results and more (news) coverage.

"We're going for impact."

He refused to name other marketers which the group plans to target. "We are promoting buy American, but we also are taking our gloves off and going after companies that we think are responsible for the trade deficit," he said.

In a news release, Made in the USA also noted that in the 1980s, more than 65,000 US footwear workers lost their jobs when Nike and other shoe manufacturers moved manufacturing to Indonesia where the workers are paid 14 US cents an hour.

It cited a press report which said it costs Nike US$ 5.95 to make a pair of Nike Crosstrainers in Indonesia while these shoes retail from US$ 44.95 to US$ 124.99 in the US.

"We go where we can make the best product at the best price. If we made Air Jordans in the US they would (sell for) US$ 300," Nike's Mr Kidd said.


SECTION: Advertising & Marketing 1; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 1080 words


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Business Publications

 

303 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Jet


November 2, 1992


Chicago Schools Troubled, Jordan And Nike To Rescue


SECTION: NATIONAL REPORT; Pg. 10


LENGTH: 224 words


Basketball magnate Michael Jordan and Nike Inc. recently, stepped to the rescue of Chicago Public Schools with checks totaling $ 200,000.

Emblazoned on the sides of giant tennis shoes, the checks were presented to Chicago Public Schools Superintendent Ted D. Kimbrough at a press conference given by Jordan and Nike Inc. 

Chicago school officials had announced in August that the budget wouldn't allow for the extracurricular activities, and entire programs, including athletics, would be wiped out.

The basketball hero and Nike President Richard Donahue revealed at the press conference that each would contributes $ 100,000, helping to save not only athletics, but other activities, including the chess and debate teams. "We feel very dedicated to the school system here in Chicago, and to the kids so that they have something to hold on to, and hopefully, some motivation in their lives," Jordan said.

Other contributors also came to the rescue when Kimbrough sent out a call to corporations and athletes. "We have collected, including the two $ 100,000 shoes, $ 915,000," Kimbrough announced at the press conference. "We still have a goal of $ 1.2 million."

Jordan indicated that his benevolence isn't shortsighted. "If next year is not what it's supposed to be, we're going to be there to try to support it," Jordan said.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Picture, Jordan greets fan 4-year-old Jawaan Walker after announcing his and Nike's contribution to Chicago Public Schools, as Superintendent Ted D. Kimbrough holds shoes bearing the $ 100,000 checks.


Copyright 1992 Johnson Publishing Company, Inc.

 

305 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


April 3, 1992, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Adidas shoe-to-shoe with Nike at NCAA


BYLINE: Gary Strauss


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 179 words


When it comes to marketing, adidas is the David of the athletic-shoe industry. But it's challenging Goliath Nike on equal footing in the NCAA basketball Final Four. 

Adidas will spend just $ 23 million on U.S. marketing this year. It isn't even buying any TV ad time for Saturday's semifinal games or Monday's championship. While the West German firm supplied just three of 64 Division I NCAA playoff teams, two - Duke and Indiana - still remain.

''This is absolutely perfect,'' says adidas USA president Peter Pirner. ''We only have a slingshot, but it's aimed well.''

Nike will spend $ 150 million on marketing this year - including tourney TV ads. It also supplied shoes to 29 playoff teams. Michigan and Cincinnati remain.

No matter what happens Saturday, a Nike and adidas-backed team will face off in the championship - with an expected viewership of nearly 70 million. So while ads can cost up to $ 300,000, adidas is getting off cheap.

''This is great exposure value,'' says Joyce Julius Cotman of sports- marketing consultant Joyce Julius and Associates.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

308 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


August 13, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Summer camp costly for Texas players


BYLINE: Maurice Patton


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 14C


LENGTH: 420 words


Bobby Crawford of Houston Dwight D. Eisenhower High and Marcus Thomas of Houston MacArthur face four-game suspensions this season for attending the summer Nike/All-American Academic Camp.

Marcus Mitchell of Houston Langham Creek is eligible to play the entire season, though he participated in the camp last month in Indianapolis.

All three are among 11 Texas players who competed for the Houston STAND (Students Taking Action Not Drugs) basketball team organized by former Houston Rocket John Lucas and partner Jay Parker for a series of summer tournaments, including the Nike event. 

''I don't understand how you have a right to keep a kid from going outside the state to showcase his skills,'' said Lucas.

The University Interscholastic League, which governs Texas public high school athletics, has a rule making it illegal for a student-athlete to attend invitation-only camps.

''It's not really a camp. Only two hours a day are spent on basketball,'' said Bob Gibbons, Nike's selection committee chairman. ''This is really an academic program. It would be great to open it to 5,000 kids, but that's not feasible.''

Only 125 student-athletes are admitted to the five-day event.

UIL athletic director Bill Farney said such ''invitation- only'' camps exploit players and don't give borderline players a chance to go.

''Does Nike accept anybody that wants to come to that camp, on a first- come, first-serve basis?'' said Farney. ''The answer to that question would be an indication as to whether it is an invitational camp.

''We're not branding all invitational camps as bad. But when you have a regulation passed by the schools, unless it's changed by the same procedure, it has to be enforced.''

Farney has left the executive committees in each district to determine the eligibility of the players in question. Harris County District Court Judge Sharolyn Wood ruled in June that participation would not be in violation of UIL rules as long as ''no financial aid, prize, gift, or thing with monetary value is given to and/or received.''

Crawford and Thomas are considering legal action against the UIL.

Seven other players are waiting for rulings from five district executive committees. The remaining player, Marvin Hill, attends Houston St. Pius, a member of the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, and is not affected by the UIL decisions.

''It's so unfair that these other kids are being penalized because they attend public schools,'' said Susan Gunnewig, Hill's guardian.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w, Patty Wood
 
CUTLINE: JOHN LUCAS: Organized Houston anti-drug team.


HIGH SCHOOLS


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

311 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 5, 1991, Tuesday


Nike nerd takes to the air, Jordan-style


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION B; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 144 words


Michael Jordan: Nerd. An unheard-of association - until this year's National Basketball Association All-Star Game on Sunday.

That's when shoe maker Nike breaks its newest commercial, featuring the high-flying maestro of the NBA airwaves, Mr. Jordan, dressed as Mars Blackmon, the nerdy character played by Spike Lee in previous Jordan/Nike ad campaigns. 

In the commercial, a genie (played by '50s rocker Little Richard) grants Mars Blackmon (Mr. Lee) one wish. That wish, naturally, is to soar like Mr. Jordan and - every flatfoot's dream - slam-dunk a basketball.

"Look, Mom, I can fly," says Mr. Jordan, the Mars Blackmon look- alike as he sails through the air.

The commercial launches the sixth generation of Air Jordan tennis shoes, which Nike premieres on the air - and Mr. Jordan premieres on his feet - each year at the All-Star Game.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jordan (left) helps make a wish come true for Spike Lee's character Mars Blackmon (right) in Nike's new ads.


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

313 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


January 17, 1991, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


CURRENTS;
Just Like Going to The Movies


BYLINE: By Patricia Leigh Brown


SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Home Desk


LENGTH: 286 words


AS every red-blooded American knows, some of the most memorable design imagery over the past decade has been lavished not on buildings, but on athletic shoes.

Now Nike , the sports and fitness company that has brought forth Air Jordans and "Just Do It," has created Nike Town, a 12,000-square-foot store in downtown Portland, Ore. The new store, which will soon be replicated elsewhere, may do for fitness merchandising what the Ralph Lauren stores did for home design.

Nike Town is modeled after a town square surrounded by freestanding pavilions.

"Did you see the movie 'Back to the Future'?" asked Gordon Thompson, Nike's creative director. "We thought the town square would be a great idea for Nike Town." If it smacks of Disney's Main Street, that too, is part of the point.

"We've tried to combine the merchandising concepts of Ralph Lauren, the fun of Disneyland, the exhibitry of the Smithsonian and the atmosphere of F.A.O Schwarz," he said.

The store, which opened in late November, uses video screens as major design elements. Like the Lauren stores, it is a total environment. In the Aqua Gear pavilion, where waterproof gear is sold, shoes and socks are mounted in front of an aquarium. Product colors are coordinated with those of the fish.

Customers try on socks around a "video pond," above, composed of nine floor monitors, which substitutes video images of sharks and other creatures for water.

Such achingly hip design, which includes an Air Jordan penthouse, signals a new approach to marketing by Nike, which plans to open a similar store in New York next year.

"People want to be entertained while shopping," Mr. Thompson said. "This is like a movie for people to go and see."


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

 

316 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Business Times (Singapore)


Nike wants more women to "just do it'


October 8, 1992


Sylvia Wong


 Nike plans to tap the women's market in a big way. Sylvia Wong reports

FROM next year, women can look forward to a new range of Nike sports accessories fashioned just for them.

Ironically, they have Reebok, Nike's arch-rival, to thank for this. Reebok's colourful and fashionable sports shoes, which took the world by storm in 1985, have made Nike see that women want sports goods not just for sports but also as fashion accessories. 

So, the company -which exhorts couch potatoes and athletes alike to "Just Do It" -is launching a new range of shoes, tights, leotards, swimming costumes and other accessories. The range is aimed at women who are likely to buy totally coordinated outfits.

John Chew, managing director of Nike Singapore Pte Ltd, said the firm had to make its women's shoes less chunky and more colourful to match Reebok's appeal.

Because women were less inclined to shop at sports outlets, Nike would set up women's corners in department stores, Mr Chew said. The company would open 10 such corners in Orchard Road department stores next year.

He said the women's market, which now accounts for only 12 per cent of Nike's turnover in Singapore, was expected to double next year after the new range comes out. But he declined to disclose Nike's total turnover for Singapore.

While women customers are getting more attention now, Nike's largest customer base remains the men and "authentic athletes". Its best-selling shoes are those in its running range, followed by cross trainers, basketball and tennis shoes.

Mr Chew said running shoes accounted for as much as 30 per cent of local turnover. Among Nike's most popular models are the Huarache, Air Max and Pegasus models. The company will bring in an improved version of its Air Max model next year. The Air Max Plus will have an air cushion all around the sole of the shoe and will retail at slightly more than $ 200 a pair.

Oregon-based Nike Inc reckons it has the largest share of the global sporting goods market. For the year ended Nov 30, 1991, it said worldwide sales jumped 20 per cent from the previous year to US$ 3.2 billion (S$ 5.1 billion).

Reebok International, its closest competitor, chalked up sales of US$ 2.7 billion for the same period while German brand Adidas was third with worldwide sales of about US$ 2.1 billion.

Nike's latest results show that for the quarter ended Aug 31, the company earned US$ 122.5 million, while sales grew 16 per cent to US$ 1.09 billion compared with US$ 947 million in the same period last year.

In Singapore, turnover has doubled in the past two years since Nike set up its wholly-owned subsidiary, Nike Singapore, to handle its own marketing and distribution. Before this, Nike was distributed by Robertson Wilson.

Mr Chew said the advantage of Nike's local agency was that it could focus its energies on selling only Nike products. Having a wholly-owned local agency also enabled Nike to carry out unique marketing strategies like its "Ekins" (Nike spelled backwards) programme.

The local company employed three Ekins, whose job is to go round to sports clubs, corporations, schools and uniformed groups to advise people on how to buy Nike shoes.

"Consumers usually buy on the basis of colour but Ekins try to educate them that they should buy shoes suited to their feet. For example, people with flat feet, high arched feet or normal arched feet require different shoes," Mr Chew said.

Nike also took over the display of its products in the shops of its 100 dealers in Singapore. The local company provided display stands and signs to shops to control the image of its products.

Mr Chew said that in Singapore it was a close fight between Nike and Reebok for the market leader position. Last year, Nike spent $ 1 million advertising its well known tag-lines like "There is no finish line" and "Just Do It" to match Reebok's "The Physics Behind the Physique". Nike's ad spending would rise by up to 20 per cent this year, Mr Chew said.

The company has already lined up a series of new ads from the US, which will be screened soon.


SECTION: Advertising & Marketing 1; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 1240 words


LOAD-DATE: October 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Who says women are the weaker sex?; Nike Singapore MD John Chew: the firm is launching a new range of sport accessories for women

318 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 6, 1991, Saturday


SPORTS BUSINESS: DAVID DAVIDSON; Super Show saves Nike $ 4 million Chicago trip


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION D; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 718 words


When the National Sporting Goods Association's World Sports Expo opens a four-day run in Chicago July 15, Nike will be conspicuous by its absence - and Atlanta's annual Super Show is the primary reason.

"We figured we were seeing 95 percent of the same people we'd already seen at the Super Show," said Mikal Peveto, Nike's marketing manager/running apparel, in Atlanta this week for the Peachtree Road Race. "We looked at the cost - we were spending $ 4 million in Chicago - and decided to put that back into the retail segment."

Instead, that money will be spent on flying representatives of Nike's top 100 accounts to its home office in Portland for an annual sales message, new product displays and other programs aimed at the retail market. 

Nike will get plenty of exposure from a recently completed agreement with The Athletics Congress (TAC) in which the company will provide uniforms for the U.S. teams participating in the Pan American Games in Cuba, the World Track and Field Championships in Tokyo and the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona.

According to Peveto, the company will supply shoes and apparel to TAC, but not money.

"We will supply radical, bold uniforms, but uniforms that at the same time will be respectful of the games and the country," Peveto said. "Nike's philosophy is to push the envelope, so the public will see a bold interpretation of our nation's colors. It will be like pro tennis star) Andre Agassi, an attitude. The uniforms will make a statement. The attitude will be aggressive on race day. That fits the attitude of the United States. It's an aggressive, daring, prideful country and our uniforms will reflect that."

FOOT PATROL: While running the Peachtree 10K course last Sunday, Peveto occupied his mind by conducting an informal shoe count. In one hour, he counted more than 1,200 runners wearing Nike shoes (53 percent of his total; Nike's market share is 51 percent). By Peveto's count, 18 percent of the runners wore Asics shoes, exactly that company's share. . . . Stan Clark, Nike's Southeast footwear specialist, says his company would like to increase its visibility during the Peachtree Road Race and will approach the Atlanta Track Club about increasing the size of its sponsorship. . . . According to Linda Hannon, this year's Peachtree Road Race Expo - moved from Colony Square to the Swissotel at Lenox Square along with race headquarters - was the biggest ever with more than 60 exhibitors. "This Expo is for Jane and John Runner,' and we hope they enjoy it," said Hannon, who coordinates the Expo. "We decided Buckhead was a more convenient location for the runners. Lenox Square definitely is the place to be on July 4 in Atlanta." . . . Athletics director Homer Rice has promoted and retitled several members of his staff at Georgia Tech, including Bernie McGregor (chief administrative officer), Kevin Bryant (assistant A.D./marketing) and Mike Finn (assistant A.D./communications). Jim Murphy will continue as chief financial officer. The changes will provide more authority for those working under Rice, who then will be able to devote more time to fund-raising and Tech's  role in the 1996 Olympics.

ASTRO-NOMICAL PRICE: John McMullen, owner of the Houston Astros, is trying to sell his team for $ 95 million, although a recent report in Financial World magazine assessed the club's value at $ 92 million. Among a group negotiating to buy the team is Charles Duncan, former president of Coca-Cola. . . . South Carolina will host its third annual International Conference on Sports Business April 1-4 next year, according to Jerry Kissel, a professor in the university's school of athletics administration. . . . Atlanta World Cup officials will narrow a list of four sites - the World Congress Center, Inforum, the International Trade and Convention Center and the old Sears building - as prospective locations for the 1994 soccer games' media center and international broadcast center. "Hosting these centers would help solidify Atlanta as a communications and technology hub," said Atlanta World Cup chairman Lewis Holland. "It offers us a continuing business opportunity with long-lasting benefits." Chicago, Dallas, Denver and Phoenix are the other finalists for the centers.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

320 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


September 6, 1992, SUNDAY, LATE FIVE STAR Edition


NIKE STEPS IN, REPLACES HOGAN TOUR


BYLINE: Bob Pastin Post-Dispatch Executive Sports Editor


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 7D


LENGTH: 1058 words


 

Nike Inc., the world's largest footwear and sports apparel company, boldly stepped forward last week and bailed out the flagging Ben Hogan Tour when it signed a multiyear partnership with the PGA Tour. Nike thus assumes sponsorship of pro golf's premier satellite tour. In doing so, Nike in effect allowed the financially struggling Ben Hogan Co. off the hook. Last year the Hogan Co. asked the PGA Tour to be released from its sponsorship, and it appeared for a time that pro golf might lose the closest thing it had to a feeder system. The Nike Tour will commence in 1993 and will be structured almost identically to the Hogan Tour with a 30-tournament schedule of $100,000 to $200,000 tournaments. The Hogan Co., based in Fort Worth, Texas, was part of the Minoru Isutani conglomerate (which also included the Pebble Beach Co.). The conglomerate crumbled earlier this year. Last spring the Hogan Co. became part of the AMF Cos. Since 1990, the Hogan Co. had committed $3.5 million annually to the Hogan Tour but found it increasingly difficult to keep up the payments in light of its parent company's travails. The PGA Tour courted potential sponsors. It had been rumored that Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola and Buick were interested, but nothing materialized. Nike stepped in at the last moment with what was reported to be a major financial commitment. The Nike Tour figures to prosper indefinitely in this new arrangement. Whereas the Hogan Co. suffered losses last year reported to be $30 million, Nike boasted revenue of $3.4 billion for its most recent fiscal year. Nike got its first exposure to golf in 1983 in the form of golf shoes. Since then, it has increased its exposure through affiliations with several PGA Tour players. Now it figures to reap enormous benefits on the advertising and marketing fronts. The 1992 Hogan Tour will generate approximately $4.3 million in prize money, which represents a 41 percent increase over 1990. Naturally, PGA Tour Commissioner Deane Beman is delighted with the new affiliation. ''Nike's commitment ensures (this tour) will remain a vital part of the PGA Tour for years to come,'' he said. Chip Shots: Entry deadline for the inaugural Missouri Handicap Championship is Sept. 16. The tournament is Sept. 24-27 at Highland Springs CC in Springfield. The event is open to all golfers with a USGA handicap index of 40.4 or below. The field is limited to the first 150 entries. The field will be split into four flights. Flight winners will be determined by the 36-hole cumulative net score. Entry forms are available at all Missouri Golf Association courses. Entry fee is $85. For information, call the MGA at (314) 636-8994. A practice round is Sept. 24 with the first round Sept. 25, second round Sept. 26 and final round Sept. 27. All play is stroke play. KASP Sports 1380 AM offers a ''Fairways and Greens Winter Golf Getaway'' Dec. 9-13, which will feature rounds of golf at the Dunes, Citrus, PGA West Stadium and Mission Hills. The hosts will be Jay Randolph Jr., Jeff Smith and Jim Sheehan of KASP's ''Fairways and Greens'' show. Cost per person is $1, 500. To register, send a $300 deposit (made out to KASP Golf Classic) with your name, address, phone number and handicap to: KASP Golf Classic, 2360 Hampton Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63139. Balance of payment is due by Nov. 1. The getaway also includes lodging, round-trip airfare to Palm Springs, Calif., cocktail party upon arrival, breakfast and cocktail party daily, awards dinner and prizes. The PGA Grand Slam of Golf, featuring 1992's four major-tournament champions, will be held Nov. 10-11 at the Kauai Lagoons Resort in Hawaii. Masters champion Fred Couples, U.S. Open champion Tom Kite, British Open champion Nick Faldo and PGA champion Nick Price will compete for a $1 million purse in the 36-hole event on Kauai's Kiele Course. Ian Woosnam, the 1991 Masters champion, won last year's competition. Richard Jarrett, Scott Edwards, Ed Schwent, who won the recent St. Louis District Championship, and Derre Ousley, who won the recent Metropolitan Championship, posted the top scores at Wednesday's USGA Mid-Amateur qualifying at Country Club at the Legends in Eureka and advance to the national Mid-Amateur Sept. 19-24 in Detroit. Jarrett took medalist honors with a par 72. Edwards, Schwent and Ousley posted 74s. Jim Plummer of Lake Saint Louis won the Missouri Golf Association's Senior Tournament at Highland Springs CC in Springfield. In the U.S. Amateur at Muirfield Village in Dublin, Ohio, Don Bliss was the only Missourian to make the cut. He was tied with six other players at 148 after two rounds of stroke play. Justin Leonard, a junior at the University of Texas, won the championship 8 and 7 over Thomas Scherrer. Coming Right Up: SUNDAY - District finals of the Chrysler National Long Driving Championships at Creve Coeur Recreation Complex, one of 15 district sites nationwide. Two players from the 26-person field will qualify for the finals in Boca Raton, Fla., Oct. 3-4. Each competitor will drive six balls that must land within a 40-yard-wide surveyed grid. TUESDAY - The Blues March of Dimes Celebrity Classic at Norwood Hills Country Club. The noon scramble will be preceded by a putting contest and buffet lunch and followed by an auction and awards banquet with comedian George Lopez the emcee. For information, call 993-6670. TUESDAY - USGA Senior Amateur qualifying at Greenbriar Hills CC. FRIDAY - Florissant Valley Jaycees tournament at Paddock Country Club. Pre-tournament festivities begin at 10:15 a.m. with golf at 11 a.m. Proceeds go to Marygrove (abused and neglected children). Entry fee is $75. For information, call 837-9999 or 837-2200. FRIDAY - Columbia Golf Tournament, Columbia, Ill., with proceeds to the Missouri and Southern Illinois perinatal program at Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital. Entry fee is $275. Format is threesome scramble. Starts at 11:30 a.m. Call 577-5605. Also on tap: Sept. 12-13 - Jim Jackson Memorial, Algonquin. Sept. 24-27 - Missouri Handicap Championship, Highland Springs (Springfield). Sept. 25 - Blue Choice Gateway PGA Pro-Am, Bogey Hills. Sept. 27 - Blue Choice Gateway PGA Shootout, Bogey Hills. Some of the information in this column came from wire services and other sportswriters around the country.


LOAD-DATE: October 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

322 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


June 10, 1991, Monday, Final Edition


Inventor, Nike To Go 1-on-1 ;
Va. Man Sues, Claims Air Jordan Idea Is His


Robert F. Howe, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: METRO; PAGE D1


LENGTH: 893 words


While the Chicago Bulls' Michael Jordan tries to blow the Los Angeles Lakers off the basketball court in the NBA finals, an Arlington inventor is putting on a full-court press against one of Jordan's biggest backers, Nike Inc.

Charles Petrosky, a 73-year-old inventor who works out of a cluttered shop in his basement, claims in a federal suit in Alexandria that the manufacturing giant swiped his invention when it marketed the Air Jordan sneaker, named after the Bulls' star guard.

"There's no doubt Nike knew about Mr. Petrosky and his idea for an air cushion sole before the introduction of the Air Max and the Air Jordan," said Joel M. Freed, Petrosky's attorney. Freed said his client patented an air cushion sole in 1978 and tried to sell the idea to Nike long before it first marketed the Air Jordan in the 1980s. 

The suit has been compared by attorneys on both sides to the case of a former Maryland man who accused several carmakers of stealing his idea for an intermittent windshield wiper now used on millions of vehicles. The Ford Motor Co. agreed to pay inventor Robert W. Kearns $ 10.2 million in that suit.

Petrosky's suit, which is not expected to come to trial until the fall, seeks what could amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars in royalties and penalties. Nike said it has sold millions of pairs of Air Jordans at a retail price of more than $ 100 a pair.

Nike's representatives said its Air Jordan and Air Max shoes bear little resemblance to the air cushion sole patented by Petrosky.

"If you look at his proposed system and you look at Nike's, no one would say they are the same," said Leslie A. Nicholson, one of Nike's attorneys. "More importantly, they work very differently."

Nicholson also said that Petrosky's invention "is remarkably similar" to an air cushion sole patented in the early 1900s and that the suit may raise the question of whether Petrosky's shoe should have been awarded a patent.

Petrosky's sole has several chambers that are connected by tiny holes. The chambers are filled using the kind of air pump and needle used to inflate basketballs. Nike's air cushions are sealed plastic bladders that are inserted into the sole of the shoe.

The theory behind each is that when the wearer walks heel to toe, the cushions redistribute the air so that the contours always provide support and a comfortable fit.

Nike representative Lindsay D. Stewart conceded that "the little guy-big guy phenomenon" is a factor in the Petrosky case and that a jury might hold more sympathy for the "basement shop-style" inventor.

Petrosky, who was hospitalized recently for infections in his cardiovascular system, said he was eager to return to his beloved basement workshop on North Jefferson Street. Though he was given last rites recently, he has improved, and doctors have given him a favorable prognosis.

"When I get to feeling better, I'm going to get back at it," Petrosky said from his bed in Arlington Hospital. He said he continues to have new ideas and yearns for the days when he would "get up at 2 o'clock in the morning and go down to the basement and tinker around."

Petrosky's tinkering dates to the late 1940s, when he was discharged from the Army after World War II and he and a friend opened a barbershop in the Ballston area.

He dreamed up a razor strop that was mounted on a support beam so the barber could sharpen his straight razor without having to use two hands. Charles T. Petrosky, the inventor's 38-year-old son, said his father failed to patent the gadget and was angry when he later saw a mounted strop advertised in a trade journal.

"It was the fish that got away," the inventor's son said.

From then on -- especially when the elder Petrosky retired from cutting hair in 1975 -- the inventor was far more mindful of patenting his ideas. He was awarded nine patents over the years, including one for a ring with a small blade attached that could be used in self-defense and another for a system designed to rid cities of rats.

Petrosky's son said his father invented the ring because he was concerned about increasing urban violence and assaults against women. "If a woman slapped someone across the face with the ring on, it would scratch them -- mark them -- so that police could identify them easier," he said.

The "classic better rat trap" sat on the bed of a truck and used bait to lure rats out of alleys, up a ramp and into a chamber where they could not escape. "All the man would have to do is drop by in the morning and pick up the truck," Petrosky's son said. While the truck was being driven away, the rats would be killed by fumes pumped into the chamber from the truck's exhaust, he said.

Neither invention captured consumers' imaginations, and though a few rings were manufactured, none was ever sold, Petrosky's son said.

"I just never got off the ground in marketing," the elder Petrosky said.

Freed refused to let the Petroskys discuss the inspiration for the air cushion sole because of the lawsuit. But a 1978 newspaper article said Petrosky had pinned his hopes for fame and fortune on what he described as a "walking-on-air" shoe.

"You take a common football needle and hand air pump, and just pump away," he told the now-defunct Washington Star. "A gunky substance inside seals it when you remove the needle. It's a million-dollar idea."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: VIRGINIA NEWS


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

325 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


January 22, 1992, Wednesday, 1* EDITION


COLUMN ONE


BYLINE: CLIVE MOSTYN; VANSUN


SECTION: FEATURES; COLUMN ONE; Pg. C1


LENGTH: 426 words


 

IN Swoosh: The Unauthorized Story of Nike and the Men Who Played There, authors J.B. Strasser and Laurie Becklund say the Fortune 500 running-shoe company started by Philip Knight seemed destined to fail in the early days. Among the gaffes:

* Nike's Japanese manufacturer once proudly offered a discus-thrower's shoe called the Throw-Up.

* When some prescient staffer signed Bo Jackson in 1986 to

hustle Nike products, Jackson was playing minor-league baseball for the Memphis Chicks. Knight demanded to know who signed the guy so the idiot could be fired. 

* The authors describe executive retreats, known as "Buttfaces," enlivened by drinking marathons. And at Nike's first national sales conference, a rep from Texas did a brisk business selling marijuana pipes to colleagues.

* When Nike decided to establish a new manufacturer in Korea, a company exec flew to Seoul and asked the desk clerk at his hotel, "Where can I find some shoe

factories?"

* And then there's the story about a Taiwanese business trip Knight and a colleague named Gorman made. At a toast-filled banquet, Knight, an old Asia hand, matched his hosts drink for drink. Gorman gave up and tossed his drinks under the table, where they splattered on Knight's pant leg. When the totally blotto Knight realized what Gorman had done, he knocked him down a flight of stairs. Then he vomited and lost a contact lens in the mess.

GYPSY STYLINGS

Hankering for some old-

fashioned gypsy string music? Try Gypsalero at the Glass Slipper, tonight at 9.

The acoustic Vancouver quartet draws on influences ranging from Django Reinhardt to John McLaughlin and embraces the styles of samba, swing, classical, czardas and tangos.

TRULY, MADLY, DEEPLY, AGAIN

Julia Roberts isn't the only one who found consolation in the arms of another after the big wedding that wasn't last summer.

Her ex, Kiefer Sutherland has fallen for aspiring actress Lisa Stothard. Since their first dinner date last fall, the two have been inseparable - together nearly every day, including Thanksgiving at his home in Montana and Christmas with her folks in Wisconsin.

For their two-week anniversary, he rented an ice rink, packed a picnic and took her skating. Not long after, she moved in.

She's swooning. He's smiling. And word is they're looking at real estate in Los Angeles - together.

HI HONEY,

I'M HOME

I gave her little hints, and let her guess the rest.

- a man on The Oprah Winfrey Show describing how he revealed to his wife that he had been a male prostitute.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

326 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 24, 1992, Friday, INTERNATIONAL EDITION


IOC BOARD


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 376 words


American Anita Defrantz was elected onto the International Olympic Committee's executive board on Thursday to replace Robert Helmick, the former U.S. sports chief who resigned in a corruption scandal.

Defrantz, who won a rowing bronze medal at the 1976 Montreal Games, was one of three IOC members elected to the 11-member board on the final day of the 99th IOC Session.

The other two were Canadian Dick Pound and India's Ashwini Kumar, both former IOC vice-presidents. 
 
 SPANISH NATIONALISM: The mayor of Barcelona has appealed to citizens not to rock the boat during the Olympics as controversy rumbles on over Catalan nationalism at the Games. In an appeal read on the Catalan channel of Spanish television and published Thursday in newspapers, Mayor Pasqual Maragall declared:

''We were chosen to organize the Games but they don't belong to us. They belong to all mankind.''

The two million people of Barcelona, Spain's second city and the capital of its nationalist Catalonia region, had a duty to show the ''maximum of composure, civility and naturalness'' in their behaviour.

The appeal by Maragall, who is also president of the Barcelona organizing committee COOB, follows a bitter row over the extent to which the biggest Olympics in history should be seen as Catalan - not

Spanish - Games.     Thousands of apartments in Barcelona are flying

 

yellow and red striped Catalan flags from their balconies. Some have the word ''Independence'' scrawled on them.
 
NIKE APPAREL: U.S. athletes expect to wear their Nike apparel at the Olympics, even though a Spanish court rejected Nike's final appeal in a multimillion-dollar trademark feud, the U.S. Olympic Committee says.

The entire U.S. track and field team has a contract to wear Nike apparel. Many other American athletes wear Nike shoes.

''Based on what we have seen, we don't think the interpretation has anything to do with competitive gear or any other apparel or shoes worn by American or other athletes in the Games,'' USOC spokesman Mike Moran said.

''We would hope this court would not attempt to dictate to any athlete from any nation what competitive gear they would wear in these Games.''

Contributing: Karen Allen, Steve Wieberg


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Olympics Line


1992 OLYMPIC GAMES PREVIEW


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

329 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


December 18, 1991, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION


Nike up 6%


BYLINE: Financial Times of London and Financial Post news services


SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT & FINANCE; Pg. 15, INTERNATIONAL COMPANY NEWS


LENGTH: 70 words


 Nike Inc., the U.S.'s largest athletic shoe maker, reported earnings of US$61.5 million (C$70.3 million), or US80 cents a share, for the second quarter ended Nov. 30, an increase of 6% from US$58.1 million (US77 cents) in the same period last year. Revenues for the quarter increased 15% to US$743.4 million from US$648.8 million. The earnings were slightly better than expected by Wall Street analysts.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: NEWS

352 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


July 10, 1991, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION


Nike confident


BYLINE: Financial Times of London and Financial Post news services


SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT & FINANCE; Pg. 14, INTERNATIONAL COMPANY NEWS


LENGTH: 112 words


Shoe manufacturer Nike Inc. is ''comfortable'' with analysts' estimates it will increase net income 14%-20% to between US$3.65 and US$3.85 a share for the fiscal year ended May 31. Chairman and chief executive Philip Knight declined to give specific estimates, although he did say total net income would increase about 15% for the year - a gain that would indicate total net income of about US$279.4 million (C$320.2 million) for the Beaverton, Ore.-based company. He said sales for the year topped US$3 billion, a 34% jump from year-earlier sales of US$2.2 billion. The company is scheduled to report fourth-quarter and fiscal year earnings today.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: NEWS


Copyright 1991 Financial Post Ltd.

 

354 of 998 DOCUMENTS

356 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


March 17, 1992, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION


Nike earnings rise


BYLINE: Financial Times of London and Financial Post news services


SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20, INTERNATIONAL COMPANY NEWS


LENGTH: 58 words


Running shoe giant Nike Inc. yesterday reported earnings of US$82.5 million (US$1.08 a share) for the third quarter ended Feb. 29, up 17% from US$70.7 million (US93 cents) for the same period last year.

Revenue increased 8% to US$867 million from US$802.2 million in the year-ago quarter and were a record for the third quarter.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: NEWS


Copyright 1992 Financial Post Ltd.

 

359 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Hobart Mercury


June 1, 1991 Saturday


BYLINE: AAP


LENGTH: 244 words


New-wave sneakers finally get their sea legs New York BEACHCOMBERS along Oregon's north coast are finding new treasures from the sea - hundreds of Nike sport shoes washing ashore a year after a cargo ship mishap.

Since April 2, Burke and Lisa Pond have found more than 140 Nike shoes. 

Steve McLoed, who until recently had never owned a Nike shoe, now boasts about 70. Shirley Tarnasky has found 50 Nikes near her oceanfront home in Rockaway Beach.

Some people are now carting sneakers and hiking boots home by the wheelbarrow load.

But the storm-tossed shoes aren't coming ashore in pairs, prompting Shirley Tarnasky to form the Sneaker Society to promote sneaker swaps at which people can trade to create matching pairs.

Nike transportation manager Rich Hastings said yesterday the shoes were from five boxcar-size containers that fell from a Seattle-bound cargo ship in the Pacific Ocean in May last year.

About 40,000 pairs of Nikes were lost but now were reaching Oregon after traveling thousands of miles on ocean currents, Mr Hastings said.

Though coated with seaweed and filled with sand and long-neck clams, most of the shoes are as good as new after a cleaning, Ms Tarnasky said.

She said Nike was missing the boat by not taking more interest in the seagoing sneakers.

"The advertising possibilities are obvious," she said. "Shoes that can float around in the ocean for a year and not come apart at the seams just have to be good." AP


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: MER


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

361 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


June 28, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Nike knows hurting Bo to make All-Star show


BYLINE: Ben Brown


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 186 words


Bo Jackson has been unable to play a single inning of baseball in the '91 season, but he'll still make an appearance during the July 9 All-Star Game.

Nike has purchased four minutes of ad time during the prime-time telecast. And for the third year, the shoe company is using the game to premier a new Bo ad campaign.

Past commercials - including the famous ''Bo knows'' - have been award- winners. The new series will kickoff with a 60-second spot that highlights this year's theme.

Nike is keeping details of the new campaign secret until next week. But this much has leaked: The new spots will have the world's most famous two- sport athlete singing and dancing and will involve several other guest athletes.

Jackson injured his hip last January as an NFL running back for the Los Angeles Raiders. He was released by baseball's Kansas City Royals in spring training, then signed by the Chicago White Sox.

Since the regular season began, Jackson has been working on an intensive rehabilitation program and vows to return to baseball.

He is expected to remain on the disabled list, though, until August.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, Nick Ut, AP
 
CUTLINE: ALL-STAR SPOT: Injured hip or not, Bo Jackson will be showing off some new moves in a series of Nike commercials that will debut during CBS' telecast of baseball's All-Star Game July 9.


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

364 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Daily Mail (London)


July 23, 1992, Thursday


Make tracks, the police are after our vests!;
OLYMPIC STARS RUN INTO TRADEMARK ROW


BYLINE: David Ward


SECTION: Pg. 3


LENGTH: 894 words


 

OLYMPIC athletes could be running away from police in Barcelona . . . to stop them confiscating their track outfits.

The possibility was raised last night after a Madrid court confirmed a ban on the U.S. firm Nike, the world's largest sportswear seller, using the name on its clothing in Spain.

Judges said the trademark Nike on clothes there belongs to lawyer Juan Amigo, who bought the title 11 years ago from a sock firm which registered it in 1932. 

He wants up to £15million to allow Nike to use the name - taken from the Greek goddess of victory - during the Olympics.

The American giant, which had planned a major showcase of new designs in Barcelona, says it now faces multi-million-pound losses.

It has paid out huge sums for the right to outfit the American and Algerian track and field teams, including U.S. stars Carl Lewis and Mike Powell and Algerian Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres.

The ban affects only clothing, not Nike shoes or the firm's familiar tick-shaped 'whoosh' logo. But if the court ruling is defied, athletes could face confrontations with police trying to enforce it.

Last night, the American team was defiant. 'I'd like to see them try it,' said spokesman Mike Moran. 'The right to wear competitive gear of anyone's choice is an Olympic tradition.'

 Nike was also refusing to back down. 'It is beyond the realm of possibility that these uniforms will be taken from the athletes,' said the firm's lawyer Lindsay Stuart. 'All these products were purchased or given to the athletes outside of Spain.

'It would be the same as you going into Spain with a Nike T-shirt in your suitcase and having it taken away from you.' However, Senor Amigo's lawyer, Jose Antonio Hernandez, said: 'I trust Nike will comply with the law. If they don't comply, they'll have to pay the consequences.'

After yesterday's ruling by Spain's highest appeals court, the American Embassy arranged a meeting between Nike and Senor Amigo - but Nike cancelled the talks.

The company's Madrid attorney, Enrique Jimenez Batalla, said it will not negotiate. 'We're of the opinion that the court order does not affect the Olympic Games,' he added. 'It affects the sale of clothing in Spain.'

Mike Moran agreed. 'Spanish courts have no jurisdiction over our athletes and what they wear,' he said. 'I can't believe that anybody is going to take the uniforms off our athletes in the middle of the arena. It's too outlandish.

'The International Olympic Committee has given governing bodies of sport around the world the right to make these marketing agreements.'

 Nike's setback came despite the support of the European Commission and the Spanish and American governments. They wanted the firm to be allowed to post a bond to let it advertise and sell clothes while the case was going on.

One possibility is that it will get round the injunction by supplying athletes with outfits bearing its logo, but not the name Nike.

Choice


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Displaying the Nike name, Algeria's Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres in Barcelona - powers down the track. Now he could be forced to swop outfits . .. but they'll have to catch him first.


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Associated Newspapers Ltd.

 

365 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Daily Mail (London)


July 23, 1992, Thursday


Make tracks, the police are after our vests!;
OLYMPIC STARS RUN INTO TRADEMARK ROW


BYLINE: David Ward


SECTION: Pg. 3


LENGTH: 501 words


 

OLYMPIC athletes could be running away from police in Barcelona . . . to stop them confiscating their track outfits.

The possibility was raised last night after a Madrid court confirmed a ban on the U.S. firm Nike, the world's largest sportswear seller, using the name on its clothing in Spain.

Judges said the trademark Nike on clothes there belongs to lawyer Juan Amigo, who bought the title 11 years ago from a sock firm which registered it in 1932. 

He wants up to £15million to allow Nike to use the name - taken from the Greek goddess of victory - during the Olympics.

The American giant, which had planned a major showcase of new designs in Barcelona, says it now faces multi-million-pound losses.

It has paid out huge sums for the right to outfit the American and Algerian track and field teams, including U.S. stars Carl Lewis and Mike Powell and Algerian Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres.

The ban affects only clothing, not Nike shoes or the firm's familiar tick-shaped 'whoosh' logo. But if the court ruling is defied, athletes could face confrontations with police trying to enforce it.

Last night, the American team was defiant. 'I'd like to see them try it,' said spokesman Mike Moran. 'The right to wear competitive gear of anyone's choice is an Olympic tradition.'

 Nike was also refusing to back down. 'It is beyond the realm of possibility that these uniforms will be taken from the athletes,' said the firm's lawyer Lindsay Stuart. 'All these products were purchased or given to the athletes outside of Spain.

'It would be the same as you going into Spain with a Nike T-shirt in your suitcase and having it taken away from you.' However, Senor Amigo's lawyer, Jose Antonio Hernandez, said: 'I trust Nike will comply with the law. If they don't comply, they'll have to pay the consequences.'

After yesterday's ruling by Spain's highest appeals court, the American Embassy arranged a meeting between Nike and Senor Amigo - but Nike cancelled the talks.

The company's Madrid attorney, Enrique Jimenez Batalla, said it will not negotiate. 'We're of the opinion that the court order does not affect the Olympic Games,' he added. 'It affects the sale of clothing in Spain.'

Mike Moran agreed. 'Spanish courts have no jurisdiction over our athletes and what they wear,' he said. 'I can't believe that anybody is going to take the uniforms off our athletes in the middle of the arena. It's too outlandish.

'The International Olympic Committee has given governing bodies of sport around the world the right to make these marketing agreements.'

 Nike's setback came despite the support of the European Commission and the Spanish and American governments. They wanted the firm to be allowed to post a bond to let it advertise and sell clothes while the case was going on.

One possibility is that it will get round the injunction by supplying athletes with outfits bearing its logo, but not the name Nike.

Choice


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Displaying the Nike name, Algeria's Noureddine Morceli - favourite to win the 1,500 metres in Barcelona - powers down the track. Now he could be forced to swop outfits . .. but they'll have to catch him first.


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Associated Newspapers Ltd.

 

368 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 11, 1992, Saturday, Late Edition - Final


COMPANY NEWS;
Nike's Olympian Trademark Fight


BYLINE: Special to The New York Times


SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 3; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 754 words


DATELINE: MADRID, July 10


Imagine the following live broadcast during the Olympic Games this month: The Spanish police interrupt a basketball game and ask American athletes to strip. The officers then confiscate any shirts or shorts carrying Nike Inc.'s logo.

Although such a scene is a worst-case scenario, it could happen as a result of a dispute over trademark rights between the Beaverton, Ore., maker of athletic wear and Juan Amigo, a lawyer and associate of Nike's former distributor in Spain. 

 Nike, sponsor of American Olympic teams, had hoped for wide advertising exposure during the Games. But that hope has been dashed by a Spanish court ruling that bans the company from marketing its sports clothing during the Olympics. An appeal of the ruling, which does not forbid Nike to market its logo on shoes, is unlikely to be taken up in time for the July 25 start of the Games.
 
'Tremendous Economic Damage'

"It's unfair that the court is supporting someone who is taking advantage of someone else's success and who is causing tremendous economic damage," complained Cesar Garcelan, marketing director of American Nike, the company's current distributor in Spain, who estimates Nike's apparel sales in Spain at more than 2 billion pesetas, or $20 million, a year.

The company must now sell its clothing line at souvenir stands in Barcelona without the logo. Lawyers for Nike estimate that at the Olympic stand, those lost apparel sales were expected to represent about 10 percent of total sales. Sports bags account for perhaps another 10 percent, with shoes, which Nike is allowed to market, representing the bulk of the sales.

Richard K. Donahue, Nike's president and chief operating officer, was quoted in the Spanish business paper Expansion as saying that the company's trademark rights have been "trampled" in Spain.
 
No Negotiation 'With Pirates'

A United States Embassy official said that while the Embassy was supporting the American company, trademark battles often occurred in Spain and companies usually agreed to settlements in which they paid to gain control of their names. Adidas A.G. had a similar case and wound up paying.

But one Nike executive said, "Our company's policy is not to negotiate with pirates."

The former Nike distributor and Mr. Amigo are now marketing their own identical range of Nike sportswear. Various people involved in the case contend that Mr. Amigo has asked for amounts varying from an early offer of $8 million to $10 million to settle the wrangle.

Mr. Amigo and the lawyers who are handling his case were unavailable for comment.

The name Nike was first registered in Spain in 1932 by a Catalonian sock knitter and included a picture of a statue of an armless Greek goddess that stands at one of the stairway entrances to the Louvre in Paris titled, "The Victory of Samotrace." The word "NIKE" is written at the pedestal in this 1932 registration.

Mr. Amigo bought the rights to this trademark, which had never been used, in 1982. The Nike company in Oregon was granted trademark registration for shoes in 1983 and for sports clothes several years later.

Trouble started when the American company decided to change distributors in 1989 when its contract expired. Mr. Amigo, a friend and associate of the former distributor, according to Spanish Nike sources, then sought to register as a trademark a practically identical version of the United States logo, as well as some 200 versions of names using the word "Nike."

Spain's trademark registrar denied the application. Mr. Amigo then filed for an injunction banning the marketing of Nike apparel in Spain on the ground that the two logos, the 1932 Greek goddess Nike and the American trademark, were "confusing for clients." A lower court ruled in favor of the injunction in March 1991.

Nike appealed to Spain's Constitutional Court, the highest court. In April 1991, the court accepted the proceeding, but a definitive ruling is not expected for two to three years, well after the summer games.

Because the Constitutional Court normally rejects about 90 percent of all appeals, Nike applied to post bond as a precaution that would allow the company to market its logo until a final ruling was made. It lost this second proceeding July 3 and has appealed in a last-ditch effort that is unlikely to beat the Olympic deadline.

"It is absolutely incredible that this man, Mr. Juan Amigo, can affect Nike's exposure all over the world by preventing Nike from dressing the U.S. team," Mr. Garcelan complained.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: A dispute over trademark rights is dashing Nike's plans to market its sports clothing at the Barcelona Olympics. The Nike logo was prominent at Nike's successful retail store at the 1988 Games in Korea. (Nike)


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

386 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


August 15, 1992


CURSE OF NIKE


BYLINE: ROBERT NEEDHAM


SECTION: THE GUARDIAN TABLOID PAGE; Pg. 37


LENGTH: 426 words


 

IF, LIKE Nike, your range of sports apparel is named after the Greek goddess of victory, it may be embarrassing when it is worn by losers rather than winners.

If, like Nike, you had plastered the images of these losers on billboards across the world in expectation of them being winners, it may be acutely, excruciatingly embarrassing. And if, like Nike, you had paid millions of dollars to these losers for the privilege, you might be wondering about the wisdom of your Olympic investment. 

BILLBOARD 1: "You have just passed Michael Johnson. More than most athletes will do this summer."

Well, "most athletes" - the badminton players, for instance - were not competing against Johnson. But even within his chosen event, the 200m sprint, at least five runners proved they could pass the Nike-emblazoned Johnson - he came sixth of eight in his semi-final, failing even to qualify for the final.

BUBKA: brought to earthALLSPORT

BILLBOARD 2: "Spanish air traffic control has been warned."

They needn't have been. Sergey Bubka, the best pole vaulter in history, the long-serving, Nike-wearing world record holder (6.11m) and world champion, failed even to clear his opening height in the pole vault final. The Ukrainian made two attempts at 5.70m, then had a foolhardy, equally unsuccessful stab at 5.75m.

BILLBOARD 3: "Ever heard the Algerian national anthem? You will."

Oh no, you won't. At least, not as a result of the performance of Nike-toting Nourredine Morceli. He came a modest seventh in the 1500m final.

Other Nike-brandishing flops:

- Kenyan runner Richard Chelimo had his 10,000m gold medal taken away from him. He finished second in the race, but was awarded the gold after being judged to have been impeded by Moroccans. Unfortunately, the decision was later reversed.

- Jim Courier, possessor of the most lucrative shoe contract outside American basketball - worth at least $ 4 million a year over five years - was beaten in the tennis quarter-finals by unknown Marc Rosset from Switzerland, 6-4, 6-2, 6-0.

- Even the six Nike-soled members of the basketball Dream Team - notably Michael Jordan - made themselves unpopular by cynically draping American flags over their shoulders, in order to hide the Reebok logo on their tracksuits.

Such footwear-associated cock-ups are uncannily reminiscent of goddess Nike's most famous image, depicted in a frieze on the Acropolis: on her way to deliver a message to the embattled city of Athens, Nike has to stop to fix her sandal, making her late.


LOAD-DATE: May 7, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Guardian Newspapers Limited

 

388 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


April 23, 1992, Thursday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION


Nike may drop Krabbe


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 43, SPORTS BRIEFS


LENGTH: 60 words


German sprint star Katrin Krabbe is in danger of losing her sponsorship with Nike unless she is cleared of drug use next month by track and field's governing body, the German magazine Stern claims. Krabbe, Grit Breuer and Silke Moeller were suspended Feb. 15 by German track officials for manipulating urine samples at a training camp last year.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: NEWS


Copyright 1992 Financial Post Ltd.

 

390 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 19, 1991, Tuesday


Thanks to endorsements, Bo won't know poverty


BYLINE: By Mike Fish Staff writersports; personalities; endorsements; salaries


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 05


LENGTH: 495 words


Even if Bo Jackson's professional sports career is in limbo, Bo knows he can always hawk sneakers.

A spokeswoman for Nike Inc., provider of one of Jackson's many paychecks, says her company "has never cancelled a contract with any professional athlete due to injury or illness."

Liz Dolan added that there is nothing in Jackson's contract with Nike stipulating he has to play two sports, or even one. 

Last spring, Jackson, whose football and baseball careers are jeopardized by a hip injury, signed an extension with Nike through 1993.

"We're not going to cut him,'' said Dolan, commenting from Nike headquarters in Beaverton, Ore. "Our fitness center is named after Bo. So we'd like to invite Bo to come spend the next year rehabilitating himself at the Bo Jackson Sports and Fitness Center."

Nike didn't dump Michael Jordan when he had an injury that sidelined him in the second year of his contract. Dolan suggested Jackson's career may not be over.

"Bo is a surprising, explosive athlete. I wouldn't jump to any conclusions," Dolan said.

Forbes magazine recently reported Jackson's annual endorsement income at $ 2.5 million. His agent, Richard Woods, calls the figure conservative.

Jackson, the ultimate football/baseball hybrid, can be seen in ad campaigns for Nike, AT&T, Cheerios and Pepsi. He also serves as spokesman for Bo-Med - medical supplies for weekend warriors, of which he is part of a joint venture - and he's pursuing the possibility of starting a restaurant franchise.

But if Jackson is restricted to playing only one sport, or none at all, it certainly diminishes his superman aura.

"The two-sport thing has been the cornerstone of our campaign," Fred Schreyer, Nike's director of sports marketing, said recently. "I have no doubt he would be a star if he played one sport, and he might be a celebrity as well, but I don't think we ever would have gone the way we have if it wasn't the two-sport thing.

"It's the guy who can do anything. That really stems from the fact he's kind of doing things nobody else has done."; Bo Jackson's career stats; BASEBALL

Year ............. HR .......... RBI ......... Avg.

1986 ............. 2 .......... 9 ......... .207

1987 ............. 22 .......... 53 ......... .235

1988 ............. 25 .......... 68 ......... .246

1989 ............. 32 .......... 105 ......... .256

1990 ............. 28 .......... 78 ......... .272

Total ............. 109 .......... 313 ......... .250; FOOTBALL

Year ............ Rushes ........... Yards ......... Avg. ......... TD

1987 ............ 81 .............. 554 .......... 6.8 .......... 4

1988 ............ 136 .............. 580 .......... 4.3 .......... 3

1989 ............ 173 .............. 950 .......... 5.5 .......... 4

1990 ............ 125 .............. 698 .......... 5.6 .......... 5

Total ........... 515 .............. 2,782 ......... 5.4 .......... 16


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

392 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


May 20, 1992, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Nike Campaign Does It Again


BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT


SECTION: Section D; Page 17; Column 2; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 135 words


For the second time in two years, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., has won a Stephen E. Kelly Award for the best magazine advertising campaign. It won the $100,000 prize for work for Nike Inc.

The agency won the 1991 Kelly, announced last night by the Magazine Publishers of America at a dinner in Los Angeles, for three four-page print advertisements in a Nike campaign aimed at women. 

The campaign, which has been praised for appealing to women in an unstereotypical manner, was one of three Wieden & Kennedy campaigns for Nike among the 25 nominees.

The agency also won the Kelly in 1990 for a Nike campaign that appeared in magazines in 1989. The latest award is another in a recent series of honors for Wieden & Kennedy that included Agency of the Year from Advertising Age and Adweek.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

393 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Times


August 6, 1992, Thursday


Compromise


BYLINE: Peter Ball


SECTION: Sport


LENGTH: 163 words


Even athletes have to discover one day that life is full of those little compromises especially when sponsorship is involved. The ''Dream Team'' is one example. Reebok has sponsored the United States squad; several of the millionaire basketball players have individual deals with Nike.

Yesterday a compromise for the medal ceremony was reached all 12 players will wear the official US Olympic Committee uniform ''but in such a manner that does not reveal any commercial identification,'' according to the American basketball president, Dave Gavitt. Effectively the six Nike contracted players, including Michael Jordan, Charles Barkley and John Stockton, will be able to cover up the Reebok identification marks but not display Nike symbols.

 Nike might at least find that preferable to Sergey Bubka, the world pole vault record holder, who adorns their advertisments. Bubka was photographed in training wearing his prescribed Nike top and Adidas shorts. Whoops.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Newspapers Limited

 

397 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


October 10, 1991 Thursday


TRUTH & RUMOURS WILLIAM HOUSTON'S WORLD OF SPORT Sit on it, Jays!


BYLINE: WILLIAM HOUSTON; GAM


LENGTH: 465 words


John William Hart III is an insurance salesman in Los Angeles who also
writes poetry about baseball. He has published two books, The Tao of
Baseball and Dugout Poems, both of which are in the Baseball Hall of
Fame's library. Hart, 32, attends ball games (Dodgers) or listens to them
on the radio (television stunts the imagination). After listening to the
first game of the American League Championship Series, he offered this -
an application of the Taoist philosophy - to the Toronto Blue Jays.
Learning is the practice of remembering.
The Tao is forgetting.
Keep on forgetting until you reach the state of sitting.
To win the World Series one must forget all.
Have no private answer.
And sit.
New Bo Jackson video
Nike offers Bo Jackson fans an advertising-entertainment hybrid for the
Christmas market. It's a home video titled Bo Knows Bo: The Bo Jackson
Story. Nike collaborated with CBS"Fox Video to market a 45-minute program
that combines Nike advertising with a documentary-style look at the two-
sport athlete's life. 

Advertising Age reports that Bo Knows Bo is the first product from
Nike's new sports-entertainment division. Nike plans to market videos on
other athletes.
Steffi Graf, a pasta lover, is starring in a new German ad campaign for
Barilla, the Italian pasta marketer. In addition to noodles, she's getting
lots of cash - $3-million (U.S.) over three years. Print ads and a 20-
second television commercial show Graf wearing a variety of pasta as
earrings, a brooch, pendant and ring.

Hockey notes

On the Forbes list

There are several sports owners on the Forbes 400 list of the wealthiest people in the United States. William Wirtz (Chicago Blackhawks) and Gordon Gund (San Jose Sharks) are noticeably absent because their money is part of a family fortune. Richard DeVos, $2.9-billion (U.S.), Orlando Magic of the National Basketball Association. Paul Allen, $2.4-billion, Portland Trail Blazers (NBA). Ted Arison, $2.3-billion, Miami Heat (NBA). Edward DeBartolo Sr., $1.4-billion, Pittsburgh Penguins (NHL) and San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League. Ted Turner, $1.3-billion, Atlanta Hawks (NBA), Atlanta Braves, National League baseball. Preston Tisch, $1.15-billion, New York Giants (NFL). Jack Kent Cooke, $1.1-billion, Washington Redskins (NFL). Ewing Marion Kauffman, $835-million, Kansas City Royals (American League baseball). William Davidson, $725-million, Detroit Pistons (NBA). Carl Pohlad, $680-million, Minnesota Twins (AL). Leon Hess, $650-million, New York Jets (NFL). William Clay Ford, $610-million, Detroit Lions (NFL). Melvin Simon, $600-million, Indiana Pacers (NBA). Gus Alexander Spanos, $600-million, San Diego Chargers (NFL). Tom Monaghan, $550-million, Detroit Tigers (AL).

AD NOTES; NIKE & SPIKE

402 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


June 6, 1992, Saturday, City Edition


Kids & Kubs reveal secret: It's the shoes


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 188 words


DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG


 

Move over Michael Jordan. There's some new Kids (& Kubs) on the advertising airwaves.
 
    St. Petersburg's Three-Quarter Century Softball Club a.k.a. the Kids & Kubs is going to be featured in a Nike commercial during Major League Baseball's All-Star Game on July 14. 
 
    Editing of the commercial, which was filmed in late April at a Kids & Kubs game, hasn't been completed and a Nike spokesman said the ad's plot is not being revealed before its airing.
 
    "Given the setting and the types of players these gentlemen are, I think you can expect it to be a fun spot," said Dusty Kidd, Nike's PR director. "They're an interesting group of guys down there."
 
    Kids & Kubs president Paul Good said Nike has supplied the club with sneakers for a number of years. For the commercial, Nike donated $ 5,000 and 50 pairs of shoes to the softball club.
 
    "They filmed a number of scenes and players, but I don't know what will finally end up on the screen," Good said. "This is super for us. This is the kind of thing you dream about, getting national exposure. You can't buy that."


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1992

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 24, 1991, Wednesday


Anderson signs to represent Nike


BYLINE: By Mike Fish Staff writerbasketball; personalities; georgia/tech; advertising


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 164 words


Kenny Anderson is the latest Nike pitchman. The former Georgia Tech star has signed a multi-year deal, joining such marquee NBA players as Michael Jordan, David Robinson and Charles Barkley. 

Converse and Reebok were the other finalists for Anderson's endorsement.

Nike officials plan to feature Anderson on a national television campaign this season. Anderson, a New York schoolboy legend, was selected No. 2 overall by the New Jersey Nets in last month's NBA draft.

Richard Howell, who represents Anderson, said the contract forbids disclosure of financial terms or length. However, industry officials said after the draft that Anderson would probably receive a shoe contract for about $ 400,000 a year.

"We're obviously very pleased with it," Howell said. "You'll be seeing him on some ads."

As for Anderson's playing contract, Howell said he has had one "philosophical" meeting with Nets officials and has another meeting scheduled within the next two weeks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
