488 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


February 3, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


MUSIC;
Chopin Meets the Slam Dunk


BYLINE: By James R. Oestreich


SECTION: Section 2; Page 23; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk


LENGTH: 276 words


If, for whatever cockeyed reason, you wanted to cast a classical musician alongside a professional athlete in a sneaker commercial, you might find a likely candidate or two. But you would find a host of unlikely ones, and among the very least plausible would be the pianist Rudolf Firkusny.

Reserved and patrician in his bearing and in his playing, Mr. Firkusny, who lives in New York but was born in Napajedla, Moravia (now part of Czechoslovakia), in 1912, is the epitome of old-world grace and gentility. "I am not very much in the sport world," Mr. Firkusny said recently. 

Yet there he is on television with David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs, playing Chopin and, uh, basketball in a commercial for Nike. The idea came from James Riswold, an admirer of Mr. Firkusny's piano-playing and a copywriter for the advertising agency Weiden & Kennedy, based in Portland, Ore. Mr. Riswold's work in other Nike commercials has received wide acclaim.

Though Mr. Firkusny took part only in the final day of shooting, he said the process of repeated takes was exhausting, much as in a recording session. "For the first time I realized that it's not such an easy life to be a movie actor," he added. But there were rewards. He reported gleefully that he made one basket -- a feat, alas, not shown in the commercial.

And now Mr. Firkusny revels in a new-found fame. "Everybody saw it somehow," he said. "My mailman told me he saw me on television. The druggist and my daughter's doctor saw it. That's the magic of television. I think it was good that for once serious music was put together with sports. Music needs all kinds of encouragement."


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: A move by David Robinson, blurred, leaves Mr. Firkusny flat-footed. (The New York Times)


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

 

491 of 998 DOCUMENTS


South China Morning Post (Hong Kong)


August 5, 1992


Nike, Adidas fear tariffs' effect on HK;
Top shoemakers warn US


BYLINE: From MICHAEL CHUGANI in Washington


SECTION: Business; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 730 words


TWO of the world's biggest suppliers of sports equipment - Nike and Adidas - have warned the US Government that trade retaliation against China would seriously hurt their Hongkong operations.

 Nike, the world's largest producer of sports shoes, said if punitive tariffs were imposed the company would have to sharply raise prices or shut down its entire operation in China.

Such action would undermine its regional headquarters in Hongkong, where there would be thousands of job losses, the company said.

 Nike has urged the United States Trade Representative to target China's state- run shoe factories instead of those operated by private enterprises. 

Adidas, another industry giant, said all of its financing, purchases and shipping for Adidas merchandise manufactured in China was done through businesses in Hongkong, which would be hard hit by US trade retaliation.

For example, a company such as Yue Yuen Industrial Ltd, the large sports shoe maker which listed on the Hongkong stock exchange in June, could see its business seriously wounded.

As an original equipment manufacturer for Nike and Adidas, Yue Yuen employs 13,300 workers in its four mainland factories and nearly 200 supervisors, many from Hongkong, in operations that last year were 80 per cent devoted to the United States.

But the powerful American Textile Manufacturers Institute (ATMI) has demanded that the US impose punitive tariffs on key Chinese exports to match dollar-for-dollar the losses suffered by the US from China's trade barriers.

The groups were responding to a call by the US Government for public comment on which Chinese goods to single out for retaliation should Beijing fail to accept American demands to lift trade barriers against US products.

Most of the 20 or so trade groups and companies that responded urged the Trade Representative's office to defuse the trade row by reaching a fair-trade agreement with Beijing instead of taking punitive action.

They further urged that their products be left off the hit-list of Chinese goods should the talks fail and retaliation become necessary.

US President George Bush has set an October 10 deadline for Beijing to sign a deal that would open up China's markets or face sharply higher tariffs against Chinese exports to the US.

Deputy Trade Representative Michael Moskow increased the pressure last month with an ultimatum that unless Beijing accepted all US demands during market access talks beginning on August 19 in Beijing the US would publish a tentative hit-list of Chinese goods.

In responding to the trade office's call for public comment, ATMI said the US should target Chinese goods that made up the key parts of China's export trade and those considered as high priority items by Beijing.

The textile association added that the goods selected for punitive tariffs should be products China made exclusively for the US market - such as cotton towels, blankets and women's sweaters - so that China could not side-step punishment by exporting these products to other markets.

"Many of our member companies have long been victims of the unfair and illegal trade practices routinely carried out by China," the ATMI said.

Crampton and Knowles, a top US dye company, accused China of widespread unfair trade by using trade barriers, employing prison labour and ignoring copyright.

It urged the US to target goods that hurt China's economy most, including garments, footwear and toys.

But the Hongkong General Chamber of Commerce warned that any damage to China's economy would affect Hongkong's economy.

"To make Hongkong an innocent victim is clearly a major injustice. There can be no winners in this," the chamber said.

The Hongkong Toys Council warned the Trade Representative that retaliation against China would "critically threaten" the territory's toy manufacturers because 95 per cent of China's toy exports to the US were in fact produced by Hongkong firms on the mainland.

The Federation of Hongkong Industries urged US officials to exclude from the hit-list "those items which in your opinion might damage Hongkong industry if retaliation is necessary".

The Hongkong Watch Manufacturers Association and the Hongkong Electronics Association also pleaded against retaliation, warning that such action could result in hundreds of thousands of job losses.


LOAD-DATE: October 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: Newspaper


Copyright 1992 South China Morning Post Ltd.

 

492 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


July 14, 1992 Tuesday


Nike uniforms get Olympic approval


LENGTH: 182 words


TRADEMARK difficulties in Spain will not have any impact on the ability of national teams wearing Nike-provided uniforms to compete in the Olympic Games, the sports clothing company said today.

"Despite repeated press reports that link our trademark case to Olympic uniforms, there is no connection legally," said Nike vice-president and corporate counsel Lindsay Stewart. 

"Uniforms that bear the logo of the company who made them comply with IOC regulations restricting advertising." "The courts in Spain have ruled that we may not sell apparel or advertise apparel in their country until our trademark case is decided.We will do neither during the Olympics.

"The courts in Spain have made no ruling that bears on Olympic uniforms, which are the private property of the national team members who wear them." Nike will provide the official national uniforms to the track and field teams of the United States, Nigeria, Algeria, Paraguay and the Bahamas.

The trademark case in Spain does not affect Nike footwear which will be worn by many leading athletes.

- PA

END OF STORY

The Herald (Glasgow)


July 7, 1992


Nike in court battle


SECTION: Pg. 4


LENGTH: 77 words


 

MADRID: Nike, which has paid millions to put its name on US track and field outfits at the Barcelona Olympics, is to fight a court decision that bars advertising or sale of its sportswear in Spain and which could cost the firm £10m in Spanish sales alone. A constitutional court has refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Oregon-based companyfrom using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Caledonian Newspapers Ltd.

 

497 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


June 18, 1992 Thursday


What's in a brand name?


LENGTH: 89 words


SPAIN'S quirky trademark law is threatening to turn Nike's sponsorship of the US Olympic track and field team into a multi-million dollar fiasco.

 Nike Inc is in the midst of an ugly legal battle with a Spanish lawyer who owns the Nike name in Spain - registered 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker.And with the Olympics less than six weeks away and Nike planning to plaster its disputed name on US athletes' uniforms, the company and the lawyer, Juan Amigo Freixas, are playing a game of courtroom ollars.

AP

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1992 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

499 of 998 DOCUMENTS



Sunday Age (Melbourne, Australia)


October 4, 1992 Sunday  
Late Edition


Tennis greats with a spring in their instep


BYLINE: Stephen Dabkowski


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 527 words


IN a sport dominated by money, John McEnroe and Andre Agassi will do an unusual thing at the National Tennis Centre today _ play an exhibition match for nothing. The reason is to promote their main sponsor, Nike, and announce its success in the Australian marketplace. 

Later this year, Nike is expected to take over the mantle of market leader in the sports footwear industry from Reebok. The air sole is about to deflate the pump-action shoe.

In an industry conservatively valued at $500million a year, that is a big deal, and Nike is not going to let us forget it.

Today's exhibition tennis match is the first in a series of Nike promotions. Next in line will be its basketball wares, which may entail an Australian visit next year by the biggest superstar in the game _ Michael Jordan.

The company is among the top 10 television advertisers in the country, rivalling such traditional big spenders as Coca-Cola and McDonald's. Its formula has entailed using United States ads featuring Jordan, fellow basketballer Charles Barkley, Ukrainian pole vaulter Sergei Bubka and its "Just do it" jingle.

A survey of viewers' ad recognition during the Barcelona Olympics put Nike's advertisements near the top.

The managing director of Nike Australia, Mr Tony Peddie, said the growth of the Nike sports shoe in Australia followed the manufacturer's US success. "Our boom is product-created by the Nike formula, of being able globally to franchise athletes to products, like Michael Jordan," he said.

One of his competitors, Mr Paul Moore, group director of sporting goods at Pacific Dunlop, which has the licence to sell Adidas sports shoes in Australia, agreed, saying that Nike is flavor of the month.

"The sporting goods market in Australia is a fad market. You are very hot for a while, then something else comes up and knocks you off," he said.

"The business is driven from American trends and what youth demands.

Kids aged 14 to 18 are controlling the market." Demand is also shaped by changes in technology. Reebok generated huge sales through the pump-action technology in the tongue of its runners.

In 1979, Nike first developed its air sole. Now, through its AirJordan brand, it has matched it with Reebok in Australia. Adidas has tried to develop its own image through its torsion sole, also designed to reduce stress on the foot.

Analysts put Nike's share of the sports footwear market at 27 per cent, slightly below Reebok but rising. Next in line is Adidas (the dominant player of the early 1980s) with about 16 per cent of the market, followed by Puma (about 10 per cent) and the rest.

Mr Peddie said Nike aimed for the same success locally that it had in the US, where it has 33 per cent of the market. It had given itself 18 months to achieve that kind of dominance.

Today's challenge between McEnroe and Agassi is one of several exhibitions every year for which the players are contracted. Mr Peddie said: "This promotion is all about showing the flag for Nike. It is the first big shot in our sports marketing efforts and clearly this sort of thing is going to happen in the future. In the future we need to do something with basketball, which is such a growing sport."


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1992 The Age Company Limited
All Rights Reserved

 

501 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


November 18, 1992, Wednesday


BIZARRE BUZZ Tempers leaping at pairing of Frog and Frenchtownoddities


SECTION: LIVING; Section E; Page 3


LENGTH: 265 words


The St. Charles, Mo., City Council touched off a controversy when it agreed to designate part of the north end of the city as "Frog Town," the area's traditional nickname because it is, indeed, covered with frogs. But Lyndell Porterfield, the city attorney, pointed out that French people and their descendants consider the word "Frog" to be a derogatory reference to them. The neighborhood next to Frog Town is called Frenchtown.

SOLE SURVIVORS: A flotilla of up to 40,000 Nike gym shoes have been slowly bobbing around the Pacific Ocean since the spring of 1990. A storm struck a freighter and washed overboard its shipment of Nike shoes. Months later, the shoes began washing up on the shores of Oregon. The shoes survived the immersion with surprising resilience. And scientists following the Nike armada's progress have learned more about Pacific currents. "It has been a real bonus to our work," said marine scientist James Ingraham.

JAWS: A great white shark attacked a kayaker off California during the weekend. It was one of several encounters recorded in the past few days between human beings and sharks, prompting a warning to avoid the waters off Ano Nuevo State Reserve. Kayaker Ken Kelton was attacked by a large shark Saturday as he paddled his boat north of Santa Cruz. Although his boat was bitten, he was uninjured. Other shark sightings involved great whites biting a cod on a fisherman's line, attacking a seal and cruising near the surf line off Santa Cruz. Experts said the number of recent great white shark incidents is unusual.

From our news services


LOAD-DATE: November 24, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923290111


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

502 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


March 20, 1991, Wednesday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION


Now investors know Bo's pain


BYLINE: Jamie Wayne


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 39


LENGTH: 368 words


Stockholders and baseball card investors don't know about Bo - and the uncertainty took a toll yesterday.

Shares of Nike Inc., the Beaverton, Ore. athletic footwear giant for which baseball and football star Bo Jackson did the popular ''Bo Knows'' ad campaign, plunged US$3 3/4 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange before rallying late in the day.

 Nike stock closed down US$1 3/4 at US$45 3/4 after falling US$2 1/2 on Monday. Nike dropped US$1 5/8 on Friday, when reports that Jackson's injury could be career-threatening began to receive widespread circulation. 

The chance that the Los Angeles Raider running back and ex-Kansas City Royal outfielder may never play again has also prompted dumping of Jackson's baseball cards at big discounts, according to Jeff Kurowski, the baseball price guide co-ordinator for the respected Sports Collector's Digest

A 1986 Topps Traded card which was selling Monday for US$10 dropped to US$5 with news of Jackson's release by the Royals, he said.

''A lot of large quantities of his cards are being dumped,'' Kurowski said. ''We haven't seen a lot of activity in his football cards yet. But I imagine it will be the same result.

''A lot of the value in Bo was built because he was in the national spotlight and the expectations in both sports were so high. Now it just might turn out to be unrealized potential.''

A Wall Street analyst says not all the blame for the stock's drop should be attributed to Jackson's injury. Heidi Steinberg of Salomon Bros. in New York said Nike's earnings report, released Monday, showed ''expenses have increased, particularly selling expenses and interest costs.''

But Liz Dolan, Nike's vice-president of corporate communications, said she's puzzled by the drop in share price.''Earnings were up and the price goes down. But the stock market is very emotional; Bo's injury could have something to do with it.''

Since Jackson became Nike's most famous spokesman in 1988, sales of cross-trainers have grown to US$350 million (C$400 million). Bo's contract with Nike runs through 1993.

Jackson was on crutches yesterday as he visited his former teammates in the Royals' clubhouse.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: NEWS


Copyright 1991 Financial Post Ltd.

 

505 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Marketing News TM


May 11, 1992


Nike pledges $ 5 million for CTW show


BYLINE: by Carrie Goerne, Assistant editor


SECTION: Pg. 16


LENGTH: 515 words


Nike Inc. is breaking into new territory by pledging $ 5 million to become the sole corporate sponsor of "Ghostwriter," a new children's show being produced by the Children's Television Workshop (CTW) for public TV.

According to CTW, who also produces "Sesame Street" and "3-2-1 Contact," Nike's contribution is the largest promotional grant ever given to a children's public TV project and the first PBS show underwritten by a sporting goods company.

The new "Ghostwriter" weekly prime-time series is aimed at children ages 7-10 with an emphasis on motivating kids to read and write. "Ghostwriter" is scheduled to debut this fall on PBS and will be accompanied by an extensive multimedia outreach program. 

CTW describes the "Ghostwriter" show as "breakthrough children's programming" that tries to promote literacy by featuring hip, urban youngsters and a ghost who can only communicate through writing. The show uses original music, funky animation, and celebrity guest stars to tell stories with cliff-hanger endings.

Accompanying the TV series will be 20 million copies of a magazine based on the show, a nationally syndicated newspaper column, and a promotion and publicity campaign coordinated with Nike.

The 15-second on-air credit for Nike that will appear after every show was designed by advertising heavy hitter Wieden and Kennedy, with the theme "Exercise your head -- read."

Nike will have an advertorial page in each "Ghostwriter" magazine issue, sponsor recognition on other "Ghostwriter" material, and be able to use one of its very visible spokespeople to tout reading and the "Ghostwriter" project. The company also plans to hold one or two national contests to encourage kids to read and write.

Although "Ghostwriter" is contributing a page of its magazine to Nike, "it's not like an advertising page; they're just giving us some credit for being a $ 5 million dollar underwriter," said Virginia Henson, director of public affairs for Beaverton, Ore.-based Nike.

Last year, the company sponsored a $ 5 million commercial literacy campaign that included spots featuring Michael Jordan and Spike Lee sitting in a classroom with a blackboard that read "Don't be stoopid, stay in school."

This year, after "lengthy internal discussions . . . we decided if we were going to put all our eggs in one basket, this program was certainly one that merited [funding]," she said.

Of the show's $ 20 million startup fund, reportedly half will be used to produce 40 episodes for next year, and the other half will be used for promotion and community outreach.

The "Ghostwriter" project funding is mainly a philanthropic effort by Nike for the community, Henson said, but she also expects to reap some marketing benefits.

"When you do these types of sponsorships you obviously engender goodwill, which, hopefully, transfers to consumer loyalty toward the product," she said.

"We're always positioning ourselves as having strong emotional ties with consumers," Henson said. "For us. this is exactly the type of emotional tie we like to have with the public."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, The new "Ghostwriter" series, produced by Children's Television Workshop, uses hip, urban kids to promote literacy. Nike Inc. has already pledged $ 5 million to the show, making it the largest corporate sponsor of a children's public TV project., Photo by Frank Micelotta/CTW


Copyright 1992 American Marketing Association

The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


July 31, 1992, Friday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION


Dream Team may boycott medal ceremony


SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 35, Olympic Notebook


LENGTH: 156 words


DATELINE: Barcelona, Spain


American medal winners must wear Reebok outfits to the podium, the U.S. Olympic Committee says. But some members of the U.S. basketball team - notably Charles Barkley and Michael Jordan - say their contracts with other companies might force them to skip their expected gold medal ceremony. 

''Us Nike guys are loyal to Nike because they pay us a lot of money,'' Barkley said. ''If Reebok or the USOC is going to be upset about four or five guys not wearing a suit, it's a joke. Nike pays us a ton of money. I have two million reasons not to wear Reebok.''

Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and David Robinson are other U.S. players under contract to Nike.

Reebok has a contract with the USOC that all medal winners will wear the specially designed Reebok warmup suit after winning an Olympic medal. Money received from Reebok goes to pay thousands of athletes in training, USOC spokesman Mike Moran said.

The Washington Post


March 22, 1992, Sunday, Final Edition


Well, We All Shine...Shoes? Is There Any Song Madison Avenue Won't Steal?


Paul Farhi, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: SUNDAY SHOW; PAGE G1


LENGTH: 469 words


Plucking another treasure from the baby boomer song book, Nike Inc. has launched a new ad campaign featuring "Instant Karma," the John Lennon classic. And yes, that's Lennon, crooning from beyond the grave to help move a few more units of something called Air Huaraches.

Maybe turning John Lennon into a sneaker salesman is a tad craven, but by now it's old news. Nike, which licensed "Instant Karma" with Yoko Ono's permission, has been down this road before -- in 1987, when its use of the Beatles' "Revolution" in a commercial kicked up fan protests and a lawsuit from Paul McCartney. Advertisers have been grafting popular songs onto ad campaigns for so long that no one complains, even when Aretha Franklin transforms a song that wasn't hers, "Rescue Me," into "Deliver Me" for Pizza Hut. So, as long as Madison Avenue insists on appropriating demographically correct tunes, we might as well be helpful. How about:

For Domino's, Lennon again: "Give Pizza a Chance." 

For Crisco, George Harrison offers "My Sweet Lard."

For Sealy mattresses, Bob Dylan sings "Lay Lady Lay" (alternates: Aerosmith's "Dream On," Lennon's "How Do You Sleep?").

More Dylan: for Goodyear, "The Tires They Are a-Changin' "; for International House of Pancakes, "You Gotta Serve Somebody"; and for Kleenex, "Blowin' in the Wind."

For the Jenny Craig weight loss centers: Peter Frampton's "Baby, I Love Your Weigh."

For Trojan-brand condoms, the 5th Dimension's "Up, Up and Away (In My Beautiful Balloon)." And, of course, the Foreigner medley: "Feels Like the First Time," "Hot Blooded" and "Urgent."

Foreigner again, for Mrs. Paul's fish sticks: "Hot Breaded."

Dentu-Grip signs Paul Simon for "Slip Slidin' Away."

For Right Guard and Secret: Lynyrd Skynyrd doing "That Smell" or J. Geils Band doing "Love Stinks."

For Suzanne Somers's ThighMaster: Led Zeppelin's "Stairway to Heaven."

Root Boy Slim's "Boogie Till You Puke" for Dupont Stainmaster Carpet.

Linda Ronstadt for Isotoner: "When Will I Be Gloved?"

The Who, licensing division: for Greyhound, "Magic Bus"; for Stanley tools, "Won't Get Tooled Again"; for Bausch & Lomb, "I Can See For Miles."

Curtis Mayfield's "Superfly" for any airline.

BCCI and the NRA can fight over Warren Zevon's "Lawyers, Guns and Money."

Duraflame logs and Kingsford charcoal could bid for the rights to the Doors' "Light My Fire."

Clearasil and Roberta Flack team up for "The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face."

The Rolling Stones' "Tumbling Dice" for Harrah's casinos and resorts.

The Eurythmics, for Marriott: "Suite Dreams Are Made of This."

And Edwin Starr revives his career for Compound W: "Wart! Good God, ya'll, what is it good for? Absolutely nothin'!"

Staff writers Vince Rinehart, Scott Patton and Richard Harrington contributed to this, uh, report.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, JOHN LENNON.


TYPE: FEATURE


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

512 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


December 2, 1992, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Criticism grows along with business


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 1057 words


DATELINE: BEAVERTON, ORE.


For a company that says it's selling ''self- empowerment,'' Nike takes a lot of flak.

The harshest criticism: Nike isn't just latching onto sports, it's meddling in them.

Take CBS' broadcast of the National League playoffs, when announcer Sean McDonough suggested Nike endorser Deion Sanders played for baseball's Atlanta Braves and football's Atlanta Falcons because he let a reported $ 1 million Nike bonus for doing so ''take precedence'' over team allegiance.

Broadcast partner Tim McCarver's curt response: ''It shouldn't.'' 

Then there's the flap that Nike chairman and founder Phil Knight says prompted ''more negative calls and letters than anything else'' - whether six Nike Dream Teamers would wear Reebok-sponsored team outfits as they accepted their basketball gold medals at the Barcelona Olympics.

In his Japanese-style office in Nike's John McEnroe Building, Knight, 53, has an answer for each charge. He says the company had ''no influence'' over Sanders' two-way play and that Sanders took Nike's weekend shuttle ''because it had never been done before.''

And while Nike's Michael Jordan settled on draping a U.S. flag over the Reebok logo at Barcelona, Knight bristles that the media reduced the issue to ''a sound bite'' of an athlete picking ''his company over his country.''

A company that last year spent $ 223 million on advertising, according to Advertising Age, doesn't welcome such publicity. Still, Knight says Jordan was upset, ''and I'd be, too.''

Upset, that is, because none of the Dream Teamers ''did it for the money'' and because Jordan was presented with the Reebok sponsorship as a done deal. .

And that's in violation of a basic Nike premise: The athlete is No. 1 - at least compared to everybody else in the sports world.

That might be an unsettling concept to pro teams building fan loyalty meant to withstand lineup shuffles. Or to pro leagues, looking to move merchandise lines and TV rights as players come and go. Or to TV networks, trying to win ratings points with riveting replays, regardless of who's in focus.

The friction causes brush fires, such as the dispute about Jordan's successful request that the National Basketball Association stop selling official league merchandise bearing his likeness - gear that arguably competes with Nike's Jordan lines, which include $ 23 Air Jordan infant crib booties.

''The NBA took those rights without actually having them,'' says Knight. ''Some of the players have said stop.''

The primacy of the athlete - and the corollary that Nike helps consumers find the athlete inside themselves - is as old as the company, whose marketing strategy began with putting shoes on serious runners' feet.

Nike's headquarters, for instance, is a secular temple to athletes, complete with bust likenesses and encased relics of their exploits.

Consider an area devoted to Steve Prefontaine, an Oregon runner killed in a 1975 car accident, displaying a menacing 1974 letter from track's governing body. Prefontaine, after competing in the 1972 Olympics, had the audacity to accept $ 5,000 from an embryonic Nike for basic expenses.

The display case notes track officials' response to Prefontaine sporting a Nike logo: ''You can't do that. There are codes. There are subcodes.''

Sometimes, Nike welcomes publicity that pits it against the powers-that- be, such as when the NBA banned the original Air Jordan shoe for being too colorful.

But as Nike grew, the criticism has a new edge: that nobody is rooting for Goliath.

After slipping to archrival Reebok during the aerobics boom in the 1980s, Nike's revenues rose from $ 877 million in 1987 to $ 3.4 billion in fiscal 1992. Nike's women's category is up from 12% of overall sales two years ago to 20% of today's overall revenues. Nike hopes expanding international sales, now $ 1.2 billion, will grow to 50% of total sales by 1996, when the company projects annual sales will reach $ 6 billion.

And Nike took care of its stockholders: Forbes magazine estimates Knight's personal wealth at $ 1.9 billion, about the same as Ted Turner, cable TV magnate and owner of sports teams.

So it might have been only a matter of time until Nike's role in sports was questioned, albeit not always convincingly. At the Barcelona Olympics, Mizuno endorser Carl Lewis suggested U.S. coach Mel Rosen might have let athletes' ties to Nike factor into his relay selections.

The accusation wasn't given much credibility in the track world. And Steve Miller, a longtime track coach and Kansas State athletic director before becoming Nike's sports marketing director, dismisses the charge with more than a discourse on ethics: ''Could I - or anybody else here - keep our job if we did something like that? Absolutely not.''

Miller also says the fees Nike pays to shod major college basketball teams are guided by market forces. He says fees from about 25% of those deals go directly to colleges rather than to coaches, and that it's fine with Nike if that percentage increases, as long as Nike gets the feet. Says Miller: ''How universities run their business is their call.''

Nike's move into providing a range of services for its athletes, the latest being the Charlotte Hornets' Alonzo Mourning, has prompted speculation Nike was ready to flex its muscle in athlete management or even buy out the market leader, International Management Group.

Knight adamantly denies the IMG rumor, saying Nike ''isn't anxious to get into being a full-blown athlete management company.'' He suggests Nike's concern with an athlete's overall business is a logical extension of concern for the credibility Nike wants an endorser to project.

Bottom line: ''If sports lose their credibility,'' says Knight, ''so do we.''

But don't expect Nike to back off when sports officials call the company an interloper. Says Nike ad director Scott Bedbury: ''Does Nike have a patent on the spirit of athletics? No. But neither does anybody else.''

Is Nike too powerful?
Some critics say Nike's billion-dollar marketing muscle and flock of star endorsers are having an effect on what happens on the playing field.

Some of Nike's star endorsers
Michael Jordan
Jim Courier
Andre Agassi
Charles Barkley
David Robinson
Bo Jackson
Scottie Pippen
Deion Sanders
Sergei Bubka

 Nike Inc. revenues (in billions)
'92 $ 3.4


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, color, Sam Ward, USA TODAY, Source: Nike Inc. (Diagram, line graph; PHOTO, color, H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: SANDERS: Reported bonus for playing two sports.


TYPE: Cover Story


See sidebar; Nike chairman answers critics; See info box at end of text.


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

515 of 998 DOCUMENTS



Australian Financial Review


July 14, 1992 Tuesday  
Late Edition


ADDISON


BYLINE: Simon Lloyd


SECTION: MARKETING & MEDIA; Pg. 26


LENGTH: 525 words


UNLESS you've been hovering round the dark side of the moon lately, you'll be aware that the Barcelona Olympics are now a matter only of weeks away. 

None are more conscious of this than the folks at Channel Seven, which will be screening 21 hours a day of games to recoup through advertising revenues some of the reported $46 million the network poured into the screening rights

That money, of course, doesn't pay for the herculean operation that Seven has undertaken to ensure Australian viewers aren't tempted away from gymnastics and archery by Wendt and Hinch.

Seven has, more or less, built a medium-sized TV station in Barcelona which, of course, will all have to be pulled down less than three weeks after the opening ceremony on July 25.

Once hacks, camera crews, technicians and so on are all assembled in the city, Seven's Barcelona staff will number more than 150, which represents a pretty colossal expense account.

THE media loves a controversy story when it comes to the Olympics, and Addison has turned up a couple of them.

First, try to imagine the Spanish police interrupting a basketball game and asking the American athletes to strip their gear off, then confiscating shirts and shorts bearing the Nike logo. Ridiculous?

Not according to The New York Times, which reports that a trademark row in Spain has resulted in a judgement in favour of a Spanish lawyer, Juan Amigo, an associate of Nike's former distributor in Spain who now sells a pirate line of Nike clothing.

As sponsors of the US Olympic teams, the real Nike, of course, has counted on huge advertising exposure at the games, but Snr Amigo's court win means that Nike may not market its sports clothes - except shoes for some unexplained reason - during the Olympics. With no appeal possible before July 25, the NYT says Nike will have to sell its clothing line at souvenir stands in Barcelona without the logo.

Amigo's price to drop the ban is a cool $US10 million, about half of Nike's annual sales in Spain.

SECOND: The European Broadcasting Union, EBU, is facing huge fines, according to Reuter, for refusing to allow a private channel, Screensport, access to any Olympic coverage.

The EBU is a grouping of the main national broadcasters in Europe(including France's Antenne 2 and the BBC), but it has stubbornly refused Screensport any footage rights because it wants to pass on pooled coverage of the games to its own channel, called Eurosport.

The European Commission appears to have grown annoyed at the EBU's stance, and has threatened it with emergency rulings this week, with fines that could make the Olympic TV rights look paltry, if it does not comply.

SHE won't be covering the Olympics, but SBS will this week cover her.

In one of those table-turning exercises that TV producers, if not always the viewing public, love indulging in, Jana Wendt has been allowed out of the Nine Network for an evening to appear as the victim of a Face the Press interview, to be screened on SBS at 8 o'clock tomorrow evening.

The programme will mark only the second time Jana has appeared as an interviewee outside the Nine Network since January 1988, says the SBS publicity blurb.

Gosh.


LOAD-DATE: March 16, 2012


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved

 

517 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 25, 1992, Saturday, Final Edition


There's Nothing Cold About Logo Wars in Barcelona


Michael Wilbon


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D6; MICHAEL WILBON


LENGTH: 842 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA


Probably by August 2000, at an Olympic Stadium constructed in someplace quiet, like Madison Avenue, a new Olympic era will be ushered in: no flags, no competing nations, only corporate sponsors. There will be teams from Nike, Reebok, Mizuno, from Umbro, Speedo, Converse, from adidas, Champion and Starter, from McDonald's, Wheaties and Pizza Hut. Michael Jordan and his Nikes against Shaquille O'Neal and his Reeboks in the gold medal basketball game. If the Games of Barcelona, which open Saturday, are any indication, we're closer to this insanity than you think. 

Just in case you haven't been obsessively following this summer's Sponsor Wars, let's recap: A Barcelona-based company named Cidesport, which claims it registered the name Nike in 1932, has won a decision in a Spanish court that upholds Cidesport's right to the trademark. Supposedly, this means all sponsored athletes are prohibited from wearing the name Nike on their apparel here at the Summer Olympics. The Tribunal Constitutional didn't, however, tell us exactly how this ruling would be enforced. "What are they going to have, Nike police strip Gwen Torrence before she runs the 100?" a U.S. Olympic official asked Friday. "Are they going to rip off Carl Lewis's pants because they have the word Nike on them? They're blustering and assuring the world that's what will happen. But if they want a brouhaha like the Olympics has never seen, let them try to tell our athletes what they can and cannot wear."

Yes, indeed, you would be better off driving an athlete's Porsche into the drink before you mess with his or her clothing contract. This is more than just this little two-bit, publicity-hungry Cidesport vs. Nike. Nike also is embroiled in a set-to with its primary rival, Reebok. Each sport of each country determines its apparel sponsor, which is why the U.S. basketball team is wearing uniforms made by Champion, sporting the Champion logo, and why the U.S. track and field team is wearing Nike uniforms. But each National Olympic Committee makes its own apparel deal; in this case the USOC has made it mandatory that all athletes wear an outfit made by Henry Grethel (via JCPenney) in the Opening Ceremonies, and sweats by Reebok during the medal and closing ceremonies. So what you've got, for example, is decathlete Dave Johnson, a Reebok guy, having to compete all week in a Nike track suit.

If you don't think the Logo Wars are impassioned, consider that Michael Jordan would rather stand nude on the medal stand than wear that unspeakable "other brand" in which he would be photographed and seen by more than 1 billion people. Wearing the mandatory clothing is part of the code of conduct that each athlete signs before the Games. Still, Jordan told Sports Illustrated, "There's no way in the world I'm wearing a suit made by Reebok."

He reiterated that sentiment during a conversation in Monte Carlo last week. And a spokesman for the Dream Team said Friday, "Michael still says there's no way he's wearing it. Something will have to be resolved."

It's unimaginable that the Nike athletes, including Jordan, Charles Barkley, Scottie Pippen, David Robinson and world record pole vaulter Sergei Bubka, would ever let Cidesport, or a Spanish court for that matter, intimidate them into putting tape over the Nike logo. But it's completely imaginable that they'd tape over the word Reebok during a medal ceremony, or wear a Nike hat or some other attention-drawing piece of clothing that would pay homage to the company that pays each of them millions.

Jordan, who isn't one to budge on such issues, may have to this time. It's not as if Reebok can go out and distribute posters with his likeness, wearing its apparel, after the Olympics. He (and the five other Dream Teamers signed with Nike) already have been photographed ad nauseum wearing Champion, which is clearly a competitor. Jordan will spend much more time in a Champion uniform than he would in Reebok sweats. Nike got the deal with The Athletics Congress and Reebok has to live, uneasily, with that. So Nike will have to live with the fact that Reebok got the deal with the USOC.

You'd hope that at some point the athletes would cherish the uniform to the point, that anything having USA and the Olympic rings would transcend the issue of who makes the garment. At some point, commercialism has to be put aside, even only for a few moments. Nike won't void a deal with Jordan because he wears the USOC-issued warmups. Reebok won't revoke a deal with Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, Michael Chang, Zina Garrison or Coach Chuck Daly in the event each wears another sponsor's shirt for 10 minutes.

That, of course, is probably the naive view, the opinion of a man who isn't paid millions to do anything exclusively. Even in the few cases in life when money isn't involved, extremist pride often is. When we see Fidel Castro wearing military fatigues with a swoosh on the chest and the words "Just Do It" underneath, we'll know the whole concept of sponsorship has gone completely over the edge.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, DREAM TEAM STAR MICHAEL JORDAN, A NIKE CLIENT, VOWS HE'LL NOT BE SEEN IN A REEBOK OUTFIT FURING MEDAL CEREMONIES. STAY TUNED. REUTER


TYPE: COLUMN


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

521 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


June 7, 1992, SUNDAY, LATE FIVE STAR Edition


NIKE'S AD SHOP JUST DOES IT


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1E


LENGTH: 873 words


 

PORTLAND, Ore. - The ad agency of Wieden and Kennedy, chief image crafter of Nike shoes (''Just Do It'') and Subaru cars (''What to Drive''), is pushing the advertising envelope with its risky, intuitive campaigns and an unorthodox - to say the least - management style. Two leading trade magazines, Advertising Age and Adweek, each have named Wieden and Kennedy agency of the year, citing the countercultural nature of the firm's work. With current annual billings of $200 million, Wieden and Kennedy also has been in the running for two huge new accounts: MasterCard and Sega of America, which markets Genesis video games. Together, these represent about $115 million a year in new business. To put the significance of this another way, an agency typically keeps 15 percent of its client's billings. Yet Wieden and Kennedy staff members seem unfazed by all the attention. They wear jackets inscribed with the reminder, ''Don't Act Big, No Sharp Stuff.'' Staff lists are alphabetized by first names. Titles are left off business cards. Nobody dresses up. Beer flows from kegs on Friday afternoons. And job applicants lucky enough to get interviews are asked such things as, ''Do you like to have fun?'' (Right answer: Yes). Or, ''Which kind of Milky Way is better - plain or dark chocolate?'' (Right answer: Let's go have a drink, then decide). ''We don't have a personnel department,'' says Dan Wieden, one of the names on the door. ''What personnel manager in his right mind would hire these people?'' David Kennedy, the other founder, sometimes is mistaken for a janitor by the slew of new employees the agency has hired in the last year to cope with its startling growth. Little wonder - his work attire consists of denim pants, denim shirt, cowboy boots and a big ring of keys dangling from his belt. Wieden, 47, says he didn't have much enthusiasm for advertising when he got into the business right out of the University of Oregon. He had wanted to be ''a playwright or a poet - something meaningful,'' he says. Then, while working as a copywriter at a now-defunct Portland advertising office, he met Kennedy, who had moved his family of seven from Chicago to take a job as art director. All of a sudden, Wieden says, advertising took on a whole new meaning. ''It was like realizing there was a higher form of the profession that could be very rewarding.'' The pair eventually worked up the nerve to start their own agency in 1982. Their first account was Nike, whose billings at the time amounted to a measly $1 million a year. There is a saying in adverti sing that great clients make great advertising. There is no question, says Kennedy, 52, that the agency is the child of Nike Inc., the sports giant based in Beaverton, Ore. Nike took most of its advertising away from Wieden and Kennedy in 1983, then gave the whole thing back to the renegade ad shop in 1986. ''Nike allows us to be brave and has funded that bravery,'' Wieden says. ''They ask us to jump off cliffs - and jump off with us.'' Indeed, as Nike revenues swelled to $3 billion a year - and its ad budget to more than $100 million - Wieden and Kennedy's work has grown in stature. From the Bo (''Bo knows . . . '') Jackson self-parodies, to the teaming of Bugs Bunny and Michael Jordan, to the technically brilliant ''Instant Karma'' spot, Nike has allowed Wieden and Kennedy to push the envelope. ''A lot of agencies follow linear paths guided almost exclusively by research,'' says Scott Bedbury, Nike's director of advertising. ''Wieden and Kennedy places a very high priority on the visceral side of communication. It's a philosophy we share with them.'' In other words, it's a right brain kind of thing. The Nike spots tend to be risky, but even Wieden and Kennedy's competitors say they get the job done. ''At the end of the day when everybody goes home, it's what's in the magazines and what's on television that counts,'' says Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive officer of Chiat-Day-Mojo, a bigger agency in Venice, Calif., with a long reputation for producing creative ad campaigns. It currently handles advertising for Reebok, Nike's chief rival, and was Nike's agency from 1983 to 1986. ''Wieden and Kennedy has consistently delivered, '' Kuperman says. Despite Wieden and Kennedy's much-heralded work for Nike, the agency didn't move into advertising's major leagues until it picked up the $70 million-a-year Subaru of America account last year. To work with Subaru, the agency opened an office in Philadelphia, just across the Delaware River from Subaru headquarters in Cherry Hill, N.J. Some staff members saw it as the breakup of the Wieden and Kennedy family. Insiders and outsiders alike wondered whether the rapidly growing agency would lose its edge and become (gasp) predictable. So far, it hasn't. Wieden and Kennedy's work for Subaru - which, unlike Nike, is far from a market leader and has suffered from an identity crisis - has turned car advertising on its ear with a revolutionary campaign that mocks the 1980s ethos of automobile as status symbol. Meanwhile, back in Portland, co-creative directors Dan Wieden and David Kennedy try to figure out how to get big without getting bad.


LOAD-DATE: October 11, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Photo; PHOTO...Post-Dispatch Photo...Diesel engines on trains made travel faster in the early 1940s. This photo, taken on Feb. 11, 1940, shows visitors waiting to inspect the Missouri Pacific's new streamlined passenger train, the Eagle, at Union Station before it began operating between St. Louis, Kansas City and Omaha, Neb.


Copyright 1992 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

523 of 998 DOCUMENTS


SUNDAY MAIL (QLD)


March 31, 1991 Sunday


RED FACES AS SHOE BLUE BLACKS OUT AD


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: DAVIES R


LENGTH: 169 words


Foot in mouth disease NOW it can be told _ the true story of why Nike scrapped a television commercial for their trainer shoes. And a bizarre tale it is too. 

It seems Nike went to a lot of trouble and dollars to make a commercial in Africa for American audiences.

The idea was to have a group of Masai warriors running through the bush wearing Nike trainers and endorsing the firm's product in between spearing passing antelopes.

A grumpy looking warrior fronts the screen, mutters something in his native dialect and a translation appears on the screen ""Just do it", which is Nike America's slogan.

Unfortunately that is not quite what the warrior actually said.

Freely translated, the grumpy-looking warrior said: ""These are horrid shoes and they aren't big enough."

As luck would have it, one of the few people outside Africa who spoke the warrior's language just happened to see the commercial at its first _ and only _ showing. End of commercial. Exit sullen natives.

Exit red-faced ad makers.


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: SML


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

525 of 998 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


January 30, 1992 Thursday  
FINAL EDITION


JORDAN-NIKE DEAL COSTS NBA MILLIONS


BYLINE: The Associated Press


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 94 words


DATELINE: PORTLAND, ORE.


Michael Jordan has told the NBA it no longer can sell apparel bearing his

image, giving Nike Inc. those rights exclusively.

The Oregonian reported Jordan's decision, confirmed by the league,

Wednesday. The move, unprecedented in the NBA, means millions of dollars.

Jordan, 28, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first championship last

year, is among the NBA's most charismatic personalities. Jordan, who has been on the Nike payroll since 1984, will earn $21.2 million in endorsements this

year, according to reports.

Nike earns about $200 million a year on Jordan's image.

527 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


April 13, 1991, SATURDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


ST. LOUIS BUSINESS PRACTICES ASHCROFT BLASTS U.S. ETHICS


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 9C


LENGTH: 870 words


 

Unethical business practices hurt U.S. productivity, Gov. John D. Ashcroft said Friday in St. Louis. ''Employees steal $160 billion worth of things from their employers in this country,'' Ashcroft said. ''Time spent stealing is time not spent producing.'' Ashcroft was addressing a conference sponsored by St. Louis University Emerson Electric Center for Business Ethics. ''Rules have been relaxed in the legal profession,'' Ashcroft said. He said that advertising has permitted lawyers to solicit clients and increase the volume of litigation. Ashcroft said the country ''needs new heroes.'' Today, he said, people regarded as heroes are those ''who ask the question, 'Is it legal?' - not, 'Is it right?' '' MONSANTO Mahoney Wins Management Award Richard J. Mahoney, chairman and chief executive officer of Monsanto Co., was awarded the first Corporate Cultural Diversity Management Award on Friday. The award was presented by the Business Minority Council of Washington University's John M. Olin School of Business. The award is intended to honor efforts to increase the number of minorities and women within senior management. ''Monsanto has been at the forefront of creating and implementing management training modules which encourage development of a culturally diverse work force,'' said Robert L. Virgil, dean of Olin School. NATIONAL RJR NABISCO New Stock Offering Announced RJR Nabisco Inc. announced Friday in New York that it would issue 100 million new shares of common stock at a price of $11.25 apiece. The food and tobacco conglomerate, which said last month it would sell 75 million shares, said it increased the size of the offering because of ''greater marketplace interest.'' An earlier 129-million-share stock issue, made as part of a debt exchange offer, has proved immensely popular on Wall Street. The shares began trading at $5.50 a share on Feb. 1 and have climbed past $11. The already outstanding stock led the most-active list in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange Friday, rising 25 cents to $11.75 a share. AP NIKE Avia Sues Rival Over Patent In a battle of athletic shoe rivals, Avia is suing Nike on claims of patent infringement. The lawsuit, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Portland, Ore., accuses Nike of using a cushioning system similar to Avia's ''Cantilever'' technology in Nike's new Air 180 shoes, which sell for $125 a pair. The lawsuit asks for unspecified damages as well as an injunction to stop Nike from making and selling Air 180s, which were introduced in a nationwide advertising campaign during this year's Super Bowl. AP R.H. MACY Aggressive Ad Campai gn Planned R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., shifting gears after a year of financial angst, said Friday it is expanding advertising in an aggressive drive for new business. The retailer said it was spending $150 million on a television advertising campaign that is kicking off in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area and will reach all of Macy's markets by the beginning of 1992. The campaign is five times the retailer's $30 million annual budget for television advertising. AP REVLON INC. Second Big Asset Sale Held Revlon Inc. said Friday it would issue 40 million shares in its National Health Laboratories subsidiary, the second big asset sale announced by the cosmetics maker this week. The privately-held Revlon sold an 18 percent stake in National Health Laboratories to the public last year. The new issue will leave Revlon with approximately 42 percent of the stock in the division. Revlon said in a statement it would use the proceeds of the latest stock sale to reduce its debt load. Earlier this week, Revlon agreed to sell its Max Factor product lines and Betrix subsidiary in Germany to Procter & Gamble Co. AP USX CORP. Two New Issues Begin Trading Two new issues of USX Corp. stock began trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange - one for Marathon Oil Co. and one for the parent company's steel business. The exchange allowed trading of the shares pending an approval of the split by USX shareholders at a meeting next month in Houston. The move allows the public to decide in which of the company's main businesses to invest. The proposal calls for each share of USX stock to be converted into one share of Marathon stock and one-fifth of a share of steel stock. The Marathon Oil stock fell 37 1/2 cents to $29.37 1/2 in NYSE trading Friday. The new steel issue climbed $2.75 to $22.75 on the exchange. USX stock continues to trade normally, giving investors three ways to trade in the company. USX closed up 75 cents at $33.75. AP INTERNATIONAL JAPAN GE, Toshiba Form Joint Venture Toshiba Corp. and General Electric Co. have agreed to form a joint venture to import and sell GE appliances in Japan, officials of the two companies said Friday in Tokyo. GE Appliances Japan, Ltd., will be established in Tokyo next month to import and sell refrigerators, washer-dryers and other large appliances. GE will contribute 51 percent of the 490 million yen ($3.6 million) in capital and Toshiba will contribute 41 percent. A holding company to be established in Singapore by the two firms will put up the remaining 8 percent. Asahi News Service

529 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


September 17, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Sprint owner's shares fall on GAO report


BYLINE: John Schneidawind; Beth Belton


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 383 words


Shares of United Telecommunications Inc., owner of long-distance company Sprint, sank 1 1/8 to $ 23 5/8 Monday as investors worried that Sprint may lose or have to adjust a contract with the government.

The General Accounting Office claims the federal government is paying AT&T and Sprint $ 148 million more in the next two years than it should. It said Sprint charges too much. That could lead Congress to force Sprint to cut rates. AT&T and Sprint share a $ 25 billion contract to provide the government with long-distance phone service. 

But analysts say investor concerns about Sprint losing the contract are exaggerated. A lot of the fuss, they say, has been caused by MCI, which doesn't have a piece of the contract and keeps telling the government it could do the job more cheaply than either AT&T or Sprint.

Joel Gross of Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette says Sprint already has cut long-distance rates several times to bring them in line with AT&T's rates. Gross says investors are worried that Sprint could lose a portion of its contract in 1993 after the contract is rebid. But that's unlikely. ''There is a rebid in the fourth year of the contract, but only between the two existing players,'' Gross says.

Shoe-in: Nike Inc. gained 3 to $ 51 1/8 after the company reported a record quarter. Nike had net income of $ 114.4 million, or $ 1.50 a share - vs. $ 99.7 million, or $ 1.31 a share, last year. It had record revenue of $ 947 million. Nike President Richard Donahue told Reuter news service that he will expand his workforce by 500 to about 5,000 worldwide.

The strong first-quarter results surprised Wall Street, which had worried that consumers would balk at buying high-priced athletic shoes during a recession. But ''price resistance hasn't hit yet,'' says Kidder Peabody analyst Gary Jacobson. ''People will continue to pay north of $ 100 for sneakers.'' Still, Jacobson is in no rush to buy Nike shares. ''Now's the time to stay on the sidelines,'' he advises. He thinks Nike is vulnerable until a recovery is evident.

In fact, Nike warned that next quarter could be weak. The company's worldwide orders for shoes and apparel scheduled for delivery between now and January are $ 1.1 billion - up 2% from last year. But Jacobson had been looking for a 7% gain.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Marketline


USA TODAY'S MARKET SCOREBOARD; STREET TALK

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 20, 1991, Wednesday


Glenn Sheeley's Sportscene; Georgia Dome keeps growing easier to find


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 691 words


There's no trick to finding the Georgia Dome these days. It finds you. Nine months ago the $ 210 million project was merely a few concrete footings. Now much of the Dome's outside structure rises dramatically out of what last year was a vacant lot. On May 1, they start on the roof.

By February, 1992, the exterior will be watertight. Hey, 25 years later, they can't even say that about Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. . . . Georgia Dome officials even found two suites recently they didn't know existed. Architects had planned for four owner suites - two upper level and two lower level - but only two are needed. Dome marketing director Dennis Berkholtz leased the newly discovered ones for $ 80,000 each. . . . 

Go figure: The Georgia Dome still has a dirt floor and cannot be used. Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium puts tons of dirt over it's sodded grass to hold a motocross Saturday night.

SUPER BUDGET: How big has "The Super Show" become? Exhibit A: The Nike people have a $ 6 million budget just for this week's events at the Georgia World Congress Center. Things are so secretive regarding Nike's presentation Thursday that a security guard has been stationed next to the escalator leading to the ballroom level, under an elaborate Nike archway. Workers in the area assembling booths must wear ID bracelets. . . . Exhibit B: No other trade show in the nation requires what this one does. All current exhibitors must pay for next year's space before they leave on Feb. 24, allowing show organizers to draw interest on the money.

KISSING BANDIT: To the tune of "Brick House" by the Commodores, mascot Harry the Hawk came out during a timeout dressed as a buxom blonde and swaggered up to NBA official Dick Bavetta at last Saturday night's Hawks-Sonics game. Locking up with Harry in a sudden embrace, Bavetta laid one emphatically on the mascot's kisser. When razzed by players on the Hawks bench, Bavetta glanced over to them and said, "Hey, it's lonely on the road." . . . Hawks trainer Joe O'Toole has lost 40 pounds over a period of less than three months and is down to about 180 - no small feat considering the caloric nightmare of food on the road. It didn't come without a struggle. O'Toole's beloved afternoon ice-cream snacks are pretty much history, and he walks at least 40 minutes a day. On a recent trip to San Francisco O'Toole walked from Fisherman's Wharf across the Golden Gate Bridge and back, a distance of about nine miles, in 3 1/2 hours. . . . Somebody forgot to tell Kevin Loughery he isn't a head coach anymore. It's his voice, not Bob Weiss's, that carries from the Hawks bench. . . . Kelly Freeman, Miss Augusta, sang the national anthem Saturday night. So why were there are few catcalls when she was introduced to The Omni crowd? Mistakenly, she was referred to as Miss Augu

IN THE TRENCHES: Atlanta Falcons offensive guard John Scully, who studies battles and war strategy in his spare time, has difficulty getting a feel for the Persian Gulf conflict. "It's kind of hard to develop a mental picture," said Scully, who has a model of the Battle of Murfreesboro set up in his house. "You don't even know the disposition of troops on the border. It's truly desert warfare. The only thing you could compare it with is the North African campaign during World War II, where logistics and supplies were really how campaigns were won or lost. It's difficult to defend in the desert because it's a featureless terrain. There's no place to hide. The attacker usually is rewarded." . . . Todd Marinovich, the banished Southern Cal quarterback, still has a lifestyle unbalanced from most folks. He's never tried a Big Mac, and they've never tried cocaine. . . . A nickname that should have stuck by now for a player who moves swiftly, sometimes under enemy defenses, and occasionally inflicts great damage from the perimeter: Scud Webb. . . . Hard to believe: Dunwoody tour golfer Tim Simpson, during a recent TV interview, claiming not to be bothered if people fail to recognize his talent. Sure, and at the Masters, Simpson would shrug off a ball shanked t

534 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


April 4, 1991, Thursday


Bo finds home in Chicago; White Sox deal is pay-for-play


BYLINE: By Joe Strauss Staff writersports; personalities; contracts; football; baseball; health; conditions


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION F; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 335 words


Move over, Michael. Here comes Bo.

Creating a natural marketing tie-in with basketball star and fellow Nike pitchman Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, outfielder Bo Jackson signed with the Chicago White Sox on Wednesday. 

"It's not the fame, it's not the money, it's the chance to go out and get the world championship," said Jackson, who signed a one-year contract.

However, Toronto Blue Jays general manager Pat Gillick said he thinks an association with Nike influenced Jackson's decision as much as the White Sox's status as contenders in the American League West.

"The whole Nike deal was in Chicago. With him and Jordan owned by the same company, there is so much imagination that can come out of something like that," Gillick said.

Gillick's Blue Jays and the Atlanta Braves were the other two clubs considered seriously by Jackson, a free agent after his release by the Kansas City Royals because of a hip injury sustained in last season's NFL playoffs.

"We weren't able to get into it at all," said Braves general manager John Schuerholz. "Richard Woods Jackson's agent called me Tuesday night to tell me things were moving pretty rapidly. He didn't tell me a signing was imminent. But there was nothing we could do about it."

Jackson's salary will depend on how much he is able to play. The White Sox have options for 1992 and 1993. The first option will be automatic if Jackson is activated for at least 40 games this season. The White Sox must pick up the second option if Jackson plays at least 125 games in 1992.

Jackson will earn $ 10,000 for each game played this season or a total of $ 700,000, whichever is greater. If he fulfills all performance bonuses over the next three seasons, he will make $ 8.1 million. Bonuses earned will automatically be included in the next season's base salary.

The contract does not prohibit Jackson from fulfilling the final year of his $ 7.4 million contract with the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders if his health permits.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

535 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


January 23, 1991, Wednesday


Shoe deals fit just right for Durham


BYLINE: By David Davidson Staff writercolleges; georgia; salaries; contracts; equipment; endorsements


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 280 words


Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham may make less than athletics director Vince Dooley, but when it comes to shoe contracts, Durham's the top Dog.

According to documents obtained by The Journal-Constitution, Durham was paid a salary of $ 75,000 by Georgia in the 1986-87 basketball season.  For the '86 football season, Dooley, who was football coach and athletics director at the time, had a base salary of $ 95,000. Other income greatly increased the total packages of both men - Dooley's to $ 374,497.89, Durham's to $ 255,100.

Both also had shoe contracts with Nike. Dooley's called for a $ 30,000 endorsement fee, plus $ 2,000 in merchandise. Durham's called for a $ 35,000 endorsement fee, plus $ 1,500 in merchandise.

"That is a basic contract all coaches associated with Nike have," Durham said. "Nike has about 60 or 70 coaches. It's a quite comprehensive document. It's not like they're dealing with one person; they're dealing with 60 or 70."

Additional benefits include $ 5,000 worth (wholesale value) of merchandise for Durham to use at his camps and clinics, $ 1,500 worth (retail value) of goods for his personal use, $ 300 in merchandise for each of three assistants and 135 pairs of shoes for his team.

In exchange, Durham wears Nike shoes and sportswear exclusively.

According to figures provided two years ago by Durham's attorney, Nick Chilivis, Durham also earned $ 3,000 from a basketball contract with MacGregor and $ 1,500 from a uniform manufacturer.

Women's basketball coach Andy Landers made a base salary of $ 45,000 for the '86-87 season, but added only $ 9,500 in outside income, for a total package of $ 54,500.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

538 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 23, 1992, Thursday, INTERNATIONAL EDITION


MOSCOW TV VENTURE


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 10B


LENGTH: 537 words


Turner Broadcasting System announced plans Wednesday to build the first independent television station in Moscow in cooperation with a Russian company. The joint venture must compete with other groups for a license to use Channel 6, the last VHF frequency available in Moscow. The plan is contingent on approval by the boards of TBS and its partner, the Moscow Independent Broadcasting Co. 
 
CHAIRMAN FIRED: Hiroaki Shikanai was fired Wednesday as chairman of Sankei Shimbun, one of the most influential newspapers in Japan. ''Mr. Shikanai lacks the qualifications to represent such a company,'' said Shigeaki Hazama, president of the newspaper, part of giant media conglomerate Fuji Sankei. It's not clear why Shikanai was ousted. But Hazama confirmed reports that it was related to a scandal involving retirement benefits Shikanai alledgedly had the company pay the family of his predecessor, his father-in-law, Nobutaka Shikanai.
 
NIKE DEFEAT: The Constitutional Court in Spain rejected Nike's last-ditch appeal in its multimillion-dollar Spanish trademark feud, just days before U.S. athletes are slated to wear the Nike name in the Barcelona Olympics. The decision by Spain's highest appeals court makes it a virtual certainty that Nike will have to comply with an order barring the Beaverton, Ore., company from selling or advertising its sports apparel in Spain. Nike paid millions to put its name on U.S. and Algerian track and field teams in Barcelona.
 
BCCI PAYOUTS: The comprehensive plan to pay off the former depositors of the fraud-ridden Bank of Credit and Commerce International may now fall apart after a Luxembourg court delayed approval of the deal, Reuters reported Tuesday. If a majority of creditors oppose the plan, which has the backing of Abu Dhabi, the main stockholder in the bank, the court may ask that changes be made. But radical alterations are unlikely as a result of the Luxembourg ruling.
 
CHINESE TRADE: The House of Representatives passed two bills to clamp down on China's lucrative trade with the United States, hours after Beijing sentenced a reform-minded official to nine years in prison. Both bills face a veto threat from President Bush, who says continued contact is the best way of encouraging improvement in China's human rights record. The first bill, passed 258-135, overturned Bush's one-year extension of preferential trade treatment for Beijing. The second, narrower measure would let the so-called 'most favored nation' trading status run through next July but then impose conditions on its renewal. It passed 339-62.
 
FAA NETWORK: MCI Communications Corp. laid out the design Tuesday for its new telecommunications network for the Federal Aviation Administration, which uses a duplicate backup system to safeguard it from communications blackouts. The 4.5 million mile network has software that detects and automatically reroutes calls to a duplicate backup system.
 
BUSINESS HOLIDAYS: Banking and government offices may be affected by holidays Thursday in Egypt, Papua New Guinea and Syria; Friday in Ecuador and Venezuela; Saturday in Puerto Rico, Cuba, Maldives, Costa Rico and Equatorial Guinea.
Compiled by Darren Summers


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Moneyline


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

541 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


April 3, 1991, WEDNESDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


BACK TO THE ONE-ROOM SCHOOLHOUSE?


BYLINE: Karen M. Smith


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 3C


LENGTH: 485 words


 

The state of Missouri currently has a model for the non-graded primary school.At Nike Elementary in Catawissa, students who have previously been bound to a traditional kindergarten-through-third-grade program are now offered a 3- , 4- or 5-year program. This non-graded approach allows teachers to move children through a continuous curriculum, allowing the developmental differences. The overall goal is to ensure that all children reach their academic potential. Although the non-graded program has been compared to the one-room schoolhouse, marked differences exist. Age groups and grades are clearly identified, and preset graded curriculums are taught year to year in a rigid format. As large numbers of students began to attend, school rooms were added to existing buildings, and the different grades were split apart. This more closely aligns the one-room concept to our traditional graded schools of today. Certainly much cross-age learning occurred. Younger pupils learned from listening to older classes, and older students having problems could listen as presentations were made to younger classes. Much peer tutoring was employed, both as a help for the teacher and because the children enjoyed working together. Today's non-graded program seeks to define sets of learner objectives that allow for developmental difference s of children. Learning strategies and materials to accommodate the flexible time provisions of non-graded classrooms can be varied and diverse. What they have in common is an understanding of how to determine when the child is academically ready to move from level to level. In a non-graded primary school, there is no repeating of a grade because of academic failure. Instead of retention, students are taught at a pace that ensures academic success and growth. A child may take five years to complete the traditional K-3 program, but it occurs by progressing through the primary levels at a slower pace. Teachers do not have to subvert the system to fit the child's needs but can use flexible time provisions to move a child at any time that child has met the academic criteria for each level. A three-year program is also offered at Nike allowing a student to accelerate through the program with academic successes. The curriculum is flexible, expanding to challenge all children. The developers of Nike's non-graded primary - myself, Barb Betz and Jean Wills - have broadened the curriculum to meet student needs. They have embraced a variety of teaching strategies including cooperative learning, cross-age tutoring, extensive use of volunteers, continuous assessment and mastery learning to help each child achieve academic successes. We have not addressed or cured all the problems that face our educational system, but we believe we have taken a step in the right direction. Karen M. Smith is a teacher at Nike Elementary School, Catawissa, Mo.


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

543 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


May 31, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Beachcombers are pumped up!


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1/ FRONT


LENGTH: 239 words


DATELINE: CANNON BEACH, Ore.


Beachcombers along the Pacific coast of the United States and Canada are scrambling to collect Nike running shoes - the result of a lost cargo of footwear washed overboard from a ship a year ago.

"I am wearing a pair now, and I love them," said Steve McLeod, an artist in Cannon Beach, Ore., who has collected 70 shoes, including 10 pairs. 

Local residents of this Pacific coast town 64 kilometres (40 miles) west of Portland said the spring tides deposited hundreds of Nike shoes along the coast.

The footwear apparently washed overboard from a cargo ship more than a year ago, according to the Beaverton, Ore., athletics sportswear company.

Nike transportation manager Rick Hastings said the shoes came from five large shipping containers that washed off a ship bound from South Korea to Seattle in May, 1990.

The containers held 40,000 pairs of Nike running shoes, golf shoes and hiking boots.

Hastings said the shoes have been found as far north as Vancouver Island in British Columbia.

"They have a little bit of seaweed on them and a few barnacles. But scrape that off and you have a standard pair of shoes," Hastings said.

"The only complaint I have received is that we didn't tie the pairs together, so they have to match them."

McLeod said beachcombers have formed the Sneaker Society which meets to swap shoes to come up with pairs. He said anyone who finds shoes on the beach is welcome to join.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

544 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


March 22, 1991 Friday


Career not Olver


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 616 words


THE ex-Socceroo tag doesn't sit kindly with Jeff Olver.

The Heidelberg goalkeeper, the No.1 choice for Australia between 1986-89, is determined to regain the Socceroo crown from Robert Zabica and John Filan.

Olver believes that at 30 he is still young in goalkeeping terms.

"If you look at the World Cup finals, you'll find the average age of the keepers is 35-36 with a few exceptions, like Zoff and Shilton, going well beyond that," Olver said. 

If form rather than age is the prerequisite for a spot in the national side, Olver has gone a long way towards staking a claim with his displays for Heidelberg.

"At the start of the season all the raves were about (St George keeper) Filan but I've looked for consistency rather than spectacular saves and I'm very pleased with my own form and the team's overall," he said.

Olver was singled out for praise by coach Len McKendry after his keeping ensured a 1-0 win over Wollongong Mac and the two points made certain Heidelberg finishes clear of the relegation zone.

"That match was our cup final," he said. "It was worth four points as a defeat would have dragged us back near the bottom two." Olver's performance against Wollongong Mac earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

He receives a pair of Nike Air runners worth $280. The overall winner receives $2000 from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award. Round 24. Votes. Apia v Syd Oly: 3 Stewart (al), 2 Hooker (so), 1 Ironside (so). Heidelberg v Woll Mac: 3 Olver (h), 2 Stubbins (h), 1 Jurin (wm). Marconi v Adelaide: 3 A.Vidmar (ac), 2 Maxwell (ac), 1 Zabica (ac). Melb Cro v Melita: 3 Biskic (mc), 2 O'Donell (me), 1 Soper (me). Preston v Sunshine: 2 Parton (pm), 2 Ketsakidis (sgc), 1 Trajanovski (pm), 1 Alevizos (sgc). St Geo v South Melb: 2 El Ali (stg), 2 Durakovic (sm), 1 Petersen (sm), 1 O'Shea (stg). Woll City v Syd Cro: 3 Hollifield (wc), 1 Green (wc), 1 Stanton (scr), 1 Gibson (scr). Apia v Syd Cro: 2 Stewart (al), 1 Krslovic (scr), 1 McQuarrie (scr), 1 Franken (scr), 1 Blagojevic (al).

Leaders: 18 Filan, Franken. 17 Clarkson, Petersen. 16 Blagojevic, Durakovic, P.Okon. 15 Biskic. 14 Herd, Ivanovic, Phillips, Stewart, Stubbins. 13 Bundalo, Gimenez, Kuc, Petkovic, A.Vidmar, 12 Davidson, Katholos, Kindtner, Lowe. 11 Jackson, Kupresak, McCulloch, Soper, Spink, Tsolakis. 10 Catlin, Cerro, C.Foster, Krslovic, Marth, Nowicki, Olver, Soper, Wade, Yankos.

Player of the week. Rd 24: Jeff Olver (h).

European Cup. Qtr Fnls. 2nd leg. Dynamo Dresden (Ger) 1 Red Star (Yug) 2, abandoned 82' crowd trouble, agg 1-5; Real Madrid (Sp) 1 Spartak (USSR), agg 1-3.Marseille (Fr) 1 Milan (It) 0, agg 2-1. Porto (Port) 0 Bayern 2 (Ger), agg 1-3.
