547 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Evening Standard (London)


July 20, 1992, Monday


THE OLYMPIC ALSO-RANS;
EVEN BEFORE THE FIRST RACE, SHOE SPONSORS ARE COUNTING THE COST OF PICKI THE WRONG TEAM


BYLINE: Colin Adamson


SECTION: Pg. 12


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

THE legendary Carl Lewis has boosted his £5 million-a-year earnings with a £1 million payment to advertise Japanese shoe producers Mizuno at next week's Barcelona Olympics.

His US colleague, decathlete Dan O'Brien, picked up another cool million from rival sport shoe manufacturers Reebok in a spectacular £12 million television advertising campaign.

German golden girl Katrin Krabbe was also paid a small fortune by market leaders Nike to sport their famous flash in Spain.

At the other end of the scale, Britain's Linford Christie, the fastest man in Europe, has a £60,000-a-year contract with Puma to show off their latest footwear at the Games. 

And gritty Scottish long-distance star, Liz McColgan, perhaps the best British gold medal prospect, has recently signed a £20,000-a-year shoe deal with Asics.

The payments are part of a £1 billion bonanza on offer at Barcelona as the world's running shoe firms and corporate giants search for stars to help them out of recession.

There is, however, an ironic difference between Christie and McColgan and their American rivals, not merely a financial one.

The British stars will be on their blocks and raring to go in the events that made their names. The mega-stars on whom the shoe people pinned most of their hopes and their dollar bills will not.

Lewis failed dismally in the US sprint trials and will not be defending his Olympic title in the race to find the fastest man on earth.

Fellow trials' flop O'Brien and Krabbe - 'emotionally exhausted' after finally winning a long, bitter fight to clear herself of drug test fiddling charges - will be going to Barcelona only as spectators.

In fact, the endorsement campaigns devised by the leading sport shoe companies, competing in a cut-throat battle for a world market valued at a staggering £10 billion, are in utter disarray.

To add to the general air of despondency, the final run-up to Barcelona has been littered with other big-name casualties, leaving embarrassed ad campaign directors in the industry in danger of entering the Marketing Hall of Shame.

Other major household names in athletics who have fallen at the final hurdle, through injury, personal problems and enforced early retirement include Daley Thompson, Steve Cram, Peter Elliott, Roger Kingdom and Mary Decker-Slaney.

As a result, a new air of caution has gripped major sports sponsors in Britain, marked by a flat refusal to invest in expensive network television marketing campaigns with any of our elite track and field athletes.

The distinct lack of real big money interest is further highlighted by the fact that not one of the members of the Chafford 100 club, set up by former world javelin champion Fatima Whitbread to look after elite athletes' commercial aspirations, features among the top 10 earners in British sport.

With personal sponsorship deals totalling just £1.5 million over the past 18 months for 17 of Britain's current crop of 24 elite athletes, they have emerged as the poor relations.

Even with handsome appearance fees, grand prix prize money, newspaper interviews, fashion fees and television appearances on programmes like A Question of Sport, none of our top Olympians is understood to have earned more than £250,000 over the past year.

In 1991 Peter Elliott was Britain's top athletics earner, making £160,000 (including a £20,000-per-year contract with Asics).

Linford Christie's total earnings over the same period were reported to be over £100,000, although since his world championships success he is believed to have more than doubled his money to take over top spot.

Other leading British earners include: javelin star Steve Backley, £150,000 (£55,000 from Adidas); Liz McColgan, £100,000; 400-metres Olympic medal hopeful Roger Black, £90,000-plus (£55,000 from Adidas); and Tom McKean, £80,000-plus (£20,000-per-year from New Ballance).

According to Fatima Whitbread, most of these shoe deals have at least doubled in the cases of medallists from the world championships, with £25,000 bonus clauses built in for major Olympic success.

The insulting fact that Britain's current crop of Olympic hopefuls appear to have been labelled also-rans in the major advertising stakes will, no doubt, spur them on to greater heights in their quest for Barcelona gold.

If further incentive is needed for them to fill the apparent mega-star void, they need only look back at the riches garnered by Britain's most famous athletic rivals, Coe and Ovett.

Sebastian Coe, the only man ever to win Olympic gold twice at the blue-riband 1,500 metres distance, bought a £1 million house in Twickenham with his earnings.

Steve Ovett went on to enjoy his semi-retirement from a 16-bedroom mansion near Annan in Scotland.

Had either been around today who knows what further fortunes would have lain in store? They might even have been up among the Faldos, Eubanks, Carsons and Gazzas in the earnings stakes.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: TOP ROW, FROM LEFT: MICHAEL JOHNSON, WITH NIKE, A HOT FAVOURITE FOR BARCELON LD; KATRIN KRABBE (EX-NIKE) AND DAN O'BRIEN (EX-REEBOK) BOTH SPECTATORS ONLY AT BARCELONA. BOTTOM ROW, FROM LEFT: LIZ MCCOLGAN, WITH ASICS, A GOLD MEDAL PROSPEC T, AND LINFORD CHRISTIE, WITH PUMA, BRITAIN'S MAIN SPRINT HOPE


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Associated Newspapers Ltd.

 

549 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 5, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Nike takes scholarly approach to new Indianapolis camp


BYLINE: Mark Coomes


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 8C


LENGTH: 377 words


Indianapolis, home of the world's most famous auto race, has a new claim to fame: the Nike A.B.C.D. (Academic Betterment and Career Development) basketball camp, the USA's preeminent proving ground for high school stars.

Gentlemen, start your sneakers. The camp opens Friday and runs until the checkered flag drops Wednesday. 

Nike moved the camp when it became apparent it had outgrown Princeton University, its home since 1983. With its basketball pedigree, Indianapolis was an easy choice.

The Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis campus is adjacent to the National Institute for Fitness and Sport.

About 120 players are invited, at a cost to Nike of nearly $ 100,000. The roster reads like a who's who in high school basketball. Here's who Hoop Scoop magazine is listing as some of the top players to watch:

- Best player: California player of the year Jason Kidd, a 6-4 guard who averaged 25 points and 10 rebounds last season for Alameda St. Joseph Notre Dame.

- Best big man: Mississippi player of the year Othello Harrington, a 6-9 center who averaged 29 points and 19 rebounds for Jackson Murrah.

- Best junior: A toss-up between 7-foot Rashard Griffith of Chicago King and 6-10 Rasheed Wallace of Philadelphia Simon Gratz.

Nearly every major-college coach will be watching.

Camp academic director Frank DuBois says players spend only 40 minutes a day on basketball and about five hours on academics. After all, this is the Nike Academic Betterment and Career Development camp. ''We want these kids to know that there's more to life than basketball,'' DuBois says.
 
REINSTATED: Dennis Holthaus, the Cincinnati Aiken football coach fired last year for making a racial remark to black members of his team, must be reinstated and given back pay. Hamilton County (Ohio) Common Pleas Judge Norman Murdock said the Cincinnati Board of Education acted illegally in firing Holthaus, currently an assistant at Aiken.
 
REMATCH: Jasper (Texas) sprinter Bryan Bronson, Gatorade Circle of Champions Athlete of the Year, renews his rivalry with Wendell Gaskin of Kansas City (Kan.) Washington this weekend at Spokane, Wash. Gaskin beat Bronson in the 100 and 200 meters two weeks ago at the U.S. Junior Championships.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


HIGH SCHOOLS


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

556 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


September 23, 1992, Wednesday, City Edition


Courier signs big pact with Nike


BYLINE: DARRELL FRY


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 5C


LENGTH: 419 words


 

Jim Courier, the biggest bread-winner on the pro tennis tour this year, could  be on his way to owning the whole bakery.

Dade City's Courier, now ranked No. 2 after spending most of 1992 atop the  pyramid, has signed a reported six-year, $ 27-million endorsement contract with  Nike Inc. that takes effect Oct. 1, when his current five-year endorsement  deal with Diadora expires.

Nike officials won't confirm the figures, but Diadora advertising manager  Anne McIntosh said they are consistent with what has been floating around the  industry. 

If correct, the contract dwarfs the $ 4.14-million in prize money Courier  has earned during his five years on the pro tour (he's made a tour-leading  $ 1.55-million so far this year). He would be elevated into the same Madison  Avenue fraternity as Michael Jordan, Andre Agassi and Bo Jackson.

"We're delighted," said Dusty Kidd, public-relations manager for Nike's  tennis division. "He has a certain style unlike any other player, and he's a  supremely athletic guy and that fits in with what we like."

Courier is in Minneapolis with the U.S. Davis Cup team, which faces Sweden  in a semifinal match this weekend. He didn't return phone calls to his hotel  room.

It's a fat deal for an athlete who doesn't appear to have as marketable an  image as Jordan, Jackson, Agassi and Deion Sanders, all Nike clients. But Kidd  said the company was attracted to Courier by his on-court performance and his  clean-cut, wholesome personality.

"He likes traditional American things: red cars, red guitars and he wears  a cap. He's a real all-American guy," said Kidd, adding that athletes such as  Jordan can bring in $ 200-million in sales each year.

And you can expect to see him on your TV and in sports magazines in the  months to come, Kidd said. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., is putting together  a sizable advertising campaign for Courier, Kidd said.

Courier will be Nike's lead promoter of a new line of apparel called  Supreme Court, Kidd said. The line actually debuted last winter, but Nike  already has gotten some design input from Courier and plans to relaunch the  new line designed around Courier's image.

The tennis clothing and shoes will be dominated by the colors red, white  and khaki and feature pinstripes. The shoe, available now in stores, is called  Air Supreme Court, and comes in a low-top (suggested retail price $ 90) and  three-quarters-top model ($ 95), which is what Courier will play in. 


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO; Jim Courier.


Times Publishing Company

 

559 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


October 10, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Nike stands by magazine ad despite mental group's complaint


BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C11


LENGTH: 202 words


 

 Nike Inc. says it is standing by the approach it took in a magazine advertisement alluding to an athlete's inner voice despite complaints from an advocacy group that says it trivializes mental illness.

The Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, based in Albany, N.Y., has taken issue with the Nike ad that features football player Jerry Rice. 

The group said hearing voices is a symptom of schizophrenia, a serious and extremely common mental illness. More than 2 million young people will be struck by the disease this year, spokesperson Norma Weinerth said.

But that's not the kind of inner voice to which the ad referred, Nike spokesperson Dusty Kidd said. Rather, he said, it was meant to be inspirational.

The ad begins: "Mother and father told you repeatedly. Crazy people talk to themselves. Still you heard the voice. Loud and clear. Just Do It.

"Learn how to hit a fastball. Work on your left hand shot. Study harder. Study longer. Get a raise."

It concludes: "Crazy people talk to themselves. And finally, you realize, only a madman doesn't listen."

Alliance members complained the ad is a flippant reference to mental illness to sell shoes.

ASSOCIATED PRESS


LOAD-DATE: October 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

560 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


October 10, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Nike stands by magazine ad despite mental group's complaint


BYLINE: Associated Press


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C11


LENGTH: 207 words


 
   Nike Inc. says it is standing by the approach it took in a magazine advertisement alluding to an athlete's inner voice despite complaints from an advocacy group that says it trivializes mental illness.

The Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, based in Albany, N.Y., has taken issue with the Nike ad that features football player Jerry Rice. 

The group said hearing voices is a symptom of schizophrenia, a serious and extremely common mental illness. More than 2 million young people will be struck by the disease this year, spokesperson Norma Weinerth said.

But that's not the kind of inner voice to which the ad referred, Nike spokesperson Dusty Kidd said. Rather, he said, it was meant to be inspirational.

The ad begins: "Mother and father told you repeatedly. Crazy people talk to themselves. Still you heard the voice. Loud and clear. Just Do It.

"Learn how to hit a fastball. Work on your left hand shot. Study harder. Study longer. Get a raise."

It concludes: "Crazy people talk to themselves. And finally, you realize, only a madman doesn't listen."

Alliance members complained the ad is a flippant reference to mental illness to sell shoes.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

563 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 18, 1992, Wednesday, City Edition


Up to 40,000 Nikes wash ashore in Ore.


SOURCE: London Observer Service


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 448 words


 

This strange story began on May 27, 1990, when a storm struck the freighter  Hansa Carrier as it crossed the Pacific from Korea to the United States. The  freighter survived, but its shipment of Nike shoes was washed overboard. Not a  sole was saved. 

The incident was forgotten until that November, when Nike shoes began  appearing along the shores of Oregon.

Large hiking boots, high-top athletic shoes and other styles began to bob  landwards, at first in ones and twos, then in scores, eventually in the  thousands. To the incredulity of locals, the beaches were swamped with shoes  of many colors.

Over the past two years, up to 40,000 shoes have washed ashore.

Within weeks after the shoes started to wash up, a thriving new local  economy was created. Beachcombers held swap-meets to exchange right and left  shoes, then resold them in pairs.

They've made a fortune selling the shoes, and buyers have been pleased with  their bargains.

"I got my pair for $ 20," said James Ingraham. "That's about a quarter of  the price I would have paid in a store.

"Admittedly, they had spent a year sloshing about the Pacific, but after  I'd worn them a couple of times they loosened up and are quite comfortable  now."

The fact that the shoes were still wearable after many months' battering by  storms and water would suggest Nike products have a certain weather-proofing  prowess, a quality that could well be marketed. It hasn't been.

"We contacted Nike, but they didn't want to know," said Ingraham. "Maybe  a beachcomber's recommendation is not quite the testimony that Nike was  seeking."

The longevity of the sports shoes has been useful in another way to  Ingraham, who is an oceanographer with the National Marine Fisheries Service.

Ingraham and colleague Curtis Ebbesmeyer began studying the shoes'  oceanographic peregrinations. The data provided by plotting the Nike armada's  progress has allowed them to test several complex theories about the detailed  mechanics of Pacific currents.

"It has been a real bonus to our work," Ingraham said.

With the data, Ingraham and Ebbesmeyer produced a lengthy paper for the  journal Transactions of the American Geophysical Union. They report that many  of the shoes appeared farther south than normally would have been expected for  flotsam borne by the tropical Pacific currents that head north to Alaska.

Now, as the currents have swept back out to sea from Oregon, the shoes have  been heading south and east. Already some have appeared on the shores of  Hawaii.

"The next stop is Japan," said Ingraham. "After that, they will start on  their second circle of the Pacific Ocean." 


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Times Publishing Company

 

566 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


May 30, 1991 Thursday


TRUTH & RUMOURS WILLIAM HOUSTON'S WORLD OF SPORTS Walking re-treads


BYLINE: WILLIAM HOUSTON; GAM


LENGTH: 481 words


Julie Lewis of Portland, Ore., has a masters degree in bio-nutrition
and taught at a New England private college, which in no way explains how
she came up with the idea of manufacturing walking shoes from recycled
garbage. "I just liked the idea of creating something practical from
recycled material," said Lewis, whose creativity has resulted in other,
less successful, inventions. 

Lewis's walking shoes are made from recycled polypropylene, paper bags,
coffee filters, reclaimed tires, foam rubber and scrap metal. The idea for
the shoe came from conversations with tire recyclers and Nike founder Bill
Bowerman. The invention of a machine that weaves recycled polypropylene
made it possible. The first 5,000 pairs (they're called DejaShoes and
retail for $59 in the United States) are scheduled to reach the market
soon, she says. The company plans other styles, including a chukka boot
and a sandal.

Personal golf courses

Bo in new Nike ad

Bo Jackson, who is attempting to recover from a hip injury, will be at Major League Baseball's All-Star Game, at least on television. Nike will be introducing a new Jackson commercial, but won't say if it will be a continuation of the Bo Knows series. Nike has bought four minutes of ad times in CBS TV's July 9 broadcast and will use six spots during the game, including a 60-second commercial starring Jackson.

Jackson was released from his baseball contract with the Kansas City
Royals before the beginning of the season because of hip injuries suffered
during the National Football League season, when he plays for the Los
Angeles Raiders. He signed with the Chicago White Sox and may start
playing after the all-star break. For the past three years Nike has
started its back-to-school summer campaign with the July all-star game.

Ruth, Joe or Ruff?

Bob Fredette of the Rutland (Vt.) Daily Herald offers a baseball shaggy
dog story: A skid-row bum walks into a bar with his dog. "I don't have a
cent," the bum says to the bartender, but if my talking dog entertains
your customers awhile, will you give me a drink on the house?"

The bartender is curious, so he agrees.

"Dog," says the bum, "how did I feel when I got up this morning?"

"Ruff," the dog replies.

"Dog," says the bum, "what's on top of this bar?"

"Roof," says the dog.

"Dog," continues the bum, "who was the greatest baseball player of all
time?"

"Ruth," the dog barks.

The bartender has seen enough and throws the bum into the street.

The dog looks up at the bum and says, "Do you think I should have said
Joe DiMaggio?"

The last word

"To add injury to insult they show up wearing ties, their Rolexes and some even bring their cellular phones. They discuss the Dow Jones averages instead of batting averages." - Jerry Pritikin, 54, a Chicago Cubs Bleacher Bum, who warns that the outfield seats have been invaded by yuppies who care nothing about baseball but are there only to show off.


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1991 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

 

567 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


March 28, 1991 Thursday


Kelic hits peak form


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 495 words


IVAN KELIC is the strongest forward in the National Soccer League thi season and that's one of the reasons why he has become such a dangerous striker.

That is the claim of Alan Davidson, who has seen Kelic's development in his three seasons at Melbourne Croatia.

"We've got rugged defenders like Andrew Marth and George Hannah but in 50-50 clashes at training Marth has bounced off while Kelic has held his ground," Davidson said. 

"He's all brute strength now and that's made it hard for defenders to knock him off the ball.

Kelic equalled an NSL record on Sunday becoming only the second player to score six goals in one game.

His feat easily earned him the player of the week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

As the weekly winner he collects a pair of Nike Air runners worth $280.

Kelic, however, believes his teammates deserve most of the credit.

"It was the easiest game I've ever played in - I just stood up front and put the ball in the net," he said.

"After I scored the third from a penalty, there was a real chance of becoming the league's top scorer and my teammates started playing to me." Kelic has been working on weights in the gym three times a week."I've felt much stronger and that too has helped in the confidence." he said.

His goals this season have raised suggestions of a place in the Socceroo squad but Kelic is not getting carried away.

"The main priority is to help Melbourne Croatia make the grand final and win it. If I was to get a call-up from Eddie Thomson, it would be a bonus," he said.

Kelic is the fourth player to win the award twice this season. With one round left, anyone from eight can win.

Apart from the weekly award of Nike Air runners, the overall winner receives $2000 from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award. Round 25: Votes - Heidelberg v Syd Cro: 3 Stanton (scr), 2 Petkovic (scr), 1 Stubbins (h). Marconi v Sth Melb: 3 Trimboli (sm), 1 Katholos (m), 1 Petersen (sm), 1 Okon (m).Melb Cro v Woll Mac: 3 Kelic (mc), 2 Biskic (mc), 1 Caleta (mc). Melita v Adelaide C: 2 Genc (me), 2 Vial (me), 2 Callanan (me). St Geo v Sunshine: 3 Moffitt (stg), 2 Kindtner (sgc), 1 Harper (stg). Preston v Syd Oly: 2 Barrett (so), 2 Parton (pm), 2 Ironside (pm). Woll City v Apia: 3 Hollifield (wc), 2 Yankos (wc), 1 Bundalo (al).

Leaders: 18 Filan, Franken, Petersen. 17 Biskic, Clarkson, P. Okon.16 Blagojevic, Durakovic, 15 Petkovic, 14 Bundalo, Herd, Ivanovic, Kindtner, Phillips, Stewart, Stubbins.13 Gimenez, Katholos, Kuc, A.Vidmar, 12 Davidson, Lowe, Yankos. 11 Jackson, Kupresak, McCulloch, Parton, Soper, Spink, Tsolakis. 10 Catlin, Cerro, C.Foster, Krslovic, Marth, Nowicki, Olver, Soper, Wade.

KELIC may be credited with an extra goal. Croatia is claiming he scored two goals in the fourth round match against Apia not one as the referee recorded.

NSL general manager Peter Russell said video tape of the goal will be viewed shortly.

END OF STORY

GRAPHIC: Six of the best . . . Ivan Kelic certainly made his presence felt onSunday. Picture: CRAIG BORROW


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

570 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 25, 1992, Wednesday


BASEBALL Despite woes, Bo's dough still grows


BYLINE: By Jeff Schultz STAFF WRITERsports; personalities; fashion; earnings; advertising


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 5


LENGTH: 330 words


While doctors from Tijuana to Bangor, Maine, continue their game of prognosis roulette, it might interest those speculating about Bo Jackson's financial future that the wallet is getting fatter. Still.

"No, Nike hasn't dropped him, and, yes, he's still alive and well," Suzanne McKee, Jackson's business manager, said Tuesday before the question was asked. "He's going to Los Angeles Sunday to shoot a new Nike commercial. It's going to be with a comedian, but I can't discuss it beyond that." 

The script may be a secret but Jackson's endorsement status isn't. Nike, his major source of income, is designing another new campaign around him, despite the fact his future as an athlete is in doubt. (McKee did offer the obvious: that the commercial will deal with his rehabilitation from a hip injury.) There also are ongoing deals with Pepsi, "BoMed" sports medicine products (which is expanding distribution to Japan), Tiger Electronics games and Franklin Sports equipment.

Jackson generally commands multi-year deals and least a half-million dollars annually per endorsement, according to Nova Langtree, president of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago, though the Nike deal is well into seven figures.

Langtree, who assesses the marketability of sports stars, said Jackson's status could dip a year from now if he can't make a comeback with the Chicago White Sox. But she added, "As a spokesperson, he's gone so far beyond what is normal. And because of Nike and how cutting-edge [its campaigns] are, there's going to be a second round of drama after the surgery. We might see a bionic man thing."

McKee, who heads the newly formed "Bo Jackson Enterprises" in Mobile, said 1991 was Jackson's biggest year in terms of endorsement dollars despite his playing in only 23 games for the White Sox and that 1992 will match that.

"It ain't over - there's no fat lady singing," said McKee. "Look, Nike's named buildings after Bo. They're not going to just drop him."


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

572 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


February 7, 1991 Thursday


Marth adds starch to title chase


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 382 words


RUGGED defender Andrew Marth yesterday admitted he has not yet hit his best form despite the recent media clamor for his inclusion in the Socceroos.

The switch by Marth to a double centre-back role has helped Melbourne Croatia challenge for the NSL championship and earned praise from national coach Eddie Thomson who said the defender was on the verge of a call-up.

Thomson took note of how Marth and George Hannah blotted out Warren Spink last Sunday. Only days earlier Spink had troubled Czechoslovakia with his sharpness and confidence to take defenders on. 

Marth also took the free kick which led to the winning goal against Preston Makedonia.

While Marth concedes that his form is improving, he believes he has played better in the NSL.

"My second season at Sunshine George Cross (in 1988) was my best season and I ended up being the club's player of the year," Marth said yesterday.

"I still think I haven't played as well since although this season is now shaping up to go close."

Marth is now part of Melbourne Croatia's ambitious charge for the title.

"The change of coach (at Melbourne Croatia) has made a big difference. Ken Worden has a playing style similar to John Gardiner (Marth's coach at Sunshine) and I'm enjoying the freedom to play the ball out of the back (rather than kicking long balls)," he said.

The defender's performance earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

As the weekly winner, Marth collects a pair of Nike Air runners.

The overall winner receives $2000 in cash from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award.

Round 18. Votes. Melita v Apia: 3 Stewart (al), 2 Hughes (al), 1 Gimenez (me). Syd Oly v South Melb: 3 Wade (sm), 1 Barrett (so), 1 Phillips (so), 1 Trimboli (sm). Adel City v Sunshine: 3 Clarkson (sgc), 2 Hasler (sgc), 1 Ivanovic (ac). Marconi v Woll City: 3 Katholos (m), 2 Markovski (m), 1 Kuc (wc). Woll Mac v Syd Cro: 3 Kupresak (scr), 2 Murray (wm), 1 Franken (scr).Heidelberg v St Geo: 3 Bordignon (h), 2 Herd (h), 1 Koczka (stg). Melb Cro v Preston: 3 Marth (mc), 2 Traianedes (pm), 1 Parton (mc).

Leaders: 17 Filan. 15 Petersen. 14 Clarkson, P.Okon. 13 Bundalo, Petkovic. 12 Stubbins.

Player of the week. Rd 18: Kimon Taliadoros (sm).

St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


March 22, 1991, FRIDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


ST. LOUIS MOOG AUTOMOTIVE COREY IS NAMED DIVISION PRESIDENT


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Moog Automotive Inc. has appointed John C. Corey president of the newly formedMoog Steering and Suspension Division, which will handle the company's chassis business. Executives with Moog, a St. Louis-based maker of auto parts, said the new division will concentrate on steering and suspension products for vehicles. Another division handles the company's temperature control business. Corey was formerly senior vice president for finance and administration. Corey will report to Larry W. McCurdy, president and chief executive officer of the company. U.S. NATIONAL BANK Geoghegan Named President, CEO Dennis J. Geoghegan has been named president and chief executive of U.S. National Bank of Clayton, the company said Thursday. U.S. National opened in 1988 and has $26 million in assets. Geoghegan was vice chairman of Mark Twain Bancshares' Ellisville bank in charge of generating new business. MISSOURI FOOD BARN Official Says Business Returning Business dropped by about 18 percent during the first couple weeks of a strike that began March 3 but has since started to come back, a Food Barn official said in Kansas City. P.A. Rawalt, Food Barn's vice president of human resources, said the company's business had increased by about 9.5 percent two weeks ago and another 3 percent last week. The union, United Food and Commercial Workers Local 576, has claimed business is down by 75 percent. Rawalt also said 1,048 employees have crossed the union picket lines, which couldn't be immediately confirmed by union officials. The local represents about 2,500 Food Barn employees, about 2,100 of them union members, at 47 stores in Missouri and Kansas, most in the Kansas City area. The union members went on strike after soundly rejecting a new contract that would have required about $18 million in concessions over three years. Rawalt said Food Barn is the only remaining unionized grocery in the Kansas City area and can't continue to compete. AP ILLINOIS CATERPILLAR INC. 195 Employees To Be Laid Off Caterpillar Inc. said Thursday that 195 hourly employees will be laid off indefinitely from the company's Peoria-area plants, effective April 1. The layoffs are necessary to bring production of diesel engines in line with demand, according to a statement from the company. Caterpillar is the world's largest manufacturer of tractors and other earth-moving equipment. It employed about 60,000 people overall as of mid-1990. AP NATIONAL L.A. GEAR Rival Nike Sued In 'Sneaker War' L.A. Gear Inc. Thursday launched a counter-offensive in the ''sneaker war,'' firing a $3 billion lawsuit at rival Nike Inc. that charged it with trying to monopolize the market for high-tech sneakers and drive L.A. Gear out of the business. The countersuit was filed after Nike, the nation's largest marketer of athletic footwear, last month sued L.A. Gear for alleged patent infringement. In its countersuit, L.A. Gear said it believes Nike is trying to monopolize the high-technology basketball shoe market and eliminate L.A. Gear as a major competitor. Los Angeles-based L.A. Gear also said its countersuit denies that its new CATAPULT shoe technology infringes any Nike patents. In its suit, filed in federal court in California on Feb. 15, Nike had alleged that six models of basketball shoes sold by L.A. Gear infringe on patents for Nike's Air Jordan shoes. Reuters FDIC Bank Insurance Fund Shrank 37 The nation's bank insurance fund shrank 37 percent last year and will probably need to borrow $10 billion this year to keep bailing out depositors of failed banks, a top banking regulator said Thursday. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the FDIC's fund suffered an operating loss of $4.85 billion in 1990. ''To be conservative and to ensure that we have the funds we need on time, we will need, we believe, at least $10 billion this year and that could be higher if we experience conditions worse than we currently are forecasting,'' Seidman said. He also warned that the fund may have to borrow $35 billion by the end of 1993 - part of a new Treasury proposal that would let it borrow up to $70 billion to protect depositors. Reuters INTERNATIONAL AVIATION EC Asks For New Trade Agreement The European Community, locked in a dispute with Washington on whether its subsidies on Airbus aircraft violate free trade rules, asked Thursday for a new trade agreement to make clear what government support was allowed. It asked the Civil Aircraft Committee of the 101-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to renegotiate GATT's Civil Aircraft Code to clarify the matter and avoid such disputes, a trade source said. The United States charges that European subsidies to the four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium unfairly cut into the market of Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. The EC, in turn, says military contracts give American aircraft companies an unfair advantage. Reuters


LOAD-DATE: October 8, 1993

SUNDAY MAIL (QLD)


February 16, 1992 Sunday


THE SOUVENIR T-SHIRT


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: STEAD G


LENGTH: 177 words


THE souvenir T-shirt, always one of the most popular items during American basketball's All-star weekend, became significant this year for what was not printed on it.

T-shirts traditionally carry caricatures of the game's 10 starters. 

The late inclusion of Earvin ""Magic" Johnson to the Western Conference team seemingly would have meant an extra face. But not so.

Missing was the likeness of Eastern Conference star Michael ""Air" Jordan, who has an exclusive apparel contract with Nike.

After months of wrangling, Nike told the National Basketball Association it can no longer sell any clothes bearing the image or name of the Chicago Bulls star.

Jordan is only the beginning. Nike intends notifying the NBA of 88 other players under contract who cannot be used in any way to generate merchandising funds.

While the NBA expects to drop at least $1 million as a result of Nike's stance, it is not overly concerned.

The association's marketing arm is a $2 billion-a-year business of which only a small portion is generated from clothing.


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: SML


Copyright 1992 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

578 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


August 2, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Reebok ads 'play hard'


BYLINE: Martha T. Moore


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 275 words


Reebok International Ltd. wants advertising that's as hot as its shoes.

Its new ad campaign goes toe-to-toe with rival Nike Inc. in the pithy advice department. The first ad, airing during Monday Night Football, shows a ''sky surfer'' - a white-clad sky diver riding a snow board - somersaulting above the French Alps in his Pump cross-training shoes. The theme: ''Life is short. Play hard.''

Reebok, which will spend $ 25 million on the campaign, scored with the Pump - 4 million pairs sold in 18 months - and its Blacktop outdoor basketball shoes. Second-quarter revenue rose 30% over 1990. The company commands 24% of $ 6 billion-a-year athletic -shoe market to Nike's 30%.

But when it comes to great ads, Nike has gotten all the airtime. Their star-filled ads are virtual news events and their slogans - from ''Just do it'' to ''Bo knows'' - quickly become buzzwords. Meanwhile, Reebok has suffered a depressing series of gaffes: Its wacky ''U.B.U.'' series flopped and a bungee-jumping ad was yanked last year for implying a Nike wearer fell to his death.

''Nike has known for a long time what they stand for,'' says Dick Sittig, new creative director of ad agency Chiat/Day/
Mojo New York, which lost the account after the bungee spot but won it back this year. ''They've had the advantage of getting a head start.''

The Pump's success lets Reebok present itself as a serious sports shoe. Earlier ads talked form at the expense of performance, says David Ropes, vice president of marketing. ''It's like we were a teenager, we were feeling our oats. We're still a teenager, but now we know what we want to be when we grow up.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; color
 
CUTLINE: 'LIFE IS SHORT': One ad in new $ 25 million Reebok campaign shows woman pounding tennis balls, one with the image of her boss' face.


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

581 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 26, 1991, Tuesday


COLLEGE ATHLETICS; Schultz: Coaches need help; Says schools are better at negotiating TV deals


BYLINE: By David Davidson Staff writersports; personnel; colleges; salaries; advertising; negotiations; contracts


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 04


LENGTH: 335 words


A coach shouldn't worry about losing money if his school takes over negotiating his outside-income contract, according to NCAA executive director Dick Schultz, who handled that chore for his staff when he was athletics director at Virginia.

"Our coaches made more money because I was a better negotiator than they were," Schultz said at the NCAA's recent annual football forum in Kansas City, Mo.

Schultz said Virginia in 1982 became the first school to turn the negotiating of coaches' TV/radio contracts and other deals over to the athletics department. Other schools using the practice include Clemson, Florida State, Florida and Kentucky. 

Athletics director Vince Dooley is instituting a similar policy at Georgia and strongly hinted that it would be expanded to include shoe contracts.

Schultz and Dooley predict the consolidation of outside-income contracts will become a national trend.

"The college presidents feel more comfortable with it coming under the university and the control of the athletics department," Dooley said.

Schultz said Virginia had contracts with three shoe manufacturers, and teams other than football and basketball benefited from those contracts.

Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham is paid $ 40,000 annually for endorsing Nike shoes and $ 40,000 to do speeches and clinics for the shoe company - plus $ 2,000 in merchandise. Football coach Ray Goff last year received $ 21,250 from Nike.

However, total school control of shoe contracts for Georgia coaches will have to wait until 1996; Durham recently signed a five-year extension to his contract with Nike, which was due to expire in August.

Durham will continue to be paid the same amount throughout the five- year extension period ($ 80,000 annually plus merchandise).

Durham said he was more interested in a long-term deal with Nike than a substantial increase in dollars because he foresees cutbacks in the number of schools and coaches who receive shoe contracts in coming years.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

583 of 998 DOCUMENTS


THE OILMAN


October, 1991


Hydraulics firm launches rams and rescue kit


SECTION: SWEDEN; Pg. 119


LENGTH: 398 words


A range of stainless steel rams designed to withstand the most arduous operating conditions was introduced to the UK at Offshore Europe by Nike.

The company, Scandinavia's largest manufacturer of high pressure hydraulics, also used the Aberdeen show to launch its Reflex lightweight helicopter rescue kit, which offers separate tools for heavy cutting, pushing, and cutting in confined spaces.

"Offshore Europe provided our first opportunity to display a selected range of high pressure, heavy duty hydraulic equipment," says Hall Smith, president of Nike Hydraulics Ltd, of Burnley, Britain. In addition, Nike's display embraced pumps for manual, air, and electrical operation as well as hydraulic cutting equipment. 

"Nike has been in the hydraulic business for more than 60 years, originally as a supplier of products for the automotive industry," says Mr Smith. "It has gradually moved into products employed in heavy industries like mining, steel, pulp, paper, and the offshore sector."

The acquisition in 1988 of Bahco, Sweden's second largest manufacturer of power tools, can be seen as a significant step in this expansion process. Bahco had long historical links with the oil industry, both offshore and on land, and its range of heavy lift rams had a good reputation amongst fabricators.

The new ram range presented in Aberdeen offers the same performance as the established CXA range used in heavy fabrication yards, combined with enhanced corrosion resistance due to its stainless steel construction.

The Reflex rescue kit has been developed from Bahco's original range of rescue tools, and can be used either individually or simultaneously by up to three operators. It supplements existing heavy duty rescue tools currently supplied by Nike for offshore duties. Cutting and spreading tools, have been modified for subsea operation by remotely operated vehicles.

Since the Bahco acquisition, says Mr Smith, a great deal of rationalisation has taken place in the Nike product range, supplemented by the introduction of new tools. "This has given the company one of the most comprehensive lines on the market," he argues.

Standard rams can now be offered with capacities up to 250 tonnes, while low height, spring return rams are available with up to 200 tonnes capacity, and a range of specialist hand pumps, developing pressure up to 2,800 bar (40,000 psi).


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Picture, The Reflect lightweight rescue kit from Nike is designed for helicopter use and provides separate tools for heavy cutting and pushing in confined spaces.


Copyright 1991 PENNWELL PUBLISHING COMPANY

 

585 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Marketing News TM


September 16, 1991


Nike's vision of the ultimate store includes fantasy


BYLINE: by the Associated Press


SECTION: Pg. 9


LENGTH: 623 words


DATELINE: Portland, Ore.


Nike Inc. sells a lot of shoes at its store in hometown Portland, but it also gives something away: fantasy.

Its Nike Town is a theatrical presentation, a glittering production number starring the customers.

"People love to shop. It's kind of entertainment, a social thing," manager Mary Burns said. "Let's make it even more fun for them . . ." 

Outside in downtown Portland are the sights, sounds, and smells of rush-hour traffic, intent pedestrians, fastfood restaurants.

But inside Nike Town, you can relax in the tranquility of an open town square, with the sounds of birds chirping. The square, like the atrium of a suburban mall, is surrounded by two levels of separate shopping areas for different Nike products.

Light from a huge sparkling billboard highlights the uneven texture of brick walls and pavement and shines off manhole covers.

"Isn't it something?" says customer Vernette Stowers. "I drove all the way from Seattle. My daughter is a Nike fan."

"I don't think we meant to come up with some incredible turning point in retail or anything," said Nike Town designer Gordon Thompson. "We wanted to come up with a store that accurately represented our company and it happened to be this.

"The funniest thing is, I knew we were doing something unusual in architecture and design and in retail, but it seems to me it sort of has a life of its own now."

In a half-hour on a recent afternoon, the store's greeter counted 200 people entering the store. On weekends, it's even busier.

"We are averaging on a Saturday up to about 4,000-5,000 people," said Cathy Taylor, vice president of retail for Nike, based in suburban Beaverton.

"The last two Sunday mornings I've had 75 people in line waiting to get into the store at 11:30," Burns said.

Thompson, an architect by training, worked in industrial and interior design before coming to Nike. He said he always had "a big admiration for set designers and movies."

His fascination took him to Universal Studios in Hollywood, where he visited sound stages and the Back to the Future set, which features a town square.

"I started sketching on the way back," he said.

The retail areas surrounding the square highlight each collection with separate character.

A basketball area has wooden truss ceilings and a wooden basketball court floor. A recording and speakers beneath the raised floor subtly fill the space with the hollow bounce of basketballs and shoes squeaking on the court.

Bright tropical fish swim around shoes from the Aqua Gear collection in vertical, cylindrical tanks. Nine large TV screens set in the floor form a sort of video pond, in which customers can watch seaweed swaying among the coral on the floor of a warm ocean.

To keep inventory from cluttering the sales area, shoes are stored a floor below. Shoes of the desired style, size, and color can be called up from the stockroom at a moment's notice by computer. They arrive in a basket on a conveyor that moves up through a transparent plastic tube.

"It came from The Jetsons," Thompson said, referring to the futuristic cartoon series.

Neither Burns nor Taylor would provide sales figures, but Burns said the store, since opening in November 1990, "did exactly what we wanted it to."

Response has been so strong, Nike plans a larger store in Chicago, taking over the old Saks Fifth Avenue location. The Chicago store will contain about 33,000 square feet of retail space, compared with Portland's 7,000 square feet, and its town square will be five stories tall, Taylor said. It is scheduled to open next May.

Taylor said Nike also is looking at two sites in New York. She said plans call for two Nike Towns to open each year in "major areas of the world."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo, The Nike store in Portland sells more than shoes. It's a glittering production of the Nike mystique, featuring a high-flying Michael Jordan and an iron-pumping Bo Jackson. AP Laserphoto


Copyright 1991 American Marketing Association

 

586 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Business Times (Singapore)


A town like Nike's


November 5, 1992


Helen Chang


The US sports shoe and apparel maker has gone to town with a store concept that combines hi-tech gadgetry with environmental design to produce a sort of Disneyland and Hard Rock Cafe of the athletics world, says Helen Chang

ON a downtown street corner, in the small city of Portland, Oregon, is a store that opens into another world.

Step into the darkened porch, then through the black sliding doors, and you enter a marketing marvel -Nike Town.

Inside is a "town square" lined with boutiques on all sides. Above the square, a white plaster statue of US basketball star Michael Jordan leaps through the air, while to the left, a balcony overlooks the scene. 

Nike Town combines hi-tech gadgetry with environmental design to produce a sort of Disneyland and Hard Rock Cafe of the athletics world. Conceived as a gallery to sell the latest lines of Nike shoes and clothing under one roof, it demonstrates how a store's atmosphere is as much a marketing tool as the products themselves.

The atmosphere in Nike Town is like a theatre stage. Dark and light shadows canvass the various boutiques. Environmental music -the sounds of chirping birds and running streams -- fills the air.

Even the store hours are offbeat: Monday to Thursday 10am -7.01pm; Friday 10am -8pm; Saturday 10am -6.52pm; Sunday 11.25am -6.23pm.

Nike Town is the flagship store of the US sports shoe and apparel maker, whose worldwide headquarters -directing operations in the US, Europe and Asia -are at Beaverton, about a 20- minute drive from Portland.

Nike will not say how much revenue the store brings in, or how much it cost to build, but it is repeating the concept elsewhere.

A second Nike Town opened recently in Chicago and there plans to create up to eight more in the US in the next decade. Nike also plans to spread the chain to Europe, but there are no current plans for Asia.

Already, the Portland store has developed a cult following. Out-of-state teenagers come to see memorabilia displays to check what a favourite athlete wore during a certain game. Others sit at video displays by the half-hour. And Japanese tourists make their way to Portland just to see the store.

"We wanted to create product excitement," said store manager Jeff Nichols, about the reasons for Nike Town's design. "We wanted to make an exciting place (for customers) to look at our products."

During a recent interview, Nike founder and chief executive officer Philip Knight said: "One of the key things we try to do is to create an emotional tie with a product."

Launched in 1990, Portland's Nike Town has floor space of 15,000 sq ft, about the size of a supermarket. It draws some 40,000 visitors a year, split equally between locals and tourists.

Each of the store's 14 boutiques highlights a different sport or theme -such as running, cycling, tennis or kids' wear -with decor and furniture to match.

A boutique for Nike's line of hiking and mountain-climbing shoes and clothes, called All Conditions Gear, features a backdrop that changes from day to night, including a shimmering sunrise which turns to stars against a black sky. Display shelves are made from rock-climbing wires and pegs, and the floor is made from slate rock.

Another boutique, containing Nike's "Aqua-Gear", includes an aquarium window filled with bright tropical fish. Outside the aquarium, balanced on horizontal wire lines, are mesh shoes -used for walking on reefs -whose bright colours match those of the fish.

In the same room, surfboards protruding from the walls double as shelves, while a video "pool" on the floor shows footage of running water and coral reef life.

The store also serves as a mini sports museum, with displays of sporting memorabilia spread throughout. One panel features the different shoes worn by basketball star Michael Jordan in various national tournaments.

"People will just come in and read the memorabilia," said sales associate Hal Melhart. "They'll come in here for two hours, before they realise they can shop."

Sales staff don't spend much time getting the apparel from the shelves -small, hi-tech lifts do that. Instead, sales assistants are encouraged to "educate" visitors about Nike products.

Some say the fervour of Nike Town's employees -everyone is involved in some kind of sport -can be overwhelming. And retailing experts say the marketing efforts do not necessarily add up to more sales, since many visitors do not buy. At the day's end, they say, it's quality that will sell the products, not gimmicks.

But Nike says its stores provide what today's customers want: fun. And in a way that is fast becoming a slice of Americana.


SECTION: Advertising & Marketing 1; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 1440 words


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Inside Nike Town: The company says its stores provide what today's customers want -fun


Copyright 1992 Times Business Publications

 

588 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


August 3, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION


USOC says clothing controversy over


BYLINE: Steve Woodward; Greg Boeck


SECTION: BONUS; Pg. 5E


LENGTH: 431 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA


The official Olympic motto is:

A. Just Do It.

B. Citius. Altius. Fortius.

C. Life Is Short. Play Hard.

The answer depends on whom you ask. The International Olympic Committee stands by B, Latin for faster, higher, stronger. 

But in the marketing-crazed world of sports that is unavoidably married to the modern Games, mass-media advertising campaigns have sought to condition consumers to pick A (Nike) or C (Reebok).

Which brings us to Michael Jordan's wardrobe quandary.

He is under contract, for a reported $ 20 million, to endorse Nike and its Air Jordan shoes and related accessories.

Jordan had said he was considering not taking part in a medal ceremony if he had to wear a Reebok uniform. Reebok is the official supplier to the U.S. Olympic Committee and paid to have all U.S. Olympians wear Reebok suits on the award stand.

Jordan and five other basketball Olympians have contracts with Nike.

USOC executive director Harvey Schiller said Sunday that the flap - which might have meant no Jordan and others on the medal stand if the team wins the gold - is a ''non-issue. We have a deal.'' He wouldn't elaborate.

Said Jordan: ''I don't know anything about it, but if it's true, that's good.''

Said NBA Commissioner David Stern: ''The matter of who wears what when is going to be resolved, and I'm sure we'll have all 12 players up there.''

While Nike and Reebok are maintaining low profiles in the Jordan case, it has magnified the role of sponsors and Olympic commercialism.

Sports administrators and corporate marketing officials contend brand- name exposure is a natural and necessary byproduct that rewards huge investments by footwear manufacturers and other sponsors. ''Michael Jordan is not the problem; he earns a substantial living with or without endorsements,'' says Liz Dolan, Nike's vice president for corporate communication.

''The people for whom (no money) would be a problem are the ones whose sponsors really support them.''

Dolan says Nike does not object to Jordan making a brief appearance in Reebok's USA suit to accept an Olympic medal because ''that's ceremonial garb, and that's not the business we're in anyway.''

Should Jordan follow through on his pledge to boycott the medal ceremony and snub the Reebok outfit, don't expect a Reebok counterattack. You probably won't hear so much as a peep.

''That doesn't have any impact on Reebok,'' says John Boulter, vice president of worldwide marketing for Reebok International Ltd.

''But I would feel sorry for any athlete who did that. It would be a shame if it ended like that.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


'92 SUMMER OLYMPICS BONUS SECTION


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

591 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


February 15, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Nike stock trips on analysts' estimates


BYLINE: james Kim; Pat Guy


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 391 words


Questions surrounding Nike Inc.'s future earnings let some air out of its stock Thursday. The maker of Air Jordan and other pricey athletic shoes dropped 4 1/4 to $ 46 5/8 after two analysts scaled back their quarterly and yearly earnings estimates for the company.

Shearson Lehman Bros. analyst Josie Esquivel shaved her third-quarter estimate to 92 cents a share from $ 1. For the year ending in May, she cut her estimate to $ 4 a share from $ 4.13. Montgomery Securities analyst Alice Ruth cut her estimate to 95 cents a share from $ 1.10 for the third quarter and to $ 3.85 from $ 4 for the year. Both cited a 33% drop in Nike's ''refill'' orders for the third quarter. Refill orders are spot orders from retailers to shore up their inventories. 

Still, Esquivel says the soft market for athletic shoes that cost more than $ 100 a pair will be temporary. She ''strongly reiterated'' her buy recommendation. But Kidder, Peabody & Co. analyst Gary Jacobson says Nike is facing a period of slow growth. With the slack economy, ''we're beginning to see customers shift away from high-priced footwear to lower priced shoes,'' he says. ''In a tough retail environment, if you have a high-priced item, you'll likely have problems.''

He recommends shunning Nike stock in favor of arch-competitor Reebok International, which fell 1/4 to $ 17 5/8 Thursday. He thinks more modestly priced shoes such as Reebok's Freestyle and Princess lines are poised for higher sales in a less ostentatious decade.

Profit-taking Time: Buoyed all week on rumors of an imminent deal to sell portions of its entertainment businesses, Time Warner Inc. lost 4 3/4 to $ 110 3/4 a share as traders took profits. The stock had soared 17 1/2 points (17.9%) since Monday; 43 5/8 points (65%) since Oct. 11.

''Hope springs eternal with Time Warner stock,'' says analyst Peter Appert of Cyrus J. Lawrence. The hope: A deal will surface to help alleviate some of the load of $ 10.6 billion in debt the company is carrying.

Time Warner has been saying for more than a year that it is talking with potential international and domestic partners who would buy an equity stake in Warner Bros. studio, Home Box Office cable TV channel or its cable TV unit. Speculation is that Toshiba Corp. of Japan and Canal Plus S.A. of France are interested.
- James Kim and Pat Guy


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Street Talk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

594 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


August 25, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


SPONSORSHIP


BYLINE: Jack Carey


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 203 words


 Nike, which makes athletic equipment, is negotiating to sponsor the Hogan Tour, a training ground for aspiring PGA Tour golfers. The Hogan Tour was founded in 1990 and named for Ben Hogan, whose golf equipment company underwrote it. The Ben Hogan Co. told the PGA Tour this year it could no longer finance the tour.
 
LION'S PAW: Sophomore Kerry Collins, Penn State's projected starting quarterback, will miss the first two games this season with an injured index finger on his throwing hand, coach Joe Paterno said Monday. ''Kerry got hurt before he reported. He was playing volleyball,'' Paterno said. (College notes, 9C)
 
ROUTS ARE ON: The NFL preseason weekend ended with two routs Monday night. Rich Gannon's 52-yard pass to Anthony Carter ended a 35-point first half and the Minnesota Vikings wiped out the Cleveland Browns 56-3. Also, the Kansas City Chiefs shut out the Buffalo Bills 35-0 as Dave Krieg passed for 160 yards and two touchdowns.
 
MAGIC 32: Rookie center Shaquille O'Neal will wear jersey No. 32 in his first season with the Orlando Magic. O'Neal, the first pick of the NBA draft, wore No. 33 at Louisiana State, but Magic forward Terry Catledge decided to keep No. 33.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportsline


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

596 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


September 23, 1991 Monday


NIKE JUMPS, LA VANISHES


BYLINE: MCKENNA J


SECTION: HERALD BUSINESS; Pg. 54


LENGTH: 143 words


NIKE is in no mood for a marathon. The athletic footwear company - whose advertisements feature basketball superstar Michael Jordan - is sprinting to the lead in the earnings race in what has become a very lucrative market. 

 Nike h$as just reported a 15 per cent jump in second-quarter earnings to a record $US114.4 million.

US sales rose 5 per cent and Wall Street is bullish about the company's future.

But troubled rival LA Gear is fading fast as mounting financial troubles are complicated by shrinking credit.

After becoming the third largest shoemaker in the US in four years, the company has losses of over $US4 million and was recently bought by Stanley Gold, a shrewd Californian known for restoring troubled companies.

Nevertheless, there are whispers that the company may soon be known as LA Disappear.

END OF STORY

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS

599 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


March 7, 1991 Thursday


Herd instinct proves right


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 404 words


IT HAS taken four years, but Heidelberg's Willie Herd has finally proved himself a quality player, justifying his reputation and excellent record in Scottish football.

Herd was a prize signing by Melbourne Croatia in 1987 after accepting an invitation to play here despite being firmly established in the Scottish first division.

The midfielder admitted yesterday the first two seasons turned into disasters after tearing a cartilage in the first game at his new club. 

"I went to Brunswick Juventus the season after and had a groin problem which again required an operation and ruled me out for the full season," Herd said yesterday.

"It was frustrating and inexplicable, especially since, in 10 years of senior football in Scotland, I hardly ever missed a game, and by the time I came here I had played over 300 league games." Herd broke into senior soccer as a 17-year-old with East Fife. He was transferred for $40,000 to Falkirk when he was 20, and three years later joined Partick Thistle.

"(Melbourne Croatia's) Paul Donnelly had accepted an offer to play in Perth at the time and he got in touch. I felt I could do with a change and, on his advice, chose to join an NSL club." Herd felt he had made the wrong move after the two serious injuries.

He scored his fifth for the season on Sunday against Melita Eagles to crown off a man-of-the-match performance which earned him the title of the player-of-the-week in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.As the weekly winner, Herd picks up a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280. The end of season winner earns $2000 from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award.

Round 22. Votes. Heidelberg v Melita: 3 Herd (h), 1 Cerro (me), 1 Olver (h), 1 Callanan (me). Preston M v South Melb: 3 Maclaren (sm), 2 Durakovic (sm), 1 Crino (pm). Sunshine v Syd Oly: 3 Phillips (so), 2 Lee (so), 1 Bernal (so). St Geo v Adelaide: 3 Maxwell (ac), 1 Veart (ac), 1 Ivanovic (ac), 1 Filan (stg).Woll City v Woll Mac: 3 Kay (wm), 1 Skeen (wc), 1 Naumov (wm), 1 Martin Bourke (wm).

Leaders: 18 Filan. 17 Clarkson. 16 P.Okon. 15 Blagojevic, Petersen.14 Franken, Ivanovic, Phillips. 13 Bundalo, Kuc, Petkovic. 12 Biskic, Durakovic, Katholos, Kindtner, Stubbins. 11 Gimenez, Jackson, Kupresak, Lowe, McCulloch, Spink, Tsolakis, 10 Catlin, C.Foster, Herd, Nowicki, Soper, A.Vidmar, Wade.

Player of the week. Rd 22: Willie Herd (h).

END OF STORY

601 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 10, 1992, Monday, Final Edition


Just Sell It;
Five-Story Nike Mart Is an Instant Score


Michael Abramowitz, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: STYLE; PAGE B1


LENGTH: 852 words


DATELINE: CHICAGO


Perhaps it's just an excuse to sell sneakers for $ 100 a pop -- but what an excuse.

Walk through the doors of Nike Town, and the first thing you see is a life-size plaster statue of Mr. Nike himself -- Michael Jordan -- in mid-jump shot. To either side the walls are papered with Sports Illustrated covers featuring athletes who've endorsed Nike products.

And that's all before you get to the basketball court, the 22-foot-long, 1,000-gallon tank with live tropical fish, and the video theater where you can watch your favorite athletes work out on film, in Nike apparel. 

And the amazing dancing bears who do cartwheels before slamming the basketball home!

Well, scratch the dancing bears. Nike didn't go that far when it set up its giant new five-story retail emporium along North Michigan Avenue, Chicago's so-called Magnificent Mile of fancy boutiques and department stores. But the company appears to have spared few other expenses in designing and building what is more a color-coordinated sports museum -- the Disney World of athletics may be more like it -- than a shoe store.

"It's dope," says Larry Cowans, a 13-year-old from nearby Skokie who is spending the afternoon wandering around the store with his older brother. "That means cool," he quickly informs a befuddled questioner.

Cowans, a self-described aficionado of basketball star Charles Barkley, is what you might also call a sports-marketing dream. He's wearing a Georgetown Hoyas T-shirt and gym shorts and a Georgia Tech baseball cap. On his feet are a pair of Nike basketball sneakers.

But it's not just the aficionados who have had Nike's cash registers ringing furiously ever since Nike Town opened here a few weeks ago. On any given afternoon, the store is packed with hundreds of shoppers -- suburban housewives, packs of teenagers on summer vacation and scads of tourists who have added it to their Chicago agendas.

"I'd heard this is the place to come visit," says Clarke Reeves, an Indianapolis schoolteacher who drove up for a Cubs game. "It's kind of like an entertainment center. Instead of having to spend money, you can just browse."

Well, he did buy some T-shirts for the kids.

Reeves is exactly the kind of customer who has Vince Giacomin wearing a perpetual smile these days. Giacomin is the manager of Nike Town. He estimates that at least 5,000 people a day have visited the store since its opening, perhaps as many as 10,000 on a good day.

To put that into perspective, consider this: The Art Institute, another tourist destination only a half-dozen blocks south on Michigan Avenue, averages only 3,000 to 4,000 visitors a day. The Museum of Science and Industry gets perhaps 5,000 or 6,000.

"This is the store to go to," boasts Giacomin. "Every time you come in here, you see something you didn't see before -- because there's so much to see."

As Giacomin explains it, Nike Town represents in part the company's response to the recession. "Retail is struggling in general," he says. "The retailer only knows to put a four-letter word on the front door: SALE. We've taken a totally different approach. We're talking about creating a different environment for shopping."

Nike Town Chicago is actually the second Nike Town. The first was a similar, albeit much smaller, store in Portland, Ore., near the company's headquarters. Now Nike is planning to take the concept national, establishing a kind of Hard Rock Cafe for the sneaker and leisure fields. It has been scouting sites in Atlanta, New York and Orange County, Calif. There's even talk of going international, in London or Berlin.

Given all the hoopla over the Olympic Dream Team, it's not hard to understand the mania here over Nike Town, a veritable shrine to America's most famous athletes -- many of whom, it turns out, endorse Nike products. Giant statues of Dream Teamers Scottie Pippen and David Robinson hang from the rafters. Window displays tout the accomplishments of Ukraine's champion pole vaulter Sergei Bubka and long jumper Mike Powell. You can even see the sleek black "bat boot" worn by Michael Keaton in "Batman." (Yup, it was designed by Nike.)

Innovative design touches turn up in unlikely places. The door handles are sculpted like the Nike wings on the side of sneakers. Clerks retrieve shoes from the stock room through plastic tubes that transport the sneakers along a pulley system. As you shop for tennis shoes, the sounds of people smacking tennis balls can be heard over the Brian Eno-esque music on the stereo system, but as you walk into the basketball area, they are replaced by the noisy shouts of a playground hoops match.

Of course, the biggest shrine of all here is to Chicago's reigning prince, Bulls guard Michael Jordan. A whole section of the store is devoted to the Air Jordan line of shoes, socks, T-shirts, sweat pants and gym shorts (for $ 38 a pair; there's a half-basketball court too, for trying on your new shoes). In the background: a two-story mural of Jordan on his way to a slam dunk, pasted against blue sky and white clouds.

With big white Nike Air Jordans on his feet, of course.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, THE INTERIOR OF NIKE TOWN IN CHICAGO: THE NEW ATHLETIC-GEAR STORE IS DRAWING BIGGER CROWDS THAN THE CITY'S FAMED ART INSTITUTE. NIKE INC.


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

604 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Bond Buyer


Nike Securities Attempting to Purchase A Division of Clayton Brown & Associates


September 3, 1991, Tuesday
Correction Appended


By Karen Pierog and Karl Oxnevad


DATELINE: CHICAGO


Bob Van Kampen confirmed Friday that his new firm, Nike Securities, is negotiating with Clayton Brown & Associates Inc. to buy its packaged products division.

He said that while the deal has not yet been finalized, he expected the matter to be resolved by Oct. 1.

"We've been in discussions working with them and trying to come to an agreement," Mr. Van Kampen stated. "I believe we are moving to a resolution, but it's not a deal yet." 

Mr. Brown, the firm's chairman, could not be reached for comment.

Clayton Brown has sold about $6.5 billion of unit investment trusts since 1974, and employs 40 to 45 people in its packaged products division, according to the firm's marketing department.

Clayton Brown was once a part of a firm - Van Kampen Wauterlek & Co. - that Mr. Van Kampen started in 1967. Seven years later the firm was divided into two separate companies - Van Kampen Merritt and Clayton Brown & Associates.

Mr. Van Kampen said he was "very saddened" that the confidentiality of the negotiations was "breached" when Clayton Brown sent an internal memo to its packaged product employees saying they would continue to be employed either at Clayton Brown or at Nike.

Mr. Van Kampen started Nike in May, less than a month after Van Kampen Merritt Inc., the firm he formed in 1974 and sold to Xerox Financial Services in 1984, announced it was dropping its investment banking business to concentrate on its asset management business that includes mutual funds and unit investment trusts.

One municipal finance source said, "He's coming back in a big way to compete with Van Kampen Merritt."

A spokesman for Van Kampen Merritt did not return phone calls.

As of April, the firm had sold $19 billion of unit investment trusts and was the largest U.S. sponsor of insured tax-free unit trust investments.

Mr. Van Kampen said that all "non-compete" agreements that he made with Xerox at the time he sold the firm had since expired. He explained that the idea to acquire Clayton Brown's unit trust business occurred when Nike acquired "a key" packaged product employee from Clayton Brown who "felt there would be a possibility Clayton Brown would be interested in selling the whole department."

Mr. Van Kampen said Nike, which is operating out of temporary quarters in West Chicago, Ill., employs 20 people - including some former Van Kampen Merritt employees - involved in the trading, underwriting and sale of tax-exempt and taxable bonds to institutional investors.

The sale of its packaged products division would not have a great effect on Clayton Brown's business, according to one public finance official.

"They haven't been among the majors in that area," the source said. "They've been focusing on public finance, doing a lot of work as a co manager."


SECTION: Pg. 2


LENGTH: 468 words


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 1991, Wednesday


CORRECTION:

Bob Van Kampen, chairman of Nike Securities, clarified a comment he made in an article that appeared yesterday about negotiations between his firm and Clayton Brown & Associates to purchase Clayton Brown's packaged products division.

Mr. Van Kampen said the confidentiality of the negotiations was breached by an unknown person and that, as a result, officials at Clayton Brown issued a memo to its employees saying they would continue to be employed either at Clayton Brown or Nike.


Copyright 1991 The Bond Buyer, Inc.

 

605 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


October 25, 1991, Friday, 1* EDITION


Agassi ad is Child's play


BYLINE: FORT WORTH STAR-TELEGRAM


SECTION: ENTERTAINMENT; Pg. C6


LENGTH: 157 words


 

Tennis player Andre Agassi may be more famous for his endorsements than for his game. And, in his new ad for Nike, he's paired with Julia Child, the grande dame of food who has always refused to endorse any product. 

In the "Air. By Agassi" spot, the Las Vegas flash bashes tennis balls around a profusion of TV sets. He hits one of the sets with a ball and Child suddenly appears on the screen.

Child, who never does commercials endorsing products, says the TV spot resulted from a "snafu with my lawyers when the company asked for a clip from one of my shows" and her share of the royalties is being donated to the American Institute of Wine & Food.

Dusty Kidd, director of public relations for Nike, says Child was concerned that her spot not appear as an endorsement for the shoes. Nike chose Child, Kidd said, because she is a TV institution.

"I don't wear Nikes," the 79-year-old Child said. "I wear New Balance."

611 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


July 7, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Muhammad Ali gets Thorpe Award


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. C1


LENGTH: 461 words


Muhammad Ali received the Life Time Achievement Award last night during the Jim Thorpe Pro Sports Award Show, a two-hour live special on ABC-TV. The presentation was made by actor James Earl Jones.

Other special awards went to Bo Jackson and long jumper Mike Powell. Other winners were Michael Andretti, Cal Ripken, Michael Jordan, Terry Norris, Mark Rypien, Fred Couples, Meg Mallon, Mark Messier, Jim Courier and Monica Seles. 

No politics

CALGARY (CP) - The two Canadian cities vying to host the 2002 Winter Olympics have sent a clear, angry message to Ottawa - keep politics out of sport.

Calgary mayor Al Duerr and his Quebec City counterpart, Jean-Paul L'Allier, signed a joint declaration demanding the Canadian Olympic Association select either of the two cities as its Canadian candidate without politics coloring its decision.

Nike appeals

MADRID (AP) - Nike Inc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of Nike apparel in Spain.

Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore.-based sports apparel company from using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

Jets kicker quits

NEW YORK (AP) - New York Jets placekicker Pat Leahy, the oldest player in the NFL and the third-ranked scorer in league history, retired yesterday after 18 seasons because of a recurring sciatic nerve condition.

Leahy, 41, has 1,470 points, and trails only fellow kickers George Blanda (2,002) and Jan Stenerud (1,699).

Jockey injured

WILLOW PARK, Texas (AP) - A Trinity Meadows Raceway jockey was in good condition yesterday at a Fort Worth hospital after being thrown and trampled in a race.

Doctors said David Muirhead, 26, could be released today.

Bulgarian back

MILAN, Italy (AP) - Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria, back on track after taking two years to recover from foot surgery, will be bidding for gold in the women's high jump at the Barcelona Olympics.

Kostadinova, who set the world record of 6 feet, 10 1/4 inches at Rome in 1987, surprised even her husband by clearing 6-8 3/4 in her best effort of the season at a track meet in San Marino on the weekend.

Skiing champs

BOGOTA, Columbia, (CNW) - Jaret Llewellyn of Innisfail, Alta., and Kim de Macedo of Shawnigan Lake, B.C., won the overall titles at the seven-country Pan American Water Skiing Championships.

In the team event, the United States was first with 8,426 points and Canada, the number-one ranked nation, was second at 8,271.

In junior competition, Ryan Bush, 15, of Brampton, was second overall.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

613 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


May 31, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Beachcombers are pumped up!


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1


LENGTH: 250 words


DATELINE: CANNON BEACH, Ore.


 
   CANNON BEACH, Ore. (Reuter) - Beachcombers along the Pacific coast of the United States and Canada are scrambling to collect Nike running shoes - the result of a lost cargo of footwear washed overboard from a ship a year ago. 

"I am wearing a pair now, and I love them," said Steve McLeod, an artist in Cannon Beach, Ore., who has collected 70 shoes, including 10 pairs.

Local residents of this Pacific coast town 64 kilometres (40 miles) west of Portland said the spring tides deposited hundreds of Nike shoes along the coast.

The footwear apparently washed overboard from a cargo ship more than a year ago, according to the Beaverton, Ore., athletics sportswear company.

Nike transportation manager Rick Hastings said the shoes came from five large shipping containers that washed off a ship bound from South Korea to Seattle in May, 1990.

The containers held 40,000 pairs of Nike running shoes, golf shoes and hiking boots.

Hastings said the shoes have been found as far north as Vancouver Island in British Columbia.

"They have a little bit of seaweed on them and a few barnacles. But scrape that off and you have a standard pair of shoes," Hastings said.

"The only complaint I have received is that we didn't tie the pairs together, so they have to match them."

McLeod said beachcombers have formed the Sneaker Society which meets to swap shoes to come up with pairs. He said anyone who finds shoes on the beach is welcome to join.final-ly; shipping; accident


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

August 20, 1992 Thursday


SPORT IN BRIEF Nike drops Krabbe


BYLINE: GAM


LENGTH: 58 words


U.S. sportswear manufacturer Nike Inc. said yesterday it had cancelled
its sponsorhip deal with double world sprint champion Katrin Krabbe and
her German teammate Grit Breuer after they failed a drugs test. The two
athletes face a four-year ban from competition after random dope tests
last month showed they had taken the muscle-building drug Clenbuterol.

620 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


July 10, 1992, Friday, 1* EDITION


Nike still outrunning L.A. Gear in battle of the footwear makers: Nike scores 5th year of gains while foe tags quarterly loss


BYLINE: DEBORAH YU; LOS ANGELES DAILY NEWS


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D2


LENGTH: 401 words


DATELINE: Los Angeles


IN THE RUNNING battle of the footwear makers, Nike Inc. has further advanced its lead over L.A. Gear Inc. The Marina del Rey, Calif.-based company reported its seventh straight quarterly loss Wednesday while rival Nike of Beaverton, Ore., reported its fifth straight year of record revenues and earnings.

Nike shares jumped more than 10 per cent Wednesday while L.A. Gear dropped more than 15 per cent, closing at $ 10 5/8 , off $ 1 5/8 . L.A. Gear closed at $ 10 7/8 Thursday. 

L.A. Gear reported a net loss of $ 24.4 million US ($ 1.19 a share) for the second quarter ended May 31 compared with a net loss of $ 4 million (20 cents) in the like period a year ago.

Revenue was $ 104.7 million vs. $ 166 million.

L.A. Gear attributed its loss in part to settling three shareholder suits, at $ 13.9 million against net earnings, as well as a loss from continuing operations.

The lawsuits alleged insider trading and release of false financial statements and prospects for the company. Filed in 1990 and 1991, they name L.A. Gear and current and former officials, including founder Robert Greenberg. The company said the settlements are not admissions of guilt.

Court approval for the settlements is expected in late August.

L.A. Gear president and chief operating officer Mark Goldston said losses are expected to continue into the latter half of 1992.

L.A. Gear installed new management in September after Roy Disney-led Trefoil Capital Investors in Burbank, Calif., bailed out the firm with a $ 100-million investment convertible to a 34-per-cent stake.

Since then, new management has been intent on cutting expenses, streamlining company operations and consolidating shoe lines. Still, losses have continued to plague the company since the fourth quarter of fiscal 1990.

Meanwhile, Nike earned $ 70.7 million US (92 cents a share) in the fourth quarter ended May 31 compared with $ 58.6 million (76 cents) in the same period a year ago. Revenue was $ 847.6 million against $ 719 million.

For the year, earnings were $ 329.2 million ($ 4.30 a share) against $ 287 million ($ 3.77). Revenue rose 13.7 per cent to $ 3.41 billion in 1992.

L.A. Gear's market share dropped from 12 per cent in 1990 to eight per cent last year, while Nike saw its share grow from 29 per cent in 1990 to 30 per cent last year, according to the Sporting Goods Intelligence in Glen Mills, Pa.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
