The Washington Post


August 25, 1991, Sunday, Final Edition


BUSINESS


From news services and staff reports


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D2; FANFARE


LENGTH: 85 words


Sonny Vaccaro has left Nike Inc. and will join a new sports marketing firm, it was reported in yesterday's editions of the New York Times.

Vaccaro, who signed numerous basketball standouts and coaches to endorsement arrangements with the shoe manufacturer, will become co-chairman of DIC Sports Marketing.

The sports marketing firm is connected with DIC Animation City, Inc., a cartoon studio that will produces animated features of such sports stars as Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky and Bo Jackson.

Southwest Newswire


JULY 12, 1991, FRIDAY


NFL PRO SET & NIKE SPONSOR LOS ANGELES RAMS "MINI CAMP" SUNDAY, JULY 14


DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 12, 1991


The National Football League and the Los Angeles Rams will conduct a free clinic for over 400 area youth at Fullerton Junior College,Sunday July 14 at 12:00 p.m. This event is last in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer. The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, and Nike.

The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored by Nike will featur12hgeles Rams players including wide receiver Flipper Anderson and former Los Angeles Rams quarterback Vince Ferragamo. 

The players will stress the importance of staying in school and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence. On the field at Fullerton Junior College, the players will demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition.

"Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boys and Girls Clubs of Los Angeles to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.

Local supporters of the event include radio station KJLH-FM.

The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.

          kids.

629 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


May 10, 1991 Friday


PUBLIC EYE FIFTH COLUMN When running shoes and art meet, art ends up getting trampled, says Brian Fawcett


BYLINE: Brian Fawcett; GAM


LENGTH: 666 words


By Brian Fawcett
ESQUIRE magazine, which carries the subtitle of Man At His Best but
really ought to be subtitled Upper Middle-class New York Guys Between 35
and 50 At Their Most Cynical and Stylish, used to be one of the best
magazines this side of the Atlantic. It was politically and socially
astute if not always liberal, the prose was high-octane, and its annual
Dubious Achievement Awards, begun in the 1960s, were the best summary and
satire of our lunatic civilization available.

These days, alas, the magazine is usually more in step with our
paranoid sectarian times than it once was, and the most I'd be willing to
say about it is that it features good prose. The April 1991 issue, which
exhibits a photo of actress Ellen Barkin, has, between pages 64 and 65, an
eight-page fold-out that will tell you more about corporate sponsorship of
the arts than the magazine intended, and probably a whole lot more than
most of us ever wanted to know. 

On the front and back of the fold-out are miniaturized reproductions of
five commissioned works of art. Charles Anderson (U.S.), Ralph Steadman
(British) and Takenobu Igarushi (Japanese) are on the front, and Alphonse
Holtgreve (German) and Andre Francois (French) cover the rear. All five
artists were evidently contracted to interpret a single numerical icon -
the number 180 - and to integrate it within what is presumably their
recognizable style.

THE perpetrator is Nike Corp., whose slogan, "Just do it," has become
the low-density battle cry for a generation of narcissistic physical
activists engaged in slicking up their bodies while a third of the world
suffers from malnutrition.

The offending fold-out is an ad for Nike's new running shoe, the Nike
180 Air. The middle four pages are a masterpiece of high-style technical
gibberish about the new runner, done up in neo-Albrecht Durer with water-
colour renderings first of the shoe, and then of a skinless foot sitting
in it. Also included are a nonsensical architectural plan view of the
shoe's sole, and a couple of indecipherable technical drawings aimed at
convincing us of the 180's high-tech perfection.

The written text, printed in Spanish, German, Japanese and English,
informs us that Nike's vaunted air-cushioning unit (a see-through shell
that contains air and thus makes the shoe lighter), has been made 50 per
cent larger for the 180 runner.

On the two remaining pages of the fold-out are silver-tone cheesecake
photos of the new 180 in hot pink, navy and white. With its see-through
air unit, the runner doesn't quite strike me as the Ellen Barkin of
running shoes, who is after all, a woman of complexity and substance. The
180 is actually the opposite - a testimony to the degree to which
absolutely nothing can be aggrandized.

So what am I offended at, here, anyway? Well, practically everything
about the Nike fold-out offends me. Nowhere in the eight pages does it
admit that it is an advertisement. Au contraire, the fold-out is marked "
confidential" in five places, leading us to believe that it must be an
information leak that Esquire somehow got hold of. That it is addressed to
someone named T. Hatfield, a name that does not appear on the Esquire
masthead, seems to confirm this. The apparent authours of the information
leak are three guys in Beaverton, Ore., which is presumably the site of
Nike's design headquarters.

BUT what is most offensive here is that it tells us how the corporate
sector will, in the end, nurture and sponsor the arts. In this case, the
work of five-star visual artists serves as the fold-out's cover
decoration, and, by implication, as an illustration of how interested in
helping out the arts Nike is.

It also tells us that after a half-century of trying to integrate the
arts within the communities whose values and problems they are supposed to
reflect and articulate, we're headed back to the dark days when art wasn't
by the masters, but for them.
Brian Fawcett is a Vancouver writer and author of Public Eye: An
Investigation into the Disappearance of the World (Harper Collins).


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1991 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

634 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


November 14, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Stingers face test; Tip-off with Bisons in tourney


BYLINE: RANDY PHILLIPS; GAZETTE


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. D15


LENGTH: 466 words


 

The Stingers face powerhouse Manitoba in the first round of the 20th Concordia Nike Classic women's basketball tournament this weekend.

"If we're going to bring our program back to the level it once was, we have to play teams like Manitoba," Concordia coach Mike Hickey said. "It doesn't do any good to play against weak teams just for the sake of winning." 

Concordia lost by 23 points to Manitoba's high-powered offence in non-conference action last month that was part of the Bisons' October feed of Quebec teams as they beat McGill, Bishop's and Concordia on successive days.

The Stingers play Manitoba in the last of four opening-round games tomorrow at 8 p.m.

"We'll probably be at our strongest for the first time this season," said Hickey, whose team has won only once in seven pre- season games. "We have good quickness, so it will be our speed against their size."

The three-day Classic, which starts tomorrow at Loyola Gym, has developed into one of the premier tournaments in the country and will be closely watched to help decide the first weekly top-10 national ranking of the season, which the Canadian Interuniversity Athletic Union will release Monday.

The Laurentian Vees, CIAU national champion for the last two years, are favored to win the Classic for the third straight year, despite losing national team player Nana Robinson, a guard who has taken the year off from school.

Completing the eight-team field are the McGill Martlets and Queen's Golden Gaels, who meet in the opening game at 2 p.m., the Winnipeg Lady Wesmen and Ottawa Gee-Gees, who play at 4 p.m., and Laurentian and Waterloo Athenas at 6 p.m.

Concordia is a team - make that a progam - in transition, with a new coach, some new faces and emerging from a controversy and legacy of ineptitude that Hickey hopes is behind the team.

Hickey replaced Louisa Zerbe as head coach after last season when Zerbe resigned before the season ended over what she said was a lack of support from the Concordia athletic department.

Concordia finished last in the four-team Quebec University Women's Basketball League with a 1-11 record and missed the playoffs for the sixth consecutive year.

Zerbe compiled a 5-37 league record during her four years as head coach. On Feb. 3, 1990, Concordia ended a five-year, 0-47 losing streak.

It's Hickey's second time as head coach of the Stingers. He coached the women's team from 1976 to 1985, during which Concordia reached the CIAU national tournament four times.

Upon his return, Hickey said his first priorities were to make the women's program "enjoyable again" and Concordia the class of the Quebec league.

He appears to have succeeded on the first matter, but returning Concordia to its previous glory days might take longer than anticipated.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

The Nike Tour will stop at the Dominion Club in Richmond, for the Nike Dominion Open, June 3-6 at the 7,040-yard, par-72 club designed by Curtis Strange. A field of 138 will start.

The Nike event has been the Ben Hogan Tour since its inception in 1990. It features young players who have not qualified for the Professional Golfers' Association Tour.

USA TODAY


September 17, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Congressmen run race for charities


BYLINE: Barbara Geehan


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 138 words


Members of Congress have been running in some tight contests recently, but they will pick up the pace today in the annual Nike Capital Challenge, a 3-mile charity foot race at Washington's East Potomac Park, starting at 8 a.m.

Legislators representing 25 states are signed up, including 1991 fastest Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and fastest from the House: Rep. Susan Molinari, R- N.Y., and Rep. Bart Gordon, D-Tenn.

The purpose of the race, say sponsors, is to determine which branch of government is fittest - legislative, executive or judicial, or the media who cover them.

Some team names: Just Geren and Bear It, led by Rep. Pete Geren, D-Texas; Odor in the Court, led by federal Circuit Court Judge Glenn Archer Jr.; and Tipper's Taboo and Hillary Too, led by Charles Kolb, deputy assistant to the president.

646 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 2, 1992, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Sports of The Times;
On Loyalty To Company, Or Country?


BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON


SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 709 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain


IF the shoe fits, wear it. Especially on the Olympic gold-medal stand. And especially if you're getting paid to wear it. But if your Olympic team warm-up suit doesn't fit your portfolio of contracts, don't wear it. Especially on the gold-medal stand.

More and more, the United States Olympic team is populated not so much by athletes from all over America as by athletes from manufacturers of athletic apparel with brand names that sound like newly discovered planets. Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley from Nike. Carl Lewis from Mizuno. Dave Johnson (and his decathlon rival who didn't make the team, Dan O'Brien) from Reebok. 

In the confusion, Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley think they're here representing Nike instead of the United States.

When the two Dream Team basketball players learned that on the gold-medal stand next Saturday night they would be expected to wear official red, white and blue United States warmup suits with the planet Reebok logo, they threatened not to appear at the ceremony.

"I don't believe in endorsing my competition," Jordan said. "I feel very strongly abut loyalty to my own company."

Upon hearing of Jordan's loyalty to his company, cynics wondered about his loyalty to his country. He's here because he grew up playing basketball in the United States, not because he's an alien from the planet Nike on loan to the Olympic team.

As for loyalty to his company, how loyal was Jordan to Coca-Cola when Gatorade offered him more money?

Gatorade's slogan is "Be Like Mike." But if he doesn't appear at the gold-medal ceremony in his official Olympic warm-up suit, a new slogan suddenly might be more fashionable: Don't Be Like Mike.

Don't be like Charles Barkley either.

The Dream Team's other international diplomat explained: "Us Nike guys are loyal to Nike because they pay us a lot of money. I have two million reasons not to wear Reebok." As if those two million reasons, not to mention his other millions of reasons, were generated on the planet Nike rather than in the nation he's representing.

It's not that Jordan and Barkley didn't know this all along. According to Rule 14 of the code of conduct signed by every United States Olympic athlete, medal winners will wear apparel supplied by the United States Olympic Committee at award ceremonies.

"This rule," said Harvey Schiller, the U.S.O.C. executive director, "was approved by the Athletes Advisory Council and all athletes on our teams are expected to abide by it and all other portions of the code. It is mandatory policy that any athlete taking part in an official medal ceremoney in Barcelona will wear this apparel, without exception."

Jordan signed that agreement. But as an alien from the planet Nike, he crossed out Rule 14.

Reebok is one of 40 corporate sponsors that contribute $160 million to the U.S.O.C. treasury.

"The money we're getting for wearing the official warm-up suit is going to assist thousands of athletes in training," said Mike Moran, the U.S.O.C. director of public information. "No athlete will stand on the medal platform without this suit."

To their credit, four other Dream Team members from the planet Nike have not objected to wearing the Reebok warm-up suit at the gold-medal ceremony: Chris Mullin, Scottie Pippen, David Robinson and John Stockton.

Through the years, Olympic athletes have prospered from their contracts with manufacturers of athletic shoes. When Mike Powell, another Nike alien, set the world long-jump record in Tokyo last year, Joe Douglas, the manager of Carl Lewis from the planet Mizuno, turned to Powell's agent, Brad Hunt, and said, "You just cost my guy a million dollars."

Until now, no United States Olympian ever objected to wearing the official team warm-up suit with a rival logo.

But until now, the planet Nike was never so prominent. More than four dozen aliens are on its international track-and-field roster. It's publishing a daily newletter here. It has taken out a full-page daily advertisement, entitled "The Nike News," in L'Equipe, the French sports newspaper.

Nike is the Greek word for winged goddess of victory. But if Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley don't wear their official warm-up suits, Nike will mean broken-winged goddess of greed.


LOAD-DATE: August 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jordan (Reuters)


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

647 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


December 5, 1991, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


IN STEP: NEW MODELS OF ATHLETIC SHOES KEEP UP SALES


BYLINE: Marilou Berry Scripps Howard News Service


SECTION: STYLE WEST; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 685 words


 

AFTER A PERIOD of double-digit growth in the mid-1980s, the athletic footwear market has plateaued. In 1990 the U.S. market hit $11.9 billion on 393 million pairs of athletic footwear. That represents only a 1 percent increase in units and a 10 percent sales gain, the smallest jump since 1984. ''The overall athletic footwear market has reached a difficult point for manufacturers, as the recession and price competition from casual shoes are having some impact,'' says Sebastian DiCasoli, SGMA's director of marketing sales. Still, despite concern over cost, four out of every 10 shoes sold in the United States are athletic-style. In addition, DiCasoli says, the possibility of strong sales for athletic footwear looks bright because of greater participation in fitness walking and the continued promotion of outdoor and cross-training shoes. In an effort to spur the static market, companies are continuously bringing out new shoes. ''Without a doubt, the newest meaningful development is the system of air bladders, started by Reebok,'' says Bob Gillespie, a store manager for the Allied Sporting Goods chain. ''Nike now has an air-pressure system and L.A. Gear uses it in their R egulator Series.'' The air-pressure system provides the wearer with a custom fit. The shoe conforms to the foot, no matter what the configuration. On the premise that if air can make a shoe conform to the foot it also can make a glove conform to the hand, Spalding and Mizuno have come out with baseball gloves featuring the air system. Gillespie says his most popular shoe is Nike's $130 Charles Barkley model. ''All the kids want it,'' he says, referring to the black low-cut shoe which makes the air bladder visible through the shoe's mid-sole. ''There are probably better basketball shoes on the market but this happens to be the one that's hot right now,'' says Gillespie, whose store's price points are from $29.99 for a standard leather tennis shoe to $150 for Nike's Air Force 180 high top with air-system arch and ankle supports. Popular as the air-system shoes are, one pro shop manager and buyer is not a fan. ''I've had a lot of bad luck with pump shoes,'' says Barbara Ensner of Evansville, Ind. ''Reebok is making a pump walking shoe in which the pump malfunctions.'' Her shop does well the Nike's Challenge model, worn by top-ranked tennis pro Andre Agassi, Wilson's Pro Staff tennis shoe, and Head's Sonic, a tri-court shoe for racquetball, tennis or basketball. Another new shoe is the $125 Brooks ''Fusion'' model, with a shock-reducing fusion plate that bends with the wearer and snaps back into place, producing a rebound effect. It's rated tops by Runner's World magazine. ''The air bag has been around since the late '70s, but the fusion plate is newer,'' says Jim Nolan, a shoe store manager. Nolan's best selling shoe is still Nike's Air Jordan, named for Chicago Bulls forward, Michael Jordan. ''It's a basketball shoe,'' Nolan says, ''but 90 percent of my sales are not to basketball players.'' The Air Jordan has been the best selling basketball shoe at Nike since 1985, when the company signed the pro, according to Nike spokeswoman Melinda Gable. She says a new Air Jordan will be introduced in February that will be lighter in weight ''with a more dynamic, glove-like fit.'' In the new shoe, heavier leather has been cut away. So has some material from the outsole. After Jan. 1, Nike will introduce its Air Flight Mid, worn by Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls. Weighing only 14.3 ounces, the shoe has a specially constructed tongue. Nike's new running shoe is the Air Huarache that, according to Gable, ''is so lightweight it's minimalistic.'' Made without a heel counter, the shoe features a back strapping system and sells for $110. Cross-trainers, athletic shoes that are not sports-specific, have been popular for some time. The Sports Quarters' Nolan says he ''lives in'' Nike's cross-trainers, with leather upper and air bags in the heel only. But Gable issues a warning to those who use them for sports: ''Serious athletes should get a sports shoe.''


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

654 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 3, 1992, Friday


The Businessman For all his prowess on field(s), sports star has economic savvy


BYLINE: I.J. Rosenbergpersonal; business; contracts; personalities; atlanta; sports; advertising


SECTION: SPORTS; Section H; Page 10


LENGTH: 278 words


Forget Deion Sanders the baseball player. Forget Deion Sanders the football player. These days, the really impressive Deion Sanders is Deion Sanders the businessman. 

He's a hair salon owner. He's a spokesman for Nike. He has what his attorney describes as "a six-figure deal" with NFL Properties for trading cards. His own clothing line. His own TV show. He'd like to start his own fishing show.

"A lot of people may not realize it, but Deion is an extremely intelligent person," said attorney Eugene Parker, who represents Sanders. "And all that he does, he is looking toward his future."

With Sanders having his best baseball season this year, Parker is receiving all types of endorsement offers for his client. The craziest?

"These people wanted to market this ball shaped like a football but painted like a baseball," Parker said. "We decided against it."

Sanders's Nike deal makes him the heir apparent to that company's other two-sport spokesman, Bo Jackson, especially with Jackson's athletic future uncertain after hip-replacement surgery. Nike recently released new Jackson and Sanders commercials, both done in the same style. They will debut during baseball's All-Star Game July 14. The shoe company is also making a special batting glove for Sanders.

"There is a lot around the corner, including a likely soft drink deal," said Parker.

As much money as Sanders is bringing in now, the stakes are likely to get higher. The Falcons, who will pay him $ 750,000 this year, just offered him an extra $ 1 million to report to training camp by July 13. The Braves, who pay him $ 600,000 through July 31, want to sign him for the rest of the season.


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH921910301


GRAPHIC: photo: Jamie Dukes (left), partner in "Deion's Hair Salon."


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

655 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


December 5, 1991, Thursday, FIRST EDITION


BARBIE BOOSTS SALES


BYLINE: Donna Rosato


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 206 words


Toymaker Mattel expects record earnings this year, thanks to the popularity of its time-tested toys like the Barbie doll. Mattel Chairman and CEO John Amerman, meeting with analysts Wednesday, said he is comfortable with analysts' earnings estimates of $ 2.15 to $ 2.30 a share this year. Last year, Mattel earned $ 91.2 million, or $ 1.80 a share, on revenue of $ 1.47 billion. Amerm an added that he expects next year to be a growth year, too. Also, Amerman said Mattel is teaming with Fox Television to produce a line of fashion dolls based on the five lead characters in the popular television series Beverly Hills 90210. Dolls should be on the market as early as next year.
 
CORPORATE PROFITS: The Commerce Department said corporations' after-tax profits rose 3.9% the third quarter, the first improvement after two consecutive quarterly declines. Profits totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $ 189.9 billion vs. $ 182.7 billion in the second quarter when profits fell 3.7%.
 
 NIKE TALE: A new book tells the tale of sneaker giant Nike Inc. Swoosh: The Story of Nike and the Men Who Played There explains Nike's ups and downs and how some of its most successful products came to be. (Story, 4C.)


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Moneyline

656 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Age (Melbourne, Australia)


July 27, 1992 Monday  
Late Edition


Olympic glory is a shoo-in for Jordan, Bubka


BYLINE: Garry Linnell


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 27


LENGTH: 647 words


The shoe salesman from North Carolina sat with his hands clasped and spoke nicely about his golf game, his two children and what a privilege it was to be there. His fellow salesman from the Ukraine smiled and agreed.

In front of them sat more than 1000 representatives of the world's media. Flashes popped and television cameras recorded every nuance and every word. Selling shoes had never been easier.

Mind you, these were not your average shoe salesmen. No squeezing small shoes on to smelly, blistering feet for these two. One of them, Michael Jordan, the man from North Carolina who now plies his trade in Chicago, earns more than $25million a year. Sergei Bubka, too, lives comfortably. 

These are the Olympics and another round of Shoe Wars has begun. Nike, Reebok and a host of other shoe companies are all in Barcelona flogging their merchandise and reminding everyone how many champions they have signed to their labels.

It was Nike's turn on the weekend to do the boasting and it used Jordan and world pole-vault record-holder Bubka to do it. A cinema in downtown Barcelona was booked for the event and 15minutes before the media conference began the place was packed.

For 50minutes Jordan and Bubka answered questions, and when you left, you felt as though you had spent half a day at a convention of advertising agents. Nike signs hung from platforms and, outside in the street, a red bus with an inflated shoe pumped out loud rock music. It was all tacky, contrived and, in the end, completely meaningless.

"I'm not here because of money," said Jordan, referring to playing in the Olympics. "Nike did not influence me (to come). I came strictly on my own intitiative." But what did he feel about the way sport has been commercialised, particularly since he was sitting on a stage wearing his sponsor's products and endorsing what a terrific bunch of blokes they were? "Commercialism is a part of all professional sports," he said. "It's a way of life." That was about as interesting as it got. The rest of the time was spent either listening to sycophantic questions about how wonderful it must be to be able to soar like a bird, or listening to dull replies, several of which sounded suspiciously as though they had been rehearsed for a few minutes outside.

Of course, the media has no one but itself to blame. With Jordan's fame at such a peak around the world _ it is claimed he is the most recognisable sporting figure on the planet these days, usurping Muhammed Ali _ he has said the same things over and over until he has to click off and turn to autopilot. Yes, it's a privilege to play in the Games.

Yes, I love playing golf. Yes, it's tough being me and not having a great deal of privacy.

Yes, Michael Jordan has very little privacy. When the grindingly long NBA season is on, he spends most of his time confined to a hotel room, unable to walk the streets for fear of being mobbed. He cannot do the little things. No late evening stroll with an ice-cream. No popping into the pub for a few beers with the boys. He can't even go to a public toilet. At least there he has an advantage over the rest of us.

The Dream Team has been criticised in Barcelona for not living in the Athlete's Village, preferring instead the security and comfort of a five-star hotel. They dropped in the other day, explained Jordan, but felt the atmosphere would not have been conducive to a good preparation for the basketball tournament. Being in the village would be the same as living outside in the glare of the public. Athletes would be asking for autographs and pictures, small-time officials would be hanging from their shirt-tails.

So instead, Jordan lives on his own and occasionally drops into planned media conferences to flog his sponsor's products. Then he departs just as quickly to go back and hide inside the bubble that is his private life. Shoe salesmen never had it so tough.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1992 The Age Company Limited
All Rights Reserved

 

661 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


February 20, 1991, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Campaign for British Knights to Escalate Sneaker Wars


BYLINE: Kim Foltz


SECTION: Section D; Page 17; Column 1; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 578 words


THE latest volley in the sneaker wars will be fired tonight during the Grammy Awards show in commercials for British Knights athletic shoes that use an updated version of a classic insult.

The $15 million campaign, created by the Deutsch agency, uses the theme "Your mother wears Nike -- choose change," to warn young buyers that wearing sneakers from the older, more established market leader is "un-cool." 

Donny Deutsch, the agency's executive vice president and creative director, said the company wanted to use a twist on "Your mother wears combat boots" to make the point that Reebok and Nike were no longer on the cutting edge.

"We want to be seen as the sneakers for rebellious young people," he added. "Reebok and Nike have become so mainstream they're the sneaker of choice for little old ladies."

To make that point, one commercial features a group of Nike-clad, gray-haired women gossiping as they lounge around a tennis court. The spot tells viewers to "choose change," then shows a lineup of flashy British Knights shoes decorated with brightly colored stripes.

Another ad tells young viewers that even though they inherited their parents' genes, they need not follow in mom and dad's footsteps, implying that the only "hip" sneakers are British Knights.

"From a technical standpoint, all of the shoes are basically the same," said Larry Schwartz, an executive vice president at British Knights, which are made by Jack Schwartz Shoes Inc., New York. "We think we can stand out by being more fashion-oriented."

Officials of Nike Inc. did not return calls yesterday seeking comment on the British Knights campaign.

The potshots from British Knights are part of an increasingly aggressive battle being waged by sneaker makers. Earlier this year, Reebok International began a campaign that taunted the athletes Michael Jordan and Bo Jackson, well-known endorsers of Nike Inc. products.

In one spot for the Reebok Pump sneaker, which has an inflatable sole that the wearer can adjust by squeezing a bulb in the shoe's tongue, Dominique Wilkins, the Atlanta Hawks basketball player, says, "So Michael, my man, if you want to fly first class . . . pump up and air out," as he tosses away a Nike Air sneaker, which has an air-filled sole but is not adjustable.

In addition, L. A. Gear Inc. has been running a commercial for its Catapult sneaker that uses the slogan "Everything else is just hot air" to take a shot at the Nike Air shoe.

Advertising in the $5.5 billion sneaker category has become more aggressive as growth in the market has slowed and the industry's leaders have found it difficult to gain a technological edge.

Spending on sneaker advertising has risen substantially. Last year, the top three companies -- Nike, Reebok and L. A. Gear -- increased ad expenditures from an estimated $70 million in 1989 to about $115 million. Mr. Schwartz, whose company is ranked No. 7 in the industry, said that on average, sneaker companies spend from 5 percent to 7 percent of total retail sales on advertising.

Part of the reason for the jump in spending is the hefty fees paid to well-known athletes like Mr. Jordan and Mr. Jackson, who get $5 million to $10 million for endorsements.

The flood of sports celebrities in sneaker ads has drawn criticism from some agency executives who said the glut of personalities tended to cause confusion and made it hard for consumers to remember which sports stars wore what shoes.


LOAD-DATE: February 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

 

664 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 31, 1992, Friday, Final Edition


NOTEBOOK;
Questions of Dream Team's Attire Are Raising Ire


From News Services and Staff Reports


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D7


LENGTH: 662 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA, July 30, 1992


Michael Jordan wants to just do it in Nikes. So do David Robinson, Charles Barkley, John Stockton, Scottie Pippen and Karl Malone, all of them endorsers of Nike, the clothing/sporting goods manufacturer.

But the USOC said Jordan and his Dream Team teammates will have to wear the Reebok-made USA team warmups to be in medal ceremonies.

On Wednesday, Jordan said while he did sign a code of conduct agreement, he crossed out the section that requires athletes to wear the official team uniform. 

"They [USOC] accepted it [when he mailed back]. I didn't get it back. They know my concerns. No one has come to me personally and said, 'You better have the Reebok uniform on when you step on the stand,' " Jordan said.

In a statement issued by the USOC, Executive Director Harvey W. Schiller said: "The matter of the offical award warmup suit which is mandatory for all U.S. athletes at medal ceremonies is an official policy of the United States Olympic Committee and included in the code of conduct for all members of our delegation.

"This rule was approved by the Athletes' Advisory Council and all athletes on our teams are expected to abide by it and all other portions of the code."

Steinbrenner Steps In

George Steinbrenner will take over medical school expenses for Olympic swimmer Ron Karnaugh, whose father died of a heart attack at the Opening Ceremonies.

"I'm going to do everything I can to help the young man," Steinbrenner, a vice president of the USOC, said Thursday.

Steinbrenner was with U.S. officials and Karnaugh's mother when they woke up the swimmer early Sunday with the news his father had died.

The family's trip to Barcelona was financed by neighbors in Maplewood, N.J. The death of Peter Karnaugh, a truck driver, left the family with nothing, Steinbrenner said.

Steinbrenner said he talked with one of Karnaugh's sisters about the bills that would arrive after he enters University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark next month.

Meanwhile, Karnaugh has received a letter of support from speed skater Dan Jansen, who endured a similar tragedy at the 1988 Winter Games.

Jansen's sister, Jane Beres, died five hours before he skated in the 500-meter race at Calgary. He fell in that race and again after leading the 1,000-meter race later in the week.

Don't Make a Case Out of It

International Amateur Athletic Federation President Primo Nebiolo called on other sporting federations to help combat the growing problem of athletes appealing to civil courts.

American sprinter Butch Reynolds, suspended for two years after testing positive for drugs, won a U.S. Supreme Court injunction in June allowing him to compete in the U.S. Olympic trials.

The IAAF decided to take no further action against Reynolds before the Olympics but the subject seems certain to come up at a council meeting after the Games end Aug. 9. At the moment Reynolds can compete starting Aug. 12.

"The problem of civil cases is becoming a real problem for sport in the world," Nebiolo told a news conference.

"In athletics it's not so important because we now have 202 countries affiliated and fortunately in the big majority of these countries we don't have cases of athletes appealing to the civil courts. But, in fact, it can happen. That example can be followed and this can create a certain chaos in our organizations."

Straight Arrow

Antonio Rebollo, the disabled archer whose blazing arrow lit the Olympic flame, said he had been shabbily treated by Games organizers who cast him aside after the Opening Ceremonies.

In an interview with Spanish daily Diario 16, Rebollo said the organizing committee had been "pretty inconsiderate."

"I know some people at the top of COOB were against using me. They only decided on me because I could guarantee I wouldn't miss," said Rebollo, a polio victim and medal winner in two Paralympic Games.

Rebollo said he was given only two hours' notice he had been chosen as archer.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

668 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


December 27, 1992, Sunday


COMMENTARY Like a broken record, Sanders goes for broke


BYLINE: Mark Bradleyfootball; personalities; behavior; atlanta/falcons


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 2


LENGTH: 648 words


Say this for Deion Sanders: He is lending truth to advertising. In one Nike ad, the cynic/comedian/chain smoker Denis Leary said of Sanders: "He's out of control." Nike's copywriters meant this as a compliment, a synonym for "wacky" or "zany." But on Monday night against Dallas, Sanders wasn't wacky or zany. He was simply . . .

Out of control.

Watching Sanders that night was akin to watching a child throw a protracted fit. Clearly Sanders wasn't having one of his better games, but that wasn't the disconcerting part. (Goodness knows, we've all seen Falcons mess up before.) What was truly nettling was Sanders's apparent resolve to remain the absolute center of attention at every moment. 

An actor who overemotes is said to be chewing the scenery. On Monday night Sanders chewed so much scenery as to render the Georgia Dome an open-air facility. His actions suggested that if he wasn't allowed to make a spectacular play, the game just wasn't worth playing. Sorry. This is not how football, or any sport, works.

For every lookaway pass Earvin Johnson made on the fast break, he made 20 of the mundane sort in the half-court offense. For every one of Jerry Rice's 100-plus touchdowns, he has caught five 10-yard outs. Breathtaking moments come as a function of fundamentals, not as a counterpoint. Even if the big moment never presents itself, a game can be won in several smaller moments.

Every play isn't meant for highlight films

On Monday night, Sanders was too busy playing to the ABC cameras to worry about details. Let us recount the ways:

In the second quarter, Troy Aikman hit Michael Irvin on a slant. Sanders, assigned to cover, missed the tackle. Irvin continued downfield. Custom calls for a man who misses a tackle to hop up and pursue. Instead Sanders, among the world's fastest humans, stayed on his knees for long seconds, his arms outstretched in disbelief.

Later in the second quarter, Dallas kicked off to Sanders deep in the end zone. Sanders made no move to run the ball. Neither did he drop to a knee and down it. Instead he stood in the end zone, railing at the injustice of not being allowed to return this kick. Was he about to rail himself into a safety? No. Though screaming is not considered the universal symbol for a touchback, the nearest official finally granted Sanders one.

In the third quarter, Sanders fumbled on a kickoff return. On the next play, Emmitt Smith broke a half-dozen tackles to score. Sanders arrived just in time to shove him through the end zone and under one of the Dome's walls. If it wasn't quite a cheap shot, neither was it a serious attempt to make a tackle. (Serious tacklers don't shove opponents into the end zone.) It was merely a petulant gesture.

Speaking of petulance . . . Sanders returned to the Falcon sideline and smashed an aluminum bench. Naturally, ABC caught it all.

In the fourth quarter, Dallas kicked off for the last time. Sanders fielded the ball on his 2 and took it into the end zone. This time he kneeled down, forgetting that a touchback cannot be granted if the ball is carried into the end zone. The official, acting properly, made no signal. Had a Cowboy tagged the kneeling Sanders, it would've been a safety. At the last moment, Sanders jumped up and ran out to the Falcons' 26.

Hey, I admit it. Time was, Sanders's antics cracked me up. I still laugh when I think of him breaking up a pass against New England, then running in front of the Patriots' bench and thumping his chest. But he's no rookie anymore. He's a 25-year-old All-Pro. He's better than this.

To date, Sanders has been lucky. None of his excesses has cost his team a game - yet. (The end zone lateral against Phoenix came close.) But he has to realize that every single play isn't meant for the highlight film, or the sneaker ad. To steal from Denis Leary, I've got two words for Mr. Deion Sanders:

Grow up.


LOAD-DATE: January 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH930040043


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

669 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 23, 1992, Thursday, FIRST EDITION


Photos that embarrassed UNLV obtained by fluke


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 11C


LENGTH: 380 words


The anonymous source who provided the photos of a sports fixer and Nevada- Las Vegas basketball players that led to the resignation of UNLV basketball coach Jerry Tarkanian has come forward 14 months later to reveal how he got the shots.

Lamont Sudbury, 33, an architectural designer, says he obtained the photos by accident from the ex-wife of convicted sports fixer Richard Perry. The pictures, published by the Las Vegas Review-Journal in May 1991, showed Perry in a hot tub with former Rebels players Anderson Hunt, David Butler and Moses Scurry. 

Tarkanian, who had been involved in a 14-year battle with the NCAA, resigned several days after the photos were published. He now coaches the NBA San Antonio Spurs.

Sudbury says he got the photos from Perry's ex-wife, Joanne, with whom he had been romantically involved. She had asked him to take photos of an architectural project he completed at the Perry home, but, said Sudbury, she mistakenly returned the wrong photos, giving him the hot-tub negatives instead.

''Like everybody else in Las Vegas,'' said Sudbury in a statement, ''I was aware of an article in Time magazine that had pointed out Mr. Perry's connections to the Boston College point-shaving incident.

''However, I did not decide to do anything with the pictures until the spring of 1991, when the Review-Journal reported that Mr. Perry continued to be seen on the fringes of the UNLV program.''
 
OLYMPICS: U.S. athletes expect to wear their Nike apparel in Barcelona, even though a Spanish court rejected Nike's final appeal in a multimillion- dollar trademark feud, the U.S. Olympic Committee said Wednesday. The decision by Spain's highest appeals court makes it a virtual certainty that Nike will have to comply with an order barring it from selling or advertising apparel in Spain. But the entire U.S. track and field team has a contract to wear Nike apparel. And many other athletes wear Nike shoes.
 
BOWLING: Twin brothers Mike and Mark Scroggins of Amarillo, Texas, regained the lead through five rounds Wednesday in the $ 142,500 Beaumont (Texas) Doubles Classic. Mike averaged 238 for his last eight games and won six of those. Mark has a 12-4 match-play record overall. They totaled 15,587 pins.

Compiled by Ben Brown

TYPE: Update

670 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


April 5, 1992, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Slammin', With In-Your-Face Color


SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 46; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page


LENGTH: 467 words


Sneaker wearers are attracted to the colors of the shoes as much as to their touted technological advances, like air pumps and gel-filled heels.

Athletic shoes can be matched to sports outfits and street clothes. And there seems to be a color -- or a combination of colors -- for every taste, now that companies like Nike and Reebok are mixing colors in their athletic-shoe designs. Their choices are influenced by the fashion, surfing and ski industries. 

Basketball, running, cross-training and aerobics shoes are emerging in bright colors like "kiwi" and "aruba blue." Tinker Hatfield, creative director of Nike, said "women who take aerobics are generally interested in color because they want their sneakers to match their outfits." Other styles, like tennis and walking shoes, combine ecologically correct earth tones.

Nike's colors for spring range from gray, jade and teal to rust, olive and tan. The women's Air Elite Max at $90 combines turquoise, lime green and white; the men's Air Trainer Max is yellow, black, gray and white and sells for $115.

Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls basketball team changed the way basketball shoes are colored, Mr. Hatfield said. In 1987, Mr. Jordan wore game shoes that matched his red and black Chicago Bulls uniform. He now helps design his line of shoes for Nike. The distinctive Air Jordan, $130, is fashioned in black, yellow, fuchsia, gray, and green. It has a matching sole bearing Mr. Jordan's silhouette on the heel.

Nike shoes are sold in Manhattan at Footlocker, Lady Footlocker, Paragon Sporting Goods and Herman's.

Pamela Bennett-Boucher, trend and color forecasting manager for Reebok, likes to mix color with graphics and abstract patterns. Her shoes for spring feature earth tones. The Boulevard ($69.99), designed for outdoor basketball, comes in charcoal with clay-colored trim.

Ms. Bennett-Boucher has colored the soles of women's aerobics shoes, taking advantage of all that kicking and high-stepping. The Aerobic Lite 7000, at $74.99, is done in mandarin or hot pink on white. "There is unexpected excitement when the upper is mostly white and there is a burst of color on the soles," she said, adding that softer colors like seagreen and pink are also popular.

She uses what she calls more aggressive colors -- black, copper, orange and metallics like pewter -- for the Pump step trainer, $109.99, to give the shoe an industrial look.

For men, the runner's Pump, $129.99, is done in white, sapphire blue, and bright purple. Ms. Bennett-Boucher says men don't usually wear such interesting colors, but they do tend to want colors that stand out on a running track.

In Manhattan, Reebok shoes are sold at Athletes' Foot, Paragon Sporting Goods, Herman's, Bloomingdale's, Macy's, and other major department stores.


LOAD-DATE: April 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos of fashions

USA TODAY


July 11, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Nike camp's fabulous 5 turns out as expected


BYLINE: Valerie Lynn Dorsey; Mark Coomes


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 8C


LENGTH: 368 words


Scouts skipped the surprises in compiling a consensus list of the best players at the Nike/ABCD high school basketball camp, which concluded Tuesday in Indianapolis.

Nike's fabulous five are already fixtures on college coaches' most-wanted lists.

- 6-9 center Othella Harrington of Jackson (Miss.) Murrah, the camp's second-leading rebounder (5.9 a game) and fourth-best field-goal shooter (55.8%). Averages are lower because campers played only half of each game. 

- 6-7 small forward Corliss Williamson of Russellville (Ark.) High, the No. 9 scorer (8.9 ppg).

- 7-foot center Rashard Griffith of Chicago King, the No. 6 rebounder (4.9).

- 6-7 swingman Rodrick Rhodes of Jersey City St. Anthony, who was not among statistical leaders but helped St. Anthony to a No. 2 ranking in USA TODAY's final Super 25 poll last season.

- 6-4 guard Jason Kidd of Alameda (Calif.) St. Joseph Academy, who was second in steals (2.5) and third in assists (3.6).

Scouts did add one new name to high school basketball's social register: Damon Flint, a previously unheralded guard from Cincinnati Woodward. Flint, a 6-4 junior, ranked seventh in scoring (9.3) and fourth in three-point shooting (43.8%).

SIGNED: Shawn Estes, a second team All-USA TODAY baseball player from Minden (Nev.) Douglas High, signed with the Seattle Mariners.

Estes, 18, was Seattle's No. 1 draft pick and the 11th player chosen overall in the June draft.

Estes, a left-hander, went 8-2 with a 0.80 ERA. He struck out 141 in 62 innings and allowed only 15 hits.

The Seattle Times reported that Estes received a $ 400,000 salary package. Included is his college education paid for by the Mariners.
 
JUNIOR BOWLERS: Youths from the USA, Puerto Rico, six Canadian provinces, the Far East, European and Caribbean military commands, compete in the National Junior Bowling Championships July 17-21 at Woodland Bowl in Indianapolis.

A total of $ 45,000 in scholarships will go to the top four finishers in each division: girls handicap, boys handicap, girls scratch and boys scratch, plus the All-America boy and girl as decided by the participants.

First-place finishers in each division receives a $ 5,000 scholarship.

USA TODAY


May 10, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Women get $ 25,000 incentive to 'break 25' in Nike 8K run


BYLINE: Dick Patrick


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 141 words


DATELINE: RUNNING


Judi St. Hilaire is trying not to think about the bonus. Lynn Jennings is thinking about it, but isn't making predictions. 

The two runners could earn a $ 25,000 bonus from Clairol for breaking 25 minutes in Sunday's Nike Women's Run 8K in Washington, D.C.

Jennings, the 1990 and '91 world cross-country champion, set a U.S. record of 25: 07 in the race two years ago.

''I was wicked out of shape, 10 pounds overweight,'' she says. ''It was one of those days when mental desire pulls you through.

''Breaking 25 depends on opponents, tactics, weather. You can't say you're going to break a record. It has to evolve.''

St. Hilaire beat Jennings in last year's race, finishing in 25: 10. ''The bonus is the last thing I'm thinking about,'' St. Hilaire says. ''I just want to be competitive. We'll run fast because the quality is there.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

USA TODAY


July 29, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Valvano set to coach Nike stars


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 139 words


Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his ouster when he joins the Nike All-Star team in Europe this fall.

The team will have just one day of practice before leaving Sept. 1 for the tour of Germany and France. 

Although Valvano was never accused of wrongdoing, he was forced to leave N.C. State 15 months ago, following NCAA violations by team members. But Valvano said his season as a college basketball analyst for ABC and ESPN since then has kept him sharp.

''Hey, I coached all of last year - coached my brains out,'' he said. ''I never lost a game, either.''

Valvano said he was assured of at least one victory against the German national team.

''I'll have (NBA All-Stars) Charles Barkley and David Robinson playing for me for that game,'' he said.

The New York Times


January 30, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Jordan Reserves Rights


SECTION: Section B; Page 13; Column 3; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 85 words


MICHAEL JORDAN has told the National Basketball Association it may no longer sell apparel bearing his image, giving Nike Inc. those rights exclusively.

The Oregonian in Portland, Ore., yesterday reported Jordan's decision, confirmed by the league. The move, unprecedented in the N.B.A., means millions of dollars. 

The 28-year-old Jordan, who led the Chicago Bulls to their first N.B.A. championship last year, is among the most charismatic -- and profitable -- personalities in the league. (AP)

MTI Econews


February 20, 1991


Nike-Fiocchi JV set up


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 266 words


    Budapest, February 20, 1991 (MTI-ECONEWS) - Niktrokemia
(Nike) Industrial Plants, based at Fuzfo, Western Hungary,
and the Italian company Fiocchi, have just set up a JV under
the name Nike-Fiocchi Sports Ammunition Manufacturing, Ltd. 
     The JV's initial capital of 10.4 million USD is equally
shared by two partners.
     The Italian partner contributed cash to the venture,
with the Hungarian chemical company putting up the site and
premises of its old gunpowder manufacturing plant.
     The JV's aim is to manufacture and distribute bullets
for hunting, sports and industrial purposes, and also to
design and assemble fireworks and pyrotechnical products.
     The JV has injected 4 million USD of the initial capital
into the purchase of Fiocchi technology and manufacturing
lines.
     The production and sales forecast is for 5 million US
dollars' worth of ammunition this year and 11 million US
ddollars' worth in 1992.
     The products will be marketed in both here in Hungary
and in Italy.


LOAD-DATE: February 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 MTI Hungarian News Agency

The Washington Post


July 29, 1991, Monday, Capital Edition


BASKETBALL


From news services and staff reports


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE B2; FANFARE


LENGTH: 120 words


Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his resignation 15 months ago with a 10-day stint with the Nike All-Star team in Europe this fall.

The team will have just one day of practice before leaving Sept. 1 for the tour of Germany and France. 

"We'll probably struggle," Valvano said. "They have teams that play together year to year, and our team will be more of a hodgepodge. We'll just do the best we can."

Although Valvano was never accused of wrongdoing, he was forced to leave N.C. State following NCAA violations by team members. But Valvano said his season as a college basketball analyst for ABC and ESPN since then has kept him sharp.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

693 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 7, 1992, Tuesday


Anti-diet experts seek to redefine 'overweight' Focus is shifting from stick-thin bodies to women's self-acceptance, shapeliness


BYLINE: By Elizabeth Coady STAFF WRITERhealth; women; media; medicine; fashion


SECTION: LIVING; Section C; Page 4


LENGTH: 1145 words


There's a backlash against dieting and America's narcissistic obsession with thinness.

Dieting and stick figures are out.

Self-acceptance and shapeliness are in.

Honest imperfection is being trumpeted by a new wave of experts who contend that dieting almost always fails and frequently causes eating disorders. 

Even Nike, the '80s purveyor of sports gear, is getting in on the attitude, with a series of advertisements reminding women they may not be goddesses, but the ground beneath them is still worthy of worship.

"We know the hype is that if you want a good life, you have to be thin," says Carole Shaw, publisher of Big Beautiful Women magazine. "You're going to have a better life, you're going to have a better guy, you're going to have a better job. If we could only be what we're not.

"In real life, people of all sizes are having good and bad lives," she says. "Being thin doesn't guarantee you a wonderful life."

In 1990, the U.S. government loosened its dietary weight guidelines, except for men and women with health problems and a propensity to carry their bulk in their belly, which has higher health risks.

"The focus was to look at a healthy weight," says Jackie Haven, a nutritionist at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. "The number may not be flattering in terms of appearance. Some may think that they still are too heavy. . . . But in terms of their health, it may not make a difference."

The about-face is being hailed as a breakthrough by weight-control experts emphasizing dieters' self-esteem over weight. The experts are attempting to teach individuals to use food for nutritional reasons rather than as a sedative or a pastime.

"I'm thrilled that finally people are recognizing what women have known forever: that diets don't work," says Carol M. Munter, a New York psychotherapist and co-author of "Overcoming Overeating" (Addison-Wesley, $ 15.34). "People are finally beginning to take the evidence seriously and give up dieting."

"We get put on diets because we live in a culture that refuses to acknowledge that people come in different shapes and sizes," she says.

At the University of Toronto, "We spend most of our time helping these women realizing that they deserve to be respected," says Dr. Janet Polivy, a dieting researcher.

Diets 'don't work'

Experts are also trying to convince dieters, most of whom are women, to take their lives off hold. Many overweight people postpone job and social opportunities with the idea of losing weight.

"One woman who went through the program was waiting to apply for a job promotion until she lost 50 pounds," says Dr. Polivy, who pointed out to the woman that she had been at the job three years. The woman applied for the promotion and got it.

The new approach is advocated for individuals just a few pounds away from their ideal figure as well as to obese people.

Diets "don't work any better for people who are 400 pounds than for people who are 20 pounds overweight," says Susan Wooley, an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Cincinnati who began studying obesity in 1969. "We keep deluding ourselves."

As a college student, 5-foot-6 Susan Copeland of Marietta was a trim 128 pounds. But through the years she gradually grew to her current 153 pounds.

About 18 months ago, she tried dropping 10 pounds by using liquid diets and skipping an occasional meal. The weight stayed on, and the 34- year-old medical assistant stopped trying about six months ago.

"Since people tell me that I don't look that weight, that helps me deal with it better," she says. "I'm just content right now. . . . My priority is to eat right and to exercise and to just be healthy."

At 300 pounds, Judi Dandy of Stone Mountain used to peer into the mirror and see a fat, ugly, worthless woman. "For so many years I had been down on myself simply because of my size," she says.

She tried dieting but always regained the weight. "After I gained the last 100 pounds back, I said, 'The hell with this.' "

The 48-year-old says she's become happier and more sociable and has begun eating more healthfully since she stopped dieting. Her weight stabilized at 275 pounds.

While the new approach is welcomed by those who once struggled to be svelte, other experts say advising severely overweight individuals not to worry is foolhardy at best - and even dangerous.

"If you don't want to call it a diet, that's all right," says Dr. Reubin Andres, clinical director of the National Institute on Aging Gerontology Research Center. "But you have to control food intake. . . . To just say, 'Be happy with your body,' I can't do that."

The risk of being obese

Severely overweight individuals run higher risks for developing diabetes, hypertension, coronary artery disease and early death, Dr. Andres says. But he acknowledges, "The big argument has to do with just what is the best range of weights."

Nevertheless, anti-diet experts argue that two decades of clinical observation and psychological studies show diets contribute to obesity and eating disorders. They point out that about 95 percent of people who lose weight gain it back within five years, and that "yo-yo dieting" - the cycle of gaining, losing, then gaining weight again - is suspected of causing heart disease.

"There's nothing wrong with watching what you eat," says Ms. Dandy, founder of Southeast Super Singles, who with a friend recently opened the Refinery consignment shop for large women in Alpharetta. "But when you become a fanatic and when society is so focused on the perfect bod, this is what's causing the problem."

"If there was any diet that worked, we would all go on one diet and that would be the end of it," says Ms. Shaw, who founded BBW 13 years ago. "But there's 27,000 diets out there."

Dieters are also more likely to binge, says Dr. Polivy, who has documented differences between chronic dieters and non-dieters.

Because of this, Ms. Munter and her colleague Jane R. Hirschmann, who both counsel overweight women, eliminate any controls on the type of food clients can eat. Instead, they teach how to recognize hunger and avoid eating out of boredom, depression or anxiety.

But Dr. Andres says high diet-failure statistics should not be used to dissuade obese individuals from dieting. "It's a dismal prognosis," he says, "but it would almost be like saying, 'Look, you have cancer, we have a drug, but it's only going to cure 5 percent of the people who take it. Do you want the drug or not?' "

But Ms. Dandy welcomes the new advice. "At one time I hated myself, and now I love myself." Counseling and tips from BBW magazine helped convince her she had value.

"People treat me with respect, and I think it's because I respect myself more," she says. "I dress in much more fashionable clothing. Before, it was like, 'What difference would it make? A fat lob is a fat lob.' "


LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH921910181


GRAPHIC: photo: Judi Dandy (right) says she's happier since she gave up dieting. She and Jan Nance have opened a consignment clothing shop for large women. / WALTER STRICKLIN / Staff photo: Nike has jumped on the self-acceptance bandwagon.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 27, 1991, Thursday


New Jersey will net Anderson big shoe deal


BYLINE: By Mike Fish Staff writerAbS Being picked No. 2 overall by New Jersey rather than No. 3 by Sacramento not only means a bigger NBA contract for Kenny Anderson, it also means a bigger shoe contract. From a shoe marketing standpoint, a would-be pitchman's earning potential is far greater in the New York-New Jersey area than in Sacramento. Officials at Nike confirmed the company is negotiating to add Anderson to its stable of marquee NBA talent, which includes Michael Jordan, and that he is now in position to probably demand a better shoe deal.


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION F; PAGE 08


LENGTH: 225 words


Being picked No. 2 overall by New Jersey rather than No. 3 by Sacramento not only means a bigger NBA contract for Kenny Anderson, it also means a bigger shoe contract.

From a shoe marketing standpoint, a would-be pitchman's earning potential is far greater in the New York-New Jersey area than in Sacramento. 

Officials at Nike confirmed the company is negotiating to add Anderson to its stable of marquee NBA talent, which includes Michael Jordan, and that he is now in position to probably demand a better shoe deal.

Anderson can expect to receive a yearly shoe contract for about $ 400,000 playing in New Jersey, versus $ 300,000 in the smaller Sacramento market.

"I think it's much harder to market a guy in Sacramento," said Fred Schreyer, Nike's director of sports marketing. "You'll be on a bad team that no one is ever going to see. While New Jersey isn't a great team and no one will see them much, either, you do have the New Jersey-New York thing and Kenny being a New York schoolboy legend."

Sports agent Leigh Steinberg, who represents many of the top NFL quarterbacks, is making his first venture into the basketball arena as the agent for Nevada-Las Vegas guard Greg Anthony. Steinberg's football clients include Warren Moon, Troy Aikman and Jeff George. basketball; personalities; advertising; salaries


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

700 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


March 19, 1991 Tuesday


Boys' shoes stolen


LENGTH: 157 words


THREE youths threatened to stab two boys unless they handed over their expensive sport shoes yesterday, police said.

Police said the three robbers chased two 13-year-old Port Melbourne boys from a light rail station near Ferras St, South Melbourne, about 4pm before swiping the runners. 

The attack is part of a disturbing trend of robberies on youngsters for their expensive clothing and footwear.

Police said the robbers bundled the shoes, a $250 pair of Jordan Nike basketball shoes and a $180 pair of Nike Chers, into a black knapsack carried by one of the robbers.

The boys told police one youth told them to hand over their runners or they would be stabbed.

The robbers are described as aged 15 to 17, and police believe one of them had short red hair and a solid build.

Anyone with information about the attack should contact Sen. Det.Gerry Richardson, of South Melbourne CIB, on 696 0122.

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS

702 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


March 19, 1992, Thursday, Final Edition


Players vs. U.S. on Olympic Marketing;
At Issue Is Control of Their Likenesses on Games-Related Apparel


David Aldridge, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D4


LENGTH: 533 words


It appears that only Michael Jordan is at the center of the latest controversy over the U.S. men's Olympic basketball team's licensing rights. Agents for three other Olympians, two of them yesterday, said that their clients have not been notified of any requirement to comply with an agreement to surrender their likenesses for marketing purposes.

NBA Properties, the league's marketing arm and the Olympic licensing agent for USA Basketball, had reportedly asked all Olympians to comply with an agreement under which NBA Properties would have the rights to sell apparel with their caricatures. If the players don't comply, they would be asked to resign from the team. 

Jordan met with his agent and attorney, ProServ's David Falk, in Annapolis yesterday to decide on a course of action.

Meanwhile, Utah's John Stockton, according to USA Today, wrote USA Basketball and said he wanted to play, no matter the guidelines. Stockton is also a ProServ client, as is New York's Patrick Ewing.

At issue, once again, is an exclusive agreement between several players -- including Jordan -- and Nike, the shoe and apparel company. Under this agreement, the players have given Nike the right to use their likenesses in the sale of apparel, including T-shirts. And several players have in the last month asked the league to stop using their likenesses in the sale of apparel.

Kyle Rote, the agent for Olympian Scottie Pippen, a teammate of Jordan on the Chicago Bulls, said the rumor about an ultimatum from the league "is not factually correct. Everyone is excited about being on the Olympic team and representing the country. . . . Michael is on a different level as far as marketing."

"The rest of us appear to be on the sidelines until further notice," another Olympian's agent said.

But a league source did make contents of a March 3 letter from USA Basketball President Dave Gavitt to Nike President Phil Knight available to The Washington Post. In this letter, Gavitt warned Knight that "we reserve the right to replace any of the six [Nike represented] players on the Olympic team if Nike continues to provide resistance."

Gavitt declined to comment on the substance of any allegations, saying, "I view this whole episode, right now, as a non-story. We have 10 players [on the team] who are good players, and more important, good guys. We have acceptances from all of them and they'll honor them [the commitments]. The Olympic team is about playing for America. It's not about agents or agencies."

Jordan wondered Tuesday if NBA Properties wouldn't make a profit from the sale of apparel while the players surrendered rights to do the same. NBA Properties is representing USA Basketball because USA is a nonprofit organization.

He told reporters, "If it's going to be the way they laid it out to be, then it's going to be tough to swallow -- accept their rules or send in your resignation. I'm saying, 'I'm not here to resign from the Olympics, and I'm not here to accept your guidelines.' "

There was no word last night on what course of action Falk and Jordan would take, with the Bulls in town to play the Washington Bullets tonight. Falk did not return telephone calls.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

704 of 998 DOCUMENTS



Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)


July 27, 1992 Monday  
Late Edition


JORDAN SHOOTS A FEW FOR THE SHOE COMPANY;
OLYMPIC EXTRA


BYLINE: GARRY LINNELL


SECTION: SPECIAL SUPPLEMENT; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 534 words


BARCELONA, Sunday: The shoe salesman from Carolina sat with his hands clasped and spoke nicely about his golf game, his two children and what a privilege it was to be here. His fellow salesman from the Ukraine smiled and agreed. 

In front of them sat more than 1,000 representatives of the world's media. Flashes popped and television cameras recorded every look and every word. Selling shoes had never been easier.

Mind you, these were not your average shoe salesmen. No squeezing small shoes on to smelly, blistering feet for these two. One of them, Michael Jordan, the man from Carolina who now plies his trade in Chicago, earns more than $25 million a year. Sergey Bubka, too, lives comfortably.

These are the Olympics, and another round of Shoe Wars has begun. Nike, Reebok and a host of other shoe companies are all in Barcelona flogging their merchandise and reminding everyone how many champions they have signed to their labels.

It was Nike's turn to do the boasting on the weekend, and it used Jordan and world pole-vault record holder Bubka to do it. A cinema in downtown Barcelona was booked for the event, and 15 minutes before the conference began the place was packed.

For 50 minutes Jordan and Bubka answered questions, and when you left you felt as though you had spent half a day at a convention of advertising agents. Nike signs hung from platforms, and outside in the street a red bus with an inflated shoe pumped out loud rock music. It was all tacky, contrived, and in the end, virtually meaningless.

"I'm not here because of money," said Jordan, referring to competing in the Olympics.

"Nike did not influence me - I came strictly on my own initiative."

What did he feel about the way sport has been commercialised, particularly since he was sitting on a stage wearing his sponsor's products and endorsing what a terrific bunch they were?

"Commercialism is a part of all professional sports," he said.

That was about as interesting as it got. The rest of the time was spent listening to sycophantic questions about how wonderful it must be to be able to soar like a bird, or dull replies, several of which sounded as though they had been rehearsed for a few minutes outside.

The media has no-one but itself to blame. With Jordan's fame at a peak around the world - it is claimed he is the most recognisable sporting figure on the planet these days, usurping Muhammed Ali - he has said the same things over and over until he has to click off.

The Dream Team has been criticised for not living in the Athletes' Village in Barcelona, preferring the security and comfort of a five-star hotel. They dropped in to the village the other day, explained Jordan, but felt the atmosphere would not have helped them prepare for the basketball tournament. It would be the same as living outside in the glare of the public. Athletes would be asking for autographs and pictures, he said, small-time officials would be hanging from their shirt-tails.

So instead Jordan lives on his own and occasionally drops into a planned media conferences to flog his sponsor's products. Then he departs just as quickly to go back and hide inside the bubble which is his private life. Shoe salesmen have never had it so tough.


LOAD-DATE: July 21, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1992 John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd
All Rights Reserved

 

708 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Age (Melbourne, Australia)


September 23, 1992 Wednesday  
Late Edition


In Brief


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24


LENGTH: 285 words


US housing boost Construction starts on new homes and apartments in the United States jumped in August at the strongest rate in 18 months, the Commerce Department said today. The annual rate of starts on new homes climbed by 10.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted 1.24million units, after back-to-back declines. 

Nike record Nike yesterday reported record quarterly earnings and became the first company in the sports and fitness industry to generate more than $US1 billion ($A1.38billion) in revenues during a single quarter. Nike's net income for the three-month period, which ended 31 August, was $US122.59 million, or $US1.60 a share, an increase of seven per cent.

Field may hold more The minerals and energy group Devex believes its Tubridgi gasfield in the Pilbara region of Western Australia could hold much more gas than originally thought. "There could be several more times gas in Tubridgi than the 64 billion cubic feet figure used at the moment," the managing director, Mr George White, said yesterday in Perth.

HMA profits creep up The flour miller HMA has shrugged off restructuring costs to post a net profit of just over $1.06 million for 1991-92, up 11 per cent from the previous year. The company said in a statement yesterday that the profit result was achieved despite a drop in sales revenue of 16 per cent to $102 million.

YSL in sharp fall Yves Saint Laurent, one of the most famous Paris fashion houses, suffered a sharp fall in net profits from 41 million francs ($A11.2 million) in the first half of 1991 to 2.6 million francs in the same period this year, reflecting the depressed state of the global luxury goods market. The company stressed that the first half was traditionally slack.

710 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


November 17, 1992, Tuesday


Reebok takes a fashionable turn


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section F; Page 2


LENGTH: 225 words


Last time Reebok tried to sell its sneakers with fashion ads in 1989, the campaign went over like brown shoes with a tuxedo.

Nike - hyping its sneakers for their performance - jumped past stumbling Reebok to become the nation's No. 1 athletic shoemaker. 

Now Reebok is trying fashion ads again to try to gain ground on archrival Nike - which has 30 percent of the U.S. market compared with Reebok's 26 percent.

This time Reebok's campaign is smarter: It's for only one line, the "classic" soft leather aerobics shoe. And the fashion pitch is refashioned to seem more like a performance pitch.

The target: the same people who bought the shoes in the mid-1980s.

The estimated $ 5 million magazine campaign features thirtysomething men and women engaging in recreational activities - biking, touch football - but clearly taking it easy, and looking good in Reeboks. The slogan: "Reebok Classic. Never Gets Old."

David Ropes, vice president of marketing services for Reebok, says the ads capture the "emotional relationship" people have with the old shoes, as opposed to Reebok's newfangled, high-tech sneakers, such as The Pump.

The ads are running in People, Esquire and GQ, among other magazines. They were created by Mullen Advertising of Hamilton, Mass., the same agency that created the successful campaign for Smart Food popcorn.


LOAD-DATE: November 21, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923260156


GRAPHIC: photo: Reebok New ads for "classic" Reeboks promote the aerobics shoes as a blend of fashion and performance.


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


January 23, 1991, Wednesday


Dooley's outside' windfall; Non-coaching revenue 2 1/2 times of base salary


BYLINE: By David Davidson Staff writeruga; football; basketball; personnel; salaries; benefits; advertising; endorsements; earnings


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 223 words


Vince Dooley, man of many hats, made at least $ 374,000 in 1986 for - among other things - wearing many hats.

An Alabama company that makes Georgia hats gave Dooley, whose salary as football coach and athletics director at the time was $ 95,000, 12 dozen hats and paid him 2 percent of the gross sales of Bulldogs hats. 

Dooley's 1986 income was the subject of a three-year court fight between Dooley and The Journal-Constitution. The Georgia Supreme Court recently ordered Dooley, who retired as football coach Jan. 1, 1989, but remains athletics director, plus basketball coaches Hugh Durham and Andy Landers to disclose their incomes.

A similar case, seeking the outside incomes of athletics officials at Georgia Tech, including athletics director Homer Rice, football coach Bobby Ross and basketball coach Bobby Cremins, is pending in Superior Court.

Dooley's outside income is by no means unusual. Last year, for instance, Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz's salary was $ 90,000, but his total income $ 750,000.

Dooley made more than 2 1/2 times his base salary by being a media personality (nearly $ 200,000 from TV and radio contracts), a shoe salesman ($ 30,000 for endorsing Nike footwear), an orator ($ 12,000 from speaking engagements) and a camp counselor ($ 5,250 from the Bulldog Football Camp).


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
