The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 14, 1991, Thursday


GAMES & FACES; Bo knows just how to rock the media if he's on a roll


BYLINE: Tom Whitfieldsports; personalities


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 765 words


Among the things Bo Jackson knows is how to give the media short rations. But it was a different story this week in Portland, Ore., where Nike Inc., one of Jackson's many employers, decided to hold a news conference for high school journalists.

With two of his own children watching from a balcony above, Jackson charmed the group with stories about his poor upbringing in rural Alabama and how he became rich and famous.

His description of himself: "A nappy-headed kid who threw rocks better than some people could shoot a gun."; Caddyshack update

Occasionally, Sheryl Calcavecchia serves as caddie for her husband Mark at PGA Tour events. Noting that caddies' salaries often involve a percentage of the player's earnings, Mark observed:

"She's the only one I know of who gets 100 percent."; The Doctor is out 

In his new book "Valvano: They Gave Me a Lifetime Contract, and Then They Declared Me Dead," former N.C. State basketball coach Jim Valvano explains why he's working as a TV announcer instead of a scout.

In the late 1960s, while coaching the freshman team at Rutgers for Bill Foster, Valvano was sent to Long Island to check out a 6-foot-3 center touted by his brother. Valvano wasn't impressed, and here's the rest of the story:

"Oh, the kid visited Rutgers on his own anyway and still seemed very interested, but I convinced Foster he couldn't play at our level and that we should go after another player named Alan Cotler.

"I lost Cotler to Penn. He's now a lawyer in Philadelphia. I lost track of the other kid. He was in Philly, too, but I think he became a doctor or something. You ever hear of him? Kid's name is Julius Erving."; A fresh start

Rudy Galindo is back at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships this year, but as a solo performer, rather than as a defending pairs champion, now that his former partner, Kristi Yamaguchi, has decided to concentrate on her solo career.

Galindo has made one more adjustment in returning to singles for the first time since 1988: The spelling of his first name.

"I had changed it from Rudy to Rudi to match with Kristi," he said. "I'm into a new life and wanted everything to be fresh. So I'm back to Rudy."

Galindo smiles, jokes and avoids saying anything that could be construed as sour grapes about the end of his pairing with Yamaguchi. But it's apparent he was hurt by the parting.

"It's kind of hard to be out there by yourself," Galindo said this week as he prepared for the start of the championships. "A few times, I went to grab Kristi's hand, and it was not there."; A K' for history

Mark it down for posterity: Reid Ryan, 19-year-old son of Nolan, struck out the first batter he faced as a freshman at the University of Texas. The victim was a friend, Shayne Currin of Texas-Arlington, who spends his summers as bullpen catcher for the Texas Rangers.

Reid Ryan's fastball was clocked in the 85 mph range, and his curveball was sharp as he pitched two innings, giving up one run.

His dad didn't make the 150-mile trip from Alvin to Austin for the debut. But they'll see each other April 2 as opposing pitchers in an exhibition game.; He's learning fast

From the Associated Press: When Wayne Gretzky turned 30 last month, Los Angeles Kings owner Bruce McNall gave him a horse they saw being born while they were at the Kentucky Derby.

Gretzky and McNall are partners in the racing business, so Gretzky gave half back to McNall.

"I kept the front half, because I have learned that is the one that crosses the finish line first," joked Gretzky.; For the record . . .

- Canada's Helen Kelesi rallied from a 3-0 deficit in the third set to upset third-seeded Jana Novotna 2-6, 7-6, 7-6 in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tennis tournament. No. 2 seed Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria won her match against Ann Grossman.

- Boris Becker beat Alexander Volkov 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 in the opening round of the Donnay Indoor Championship in Brussels, Belgium.

- MaliVai Washington beat No. 16 seed Patrick McEnroe 6-0, 6-3 to advance to the quarterfinals of the $ 1 million U.S. Pro Indoor Tennis Championship in Philadelphia. (Complete tennis results, G9).

- As many as 50 intramural male and female basketball teams from area colleges will meet in the Schick Super Hoops Regional Festival on Feb. 23 at Georgia State. The top male and female teams from the one-day tournament will play their championship games March 23 at The Omni as part of the Hawks-Miami game.

Got a tip for Games & Faces? Give us a call on the message line at 222-2034.

716 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


August 8, 1992, Saturday, Final Edition


Corporations Bask In Reflected Glory;
Business Benefactors Pervade Games


William Drozdiak, Washington Post Foreign Service


SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1


LENGTH: 930 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA, Aug. 7


As the Summer Olympics draw to a close and nations around the world assess their stature in the medals table, the biggest winners emerging from this global extravaganza are not the athletes, their coaches or their governments, but their corporate sponsors.

More than any other Olympic gathering in history, these Games have served as a glittering showcase for big business. Instead of praising parents or other inspirational role models behind their accomplishments, the athletes now regularly express gratitude and devotion to the corporate entities that pay them hefty endorsements.

The emblems of Nike or Reebok are as prominent as the national flag on many uniforms. Companies rather than national Olympic committees dictate the public appearances of athletes. The entire 900-member delegation of the former Soviet Union, attending the Games for the last time as the Unified Team, was underwritten by a $ 3.5 million grant from Smirnoff and adidas. 

"They made it possible for us to be here," said Alexander Kozlovsky, vice president of the Russian Olympic Committee.

Once viewed as a grim contest between rival political systems, the Olympics began turning into a global commercial fair with the 1984 Games in Los Angeles. Instead of resorting to public funding, the Games were entirely financed by the private sector and turned a handsome profit of $ 230 million.

"The world is changing and we have to adapt to it," said Juan Antonio Samaranch, the monarchical chairman of the International Olympic Committee. "The Games might have come to an end if we did not bring commercial sponsors into the Games because cities and countries no longer can afford to stage them alone. The taxpayers will not stand for it."

The collapse of communism in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe over the past three years removed the dichotomy of Cold War conflict from Olympic competition. In these Games, the Soviet athletes say they have been motivated to perform well chiefly by the need to attract corporate support in order to sustain their future athletic careers.

For big business, marketing at the Olympics has become fierce competition. With more than 1 billion people watching the Games, the most desirable marketing goal for many companies is to see their brand name associated with the prestige and skills of the world's finest athletes. Country affiliation has dimmed.

The ultimate high-stakes battle in these Games has pitted Nike against Reebok. Nike commands the loyalties -- for a generous stipend -- of six members of the U.S. basketball team. For that reason, Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley, two of Nike's most highly compensated endorsers, adamantly refuse to be seen in the U.S. team's Reebok-designed warmup suits at the medals ceremony. They will be allowed to unzip the jacket to block public view of the Reebok logo.

"In 1984, we had triple the number of athletes today," Steve Miller, Nike's director of sports marketing, said in an interview. "But now you just can't afford to have them all. So we are trying to get the athletes who are best in their events who also have the best impact for us in the global market."

When Mike Powell's hamstring was troubling him before the long jump competition, he missed a morning news conference called by Nike so he could get treatment. No problem. A call to gold-medal-winning triple jumper Mike Conley, who won his event the night before, quickly produced a substitute.

Asked how he felt about appearing on such short notice, Conley said, "When they call, I go."

Nike has grown into a $ 3.5 billion-a-year business. More than two-thirds of its annual revenue comes from sales in the United States, but in the future the foreign sector is expected to grow dramatically. Thinking ahead, Nike is now feverishly competing to recruit the allegiance of top athletes in growing markets. It issued an occasional newsletter (titled Swoosh) on its athletes, something no national Olympic Committee, aside from the USOC, did. It issued a slick magazine -- Barcelona '92 -- featuring its athletes.

In Africa, Nike has signed up the Kenyan runners Richard Chelimo, William Mutwol and Yobes Ondieki. Noureddine Morceli, the Algerian 1,500-meter champion, is considered a key wedge into a youth-oriented North African market.

For Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States, Nike has invested a huge sum in Sergei Bubka, the Ukrainian world-record holder in the pole vault whose failure to win a medal in this year's Olympics could diminish his marketing appeal.

Nike is also looking toward China, whose 1.2 billion people may represent the biggest untapped market for high-class sporting goods in the world. Tong Li, the 110 hurdles star, has endorsed Nike, and other top Chinese athletes may soon follow.

Chelimo finished second in the men's 10,000 Monday night, then was awarded the gold medal on a judge's ruling of interference. On Tuesday the decision was reversed and Chelimo met the media to discuss it -- in a news conference set up by Nike, not the IOC or the Kenyan delegation.

Reebok has countered Nike's push by signing up Olympic basketball coach Chuck Daly, U.S. runner Suzy Hamilton and German tennis star Michael Stich. Reebok's biggest promotional tie-in was sidetracked when Dan O'Brien (of the ubiquitous Dan and Dave commercials) failed to qualify for the U.S. decathlon team.

Corporate officials acknowledge that the endorsements of gold-medal winners are no guarantee for commercial success. "It's always a gamble because you never know what will click," said Miller.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, BASKETBALL STARS MICHAEL JORDAN (LEFT) AND CHARLES BARKLEY SPEAK FIRST FOR NIKE.


TYPE: FOREIGN NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

720 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


April 2, 1991, Tuesday, FIRST EDITION


SPORTS BUSINESS;
Marketing duo tries to undo adidas' 'boring' image


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 3C


LENGTH: 492 words


Rob Strasser predicts the future of feet.

Strasser and partner Peter Moore helped create Nike's Air Jordan and Nike Air lines. Now Strasser lives in Herzogenaurach, Germany, as a marketing vice president for adidas. Together with Moore, working in the pair's Portland, Ore., marketing firm, Strasser says he's working to change adidas' image as a ''famous-but-boring brand.'' 

It's about time. Although Adi Dassler made his first gym shoe in 1920, adidas had a puny 4% share of the U.S. market last year - compared with Nike's 28% and Reebok's 21%.

While those giants tweak each other with mild wisecracks in TV ads, Strasser helped create a new adidas Equipment brand that will be rolled out nationally by August with a back-to-basics pitch. One Equipment ad, for instance, says sports isn't about ''greed ... arrogance (or) fashion.''

It's a pitch meant to attract baby boomers, many of whom are presumably becoming more sensible at the expense of their fashion sense. The shoemaker will rely on relatively low-key endorsers such as marathoner Grete Waitz. Laughs Strasser: ''The baby boomers are going to set the trends until the last one is dead.''

Another underdog, Converse, is relying on a practical pitch: It has launched a new ad campaign with the tagline ''It's What's Inside that Counts''.

But last night, adidas and Converse managed to score a conventional marketing coup in their uphill battle against the U.S. sneaker giants. Duke's basketball team wore adidas, Kansas wore Converse.

CHEST MATCH: Sam Marion recalls it as ''a hell of an experience.''

About 15 years ago, a player on a Little League team Marion managed was hit in the chest - and nearly died being rushed to the hospital.

Marion didn't forget. After borrowing heavily, Marion's International Protective Athletic Safety Corp. of Fraser, Mich., developed a $ 70 kids' safety vest suitable for baseball and other sports.

Marion's safety vest weighs 1.5 pounds and is made of compressed foam. They're available in about 50 stores so far.

They're overdue. The Consumer Products Safety Commission reports 51 baseball-related deaths between 1974 and 1984, and at least 13 in 1989-90. Last Saturday, a 15-year-old New Hampshire hockey player died after being hit with a puck in the chest.

Marion says he also has sold the Seattle Mariners on using his $ 80 adult safety jacket in practice. ''It won't be long,'' says ex-major leaguer Lary Sorensen, ''until you see most pro clubs using them.''

BLOW OUT: Smokefree Educational Services, a health advocacy group, says it will include Little Leaguers as protesters in an opening day demonstration Monday against the Marlboro billboard in New York's Shea Stadium. The group is offering to pay the New York Mets to replace the cigarette marketer. ... Saying it wants to export U.S. traditions, the World League of American Football is starting a month-long scratch-off promotion sponsored by Kentucky Fried Chicken.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w
 
CUTLINE: BASIC EQUIPMENT: adidas is trying back-to-basics theme to sell common sense-oriented baby boomers on its Equipment line.


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

723 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 5, 1992, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final


BARCELONA: NOTEBOOK;
Don't Like the Sponsor? Just Zip It


BYLINE: Special to The New York Times


SECTION: Section B; Page 13; Column 3; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 704 words


DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain


All members of the Dream Team will be there on the medal podium after all, apparently, if the Dream Team is fortunate enough to win medals.

Another controversy has been resolved with the compromise that anyone (Michael Jordan) who has a personal corporate sponsor (Nike) who objects to the team sponsor's name (Reebok) showing on the standard-issue uniform (United States) has the right to obscure what he does not want to show (logo). 

"However," Dave Gavitt, president of USA Basketball, said in a statement after meeting with United States Olympic Committee officials, "in no instance will the uniforms be defaced or covered by any other material."

So what does that mean?

"They can turn down their collars to cover the logo," a U.S.O.C. staffer said. "But we can't say that."
 
 
Party Out of Bounds

The athletes' village may appear at first glance to be a peaceful splash of high rises beside the sea but it is turning into party central. Today, a spokesman at the village said he was calling in police to begin patrols, in response to complaints about late-night noise.

"It's the only way to control the situation," said Armando Calvo, who reported complaints from some residents about athletes being loud and drunken. "Sometimes they get into arguments with volunteers checking their credentials."

El Mundo Deportivo, the Spanish sports daily, reports that the problem is largely centered on athletes who have already finished their competition. They play their music loud and return less than quietly from late parties.

"Maybe it's a mistake to give free housing; because of that, no one is leaving," said Li Gwang Sik, the North Korean bantamweight who defeated Serafim Todorov of Bulgaria on Monday to gain the boxing semifinals.

But the boxer said he understood the urge to party. "They can't make us live a monk life," he told the paper. "We're free now."
 
 
How About Dan and Robert?

Reebok doesn't have Dan and Dave in the decathlon, but it has Dave and Robert. That's Robert Zmelik of Czechoslovakia, who is a long shot to medal in the event but is welcome on Reebok's team anyway.
 
 
Tale of the Tape, and Ice Packs

The supplies are going fast for the American athletes here. Ed Ryan, head trainer for United States Olympic Committee operations at the athletes village, says American athletes have already used up 3,500 rolls of tape, 5,000 ice packs and 4,000 bandages, not to mention 1,200 disposable electric stimulation pads for use with ultrasound equipment. Ryan said there was nothing abnormal in the numbers. "We're finding dehydration is one of our biggest problems to date," he said. "The heat and humidity are creating havoc for our athletes."
 
Used Syringes Found in Village

Used syringes -- possibly for injecting vitamins -- have been found in the rooms of some athletes staying in the Olympic village.

"It appears the athletes are doing the injections themselves," said Prince Alexandre de Merode, chairman of the International Olympic Committee medical commission. De Merode said that housekeepers have been complaining about finding the syringes in wastebaskets. "I can't prejudge what they were used for," he said. "It could be nothing. It could be an innocent product like vitamins.

"But I believe this is dangerous," he said. "Athletes should be careful not to take any medication without consulting their medical doctor."

Armando Calvo, director of the Olympic Village, said needles have been found "on a general basis" throughout the village, rather than in one area. He said the cleaning company had not specified the number of syringes.

Jim Montgomery, head physician for the United States team, said it's not uncommon for athletes to take injections of vitamin B-12.

"I know for a fact that when countries came into the village, the Polyclinic ran out of B-12 and they had to get an extra supply," he said. "Everyone wanted some. A lot of our track and field guys have wanted shots."

Montgomery said he doesn't hand out syringes or let the athletes administer the injections themselves.

"We have all our used syringes right here at the sports medicine center in the village," Montgomery said. "We give the shots ourselves."(AP)


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

726 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 30, 1992, Friday


Bad image for Sanders? It's gotta be the shoes


BYLINE: By Thomas Stinsonsports; football; basketball; personalities; advertising; fashion; salaries


SECTION: SPORTS; Section H; Page 1


LENGTH: 684 words


This began as another pinata job upon the brow of Deion Sanders, who continues to dismay even when he takes his days off. Amazing. He can't make practice with the Falcons because he's having a foot inspected by a team of doctors but can still be profiling that night courtside - said foot not even wrapped - when the Hawks bring Shaquille O'Neal to town. (Fashion tip: Time, my man, to stash the Huntz Hall wardrobe.)

Worse, on the day most of the Braves take an opportunity to thank the city for another wild ride, Sanders is indisposed, vogueing in some crosstown gym for another Nike ad. This borders on civic insult. Whatever was done this month to mythicize his athletic abilities, Sanders did residual damage to his local image simultaneously, the McCarver water business a dubious quinella with the Nike air circus. 

To appear publicly with the Braves would be a hint at contrition, never a Sanders long suit. Perhaps one day, the blessed athlete will realize his life is something more than one long punt return.

But the deeper one considers the plight of Deion Sanders, one keeps bumping his head up against a shoe company with its tongs so deep into the back of America's No. 1 cornerback/outfielder. Nike has grown proficient at this, for its tongs seem to reach everyone everywhere.

Ross Perot tells the American electorate to Just Do It. The world comes to Barcelona to find five stories of Michael Jordan - and the boomerang logo - hanging from a building downtown. Morehouse's football team needs new shoes; alum Spike Lee's endorsement comes through, 120 pairs strong. Georgia Tech's basketball team to France? Nike ponies up $ 100,000.

In court as well as on court

Naturally, a company so keen on its inflated ownself can't help but periodically make a mess. Who on earth but Nike was able to pit John Thompson against the Rev. Jesse Jackson? Kids kill kids and take their $ 170 sneakers. The company is now in a snit over Jordan's appearance in a Hanes underwear commercial, fretting over His Airness's impugned image, the same image that helped sell $ 200 million of Air Jordan gear last year alone.

Alas. But if there is no altruism left in peddling athletic footwear - what happened to the singular promise of "run faster, jump higher?" - there surely is no accounting for how Nike handles its front men. The company was all too happy to provide the private jet for the Miami- Pittsburgh shuttle that puckered Sanders's relationship with Braves brass. And who scheduled Tuesday's ad shoot so who couldn't be where?

In Sanders, Nike has hooked a kid with a sublime weakness for money, and should anyone think Sanders can't keep this up, their $ 3 million deal is slashed 90 percent should Sanders stop splitting time between baseball and football. Though this leans toward indentured servitude, Sanders views the deal as the underpining to his portfolio, barking at reporters during the NLCS, "I don't need no publicity. My contract with Nike is set."

The Mourning after for Charlotte

Tell the Charlotte Hornets. Latest to roll off the Georgetown-Nike assembly line, Alonzo Mourning was chosen second in the last draft by Charlotte, which is now attempting to sign the rookie who already has a $ 16 million Nike contract in his pocket. Mourning demands a $ 2.6 million starting salary. The Hornets have but $ 1.96 million available under the salary cap. An Auerbachian nightmare, the rook has all the leverage. So untenable is Charlotte's position, at least five NBA scouts watched the team's last exhibition in readiness for the inevitable fire sale.

This is how shoes are sold in America. As if Nike was actually ever a shoe company. The Oregon firm merely designs and markets the models, all manufacturing doled out to sweatshops in Thailand, China and Taiwan. And for all the marketing, all the Bo and Prime Time and Just Doing It, an Athletic Footwear Association survey found only 12 percent of the 18- to-75 age group affected by celebrity endorsements.

Deion's world view is stilted enough. There's something else happening here. It's gotta be the shoes.


LOAD-DATE: November 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923100637


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

Herald Sun


February 15, 1991 Friday


Clarkson answers all the critics


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 408 words


DAVID CLARKSON has countered rumors about his commitment to Sunshine George Cross by grabbing a share of the lead in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

Clarkson, man of the match in the past two rounds, earned the player of the week title for his display against Wollongong Mac.

The three votes gives him 17 and equal leadership with St George keeper John Filan. 

"I had gone for five weeks without picking up votes so it's nice to get some reward for playing well," Clarkson said yesterday.

The midfielder returned to Melbourne yesterday after making a hurried dash across the Tasman to see his sick sister in Hobart.

Clarkson was a committed supporter of previous Sunshine coach Ernie Merrick, who brought him to the club from Adelaide City.

There were suggestions that Clarkson and teammate Craig Foster would walk out of the club after Merrick's dismissal but the player has killed off those rumors with his good form.

"I certainly didn't like the way Ernie was sacked but it's good to have Tony Vrzina around and it's very important for all the players to stick by the new coach," Clarkson said.

Clarkson admitted that desperation had played a part in his recent good form.

"All of us are playing for our survival as well as the club's," he said.

"I certainly hope the club won't be relegated but either way we have to try and lift ourselves and play better.

"If the worst was to happen and the club was relegated, the players will be judged on their performances if they are to get another club." As the weekly winner, Clarkson receives a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280. The end of season winner receives $2000 in cash from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award: Round 19 votes:. Adel City v Apia: 2 Maxwell (ac), 1 Csoboth (ac), 1 McFadden (al), 1 Maloney (al), 1 Zabica (ac).Melb Cro v Woll Cty: 3 Pezzano (wc), 2 Biskic (mc), 1 Talajich (mc). Marc v St Geo: 2 Harper (stg), 2 P.Okon (m), 1 O'Shea (stg), 1 Catlin (m). Melita v Preston M: 3 Trajanovski (pm), 2 Bekiaris (pm), 1 Tasevski (pm). Sth Melb v Syd Cro: 3 Kupresak (scr), 2 Franken (scr), 1 Tasios (sm). Syd Oly v Heid: 3 Saad (so), 2 Edwards (so), 1 Phillips (so). Woll Mac v Sunshine: 3 Clarkson (sgc), 2 Hunter (sgc), 1 Naumov (wm). Leaders: 17 Clarkson, Filan. 16 P.Okon. 15 Petersen.13 Bundalo, Petkovic. 12 Stubbins. 11 Biskic, Franken, Jackson, Kindtner, Kuc, Lowe, McCulloch. Phillips, Tsolakis.

END OF STORY

730 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Journal of Commerce


January 24, 1992, Friday


CLASH REPORTEDLY HURT HALLETT'S DOT DRIVE


BYLINE: MARK B. SOLOMON; Journal of Commerce Staff


SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 416 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


 

A clash between U.S. Customs Commissioner Carol B. Hallett and Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., contributed to blocking Mrs. Hallett's bid to be the next transportation secretary, industry and administration sources said Thursday.

Until Wednesday, when President Bush nominated Andrew H. Card for the post, Mrs. Hallett was considered the front-runner for it. But the Bush administration shifted gears after being notified by Sen. Packwood that he asn't happy with the choice, those sources said. 

"He had concerns, and he communicated them to the White House," according to an administration source.

Sources said Sen. Packwood and Mrs. Hallett crossed swords over the issue of fees assessed to Nike Inc., the Oregon-based footwear manufacturer. In particular, sources said, Sen. Packwood asked Mrs. Hallett to reverse a 1991 agency ruling adverse to Nike. Her refusal to do so led to an angry exchange between the two, sources said.

"She didn't bend to Packwood, and he became furious," said an industry executive close to Customs. The executive said the senator has often interceded on Nike's behalf in disputes with Customs.

Sen. Packwood sits on the Senate Commerce Committee, which is responsible for confirming Department of Transportation nominees.

Sen. Packwood denied reports that he sent a letter to the president advising him not to nominate Ms. Hallett, but declined to answer other questions about her. "I'm not going to stir up those waters now," he said.

Customs officials were unavailable for comment.

Grant Hanson, a Nike lobbyist, said the company imports millions of pairs of shoes each year and inevitably runs into conflicts with Customs over various issues. "I'm not sure if this was over a particular incident or if it might have been something brewing over a period of time," he said.

The choice of Mr. Card, who is currently deputy White House chief of staff, is being seen by some as a victory for Drew Lewis, Union Pacific Corp. chairman. Mr. Lewis lobbied for Mr. Card to win the DOT post, and had supported an effort to make him president of the Association of American Railroads.

It is unclear how much influence, if any, Mr. Lewis had in swaying President Bush. But he told securities analysts in New York Wednesday that Mr. Card's close ties to the president and his good working relationship with his predecessor, White House Chief of Staff Samuel K. Skinner, "means that transportation remains on the front burner for the administration."


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.

 

731 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


August 20, 1992, Thursday, North Suncoast Edition


Nike breaks off sponsorship deal with German sprinter Krabbe


BYLINE: PETE COUTURE


SECTION: SPORTS; SPORTS DIGEST; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 664 words


 

Nike broke off its sponsorship deal with Katrin Krabbe, the world sprint champion from Germany who's awaiting a four-year ban for failing a drug test. The sportswear company also abandoned a similar deal with Grit Breuer, Krabbe's teammate who also tested positive for a banned substance. "Every contract includes a clause that athletes are forbidden from taking performance-enhancing substances," said a Nike representative. Krabbe, the 100- and 200-meter world champion, and Breuer, the world silver medalist at 400 meters, tested positive for Clenbuterol, a muscle-building substance. Krabbe, 22, in an interview published Wednesday by the Super Illu magazine, said the athletes did not know that Clenbuterol was on the list of banned drugs. "I never consciously did anything that was forbidden," she told the magazine. "I am sorry if many fans are now disappointed in me." Thomas Springstein, coach of the two athletes, has admitted giving the drug to the two sprinters and his contract with Nike also has been canceled. The German Athletics Federation has suspended the two pending a hearing that is expected to impose the bans. 
 
 
   NBA: A day after announcing his retirement, Larry Bird was home in Indiana preparing to host a charity golf tournament. "You'll never see me at NBA games unless I'm there to work," said Bird, who will remain with the Boston Celtics as a special assistant. "I have no intentions to go on NBC (TV) and help them do games." Bird also said he doesn't want to get into coaching. On other news, the San Antonio Spurs signed free-agent guard Matt Othick of Arizona. The Chicago Bulls signed second-round draft pick Corey Williams of Oklahoma State to a multiyear contract. Terms were not disclosed; the Clippers signed free agent Charles Smith.
 
    GOLF: Tarpon Spring's Jay Overton led the North Florida PG Section Championship for the second day in a row after shooting a 7-under-par 65 at Bonnet Creek Golf Club in Orlando. Overton, the head pro at the Innisbrook Resort, is 18 under for 36 holes and takes a five-stroke advantage into the final round today. Mike Domalske of Sarasota shot 63 to move into second at 131.
 
    TRACK AND FIELD: Carl Lewis, who failed to make the U.S. Olympic team in the 100 meters, proved he is still a major force in sprinting by beating a world-class field at a meet in Zurich, Switzerland. Lewis, 31, powered through the final 30 yards and finished in 10.07 seconds, beating a field that included six finalists at Barcelona. Olympic champion Linford Christie of Britain had declined to take on Lewis at the meet.
 
    COLLEGE BASEBALL: Joey Arnold, who had a .360 batting average for Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville last season, is transferring to the University of Florida to play for his father, Gators coach Joe Arnold. Joey, a 6-foot-1, 180-pound shortstop, graduated from Gainesville High in 1990.
 
    BOWLING: Greg Kemp regained the lead after five rounds of the PBA's ABC West Lanes Open in Mechanicsburg, Pa. Kemp averaged 244 his first three games on the way to an 8,175 total. Jim Pencak averaged 241 his last eight games to move into second at 8,057. In other bowling, John Handegard had a pair of 268 games to take a 47-pin lead in the Lansing (Mich.) Senior Open.
 

 
   BOWLING: Bob Vespi averaged 243 in his last eight games to jump from third to first and will be the top seed for today's finals of the PBA ABC West Lanes Open in Mechanicsburg, Pa. Barry Gurney, a first-year pro, won his first title by defeating Tommy Evans 243-166 for the championship of the Lansing (Mich.) PBA Senior Open. Stacy Rider and Anne Marie Duggan became the first repeat winners of the LPBT's National Doubles Tournament.
 
    MISCELLANY: Mildred "Millie" Schembechler, wife of former Michigan football coach and former Detroit Tigers president Bo Schembechler, died of cancer in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 63.
  Compiled by Pete Couture.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 1992

Jet


April 6, 1992


Jordan's Face Absent From Olympic Apparel


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 50


LENGTH: 100 words


In a compromise move, Michael Jordan's face will not appear on t-shirts featuring the U.S. Olympic basketball team, and instead, Nike Corp., which owns the rights to Jordan's likeness on apparel, will pay a financial settlement to USA Basketball, which is sponsoring the U.S. Olympic team. 

The NBA had threatened to ban players from the U.S. team who would not allow their likenesses to appear on USA basketball apparel. Jordan sold the rights to use his likeness to Nike, and Nike refused to relinquish those rights. Jordan's likeness was also missing from NBA All-Star Game t-shirts.

The Globe and Mail (Canada)


January 30, 1992 Thursday


SPORT IN BRIEF Nike owns Jordan


BYLINE: GAM


LENGTH: 63 words


Michael Jordan has told the National Basketball Association it may no
longer sell apparel bearing his image, giving Nike Inc. those rights
exclusively. The move, unprecedented in the NBA, means millions of
dollars. Jordan, 28, of the Chicago Bulls, is among the most charismatic,
and profitable, personalities in the league. Nike takes in about $200-
million a year on Jordan's image.

The Times


December 19, 1992, Saturday


Nike orders run ahead


SECTION: Business


LENGTH: 84 words


 NIKE said its worldwide orders for athletic footwear and apparel scheduled for delivery between December and April totalled $1.6 billion, 18 per cent higher than the same period last year.

Second-quarter earnings to November 30 totalling $76 million, or $0.98 per share ($61.5 million or $0.80 per share). Nike said its total international sales grew 30 per cent to a record $372.9 million and represented 43 per cent of second quarter revenues, compared to 39 per cent in the same period last year.

Southwest Newswire


JULY 12, 1991, FRIDAY


NFL PRO SET & NIKE SPONSOR SAN DIEGO CHARGERS "MINI CAMP" SATURDAY, JULY 13


DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, July 12, 1991


The National Football League and the San Diego Chargers will conduct a free clinic for over 400 area youth at the University of California at San Diego, Saturday July 13 at 1:00 p.m. This event is the 26th in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer. The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, and Nike.

The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored by Nike will feature 11 San Diego Chargers players including running back/tight end Rod Bernstine, running back Ronnie Harmon and quarterback John Friesz. 

The players will stress the importance of staying in school, and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence. On the Chargers' training camp practice field, the players will demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition.

"Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boys and Girls Clubs of San Diego to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.

Local sponsors include radio station XTRA and Domino's Pizza who will provide free lunch to all camp participants.

The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.

The Advertiser


July 8, 1992 Wednesday


Games ban on Nike


LENGTH: 98 words


MADRID, Spain: Nike Incorporated, which paid millions of dollars to put its name on the United States athletic team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of its apparel in Spain.

Spain's Constitutional Court last week prohibited the sports apparel company from using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

If further legal action fails the firm stands to lose $US20 million ($A26.93 million) in sales in Spain alone and many times that sum worldwide.


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: ADV


Copyright 1992 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

745 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Evening Standard (London)


June 9, 1992, Tuesday


Party girl held till dawn by designer gear rapist


BYLINE: Gervase Webb


SECTION: Pg. 18


LENGTH: 880 words


 

WHAT started as a quick cigarette outside a party ended up as a harrowing five-hour rape ordeal on a nearby council estate for a 17-year-old girl, detectives revealed today.

Her fashionably-dressed young attacker raped her three times after she braved a group of would-be gatecrashers outside the party in Heath Road, Battersea, for a quiet smoke in the street.

The attack lasted until dawn. Detectives today descibed it as particularly savage and said the girl was 'severely traumatised'. 

The rape took place nearly a month ago, but police have only now been persuaded to publicise the ordeal in the hope that possible witnesses will come forward.

The girl was attacked shortly after 1.30am on Sunday 10 May. The rapist wore a pair of £100 Nike AirMax trainers and a gold ring with the word Nike on his left hand.

'We were told that this ring was quite unusual, and hoped that inquiries with the supplier might have led us to the attacker,' said acting Detective Segeant Mark Woolner, leading the investigation.

'Unfortunately that lead didn't take us as far as we hoped, and we are now appealing for witnesses.'

A spokesman added: 'There was a large group of would-be gatecrashers outside, and she walked down the street to avoid them and have a cigarette.

'She was approached by a youth aged between 16 and 19 who struck up a conversation about how to get into the party. Then the girl turned and walked away, intending to go to a friend's house.'

But the youth followed her towards Dansworth Road and as far as a council block, Sharp House, nearby.

'She carried on, thinking he had walked away. Suddenly she felt cold metal against her neck, and behind her was the youth saying he had a knife.'

There followed a harrowing ordeal, as the attacker dragged the girl first to the rear of the Hope pub - where he was disturbed by a barking dog - then to bushes outside nearby Shore House and then to a third-floor landing in Sharp House.

'In all she was raped three times over five hours,' said the spokesman.

'It was getting light by the time she was able to run away - but only after he had robbed her of just over £1. All the time she was terrified to cry out, believing that she might be killed.'

She said the rapist was about 5ft 7in tall, of proportionate build, dark skinned with conventionally-cut afro hair, gelled down.

He was wearing a red, white and blue cotton scarf, heavy sky-blue tee-shirt, tan bomber jacket and faded baggy blue cord trousers.

'This was an entirely opportunistic attack on a defenceless young girl, and there is a serious danger that this person might strike again,' said DS Woolner.

'We would appeal to anyone who might have seen something, or who recognises him or his ring to contact us at Battersea on 071 350 1122.'


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Photofit of the attacker


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Associated Newspapers Ltd.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


November 5, 1992, Thursday


GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE Wilkins gets a ribbing at Hawks tipoff lunch


BYLINE: By Glenn Sheeleysports; atlanta/hawks/braves/falcons; personalities; radio; speeches; advertising; fashion


SECTION: SPORTS; Section H; Page 2


LENGTH: 567 words


A day away from opening a season that could test the talents of coach Bob Weiss's magic act, the Atlanta Hawks held their annual tipoff luncheon Wednesday at the Omni Hotel. The highlights: General manager Pete Babcock made reference to Dominique Wilkins having gotten married during the off-season, glanced at his star player's table and said, "You are still married, aren't you?" . . . Bob Houghton, new general manager for WGST, which broadcasts Hawks games, called Weiss "a boyhood idol of mine." (They looked to be about the same age). . . . Emcee Steve Holman joked with Wilkins, contending that the player has slowed down quite a bit since his recent marriage to Nicole Berry. "She calls their water bed," said Holman, "the Dead Sea." . . . Weiss said he's developed quite a reputation as a luncheon speaker, but admitted, "It's just because I get to follow Steve." . . . Rick Shaw, who produced Braves broadcasts for WGST last year - Braves and Georgia football for WSB before that - has been named executive sports producer by the station. . . . New Hawk Mookie Blaylock, who attended Wednesday after the trade that sent Rumeal Robinson to the New Jersey Nets, must have felt flattered. How many teams rent a hotel ballroom and hold a luncheon for a player the day he arrives in town? . . . Weiss was honorary bartender and did a few of his magic tricks Wednesday night at T.G.I. Friday's at the Prado for the "International Bartender Championships" to benefit the Atlanta Cities in Schools program. . . . The bad news is that New England Patriots coach Dick MacPherson has been hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. The good news is that for 2-4 weeks he won't have to look at his 0-8 team. . . . Baltimore Orioles first baseman Glenn Davis of Columbus, Ga., is holding his Baseballfest golf tournament Friday at Orchard Hills Golf Club in Newnan to benefit the Carpenter's Way Ranch, a Christian home for abused and neglected children. Among those expected to attend are Braves David Justice and John Smoltz, Braves coach Clarence Jones, Wally Joyner of Kansas City and former Oakland A's pitcher Vida Blue.

He's making a list and checking it twice

Is it Nike or hokey? Deion Sanders filmed yet another commercial for Nike Wednesday at the Riverwood Studios outside of Atlanta, featuring five of his Falcons teammates as Christmas elves. Mike Gann, Tim Green, Darion Conner, Jamie Dukes and Houston Hoover were cast as Deion's little helpers. The star's part was as, uh, "Sander Claus." As you'll see in the commercial, which is to be aired nationwide during the Christmas season, the elves will be tending to Nike boxes going through Sander Claus's factory. Eat your heart out, Bo Jackson. . . . Apparently, nobody was more disappointed than Billy Ray Cyrus over his being unable to sing the national anthem at last Sunday's Falcons-Rams game at the Georgia Dome. Cyrus, who didn't get to bed until 4 a.m. Sunday morning after two concerts Saturday night at Lanierland, wanted to sing despite an overstressed throat but was advised not to by his manager. Cyrus had just stepped out of the shower at about kickoff Sunday and was distressed to hear TV announcers referring to him as a no-show. Cyrus, who would have received no pay for the performance, has told the Falcons he'll sing at a later date as soon as possible and will pay his own expenses.Photo: Mug sh ot of Bob Weiss


LOAD-DATE: November 11, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923160092


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

750 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


November 17, 1991, Sunday, SUNDAY SECOND EDITION


Drifting Nikes help ocean research


BYLINE: Reuter


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. F5


LENGTH: 318 words


DATELINE: SEATTLE


 
   SEATTLE (Reuter) - A Seattle-based oceanographer believes that 80,000 Nike shoes will help explain the mysteries of trans-Pacific migration, the spread of oil spills and where bodies lost at sea will wash ashore.

The researcher, Curtis Ebbesmeyer, has been studying the path of the drifting sneakers and sport shoes to learn more about how ocean currents work.

The shoes - with a retail value of about $2.5 million - were accidentally dumped at sea in the Pacific Ocean by a freighter nearly 18 months ago and around 2,000 have washed ashore on West Coast beaches from Oregon to British Columbia. 

"He's had a lot of interest in these Nikes, where they fell in and where they drifted," said Shannon Flotre, a colleague at Evans-Hamilton Inc., a Seattle-area oceanography firm in which Ebbesmeyer is a co-owner and oceanographer.

Ebbesmeyer, who was not available for comment on his study, is a specialist on Puget Sound who also has expertise in statistics of drifting objects and keeps records on drifting portions of shipwrecks, icebergs and other matter.

The data may help explain migration and anthropology of Pacific Island peoples and is frequently used in oil spill research and even in locating bodies lost overboard.

The May, 1990, accident created the largest single drop of man-made drift objects in the North Pacific, surpassing 20,000 drift bottles dumped in the Pacific during the 1950s by a Canadian government research project.

Rich Hastings, transport manager at Beaverton, Ore.-based Nike Inc., said the cargo was bound for Seattle from Korea and apparently was lost about 600 miles due south of Anchorage, Alaska.

"We do have an air cushioning system - some of the shoes had compressed air, which helped them float," Hastings said. "I'm glad it can be at least some benefit. It's not littering the beaches because they're picked up as soon as they land."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


July 14, 1992, Tuesday, City Edition


Kids & Kubs' Bakewell gets Nike treatment


BYLINE: KEVIN THOMAS


SECTION: SPORTS; ALL-STAR GAME NOTEBOOK; Pg. 4C


LENGTH: 131 words


 

The Kids & Kubs softball team and its living legend, centenarian George Bakewell, will be featured in a Nike commercial, airing for the first time tonight during the All-Star Game.
 
    Bakewell turned 100 in April, having finished his record 24th season with the famous St. Petersburg-based club. Kids & Kubs players must be 75 or older.
 
    In the commercial, there will be a close-up of Bakewell and a mention of the fact that, if Babe Ruth still were alive, Bakewell still would be three years older than the Babe, according to Nike spokesman Dusty Kidd.
 
    "It's a look at the team and how they typify the fact that older folks can stay active in sports," said Kidd, who added that the commercial will run for up to three months.
KEVIN THOMAS

USA TODAY


June 18, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


U.S. Open puts lightning detectors in demand


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 445 words


''Sometimes we've wondered if we're a solution in search of a problem,'' says Jim Gallagher, marketing manager for Airborne Research Associates of Waltham, Mass. ''But now we're getting lots of calls.''

That attention came after a U.S. Open spectator was killed by lightning Thursday. ARA markets $ 395 M-10 Optical Lightning Detectors, a radar and camera system the size of a Walkman that is billed as more effective than lightning detectors on airplanes. Pro golf officials and about 200 golf course pros already use the device, says Gallagher. The company hopes to expand to other outdoor sports - especially boating. 

Developed by ARA president and ex-MIT physicist Ralph Markson, the device detects ''intracloud lightning'' invisible to the human eye, to sense lightning 20 minutes away. Sometimes, says Gallagher, the device finds that ''threatening-looking clouds aren't really threatening.''

TRACK STAR: Publicly held Churchill Downs Inc. will ask stockholders on June 20 to allow its over-the-counter stock shares to increase from 1 million to as many as 10 million. The idea is to prevent any takeover bid and to provide funding for expansion. ... The Winter Baseball League, hoping to launch a six-team Florida league in November, says it will try to sign minor league players in major league baseball organizations. The WBL, whose commissioner is ex-major leaguer Bobby Bonds, has $ 105,000 team salary caps. ... Since Nike's Nike Town company store draws about 5,000 browsers each Saturday, says spokeswoman Liz Dolan, a Nike Town will open in Chicago in May. Another possible site: Berlin. ... Six original National Hockey League teams will wear ''classic'' sweaters in openers next season, partly to hype a new NHL line of old-time league clothing. ... Major League Baseball says undercover Toronto police will search for souvenir counterfeiters before the July 9 All-Star game. Maximum penalty: up to five years in prison. ... Need to phone or fax any sports group? The new Sports Address Bible has 7,500 listings. Call 213-395-6533.

HEY, YOGI! National parks generate about $ 500 million annually in concession revenues. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., thinks Uncle Sam deserves a bigger share. With 41 concession contracts expiring this year, Synar proposed a bill to give the U.S. government 22.5% of gross concession revenues, up from the current 2.5%. ... Among all sports activities, stair-climbing has had the biggest growth in ''frequent'' participants: a 500% jump to 1.8 million in three years. ... Advance Sports Concepts of Columbus, Ohio, says seven NBA teams now use its $ 80 Big Ball, a practice ball two inches wider than regulation.

759 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


March 19, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Chrysler may sell controlling stake in financial unit


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C7


LENGTH: 198 words


 

Chrysler Corp. may sell a majority stake in its profitable financial services subsidiary, hoping to distance the unit from the automaker's financial troubles.

Sale of a controlling interest would represent a change of heart by Chrysler, which late last year said it might sell only a minority interest in Chrysler Financial Corp., in an effort to boost the unit's credit rating and expand its access to cheaper financing. 

Chrysler yesterday gave no indication of what it is asking for the unit, but the finance arm reportedly carries a book value of about $ 2.5 billion.

Nike's profit up

Nike Inc., the largest U.S. marketer of athletic shoes, yesterday reported third-quarter earnings jumped 12 per cent but the performance disappointed Wall Street and Nike's stock price tumbled.

The sneaker maker - whose earnings were restrained by advertising and interest costs - earned $ 70.7 million (U.S.) in the quarter ended Feb. 28, or 93 cents a share, up from $ 63.1 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier.

Separately, the once high-flying sneaker maker L.A. Gear Inc. said it has reached agreement with its banks to restructure loan agreements.

WIRE AGENCIES


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

Chrysler may sell controlling stake in financial unit


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C7


LENGTH: 204 words


 
   Chrysler Corp. may sell a majority stake in its profitable financial services subsidiary, hoping to distance the unit from the automaker's financial troubles.

Sale of a controlling interest would represent a change of heart by Chrysler, which late last year said it might sell only a minority interest in Chrysler Financial Corp., in an effort to boost the unit's credit rating and expand its access to cheaper financing. 

Chrysler yesterday gave no indication of what it is asking for the unit, but the finance arm reportedly carries a book value of about $2.5 billion.

Nike's profit up

Nike Inc., the largest U.S. marketer of athletic shoes, yesterday reported third-quarter earnings jumped 12 per cent but the performance disappointed Wall Street and Nike's stock price tumbled.

The Washington Post


July 26, 1992, Sunday, Final Edition


AROUND THE NBA


From News Services


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D2


LENGTH: 156 words


A CHANGED CHARLES: No sooner did Charles Barkley leave Philadelphia than he develops a new -- well, sort of new -- image, courtesy of Nike shoes.

In his latest commercial for Nike, the new Phoenix Sun does an autobiographical rap about his fabled brawls, his spitting, the many times he's been fined, his success as a basketball player, his anti-hero reputation and even plugs his recent book, as well as Nike's sneakers. And all this in 60 seconds.

He is really "Charming Charles." As he put it in the ad: "The pocket says it pays to be mean. Excuse me, but don't I have the cutest smile you've ever seen?"

HARPER WANTS TRADE: Mavericks guard Derek Harper has asked the team to deal him to one of four or five teams before next season, his agent George Andrews says.

Two of the teams reportedly on Harper's list are the Knicks, who acquired former Dallas teammate Rolando Blackman earlier this summer, and the Bulls.

Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

767 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Sunday Times (London)


August 18, 1991, Sunday


Pentland races for Adidas deal


BYLINE: Iain Jenkins


SECTION: Business


LENGTH: 351 words


PENTLAND, the British sports-goods firm, is set to negotiate a lucrative contractto arrange the to manufacture of Adidas sportswear products in the Far East following its move to buy a 20% stake in the German giant from Bernard Tapie.

The deal could revitalise the fortunes of Adidas and enable it to catch up recover some of the ground that has been lost to its two American arch-rivals, Reebok and Nike.

Further, Paris financiers expect Pentland's Pounds 47m Adidas investment to lead to it taking control of Adidas next summer when Tapie faces his next financial crunch. 

In the meantime Pentland, famous for its role in which made its mark pushing Reebok to the top of the sports footwear league table, will focus its efforts on securing a lucrative sourcing contract in the Far East with Adidas.

It hopes the contract will mirror the long-term deal with Reebok that played a key role in the footwear company's ''miracle turnround'' in the 1980s, when it caught up with Nike earning Pentland Pounds 6m profit last year.

Adidas lost out in the cut-throat battle with Reebok and Nike as because it was slow to follow them into the Far East. Today 85% of the West German giant's shoes are made in the Far East but Pentland's expertise in this area should be able to cut costs further.

For Pentland, whose brands include Pony and Speedo, the attraction is that net margins at Adidas are only one and a half percent 112% compared with 10% at Nike and Reebok. If they can sort out the Adidas sourcing, profits at Adidas could explode from the current Pounds 19m.

Reebok's decision to terminate the sourcing contract with Pentland was a key factor that persuaded the British firm to sell part of its stake for Pounds 200m. Today with Reebok shares riding high at $32, Pentland may soon sell its remaining 13% stake, which is worth another Pounds 222m.

The sourcing contract is the icing on the cake but Pentland does not hide its ambition to own Adidas. The chance could come next summer when Tapie will have to must find another Pounds 160m to finance the second part of the Adidas purchase.


LOAD-DATE: August 21, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Times Newspapers Limited

 

768 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Times


July 16, 1991, Tuesday


Goddess returns in triumph


BYLINE: From Ian Murray in Bonn


SECTION: Overseas news


LENGTH: 456 words


AMID controversy and angst, Nike, the winged Greek goddess of victory, was hoisted back to the top of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin yesterday in preparation for the monument's 200th birthday celebrations on August 6.

Almost destroyed a year and a half ago by joyful souvenir hunters on the first New Year's Eve after the Berlin Wall came down, Nike and her four horses have spent the past 15 months having a Pounds 100,000 renovation to protect her from vandals and the environment.

More than a thousand people turned out yesterday to watch as a crane lowered the copper statue and her chariot on to the 60ft high gate. Typically for modern Germany, however, the return of the goddess has provoked a profound argument about what she ought to symbolise. When she was locked away behind the wall staring eastwards down Unter den Linden at the decaying communist state, the triumphalism she once represented did not matter. 

In a united country, however, Nike's return with Iron Cross and Prussian eagle on her staff, has created worries that she will give the wrong message to the world about German ambitions for the future. Helmut Kohl, the chancellor, has also run into criticism over his plan, announced yesterday, to attend the ceremony taking place in Potsdam on August 17, when the remains of Frederick the Great of Prussia are to be moved. Frau Herta Daubler-Gmelin, deputy chairman of the opposition Social Democrats complained that this would rouse mistrust in Germany's neighbours.

Similar arguments are being roused by the statue of Nike. Two hundred years ago she was designed by Johann Schadow, court sculptor to King Friedrich Wilhelm II of Prussia, to represent Irene, the goddess of peace. Napoleon changed all that. When he arrived in the city fresh from his triumph at Jena in 1806 he liked the look of the statue and decided to pack it up and send it back to Paris as part of his booty. The goddess lived in exile for eight years until Field Marshall Blucher secured her release in 1814 after Napoleon's first defeat.

She returned in triumph, not as Irene but as Nike, complete with cross, oak leaves, and eagle. As such she presided over the victory parades of the Prussians, the German Empire and the Third Reich. In 1945, however, the gate and the statue were badly damaged in the battle for the city.

Using the scrap and pictures as a model the East German government managed to copy and replace the statue in 1958 without the victory symbols, carefully describing her in the official guidebooks as ''the peace goddess''. Now Friedbert Pfluger, a Christian Democrat Bundestag member from the west German state of Lower Saxony, has started a protest movement about the symbols of victory on her staff.


LOAD-DATE: July 17, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Times Newspapers Limited

 

771 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 24, 1991, Wednesday


Nike's Vaccaro a conduit to coaches and players


BYLINE: By Mike Fish Staff writersports; personalities; advertising; management


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 922 words


One of the most influential characters in basketball is a pudgy former high school coach who counts John Thompson and Jerry Tarkanian among his close friends.

John Paul "Sonny" Vaccaro has been ranked one of the 100 most powerful people in sports by The Sporting News. He's No. 80, right behind Michael Jordan.

Without question, Vaccaro, 52, is the greatest sneaker salesman in America. He is Nike's conduit to the big-name college coaches and marquee programs such as Georgetown and Syracuse, signing coaches to six-figure contracts, some in the neighborhood of $ 200,000, for the favor of outfitting their teams in Nike gear. 

Nike hosts summer camps showcasing the country's finest high school players, with all invitees approved by Vaccaro. Nike sponsors the Dapper Dan Roundball Classic, the granddaddy of national high school all-star games, which Vaccaro started in Pittsburgh in 1965.

But critics have trashed Vaccaro for allegedly directing top recruits to college coaches under contract to Nike. NCAA investigators, in general, are leery of his cozy relationship with both players and coaches.

Now, in the wake of the NBA draft, Vaccaro is under attack from agents who claim he is cutting into their business. Vaccaro, although not involved in contract negotiations, has a hand in the marketing of several first-round picks - including Billy Owens, Dikembe Mutombo and Stacey Augmon, and he is negotiating with Larry Johnson, the No. 1 pick in the draft.

All of the draft picks played at college programs under contract to Nike.

"Everything is an angle," said agent Ron Grinker, who represents Danny Manning, the first pick in the 1988 draft. "I deal with him for players on shoe contracts . But now, I have to worry about him talking to players. He can go on any college campus where he has college coaches under contract and talk to every player. It's a scenario that is not very tasteful to me."

Charles Grantham, executive director of the NBA Players Association, said he has been assured by Vaccaro that he will not be involved in negotiating player contracts. The NBA players union has no jurisdiction over endorsements.

Vaccaro and Nike officials deny any potential conflict, saying his latest business venture is independent of the athletic wear company. Vaccaro describes himself as a consultant for DIC Marketing, a Burbank, Calif., firm that has secured agreements to represent the players.

"I am the conduit, the go-between," Vaccaro said. "They approached me a year ago and said they wanted to get involved with athletes. They knew I've been around athletes all my life."

Vaccaro said he screened agents for some of the players, further raising the ire of those who couldn't get interviews. He also negotiated deals for trading cards on behalf of several players - among them Augmon, Owens, Mutombo, Greg Anthony, Anderson Hunt and George Ackles.

Several agents accused Vaccaro of directing Augmon, the Atlanta Hawks' top draft choice, and Owens to player representative Arn Tellem. Vaccaro and Tellem, however, deny they have a business relationship.

"A couple of the agents I've heard from believe Sonny locked them out of a chance to get these guys," said Fred Schreyer, Nike's director of sports marketing. "I don't believe that's the case. The few players he is advising are kids he has been close to for a long time."

Magic Johnson's agent, Lon Rosen, said the only way to get to Augmon was through Vaccaro. He never met the player.

"I've been with Sonny for five years and I trust him," said Augmon. "He's the Nike guy and he's been around our program. I met him in high school at the Dapper Dan, and I've been keeping close to him because he lives in the L.A. area. We go out to dinner. I know his wife."

By conservative estimates, Vaccaro has signed more than 60 major college coaches - among them Bobby Cremins of Georgia Tech and Hugh Durham of Georgia - to contracts with Nike, along with more than 25 of the country's most influential high school coaches.

The money Vaccaro can put in coaches' pockets has elevated him to the position of power broker. In some instances, college coaches find themselves earning more in "shoe money" than is paid them by their respective universities.

"Sonny, by his reputation, is a controversial guy," said David Falk of ProServ. "He's got lots of contacts and can bring something to the party. I don't think that's all bad, but I think it threatens a lot of people. They feel he may have an advantage through his contacts and may be able to do things for players they're not able to do."

Publicly, Falk is reluctant to criticize Vaccaro's dealings. Thompson, the Georgetown coach, is friends of both, and several of his former players are represented by Falk. But even Vaccaro acknowledges that Falk is upset that while his agency is negotiating the contract for Mutombo, Georgetown's latest star, Vaccaro will be responsible for the marketing and endorsements.

"This is the first time ProServ has lost a player to a marketing situation," said Vaccaro, who previously tried his hand as a gambler and rock 'n' roll concert promoter. "They sort of pride themselves on what they've done with Michael Jordan , so they're upset about Mutombo. It's the first time an outsider, so to speak, has entered their domain.

"I don't do anything illegal with any of these kids. I know probably all the kids. If they're worried about that, they ought to pray I don't become an agent."


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

773 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


August 5, 1992, Wednesday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS BARCELONA SCENE Unzipped, folded collar solves uniform flap


BYLINE: By Bert Roughton Jr. and Ailene Voisin STAFF WRITERSolympics; fashion; advertising; competition; results


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 7


LENGTH: 602 words


Barcelona - The crisis over the Dream Team's raiment for the inevitable gold medal ceremony was resolved Tuesday, avoiding a potentially embarrassing situation for the U.S. Olympic Team and further annoyance to the rest of the Olympic community.

Some Dream Teamers - many of whom are under contract to Nike - had indicated they would not participate in the ceremony if they had to comply with U.S. Olympic Committee (USOC) demands that they wear the official U.S. uniform, which is produced by Nike's archrival Reebok.

But the compromise leaves the players free to hide the word "Reebok," which appears on the right side of the uniform's jacket, simply by leaving it unzipped and thus folded over the name. 

"In the event the men's basketball team wins a medal, all members will appear on the medal platform in the uniform issued by the U.S. Olympic Committee," David Gavitt, president of USA Basketball said after meeting with USOC officials. "Some players may chose to wear the awards suit in a manner that does not reveal any commercial identification. However, in no instance will the uniform be defaced or covered by any other material."

Despite the resolution, Olympic officials are becoming increasingly tired of the disruption the Dream Team has brought to the Games. "There's a limit on being able to behave like a rock star," said Richard Pound, an International Olympic Committee (IOC) vice president.

"They're not coachable, approachable or governable by the USOC," Pound said. "At the end of all this, there will be some careful assessment of this experience."

He said it might be wise to limit the number of NBA players or eliminate them altogether.

The controversy also has the sponsors wondering about whether the image of their products has been tarnished.

"This is starting to take away from the great basketball exhibition of the team and is a distraction for many of the other sports as well," said Reebok vice president John Boulter.

He said such disputes "could destroy some of the fabric of the Olympic spirit."

The fabric has been strained frequently during the Barcelona Olympics, which has demonstrated the difficulty of mixing superstars with other Olympic athletes.

While the other athletes stay in the Olympic Village, which was intended as a place for the world's youth to get to know one another, the stars have stayed in hotel suites.

This annoys LeRoy Walker, head of the U.S. delegation and likely next president of the USOC. Walker also is the senior vice president for sport at the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games."It's a way of saying 'I'm better than you. I don't have to deal with you peons,' " Walker said.

U.S. Olympic team members are becoming increasingly unhappy that some super-elite athletes don't want to bunk in with them, Walker said. "They are all Olympians and they have all paid the price. They feel they should all be on the same level."

Because of that resentment, Walker has begun a campaign to force all American athletes to reside together in future Games, even it it means going without NBA players.

Borislav Stankovic, executive director of the international basketball federation, took exception to Walker's comments.

"I would ask [Walker] what will happen when [the U.S. sends] one other team that will not win a gold medal," Stankovic said. "I think it will do tremendous damage if they [NBA players] will not come again.

"Nobody in international circles is complaining about the Dream Team," he said. "The teams are losing by 30 or 40 points and they are happy."

The Associated Press contributed to this report.


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922270130


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

774 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


January 24, 1991 Thursday


TRUTH AND RUMOURS WILLIAM HOUSTON'S WORLD OF SPORT Canadian agent resigns


BYLINE: WILLIAM HOUSTON; GAM


LENGTH: 525 words


Steve Yormak, one of the few baseball agents based in Canada, has
resigned his certification after facing an investigation by the Major
League Players Association. Yormak, whose clients included Toronto Blue
Jay outfielders Rob Ducey and Glenallen Hill, is a lawyer in the London,
Ont., area and a Canadian citizen, although he was born in the United
States. Mike Weiner, the assistant general counsel of the players
association, said: "He resigned his certification as an agent in the
context of an investigation. The end result was that Mr. Yormak chose to
resign." 

Ducey and Hill have not been without controversy as Blue Jays. Ducey, a
Canadian from Cambridge, Ont., has requested trades after assignments to
the minor leagues. He also sued the SkyDome over a knee injury suffered in
1989. Hill was embroiled in a dispute with the Jays over his 1990 contract
offer. Yormak chose not to comment on his resignation. He says he has
moved into the baseball marketing and licencing business.

 Nike revises ads

A last-minute change in advertising strategy by Nike has eliminated from the North American market a television commercial directed by Canadian David Cronenberg. An ad campaign for the Air 180 running shoe was to include commercials made by 12 internationally renowned directors including Cronenberg, Frederico Fellini of Italy, Eiko of Japan, the Laurenstein brothers of Germany and Jean-Luc Godard of France. Each director shot a 15-second segment depicting one concept of the Air 180 shoe. It was to be shown Sunday during the Super Bowl.

Cronenberg's spot, filmed in Toronto in October, is set on a distant
planet and features a creature that farms Air 180s growing in insect-like
pods. In December, however, Nike pulled the plug on the international TV
spots for the North American market, although they will be aired in Europe
and Asia. Glenn Wakefield, the national advertising manager of Nike
Canada, said there were two main reasons for the change - differences
between North American and European and Asian tastes in advertising and
knowledge of Nike. The ads were "very European," he said. "More of an
artistic theme."
Sources: Marketing, Advertising Age

Super Bowl ratings, Part 2

Pot luck in drug testing

A booklet with the title, Drug Free, has been published by the U.S. Olympic Committee to warn athletes about the dangers of drug use. In addition to discouraging competitors from using steroids and other performance-enhancing substances, the booklet appears to be a how-to for avoiding detection of marijuana use. Marijuana is not considered a performance-enhancing drug and it is not on the International Olympic Committee's banned list. However, it is banned by the national governing bodies of some sports and may be tested for at their request.

Under the heading How long does marijuana stay in the system? the USOC
reports, "Breakdown products can show up in urine four to 10 days after
smoking a single joint, and up to 36 days after chronic marijuana smokers
quit. THC, the mind-altering ingredient in marijuana, is absorbed into the
body and transformed into metabolites, which can be detected in the urine
for weeks after use."


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1991 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

 

777 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


September 22, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final


If the Shoe Floats, Follow It


BYLINE: By WALTER SULLIVAN


SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Science Desk


LENGTH: 469 words


A SEVERE storm two years ago has given scientists unusual tools for studying the currents of the Pacific: shoes.

The shoes went from mere footwear to tools of science on May 27, 1990, when the freighter Hansa Carrier ran into heavy weather en route from South Korea to the Pacific Northwest and 21 cargo containers were lost overboard. Five of the containers were filled with 80,000 Nike products, many of them buoyant. 

Since then, in a confirmation of theories about currents in the Northwest Pacific, thousands of sneakers, hiking boots, children's sandals and other shoes have been picked up along beaches from British Columbia to Oregon and as far into the mid-Pacific as Hawaii.

That is just where oceanographers would have expected to find them. It has long been known that the Subarctic Current flows from the mid-Pacific northeast to the coasts of Alaska and British Columbia, one fork sweeping south to California, then back toward Hawaii.

Two oceanographers, Curtis C. Ebbesmeyer of Evans-Hamilton Inc., a physical oceanographic firm in Seattle, and W. James Ingraham Jr., with the National Marine Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, began collecting reports on the seagoing shoes a year later, after reading an account in a Seattle newspaper of footwear washing up on beaches. They collected reports from local papers and befriended beachcombers along the coasts of Canada and the United States. Limiting their count to the most reliable finds, they determined that 1,300 shoes had been picked up, including as many as 250 from a single beach.

The scientists described this impromptu experiment in the current issue of Eos, published by the American Geophysical Union.

Despite months at sea, many of the shoes have been wearable after washing. The problem, though, is that the shoes were not tied together. So beachcombers have been holding "swap meets" to search for mates to their finds.

The shoes confirm results of more conventional current-tracing efforts in which large numbers of bottles were dumped in the sea. During 1960-71, for example, 21,615 were released off Oregon by Oregon State University. In a 1956-59project, 33,869 were set adrift. The Scripps Institution of Oceanography released 148,384 off California and Mexico from 1955 to 1971.

Assuming that many, but not all, shoes escaped from the containers, the recovery rate of 1.6 percent was not very different from that of 4,518 bottles released in one test near the same current but closer to the West Coast. Of these 2.8 percent were recovered.

If other shoes survive -- and if theories about Pacific currents are correct -- "some should arrive in Asia and Japan" in a few years when, the researchers said, "hopefully we will hear from our western Pacific colleagues."


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Drawing


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

780 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 28, 1992, Wednesday


GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE Sanders has a full dayfilming a commercial


BYLINE: By Glenn Sheeleysports; competition; baseball; atlanta/braves; public; reaction; golf


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 2


LENGTH: 458 words


While his Braves colleagues were being honored at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium Tuesday and also thanking the fans for their season-long support, Deion Sanders did a Grand Slam Salute to his commercial interests. Sanders spent the day filming a Nike commercial at Georgia Tech - on the baseball field, the football practice field, the track, in Bobby Dodd Stadium and in the weight room. For the commercial, Sanders wore Nike Air shoes trimmed in gold. When last seen at Tech Tuesday night, Sanders was getting spritzed with some fake sweat-in-a-bottle near some weights. His Braves uniform hung on some equipment nearby. . . . Braves outfielder Otis Nixon will receive a nice payback for at the last minute supplying heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield with behind-the- plate tickets for the World Series. Holyfield will get Nixon close-up seats for his Nov. 13 fight against Riddick Bowe in Las Vegas. . . . Nixon, on standing by his bunt attempt in the 11th inning: "Every single time I go up there, that's on my mind. For me, it's not a low-percentage m ove." 

Golf tournaments have replaced postseason baseball for supplying the Braves with competitive outlets, and everyone but the batboys seems to be holding one. Travel director Bill Acree's tournament for hemophilia is today at the Polo Fields. The Pete Van Wieren celebrity golf tournament for the Atlanta-based Children's Wish Foundation, organized by the Braves' Jeff Treadway and Griffin's Alvin Goldstein, is Thursday at the Griffin Country Club. Pitcher John Smoltz's tournament, to benefit Atlanta's Table, is Nov. 7 at Eagle's Landing. . . . Something you don't see every day: Braves manager Bobby Cox in the dugout wearing a business suit instead of a baseball suit. The last time? "Never," Cox said. . . . Naturally, the Braves wanted one more game, but there was no shortage of them in 1992. From spring training on, the Braves played 203 games - 30 in Florida, 162 in the regular season and 13 in post-season. . . . A woman assembling Braves for introductions asked pitcher Tom Glavine in the dugout, "Who are you?" "I'm Steve Avery," Glavine said. "I'm one of the lesser-known players." . . . Golf pro Paul Azinger, a Braves fanatic, told our Tom McCollister after a practice round for the PGA Tour Championship, "Condolences, man, it was tough. I was really pulling for them. So close two years straight." Azinger wanted to know if Nixon was second-guessed for bunting with two outs but called the move "gutsy on his part." He called Cox's decision to remain with Charlie Leibrandt against Dave Winfield "a close call." Azinger asked, "Is Ron Gant some kind of upset he wasn't used? But how can you argue with how Deion played? He might be MVP if the Braves win."
