October 28, 1992, Wednesday


GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE Commercial appeals to Deion


BYLINE: By Glenn Sheeleysports; atlanta/braves; personalities; advertising; fashion; behavior; golf


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 8


LENGTH: 589 words


While his Braves colleagues were being honored at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium Tuesday and also thanking the fans for their season-long support, Deion Sanders did a Grand Slam Salute to his commercial interests. Sanders spent the day filming a Nike commercial at Georgia Tech - on the baseball field, the practice football field, the track, in Bobby Dodd Stadium and in the weight room. For the commerical Sanders wore Nike Air shoes trimmed in gold. Go figure. When last seen at Tech Tuesday night, Sanders was getting spritzed with some fake-sweat-in-a- bottle near some weights. His Braves uniform hung to some equipment nearby. . . . Braves outfielder Otis Nixon will receive a nice payback for at the last minute supplying heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield with behind-the-plate tickets for the World Series. Holyfield will get Nixon close-up seats for his Nov. 13 fight against Riddick Bowe in Las Vegas. . . . Nixon, on standing by his bunt attempt in the 11th inning: "Every single time I go up there, that's on my mind. For me, it's not a lo w-percentage move." 

A season for celebrity golf

Golf tournaments have replaced postseason baseball to supply the Braves with competitive outlets, and everyone but the bat boys seems to be holding one. Travel director Bill Acree's tournament for hemophilia is today at the Polo Fields. The Pete Van Wieren celebrity golf tournament for the Atlanta-based Children's Wish Foundation, organized by the Braves' Jeff Treadway and Griffin Alvin Goldstein, is Thursday at the Griffin Country Club. Pitcher John Smoltz's tournament, to benefit Atlanta's Table, is Nov. 7 at Eagle's Landing. . . . Something you don't see every day: Braves manager Bobby Cox in the dugout wearing a business suit instead of a baseball suit. The last time? "Never," Cox said. . . . Naturally, the Braves wanted one more game, but there was no shortage of them in 1992. From spring training on, the Braves played 203 games - 30 in Florida, 162 in the regular season and 13 in post-season. . . . A woman assembling Braves for introductions asked pitcher Tom Glavine in the dugout, "Who are you?" "I'm Steve Avery," Glavine said. "I'm one of the lesser-known players." . . . Golf pro Paul Azinger, a Braves fanatic, told our Tom McCollister after a practice round for the PGA Tour Championship, "Condolences, man, it was tough. I was really pulling for them. So close two years straight." Azinger wanted to know if Nixon was second-guessed for bunting with two outs but called the move "gutsy on his part." He called Cox's decision to remain with Charlie Leibrandt against Dave Winfield "a close call." Azinger asked, "Is Ron Gant some kind of upset he wasn't used? But how can you argue with how Deion played? He might be MVP if the Braves win."

Don't mess with his head

It was quite a nasty night at Saturday's Northwestern State- Northeast Louisiana game in Natchitoces, La. - not fit for man or beast or men portraying beasts. A fight broke out late in the second quarter between the NSU mascot, Vic the Demon, and NLU's Chief Brave Spirit. "The Northeast mascot has always had a reputation of playing it rough. He was shoving me around hard before the fight," said Shane Clabaugh, who plays Vic. "But after he tore my head off that was it. That goes against the code of ethics for mascots." . . . Dirty Al's in Marietta is holding a "Party with the Pros" Thursday to benefit the March of Dimes. Duane Ferrell of the Hawks, the Falcons' Erric Pegram and the Falcons cheerleaders will attend.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH923060057

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 19, 1992, Tuesday


Kids rank ads


BYLINE: By Jeffry Scottbusiness; advertising; aviation; tobacco; children; personnel


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section B; Page 2


LENGTH: 116 words


"Old Joe," the smooth cartoon character for Camel cigarettes, showed up as the favorite print ad among boys from 8 to 12 years old, followed by the public service campaign "Just Say No to Drugs." 

That's according to a survey by Xtreme Inc., a New York-based consulting company. It polled 500 youths who are members of the Xtreme Consumer Panel, a national network of 2,000 males and females from 8 to 24 years.

Girls from 8 to 12 preferred print ads for Noxzema, Diet Pepsi and Nike.

Appealing equally to males and females from 8 to 24 were Pepsi's TV commercial featuring model Cindy Crawford; the Nike Hare Jordan commercial; and a Little Caesars commercial featuring a conga line.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Mug shot of Guy Tucker


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

785 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Times


August 10, 1992, Monday


Losers in selling stakes


BYLINE: From John Goodbody, in Barcelona


SECTION: Sport


LENGTH: 321 words


 NIKE, the American sportswear company, built a huge advertising campaign around four of its sponsored athletes at the Olympic Games. Posters appeared around the world telling the public how successful Nike's competitors would be. The trouble is that only one of the four was a winner at the Games. 

Michael Johnson, the firmest of favourites for the 200 metres, was displayed on advertising hoardings that congratulated the reader for doing something few athletes would be able to do at the Games: passing Johnson. Unfortunately, the American was suffering from a viral complaint for the semi-final and four people passed him as he failed to make the final.

Still, there was always Sergey Bubka, from Ukraine. As Olympic and world champion and world record-holder, he was expected to soar to victory in the pole vault on Friday. The poster proclaimed: ''Spanish air traffic control has been notified''. Bubka failed with his two opening vaults at 5.70 metres, then tried 5.75 and missed that. He was out of the competition without a clearance.

Well, at least Nourredine Morceli, the world champion from Algeria, would save Nike's face by winning the 1,500 metres on Saturday in the commanding fashion with which he secured the world title last year. The advertising slogan read: ''Ever heard the Algerian national anthem? You will.'' Well, we did but not for Morceli. Hassiba Boulmerka ran away with the women's 1,500 metres.

She stood on the podium in tears, listening to the Algerian national anthem and wearing her kit emblazoned with the name of Diadora, an Italian sportswear manufacturer. Morceli, meanwhile, finished seventh in the men's 1,500 metres. Nobody from Nike was available to comment on the embarrassment.

Fortunately, Michael Jordan, the fourth competitor selected for Nike's campaign, had the rest of the Dream Team alongside him and the United States squad easily took the basketball.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Newspapers Limited

Southwest Newswire


JUNE 24, 1991, MONDAY


NFL PRO SET & NIKE SPONSOR INDIANAPOLIS COLTS 'MINI CAMP' SATURDAY, JUNE 29


DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, IND., June 24, 1991


The National Football League and the Indianapolis Colts will conduct a free clinic for over 400 area youth at Hoosier Dome, Saturday, June 29 at 9:00 a.m. This event is the 23rd in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer. The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, and Nike. 

The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored by Nike will feature a number of Indianapolis Colts players who have volunteered their time as coaches.

The players will stress the importance of staying in school, and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence. At the Hoosier Dome, the players will also demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition.

"Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boy's and Girl's Club of Indianapolis to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.

Domino's Pizza will provide free lunch to all camp participants.

The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.


CONTACT: Larry Lundy or Sheilah Tucker, both of Advantage Marketing Group, Inc., 214/869-2244.


LOAD-DATE: 910624

DISTRIBUTION: TO SPORTS DESKS

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C

Legion's best ... The American Legion World Series begins today in Fargo, N.D. First-round pairings: Arlington Heights, Ill. (41-15) vs. Newbury Park, Calif. (36-2); East Hartford, Conn. (49-8) vs. Medford, Ore. (43-15); Guaynabo, Puerto Rico (30-7) vs. Brooklawn, N.J. (43-9) and Gonzales, La. (48- 9) vs. Fargo, N.D. (64-10).

Footing the bill ... PGA Tour Commissioner Deane Beman will announce today that Nike will sponsor the 30-tournament Hogan Tour for aspiring PGA Tour players.

NFL PRO SET & NIKE SPONSOR NEW YORK GIANTS 'MINI CAMP' FRIDAY, JUNE 28


DATELINE: NEW YORK, June 24, 1991


The National Football League and the New York Giants will conduct a free clinic for over 600 area youth at Giants Stadium, Friday, June 28 at 10:00 a.m. This event is the 22nd in a series of 27 throughout the League this spring/summer. The camps are sponsored by Pro Set, the manufacturer of the Official NFL Trading Card, and Nike. 

The "NFL Pro Set Mini Camp for Kids" sponsored by Nike will feature 15 New York Giants players including offensive lineman Bart Oates, linebacker Carl Banks, running back O.J. Anderson, linebacker Lawrence Taylor and defensive back Everson Walls.

The players will stress the importance of staying in school, and deliver impactful motivation messages on striving for individual excellence. On the field at Giants Stadium, the players will demonstrate football skills and techniques of game preparation, fitness and nutrition.

"Mini Camp" participants have been selected through the United Way and Boys and Girls Clubs of New York to provide this opportunity for those who would benefit most from the program.

The public is invited to attend the clinic as spectators at no charge.

The Toronto Star


July 7, 1992, Tuesday, AM


Muhammad Ali gets Thorpe Award


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. C1


LENGTH: 468 words


 
   HOLLYWOOD, Calif. (AP) - Muhammad Ali received the Life Time Achievement Award last night during the Jim Thorpe Pro Sports Award Show, a two-hour live special on ABC-TV. The presentation was made by actor James Earl Jones. 

Other special awards went to Bo Jackson and long jumper Mike Powell. Other winners were Michael Andretti, Cal Ripken, Michael Jordan, Terry Norris, Mark Rypien, Fred Couples, Meg Mallon, Mark Messier, Jim Courier and Monica Seles.

No politics

CALGARY (CP) - The two Canadian cities vying to host the 2002 Winter Olympics have sent a clear, angry message to Ottawa - keep politics out of sport.

Calgary mayor Al Duerr and his Quebec City counterpart, Jean-Paul L'Allier, signed a joint declaration demanding the Canadian Olympic Association select either of the two cities as its Canadian candidate without politics coloring its decision.

Nike appeals

MADRID (AP) - Nike Inc., which paid millions to put its name on the U.S. track and field team's uniforms at the Barcelona Olympics, is appealing a stunning high court decision that bars the advertising or sale of Nike apparel in Spain.

Spain's Constitutional Court last week refused to lift a lower court order prohibiting the Beaverton, Ore.-based sports apparel company from using the Nike name on clothing because a Barcelona firm registered the trademark first in 1932.

Jets kicker quits

NEW YORK (AP) - New York Jets placekicker Pat Leahy, the oldest player in the NFL and the third-ranked scorer in league history, retired yesterday after 18 seasons because of a recurring sciatic nerve condition.

Leahy, 41, has 1,470 points, and trails only fellow kickers George Blanda (2,002) and Jan Stenerud (1,699).

Jockey injured

WILLOW PARK, Texas (AP) - A Trinity Meadows Raceway jockey was in good condition yesterday at a Fort Worth hospital after being thrown and trampled in a race.

Doctors said David Muirhead, 26, could be released today.

Bulgarian back

MILAN, Italy (AP) - Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria, back on track after taking two years to recover from foot surgery, will be bidding for gold in the women's high jump at the Barcelona Olympics.

Kostadinova, who set the world record of 6 feet, 10 1/4 inches at Rome in 1987, surprised even her husband by clearing 6-8 3/4 in her best effort of the season at a track meet in San Marino on the weekend.

Skiing champs

BOGOTA, Columbia, (CNW) - Jaret Llewellyn of Innisfail, Alta., and Kim de Macedo of Shawnigan Lake, B.C., won the overall titles at the seven-country Pan American Water Skiing Championships.

In the team event, the United States was first with 8,426 points and Canada, the number-one ranked nation, was second at 8,271.

In junior competition, Ryan Bush, 15, of Brampton, was second overall.quickly


LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

USA TODAY


July 16, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Basketball seniors to watch next season


BYLINE: Pat Forde


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 9C


LENGTH: 506 words


Reporter Pat Forde covered last week's NIKE All-American Academic basketball camp. After talking to scouts and coaches, Forde compiled an early, unofficial list of high school prospects to watch in the coming year. Many have called this coming year's senior class one of the best ever. 
 
 Joey Beard, Reston (Va.) South Lakes, F, 6-10, 210. Comment: Smooth, skilled big man who can play either forward position. Considering Duke, North Carolina, Virginia and Notre Dame.
 
Damon Flint, Cincinnati Woodward, G, 6-0, 180. Comment: Explosive guard with shooting range, too. Starred at Nike last year but chose not to attend this year. Schools: Michigan, Ohio State, Arkansas, Cincinnati, Kentucky.
 
Rashard Griffith, Chicago King, C, 7-1, 260. Comment: Has dropped 20 pounds since last year and added muscle but still could add a killer instinct. Says he's ''wide open'' on college choice, but Illinois, Louisiana State and Georgetown appear to be working hardest for his services.
 
Ronnie Henderson, Jackson (Miss.) Murrah, G, 6-0, 180. Comment: Some have enthusiastically compared his athletic ability to Michael Jordan's, but scout Bob Gibbons said he could improve his basketball skills. LSU, UCLA, Kentucky, Ohio State could be the leaders in the clubhouse, but nothing's solid.
 
Randy Livingston, New Orleans Newman, G, 6-0, 188. Comment: Some say he's the best player in the class, but he got off to a slow start at Nike. Great athlete who can play either guard position but isn't a great shooter yet. Kentucky, LSU and North Carolina tops his list now, but says he's still open to others.
 
Darnell Robinson, Emeryville (Calif.) Emery, C, 6-11, 230. Comment: A true back-to-the-basket post player. Plays more aggressively than the stereotypical California center. School choices uncertain.
 
Jerry Stackhouse, Kinston (N.C.) Kinston, F, 6-7, 217. Comment: The star of the first few days at Nike. Can handle the ball, shoot it, rebound it, and he packs a relentless attitude, to boot. Played hard all the time. Looks like he'll stay in ACC country, with North Carolina State, Duke, Wake Forest, North Carolina and Florida State atop his list.
 
Jacque Vaughn, Pasadena (Calif.) Muir, G, 6-0, 165. Comment: Some question his size, but few question his quickness, penetrating ability and tenacity. Improved stock last year at Nike. Has no finalists for college choice yet but initially likes Kansas, Kentucky and Georgetown.
 
Rasheed Wallace, Philadelphia Simon Gratz, C, 6-11, 217. Comment: Another Alonzo Mourning? Rebounds, goes after shots and he has touch to 15 feet. Several big men said he was the toughest guy to play in camp. Has a list of 10 schools, including Temple, Georgetown, Massachusetts, Villanova, Maryland, Syracuse, Ohio State and Kentucky.
 
Dontonio Wingfield, Albany (Ga.) Westover, F, 6-8, 235. Comment: Wowed 'em last year at Nike. Did not attend this year. Has good agility and hands. Consistency the only question. Has many school choices.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w
 
CUTLINE: DRIVING FORCE: Jacque Vaughn, right, of Pasadena (Calif.) Muir drives past Kiwane Garris during the Nike camp. His quickness is one of his top attributes.


HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS;


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

800 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Times


July 3, 1992, Friday


Hi-Tec stumbles in Olympic year


BYLINE: By George Sivell


SECTION: Business


LENGTH: 353 words


FRANK van Wezel might have expected Olympic year to lift Hi-Tec, the sports shoe group, to the heights; instead it appears to be plumbing the Stygian depths.

The stock market put the boot in to the personal fortune of Mr van Wezel, the chairman of Hi-Tec, after he delivered a profits warning at the sports shoe group's annual meeting. Mr van Wezel lost Pounds 16.63 million on paper yesterday as the shares fell from 175p to 106p. He still owns 56 per cent of Hi-Tec shares, worth Pounds 25.5 million on paper at last night's close. 

Behind the profits warning lies an admission of temporary defeat by Hi-Tec in the race against Nike and Reebok for the British training shoe market.

Khaleeq Taimuri, analyst at Carr Kitcat & Aitken, the broker, said ''the dumping of excess stock'', combined with the lack of upturn in consumer demand, had hurt Hi-Tec. Mr Taimuri said Nike, Reebok and LA Gear had been cutting prices by up to 40 per cent to achieve sales in Britain. Such discounts bring Nike and Reebok into the price range traditionally occupied by Hi-Tec, forcing Hi-Tec in turn to cut prices to maintain sales.

Mr Taimuri has cut his forecast for the full year to January 1993 from Pounds 11 million pre-tax profit to Pounds 4 million. He expects a break-even at the half-year stage.

Yesterday's events appear to justify Hi-Tecs efforts to diversify out of the British training shoe market into broader markets around the world. Analysts say the North American hiking market is going well for Hi-Tec and expect European textiles brands to do well.

At the annual meeting, Mr van Wezel said: ''Our UK sales so far this year are significantly below those achieved in the corresponding period of last year, and are below our earlier expectations, and we are experiencing a sharper squeeze on margins. Inevitably, these factors will have a pronounced adverse impact on our overall results for the first half of this year.

''We have already taken steps to reduce our British cost base, for example, by reductions in our workforce, and we are keeping a tight control on working capital.''


LOAD-DATE: July 4, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Newspapers Limited

 

801 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Times


July 3, 1992, Friday


Hi-Tec stumbles in Olympic year


BYLINE: By George Sivell


SECTION: Business


LENGTH: 353 words


FRANK van Wezel might have expected Olympic year to lift Hi-Tec, the sports shoe group, to the heights; instead it appears to be plumbing the Stygian depths.

The stock market put the boot in to the personal fortune of Mr van Wezel, the chairman of Hi-Tec, after he delivered a profits warning at the sports shoe group's annual meeting. LOAD-DATE: July 4, 1992

802 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


November 11, 1992, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Footwear flotsam carries clues about ocean's flow; Nike's sole survivors hit the beaches


BYLINE: ROBIN MCKIE; OBSERVER, LONDON


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2


LENGTH: 492 words


DATELINE: LONDON


For the past 18 months, a Japanese armada has been sailing silently across the Pacific. Now, these secret invaders have begun to infiltrate the shores of the United States. It sounds like a sinister attempt to redress the outcome of World War II. In fact, the explanation for the invasion is pedestrian, quite literally, for the flotilla is made up of 40,000 Nike training shoes that have been slowly bobbing around the Pacific Ocean since the spring of 1990. 

News that these sartorial requisites have met a watery fate may dismay the youth of the West. However, it has brought joy to Oregon's beachcombers, who have been making a fortune reselling the trainers which, bizarrely, have survived their briny immersion with surprising resilience.

Odder still, the data provided by plotting the Nike armada's progress has allowed oceanographers to test several complex theories about the detailed mechanics of Pacific currents. "It has been a real bonus to our work," said James Ingraham of the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service.

This strange story began on May 17, 1990, when a storm struck the freighter Hansa Carrier, which was en route from Korea to the U.S. The ship survived, but its shipment of Nikes was washed overboard. Not a sole was saved.

The incident was forgotten until November that year, when Nike trainers began appearing along the shores of Oregon. Large hiking boots, high-top trainers and loafers began to bob landwards, at first in ones and twos, eventually in the thousands. To the incredulity of locals, the beaches were swamped with multicolored trainers.

Within weeks, this well-heeled landing army had created a thriving new local economy. Beachcombers held swap-meets where they exchanged right and left shoes, which they then resold in pairs.

"I got my pair for $ 20," said Ingraham. "That's about a quarter of the price I would have paid in a store. Admittedly, they had spent a year sloshing about the Pacific, but after I'd worn them a couple of times they loosened up and are quite comfortable now."

The fact that the shoes were still wearable after many months' battering by storms would suggest Nike products have a certain weather-resistance, a quality that could well be marketed. However, this has not been seized upon.

Maybe not, but the longevity of the trainers has been a real boost for Ingraham who, with colleague Curtis Ebbesmeyer, began studying the shoes' peregrinations. They used the data to produce a lengthy paper for the Transactions of the American Geophysical Union.

They report that many of the shoes appeared farther south than would be expected for flotsam borne by the tropical currents that head northward to Alaska.

Now, as the currents have swept back out to sea from Oregon, already some of the shoes have appeared on the shores of Hawaii.

"The next stop is Japan," Ingraham said. "After that, they will start on their second circle of the Pacific Ocean."


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CanWest Global Communications Corp.

SUNDAY MAIL (QLD)


January 12, 1992 Sunday


SHOE RIVALS HALT BATTLE


SOURCE: QNP


BYLINE: STEAD G


LENGTH: 82 words


Shoe rivals halt battle THINGS are tough in the leisurewear business, but at least a truce has been called in the war over hi-tech basketball shoes.

Sports rivals Nike and LA Gear have dropped a legal battle over British patents for the sporty shoes, bringing at least a temporary end to the war of words between the big business competitors.

Nike had claimed LA Gear infringed patent rights while LA Gear launched a counter-claim that Nike were trying to drive them out of business.

806 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Daily Yomiuri


August 27, 1992, Thursday


Nike To Bring NBA Stars


SECTION: Pg. 12


LENGTH: 175 words


 

Veteran Moses Malone and All-Star guard Tim Hardaway are among six National Basketball Association players who will come to Tokyo to play in an exhibition event next month sponsored by Nike Japan Corp.

The six NBA players will be divided into two teams along with players from the Japan Basketball League in an exhibition game on Sept. 24 at 6:30 p.m. at Tokyo's Yoyogi No. 2 Gym. A spokesman for the event, called "Nike Force Tour Japan 1992" and which will include slam-dunk and three-point shooting contests, said a sellout is expected. 

Scheduled to appear with Malone, a three-time MVP currently with the Milwaukee Bucks, and the Golden State Warriors' Hardaway are Golden State forward Billy Owens, Chicago guard B.J. Armstrong and Washington forward-center Pervis Ellison. A sixth player will be named later.

Ticket prices are 10,300 yen, 7,210 yen and 5,150 yen and must be reserved by phone in advance. Call 03-3293-2500 between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. from Aug. 30. Tickets will be mailed in exchange for cash by registered mail.

808 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


May 28, 1992, Thursday, 1* EDITION


COLUMN ONE


BYLINE: VANSUN


SECTION: SPORTS; COLUMN ONE; Pg. D7


LENGTH: 314 words


 

THE POST-SEASON awards are starting to pile up for the Vancouver Canucks. On Tuesday, Pat Quinn was named coach-of-the-year by The Sporting News while on Wednesday, forward Ryan Walter was honored as the 1992 NHL Man of the Year.

The award is presented annually to the player best recognized in the community as a "positive role model through his conduct on and off the ice." Walter received a $ 20,000 cheque that will be split equally between Canuck Place and Montreal-based Hockey Ministries International, which runs free hockey camps for underprivileged children. 

"There's one in Vancouver and one in Montreal, the two places where my heart has been," said Walter, who spent nine seasons with the Canadiens before moving to the Canucks last fall.

JUST FILM IT

The Whistler area is providing the setting for a new series of Nike TV ads now being filmed by a Portland, Ore.-based agency. The four ads follow a theme entitled "Nike Wild." According to a Whistler Resort news release the commercials feature a "new line of Nike active wear modelled in various action adventures such as mountain biking, wind surfing, white water rafting and mountain climbing."

The ads are expected to air nationally across the U.S.

MOVING WEST

The Canadian Open golf tournament in Vancouver? It's not a sure thing, but Sun golf writer Arv Olson reports on page D11 today that the Royal Canadian Golf Association is considering moving the Open from its permanent site at Glen Abbey near Toronto once every five years.

SNOW JOB

There are many claimants to the longest drive of all time in golf. However, an Australian named Nils Lied, working at a weather station in Antarctica, reportedly drove a ball 2,640 yards.

How did he do it? Well, a report in "Amazing, but True Golf Facts," says the ball landed on smooth, frozen ice covering a bay and just kept rolling.

809 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


March 25, 1992, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Jordan talks about Thomas, Olympics, Barkley and the book


BYLINE: David Dupree


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 9C


LENGTH: 615 words


Q: Has all that has happened to you thus far this season - the book criticizing you (Jordan Rules), the licensing controversies and other things, made this year less fun than it might have been?

A: It's like a soap opera. Stay tuned for the next development. Playing basketball is fun. It's less fun off the court, though. That's been the big difference of this year and past years. I've been able to escape it all and just go out and play, but once I step off the court, there are a lot of questions I have to deal with - the book, greediness and different accusations. I just have to be truthful and stand up and answer the questions. You can't beat around the bush and say no comment, because that keeps it going. 

Q: Why did you agree to play in the Olympics in the first place?

A: I wasn't really playing for financial reasons and I wasn't looking for any more endorsements. I was only playing because I wanted to hang out with the guys for the summer and be a part of history. Had I known it was going to be a headache like this from the merchandising and licensing stuff, I never would have committed to play.

Q: With the agreement between Nike and NBA Properties, your likeness can't be used on apparel not sold by Nike, and Nike cannot use the Olympics or its symbol on items. The That almost makes you a man without a country, doesn't it?

A: I represent a country, but I can't be sold by one.

Q: What do you think of Charles Barkley (the outspoken forward of the Philadelphia 76ers)?

A: There is always some value in what he says. Who can tell him to shut up? Nobody. He's going to say what he wants. Some people like it, some don't. There's a lot of truth in what he says, but with that truth there is always some doubt of the other stuff that's in there. Either the language or the racism that he adds to his different comments makes it difficult for most people to fully understand, but we as basketball players, and some blacks, understand what he is saying.

Q: What is the real story as to why you and Isiah Thomas don't seem to get along?

A: The problem has always been he plays for a team I don't like and I play for a team he doesn't like. I've never had a real problem with him. I just don't know him that well and he doesn't know me. There was some competitive jealousy when I first came into the league. Magic Johnson was a part of that, but I was able to spend time with him and and we got past that. There just hasn't been the opportunity for me and Isiah to spend time away from the rivalry.

Q: Who is your toughest competition in getting back to the NBA Finals?

A: I don't care what anybody says, you can't look past Detroit. They scare you. They have the experience and the same nucleus that won the back-to- backs.

Q: With Larry Bird and Magic Johnson at or near the end of their careers, how do you like being designated as the next ambassador for the NBA?

A: I think everybody is kind of force-feeding me. I'm a part of the league and I want to uphold the NBA's way, but I think other players have to help out, too. The only guy I know who carried the label of ambassador by himself for a time was Dr. J.

Q: How do most teams defense you?

A: Everyone knows that driving is my strong point and the weakest part of my game is my jump shot. So most teams try to take away the drive, but when I'm knocking down my jump shot, they usually just try to double-team me.

Q: Is Scottie Pippen the best player you ever played with?

A: In my eight years in the NBA, yeah. In some ways it's like looking at a mirror. He doesn't want to play at just one end of the floor, either, and you don't find that every day at this level. He's very dedicated.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY; PHOTO; b/w, Porter Binks, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: MICHAEL JORDAN: 'It's less fun off the court.' CUTLINE: 'SOAP OPERA' STAR: Michael Jordan says controversies surrounding him have made his life more complicated once he steps off the court.


NBA; The defending NBA champion Chicago Bulls have the best record in the league and Michael Jordan is on his way to his sixth consecutive scoring title and perhaps his third MVP award. USA TODAY NBA writer David DuPree recently interviewed him, before gambling allegations concerning Jordan were reported. Excerpts:

810 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


June 9, 1991, Sunday, City Edition


Jordan's a wonder, but even he questions heroes as role models


SOURCE: Economist


SECTION: PERSPECTIVE; Pg. 8D


LENGTH: 865 words


 

Michael Jordan, a 28-year-old basketball player with the Chicago Bulls, is the City of Broad Shoulders' latest hero. Even in the intense, slightly unbelievable athleticism of professional basketball, he does things that make you gasp.
 
    Many knowledgeable judges reckon he is the most thrilling player ever to grace the court. Columnist George Will has suggested, tongue only half in cheek, that (along with such luminaries as Frank Lloyd Wright and Aaron Copland) Jordan's face should grace high-denomination dollars. 
 
    In previous years, Jordan has had to play in a Bulls team that collapsed when the going got tough and in the National Basketball Association's play-offs, thegoing gets very tough indeed. This year, however, the Bulls are playing the Los Angeles Lakers for the championship.
 
    Professional basketball, more than any other American sport, is dominated by blacks. Since to play professional basketball at all you need great discipline, and to play it at Jordan's level you need extraordinary flair and imagination, it is hardly surprising that the great search for "role models" for black children should have fastened on the Bulls' star. Since Jordan is intelligent and articulate, notable for good sportsmanship and devoted to charitable work (though without ever seeming cloyingly goody-goody about it), he is an obvious choice.
 
    There is, however, a catch two catches, actually. The first is Jordan's association with Nike, America's leading maker of sneakers. Jordan has been endorsing Nike products since 1984: the Air Jordan shoe is Nike's best-selling line. He is not alone; other black heroes like filmmaker Spike Lee and John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown University, also endorse Nike products.
 
    What is wrong with that? According to Jesse Jackson, black America's most popular politician and a basketball fan, a lot. Nike, he argues, is promoting an "ethos of mindless materialism" by encouraging black children to buy sneakers (the latest Air Jordan costs $ 125) that they cannot afford. That sounds like killjoyism taken to the limit, but Jackson has a point.
 
    It is not as if inner-city children buy just one pair of sneakers; the pressure from the street is to keep up with the latest fashions. Some youngsters own as many as 50 pairs of sneakers; one 14-year-old boy told the Washington Post he spent $ 2,000 a year on shoes.
 
    You do not need to be a genius to work out one of the most likely ways in which some inner-city youngsters come by such sums: It is by selling drugs. Some drug dealers use sneakers as a way of recruiting youngsters to their gangs; some gangs identify themselves by the sneakers they wear, or accept stolen sneakers as payment for drugs. There have even been incidents where people
 

 
R have been murdered for their high-fashion basketball shoes.
 
    Nike, to be fair, makes sure that its role-model endorsers like Jordan appear in advertisements warning kids off drugs and encouraging them to stay in school. But Jackson is entitled to wonder whether those messages are as strong as the ones coming from the street.
 
    The bigger catch is in the very idea of role models. Behind the search for role models lies the assumption that only great people such as Martin Luther King, Malcolm X or Jordan himself are worthy of emulation. When those idols are found to have feet of clay andeveryone who draws breath does the pain of disenchantment can be profound.
 
Jordan himself knows the pressure that role-modelling puts on him: "I'm not a perfect person," he has said. He agrees with Charles Barkley, another NBA star, that the most useful role models for childrenare not heroes like himself but their parents.
 
    There is another drawback to role models. The majority of children have no chance of fame on the basketball court, or anywhere else. The veneration of sportsmen and women subtly denigrates more mundane but realistic goals like getting a steady job.
 
    What blacks need is not superstars but economic opportunity; and, as two recent sets of studies by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute have shown (as if the point needed laboring), anyone who thinks that they have such opportunity in the same measure as whites is deluding himself.
 
    None of this should be taken as an excuse to denigrate Jordan's talent. But it is a shame that America's obsession with sports means that his kind of talent is celebrated more than that of other men and women.
 
    As his city prepared for the NBA finals, Chicago magazine ran an article on Cyrus Colter, who in his long life has been one of Chicago's leading black lawyers, academics and public servants, and who, when most men would have put on the slippers, took to writing award-winning novels, short stories and poems. His has been an extraordinary tale; it is probably known to fewer than 1 percent of the young blacks who worship Michael Jordan.
1991 The Economist Newspaper Limited. All rights reserved. Distributed by Special Features/Syndication Sales
 
Reprinted from the Economist magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO, Associated Press; Michael Jordan and his Chicago Bulls are playing the Lakers for the championship


Times Publishing Company

 

815 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 30, 1992, Thursday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS BARCELONA SCENE Media turnout a shoo-in with Olympians as bait


BYLINE: By Melissa Turner STAFF WRITERolympics; advertising; business; equipment; personalities; media


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 9


LENGTH: 492 words


Barcelona - It's Day Four of the Olympic Games and Jennifer Capriati is winning her first Olympic tennis match; the U.S. women's volleyball team is losing to blood rival Japan; and Janet Evans is swimming the 800- meter freestyle preliminaries.

And you want to entice several hundred top reporters and photographers from the international sports press away from the venues to listen to a pitch for your new track shoes?

Right. 

So here's what you do. Post a notice on the Olympic bulletin board. "Leroy Burrell Press Conference." Burrell is only the former world-record holder and a gold medal threat in the 100-meter dash.

Of course, the sports media forgoes the competition and heads en masse to the posh Hotel Avenida Palace. They're hot to quiz Burrell on the controversy surrounding the selection of the 400-meter relay team.

And they will, but only after picking up Asics's thick press kit, complete with color brochures and Asics Corp.'s annual report. It's the newfangled Olympic news conference. Trot out superstar athletes, offer up some food and drink and the media will come. The media gets a few good quotes, and you get your prominently displayed company logo in every photo that goes out across the international wire services.

Here in Barcelona, the ever-competitive athletic shoe companies have got this marketing ploy down.

Mizuno pulled them in Friday with Carl Lewis. While Mizuno's chairman passed his new featherweight jumping shoe through the sweaty press corps imprisoned in an amphitheater at Poble Espanol on Montjuic last week, Lewis fed them bits about his devastating failure to make the 400-meter relay team.

Nike showed not one, but two feature-length commercials in the Palacio Balana Cinema before Nike sports marketing director Steve Miller paraded out "The Sultans of Suspension" - Michael Jordan and Sergei Bubka - to the sounds of James Browns's "Gravity." "Air Jordan" meeting "Aeroflot," quipped emcee Ahmad Rashad.

In addition to individual contracts with spokestars such as Jordan and Bubka, industry leader Nike compensates the U.S. track and field team to the tune of $ 1 million a year to wear its gear.

Asics's ambassador Burrell - as a member of the U.S. track and field team - also wears Nike uniforms, but he made it clear he wears Asics shoes.

All these sponsorships are a bit confusing for the consumer.

Japanese shoemaker Asics is the official shoe of the Barcelona Games - it supplied some 90,000 pairs to the Olympic volunteers, torch runners and organizing committee staff. Nike is the official shoe of the U.S. track team; but Reebok is an official sponsor of the entire U.S. Olympic team, and is supplying the official award ceremony uniforms.

So try to picture this: Burrell wins the 100-meter in his Asics. He pulls on his Reebok suit over his Nike uniform and listens to the National anthem wearing all three brands.

Seems it's getting a bit confusing for the media, too.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922180159


GRAPHIC: photo: The Asics' Corp. uses sprinter Leroy Burrell to lure the media in Barcelona. Each competitive athletic shoe company offers up a different athlete in its marketing ploy. / MARLENE KARAS / Staff


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

817 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 14, 1992, Sunday


Shaquille O'Neal finds good fit with Reebok


BYLINE: By Ernest Holsendolphbusiness; reviews; earnings; finances; personalities


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section H; Page 3


LENGTH: 150 words


It's Reebok!

When prize basketball player Shaquille O'Neal left Louisiana State this spring and put himself on the professional market, the athletic shoe makers gave him the full-court press. 

Reebok beat out the others, including Nike, its main rival, and gets to crow. Celebrating like a prospector who found pure gold, Reebok executives put a pair of size 21s on the young 7-footer and gave him a coming-out party last week.

Some party.

He hasn't played a minute yet for a pro team, but the Massachusetts- based maker of athletic shoes signed him to a $ 3 million-a-year contract, just to wear those shoes and speak kindly about them.

Poor Nike will have to make do with Michael Jordan.

These shoes are big business. Reebok last year had revenue of $ 2.7 billion, mostly selling shoes and other sports apparel.

Ernest Holsendolph's column appears every Sunday, Wednesday and Friday.


LOAD-DATE: June 16, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

819 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 19, 1991, Friday


Little agency creating ads for Subaru; Firm gained fame for Bo knows' campaign


BYLINE: By Larry Fishautomotive; advertising


SECTION: WHEELS; SECTION S; PAGE 10


LENGTH: 929 words


PHILADELPHIA - Sales of Nike Inc.'s new cross-training athletic shoe went from zero in 1987 to an estimated $ 400 million this year, and Bo and everybody else know one big reason why.

In addition to selling a lot of shoes, the advertising campaign featuring athlete Bo Jackson firmly established the small ad shop of Wieden & Kennedy as undoubtedly the hottest agency in Portland, Ore.

Now Wieden & Kennedy has taken on another challenge, that of trying to get Subaru of America out of reverse. As a result of its landing the high-profile, high-billing account, Wieden & Kennedy is opening a Philadelphia branch, which, by itself, will rank as one of the city's largest agencies. 

The first Subaru ads by Wieden & Kennedy are to appear around Labor Day. Both the car company and the agency are mum on the content, but Subaru's director of advertising, Mark Dunn, promises that "they're definitely something completely different" from other auto ads.

The campaign already is something different in one respect. Virtually all automotive advertising has been done by big Madison Avenue- based agencies. Nine-year-old Wieden & Kennedy, by contrast, had never had a nationwide client until it won the account of Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore.; Bo knows' brought attention

The overwhelming success of the "Bo knows" ads brought prosperity and rapid growth to Wieden & Kennedy. For several years, the agency had all it could handle just keeping up with its star account.

But when Subaru went looking for a new agency about three months ago, Wieden & Kennedy felt it was ready for another big account. And Subaru, suffering from losses and shrinking market share, was ready to try something fresh.

Subaru of America, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., took off in the 1970s with what was then a unique product, an inexpensive four-wheel-drive passenger car. With Subaru all the way was its New York ad agency, Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver.

But Subaru went into a skid in the mid-'80s. Other carmakers brought out and elaborated on four-wheel-drive models, and they had other models and better-established corporate identities to lure customers.

Subaru of America began suffering losses and shrinking sales, and, last fall, the parent carmaker back in Japan, Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., took matters into its own hands. It bought the Subaru of America stock that had been publicly held and began direct operation of the subsidiary.; Wanted to be major account

On April 11, Subaru put its advertising account "into review," meaning it was up for grabs. Subaru was looking for some specific traits in its agency, said spokesman Richard Marshall.

"We wanted to be a major account but not their sole account," he said. Nor did Subaru want to be one of many sizable accounts held by an agency.

The strategy was to find an agency big enough to have the resources to service a national account but small enough that Subaru would command management's undivided attention.

A consultant helped narrow the list to a half-dozen candidates. One by one, they trooped to a meeting room in the Hyatt Cherry Hill to make a presentation for about nine top-ranking Subaru executives.

David Luhr led Wieden & Kennedy's four-hour presentation. Although he can't discuss the creative concepts he pitched, he says that the presentation was built around the idea that "Subaru always has had a distinct personality. It was not a Honda, not a Toyota; it was always styled a little differently."; Basic, reliable, but dull

Subaru has always been thought of as a car that was "basic, Spartan, durable and reliable, but not very pretty to look at," says Mr. Marshall of Subaru.

Indeed, that is the theme of Levine, Huntley's last work for Subaru, the "Never Die" commercials that depict latter-day, upscale Subaru drivers discomfited to run across battered but hard-working old Subarus that look as if they are being driven by Okies escaping the Dust Bowl.

The ads clearly say that Subaru wants a new image. It now falls to Wieden & Kennedy to determine what that image will be.

The market for compact and subcompact cars is extremely competitive, with literally dozens of similarly priced and equipped contenders.

In that kind of market, "advertising can really make a difference," Mr. Luhr says, so Wieden & Kennedy can rightly claim credit if Subaru's fortunes begin to turn around. By the same token, Subaru has placed a great chunk of its fate in the agency's hands.

Wieden & Kennedy promised Subaru that it would open a branch near Cherry Hill to service the account.; Philadelphia office planned

Bid the middle of July, Mr. Luhr also plans to staff an office of about 40. Enough people will be brought in from Portland to assure that the new office really is a Wieden & Kennedy site, but the majority are expected to be new hires.

The Philadelphia office will be a branch, but one that could grow as large as its home office. The Portland office has about 120 employees and handles $ 250 million in annual billings.

The Subaru account alone will have 40 employees and up to $ 70 million in billings. In Philadelphia, where relatively few agencies handle national accounts, few shops have billings of more than $ 100 million from all sources.

Mr. Luhr says the Philadelphia office eventually will look for other accounts, but for about a year or so, it will handle only Subaru.

"This is a huge account for us, and we're going to get comfortable with it first," he says.

Larry Fish writes for Knight-Ridder Newspapers.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photo: The Subaru Legacy L: Although the company's cars are perceived as reliable, sales have slipped / Subaru

821 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 13, 1991, Wednesday


Bankruptcy petition filed against Hickok's


BYLINE: By - Sonia Murraybusiness; closings; courts; transactions; economy; conditions


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION B; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 150 words


After market conditions and financing problems forced Hickok's Sporting Goods to close seven of its eight stores last month, three major creditors have dealt another blow to the 32-year-old business: an involuntary bankruptcy petition.

Russell Corp., Nike Inc. and Reebok International filed the Chapter 7 petition against the Atlanta-based chain last Friday in the federal bankruptcy court for the northern district of Georgia. 

An involuntary Chapter 7 petition is a way creditors can force a business into bankruptcy, sell off its assets and get their money back. The petition states Hickok's and its parent firm, the Young Group Inc., owe the Russell Corp. $ 456,405, Nike $ 377,914 and Reebok International $ 891,491 for goods sold and delivered.

Hickok's can either agree to the filing or try to fight it. Officials of the company said they were not prepared to comment.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

823 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


October 11, 1992, SUNDAY, LATE FIVE STAR Edition


'PRIME TIME' WILL WORK OVERTIME SUNDAY


BYLINE: Rick Hummel Of the Post-Dispatch Staff


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 4C


LENGTH: 728 words


 

PITTSBURGH - Deion Sanders, who might well be the Atlanta Braves' 25th man now, will play football Sunday in Miami for the Atlanta Falcons. Sanders was to leave after Saturday's fourth game of the National League Championship Series on a private plane apparently sponsored by Nike, for whom he does commercials. Sanders is paid $1 million by Nike if he plays both sports and $100,000 if he plays just one. Additionally, he would forfeit $118,000 in football salary if he did not show up Sunday in Miami. That represents 1/17 of his $2 million salary. Nike is said to be planning a commercial around Sanders' two-sports-in-one-day adventure. Sanders is expected back here Sunday night for the fifth game of the playoffs. Braves general manager John Schuerholz said he would not have placed Sanders, who's called ''Prime Time,'' on his 25-man playoff roster if he had known he was going to try to play both sports. ''If he gets banged up and can't play, it puts us at a disadvantage,'' Schuerholz said. Manager Bobby Cox of the Braves said, ''I thought we had him exclusively through the playoffs and the World Series, and that's not fact.'' Braves President Stan Kasten said: ''We have been informed he will play football. There's nothing else to say. Everything else will wait for another time.'' Sanders, on why he no longer is talking to the Atlanta media, or most everybody else, said: ''They had a privilege. They abused the privilege. They lost the privilege.'' Bob Walk, Sunday's starter for the Pittsburgh Pirates in Game 5, made 19 starts, completing one durin g the season. He was 6-6 with a 3.38 earned-run average when starting. Walk may be remembered as the pitcher who started the first game of the 1980 World Series for the Philadelphia Phillies against the Kansas City Royals. ''I don't think back then I realized what was happening,'' Walk said. ''I think I realize now what's at stake. It means a little bit more to me now than it did then. ''My goal is to go out and hopefully throw six or seven innings, and when I leave the game hope my team has a chance to win.'' Walk is the only National League pitcher with at least 10 decisions a year to have a winning record in each of the last six seasons. He is also the only remaining player from manager Jim Leyland's first team, which lost 98 games in 1986. ''The past few years I've pretty much gone wherever (Leyland) wants me to go,'' Walk said. ''When I went into his office yesterday and he told me, of course, I was surprised. I think he said, 'You're starting Game 5.' And I said, 'Starting?' '' Walk, 35, has had almost constant groin injuries the last few years. ''I don't feel I'll ever go out there again and not have an ache or pain somewhere,'' he said. Against Atlanta, Walk is 5-9 in his career. ''They are probably one of the teams that have given me more trouble than anyone else,'' Walk said. ''I had success against a couple of guys who I won't mention - I don't want to jinx myself.'' One of them probably is Dave Justice, who is one for eight against Walk. Otis Nixon is three for 15. However, the Braves are batting .303 overall against Walk. While Braves catcher Greg Olson, a 1991 World Series notable who has ankle and leg injuries, entertains media as he supports himself on crutches, backup Damon Berryhill wonders why he was shortchanged. ''I thought it was a joke,'' said Berryhill, a former Cub. ''It was like Greg had played all the games and I hadn't at all. I think he was seven games ahead of me.'' Unlike Olson, Berryhill prefers the shadows. 'Greg is a politician and I'm not one for the spotlight,'' Berryhill said. Atlanta second baseman Mark Lemke, who has a .226 major-league career average, had 16 hits in his last 32 postseason at-bats before Saturday's game. Braves lefthander Steve Avery, who will start the fifth game for Atlanta, has beaten the Pirates three times in succession in the last two playoff series. He has given up just four earned runs, all in the second game this year, in 22 2/3 innings. ''Any time you have confidence against a team, it makes it easier to go out against them,'' Avery said. ''I don't know how much they think about it when I'm out there - if they're pressing a little bit to get to me early. I don't know what the reason is they haven't had much success against me, but it's an advantage for me.''


LOAD-DATE: October 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

825 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


August 3, 1992, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


EYE OPENERS


BYLINE: Compiled by Ray Jordan Of the Post-Dispatch Staff


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 463 words


 

Memo to MICHAEL JORDAN: Decathlete DAVE JOHNSON, who is Mr. Reebok, says he will proudly wear the Nike-sponsored U.S. track and field uniform with not a moment's thought to company loyalty and all the other Jordan-inspired malarkey. He will wear his Reebok warm-up, will strip to his Nike uniform, and stand on the medal stand (he hopes) with his official Reebok suit. ''The reason we're here is to represent our country, not our company,'' he told BOB KRAVITZ of the Rocky Mountain News. ''When you get here, company things need to be left at home.'' Let's review, for all the brand-name shoppers. Nike makes the track uniforms for the U.S. team. Champion makes the basketball uniforms. The boxing uniforms are made by adidas. Forty sponsors are paying a collective $160 million to the U.S. Olympic Committee and each athlete gets about $3,000 worth of luggage, cosmetics, jewelry, chewing gum, diet soda, etc. But apparently that's not enough for Jordan, who probably makes more per breath than that. ''I feel very strongly about loyalty to my own company,'' he has said. Says MIKE LITTWIN of the Baltimore Sun: ''I'm waiting for him to say he regrets he has but one life to give to his shoe company.'' And furthermore . . . Johnson summarily dismisses the idea that Jordan or SERGEI BUBKA could become great decathletes. ''Take my word for it,'' Johnson said. ''I can come closer to dunking a basketball like Jordan than Jordan could to pole vaulting or throwing the javelin.'' Wait'll promoters get wind of this. Coming soon! To an arena near you! The Battle of the World's Greatest Athletes (and shoe companies)! Now you know: Gold, silver and bronze medals were not always the reward for finishing in the first three places at the Olympic Games. In the 1900 Paris Games, valuable pieces of art were presented instead. For the U.S. Olympic team, one size obviously does not fit all. Reebok says it produced 38,000 pieces of clothing in 12 sizes ranging from double extra-small for female gymnasts to size-6 extra large for MARK HENRY, the 367-pound weightlifter. Henry may need a tuck in his tights. ''I've dropped about 4 pounds, you know, walkin' and scopin' out the local (Barcelona) scene,'' he said. ''Ain't much food here I can call by name, but I'm hoping to get back up to 367 before my competition.'' QUOTE/UNQUOTE ''We're here for free, we've given up our summer. There's a lot of money up here, a lot of people putting their livelihoods at stake just to be here.'' MAGIC JOHNSON, Dream Teamer POST PUZZLER Who set a world long jump record during the 1924 Olympics but got only a bronze medal? (Answer Tuesday) SUNDAY'S POST PUZZLER: When was the last time an American won the 1,500 meters at the Summer Olympics? ANSWER: Mel Sheppard in 1908.


LOAD-DATE: October 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Photo; PHOTO ... Joy Ride: France's ERIC SRECKI being hoisted by fans after winning the Olympic gold medal in men's individual epee fencing.


Copyright 1992 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

826 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


March 24, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Converse in Adland, Playing Catch-Up Ball


BYLINE: By AIMEE L. STERN; Aimee L. Stern is a New York-based writer who often reports on advertising.


SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 2001 words


DATELINE: BOSTON


After more than 70 years in the sneaker business, Converse Inc. is pinning its future on five words.

Caught flatfooted in the great sneaker war of the 80's, the company has been eating the dust raised by Nike, Reebok and L.A. Gear for five years. Using glitzy, celebrity-studded commercials to push one new line of high-performance sneakers after another, the Big Three have grabbed two-thirds of the athletic shoe business while helping to triple its size, to $5.6 billion annually in the United States. Meanwhile, Converse, hobbled by a scattershot approach to marketing, has been stuck with a 2 percent share. 

Now the company is gambling $22 million on a new ad campaign built around the slogan, "It's What's Inside That Counts." The campaign, which begins Thursday, is designed to highlight the company's long tradition of making solid, if unexciting, sneakers -- at a price lower than the Big Three.

The campaign, which features basketball stars Larry Bird and Bernard King, is particularly important to Converse, which has recently been operating in the troubled shadow of its parent, Interco Inc. The St. Louis-based furniture and footwear company, weighed down with debt in fighting off a hostile takeover 1988 attempt, filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.

The Boston-based advertising agency that is producing the commercials, Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, has a lot riding on the campaign as well. The second-largest agency in New England after Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., IQ&J has represented Converse for eight years and counts it as one of its most important national clients. Although IQ&J largely escaped blame for past marketing failings -- Converse says a lack of direction on its own part was the chief villain -- the agency is under intense pressure to deliver the goods with the new campaign. Just last Friday, the point was underscored when Hill, Holiday lost its Reebok account.

How Converse and IQ&J worked together is a tale of creative chaos, tight deadlines and taut nerves. The three-month the effort tested the resources -- and the patience -- of client and agency both.

The effort began in earnest last September. Gordon Tucker, Converse's fourth marketing director in as many years, had concluded a summer of research with a list of adjectives that encapsulated consumer and trade perceptions of the company's major products, which include Magic Johnson basketball shoes and Chuck Taylor All Stars.

The company had been marketing its brands separately, diluting the impact of the Converse name. The adjectives -- confident, passionate, hard-working, tough, selfish and genuine -- were to be used as guidelines for pushing the Converse name itself, particularly with the key buying group, teen-agers.

IQ&J assigned two creative teams to the project to compete in coming up with the campaign, a traditional industry practice. The teams were a study in contrasts.

One paired Don Pogany, a copywriter who recently left the agency, with Peter Favat, an art director. Both men wear faded blue jeans to work; Mr. Favat accents his with cowboy boots and a small gold earring. They had made ads before for Converse, marked by fast-paced editing and clever punch lines.

The second team, new to the Converse account, consisted of Mike Sheehan, in the copywriter slot, and Robert Rich as the art director, both of whom are more conservative in dress and taste. They favor a simple, direct approach in their ads.

While some agencies devise campaigns on their own and present finished ideas to clients, IQ&J executives prefer to hold a series of sessions in which they show their work in progress. At these, the "tissue meetings," concepts are explored through drawings on tissue paper.

"Involving the client in the creative process means there are no surprises," said Bruce Kelley, IQ&J's president.

The first meeting was scheduled for Nov. 13. Mr. Tucker wanted a finished campaign idea by the end of that month, in time for Converse's annual sales meeting on Dec. 2.

The two creative teams plowed through newspapers, magazines and books looking for sports images. They devised three potential campaigns, tried to eliminate one but finally decided to present all three.

The morning of the first tissue meeting was cold even by Massachusetts standards. About a dozen executives met in a cramped conference room at Converse headquarters in North Reading, Mass., about 20 miles north of Boston. The atmosphere was casual. IQ&J's executive creative director, Christine Chamberlin, explained the ground rules: a first tissue meeting was meant to be a broad review, a place to discard concepts the client didn't like.

The agency opened with "Worn in the USA," which everyone agreed was the wildest but weakest idea. Mr. Favat turned on a boom box and danced around the room in flawless imitation of a team mascot at a half-time show. The campaign, he said, would depict fans of a high school football team readying themselves for the game. Mr. Tucker laughed, but it was clear he didn't take the approach seriously.

Then came a campaign built around a school locker room. One ad closed with a voice reminiscing, "The moments are temporary but some things are permanent. Converse -- some things never wear out."

To present the third concept, "The Original," Mr. Sheehan also took his audience inside a school locker room. A coach tossed boxes of Converse sneakers at his players. "We play as a team, we dress as a team," he tells them. The tagline: "Converse -- The Original."

Mr. Tucker asked the agency people which approach they preferred and Mr. Kelley pushed hard for "The Original."

"It shows there is us and there is them," Mr. Kelley said, explaining that it set Converse apart from other brands with its "pre-emptive statement" that it was the original sneaker. Mr. Tucker was unconvinced, arguing that such a distinction had little meaning outside the industry. But he liked the idea of associating Converse with the timeless moments and youthful exuberance of sports. "Sports teach kids about values," he concluded. "That image fits us."

The four members of the creative teams smiled politely like small children chastised by their mothers.

The second tissue meeting was scheduled at IQ&J's offices for 5:30 P.M. on Nov. 20, two days before Thanksgiving. The meeting started about an hour late because the agency people simply couldn't agree on what to present. Some thought Mr. Tucker's suggestion of associating sports with values was hokey. Some felt Converse needed to outdo the stylized approach of other sneaker companies. Some refused to give up on "The Original."

Mr. Kelley tried to start the meeting off on a positive note by introducing an idea for a new Magic Johnson billboard. Mr. Tucker hated it. The agency then tried to salvage "The Original" theme. Mr. Sheehan and Mr. Rich had discovered that several Larry Birds were listed in local phone books. They envisioned ads asking "What is an original?" in which these noncelebrities would discuss their feelings about sports. But the consensus was that the idea closely resembled Reebok's unsuccessful "UBU" (you-be-you) campaign from a couple of years earlier.

Ms. Chamberlin addressed Mr. Tucker's values issue head-on with an idea entitled "Stand for Something." She offered examples of coaches lecturing athletes on the sins of being late to practice and letting the team down. Mr. Tucker politely suggested it was too preachy.

After four hours, Mr. Tucker was frustrated. The agency had presented a jumble of ideas. He liked the regular guy approach and was still attached to looking inside the minds of young athletes and examining their feelings about sports. Ms. Chamberlin told her staff to enjoy Thanksgiving and come in over the weekend.

But early on Monday, the 26th, Ms. Chamberlin told IQ&J's chairman, Richard C. Garrison, that her staff was still at odds.

Mr. Garrison drove to Converse's offices in an attempt to buy more time. Mr. Tucker refused. Mr. Garrison then vowed that by the time Mr. Tucker left Friday for his sales meeting in Miami, IQ&J would have sold him a finished campaign.

Mr. Garrison returned to IQ&J and tersely told the Converse team they needed to stop bickering and find an answer.

The next day, the group went back to its list of 300 taglines and finally saw what it had been looking for. "It's What's Inside That Counts" had been analyzed, re-analyzed and finally dumped shortly before the previous meeting. Now, it fit the bill. It addressed the values issue that Mr. Tucker insisted upon. And the word "inside" gave Converse an opportunity to sell specific product benefits of its shoes.

Armed with the tagline, the creative teams dusted off the second version of "The Original" campaign, devising a number of ads featuring noncelebrities talking about sports. (The focus ultimately changed to celebrities discussing their lives.) The campaign's tone belonged to the Sheehan-Rich team. The proposed look -- including a reliance on fast-paced editing -- came from Mr. Pogany and Mr. Favat.

Mr. Garrison called Mr. Tucker to say the agency had found the answer. Privately, he and Mr. Kelley kept their fingers crossed.

Mr. Tucker arrived at IQ&J at precisely 8 A.M. on Friday, and two hours later he bought the campaign. When he left, he found a limousine with champagne waiting at the curb, courtesy of Mr. Garrison, to take him to the airport.

It was Mr. Tucker's turn to sell the campaign, to Converse's president, Gilbert Ford. On Saturday, Mr. Ford signed on. On Sunday, so did the sales force. Now, after nearly four months of production, the question is whether the public will sign on, too.
 
MAKING IT -- OFF MAD. AVE.

Richard C. Garrison, the chairman and chief executive of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, is determined to hold onto the Converse account, which, after Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. and T. J. Maxx, a national chain of discount apparel stores, is the biggest client at the Boston-based agency.

Moreover, Mr. Garrison wants to use the new Converse campaign as a national showcase for IQ&J.

"The creative element of the advertising is particularly powerful in the sneaker wars," he said. "We want to deal with accounts that have high-quality brand names and high visibility as national players."

Mr. Garrison's notion of national prominence does not include moving out of Boston, however. Although many regional agencies expand by opening offices in other cities, Mr. Garrison believes national accounts will come to him.

He wants his firm to remain a single office focusing on large accounts in the Northeast corridor and linking up with international agency networks at his clients' request. He dubs IQ&J a mini-network because it provides a range of communications services -- public relations, design and direct response -- in addition to advertising.

IQ&J's turbulent recent history makes Mr. Garrison leery of rapid expansion. In 1986, Quinn & Johnson/BBDO, a small Boston subsidiary of the large New York agency, BBDO Inc., bought 80-year-old Ingalls Associates to create Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson. But then BBDO merged with two other mega-agencies, Doyle Dane Bernbach of New York and Needham Harper Worldwide of Chicago, to form the Omnicom Group, which had $8.4 billion in billings last year.

The 42-year-old Mr. Garrison, who had become president of the combined IQ&J, quickly discovered he was a very small fish in a huge pond. So in February 1989, he and four partners borrowed $4.5 million to purchase IQ&J. The five felt that conflicts of interest with Omnicom accounts restricted the agency's growth. Since the firm became independent, its total billings have grown 14 percent, to $134 million last year.

Freedom also allowed Mr. Garrison to infuse the agency with an entrepreneurial spirit. "There's a lot of screaming and yelling and passion flowing in the halls," Mr. Garrison says with a mischievous grin. "But we don't have that many jerks."


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Christine Chamberlin and Richard Garrison of Boston-based IQ&J (Jim Bourg for The New York Times); Bernard King and Larry Bird star in the new IQ&J campaign. (Converse Inc.)
 
Graph: "Sneakers: The Foot War," tracks sales of athletic footwear for Converse, Reebok, L.A. Gear and Nike, 1987-1990 (Source: Goods Intelligence); tracks spending on adult atheltic footwear advertising, 1987-3rd quarter 1990 (Source: Leading National Advertisers)

Herald Sun


January 31, 1991 Thursday


Finals time for South


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 475 words


SOUTH Melbourne is finding out that every one of its NSL games is a virtual Cup final.

If it's not a local derby, it has been the pressure of bouncing back from a defeat or hitting back at criticism of its playing style. Even against the lower sides the expectations have been not only to win comfortably, but also to do it with flair. 

South's annual clashes against sister club Sydney Olympic have also been regarded as special and a means of proving which of the Greek backed clubs is more dominant in the competition.

Sunday's clash between the two in Sydney has an added ingredient, according to South striker Kimon Taliadoros.

"Every game South Melbourne plays is a big game, but personally, I have been looking forward to this one for some time," Taliadoros said yesterday.

"They knocked us out of the finals last season and this is more of a revenge game for me. It was that way when we met them at home earlier this season, but I believe we still owe them." Taliadoros celebrated his return to the senior side after a seven-week absence by scoring two goals in the 7-3 win over Wollongong Mac last Sunday.

His effort earned him the player of the week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award for round 17.

"It is certainly the highest scoring game I've been involved in my senior career," he said.

Taliadoros paid special credit to his striking partner Paul Trimboli for the goals.

"If you look into them, you'll find that Trimmers was involved in almost all the goals at some stage.He was an integral part of my two," he said.

"As is the case with most South Melbourne goals, they were the result of excellent teamwork. I was lucky to be the last man at the end of the line to apply the finishing touch." As the player of the week, Taliadoros receives a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280, as well as collecting votes towards the Golden Boot.

The end of season winner of the award receives $2000 from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award.

Round 17. Votes. Apia v Melb Cro: 2 Selemidis (mc), 2 Blagojevic (al), 1 Davidson (mc), 1 Hughes (al). Preston v Marconi: 2 Katholos (m), 2 Catlin (m), 1 Jackson (pm), Lowe (m). South Melb v Woll Mac: 3 Taliadoros (sm), 2 Tsolakis (sm), 1 Nastevski (wm).St Geo v Syd Oly: 2 O'Shea (stg), 2 Ilic (stg), 1 Edwards (so), 1 Meier (so). Sunshine v Melita: 2 Soper (me), 2 Genc (me), 1 Brown (me), 1 Nowicki (me). Syd Cro v Adelaide C: 2 Maxwell (ac), 2 T.Vidmar (ac), 1 Stanton (scr), 1 A.Vidmar (ac). Woll City v Heidelberg: 3 Cahout (wc), 2 Kuc (wc), 1 Scott (h).

Leaders: 17 Filan. 15 Petersen. 14 P.Okon. 13 Bundalo, Petkovic. 12 Stubbins. 11 Clarkson, Jackson, Kindtner, Lowe, McCulloch. Tsolakis, 10 Blagojevic, Nowicki, Spink. 9 Biskic, Durakovic, Gray, Ivanovic, Krslovic, Kuc, Phillips, A.Vidmar. T.Vidmar. P.Wilson.

END OF STORY

Herald Sun


March 14, 1991 Thursday


Davo opts to kick on


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 394 words


ALAN DAVIDSON'S return to international soccer may well be in jeopardy with his decision to postpone indefinitely the operation he needs to repair knee ligaments.

Davidson was told by Socceroo doctor Siri Kanangara to book in for the operation, but the utility has delayed it for several weeks to help out Melbourne Croatia. He has now decided to postpone surgery until the end of the season. 

"I've put it on hold and will get it done when I can (after the season)," he said yesterday. "We have had a lot of injuries and suspensions and I agreed to delay it.

"The club knows I could break down any time or, providing I'm lucky, I could go right through."

Davidson's operation will rule him out for up to five weeks and, if he was to have it immediately after the league campaign, it would virtually rule him out of international commitments.

He may delay it further but at this stage he doesn't want to think that far ahead. The media hailed Davidson's performance on the weekend as his best club game for several seasons.

His display in Melbourne Croatia's match at Olympic earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

The weekly winner receives a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280.

The end of season winner, based on the weekly votes, collects $2000 cash.

St George keeper John Filan remains the leader on 18 votes. Davidson has moved up to 12 votes.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award. Round 23. Votes: Adelaide v Heidelberg: 3 Veart (ac), 2 Brattan (h), 1 Herd (h). Melita v Marconi: 3 Cerro (me), 2 Gimenez (me), 1 Lowe (m). South Melb v Woll City: 3 Yankos (wc), 2 Durakovic (sm), 1 Blair (sm). Sunshine v Apia: 3 Mori (sgc), 2 M.Brown (al), 1 McQuarrie (al). Syd Cro v Preston: 3 Franken (scr), 2 Roodhouse (pm), 1 Traianedes (pm). Syd Oly v Melb Cro: 3 Davidson (mc), 2 Marth (mc), 1 Hannah (mc). Woll Mac v St Geo: 3 Koczka (stg), 2 Baillie (stg), 1 Martin Bourke (wm).

Leaders: 18 Filan. 17 Clarkson, Franken. 16 P.Okon. 15 Blagojevic, Petersen. 14 Durakovic, Ivanovic, Phillips.13 Bundalo, Gimenez, Kuc, Petkovic. 12 Biskic, Davidson, Katholos, Kindtner, Lowe, Stubbins. 11 Herd, Jackson, Kupresak, McCulloch, Spink, Tsolakis, 10 Catlin, Cerro, C.Foster, Marth, Nowicki, Soper, A.Vidmar, Wade, Yankos.

Player of the week. Rd 23: Alan Davidson (mc).

END OF STORY

The Washington Post


October 4, 1992, Sunday, Final Edition


AROUND THE NFL


From News Services


SECTION: SPORTS; PAGE D11


LENGTH: 344 words


ON THE OTHER FOOT: Deion Sanders's endorsement contract with Nike athletic shoes would drop sharply in value if the two-sport star decided to play only baseball or football, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.

The three-year deal signed this year gives Sanders about $ 1 million a year, provided he remains in both sports, according to an attorney who reviewed the deal for the newspaper.

Nike spokeswoman Lisa DeNeffe declined to comment on terms of the contract. Sanders's agent, Eugene Parker, could not be reached, the newspaper reported yesterday. 

If Sanders, who is an outfielder for the Braves and a cornerback for the Falcons, decided to play just one sport, the contract's value would drop to about $ 100,000, the Journal-Constitution said. Nike also has an option to drop the contract completely if Sanders chooses one sport.

Sanders appeared headed toward making a decision to play either baseball or football exclusively. However, he reached an agreement this summer to remain a part-timer with each team.

MOVES: The Broncos waived RB Jeff Alexander and signed LB John Sullins from the practice squad. ... The 49ers activated WR Ron Lewis and placed LB Mitch Donahue on IR.

NO DEFENSE: The only knock on the newest member of the Dolphins is that he's too small to play in the defensive line.

That's where Miami really needs help. But the Dolphins instead spiced up their offense this week by signing free agent TE Keith Jackson.

With Dan Marino, Richmond Webb and the three Marks -- Clayton, Duper and Higgs -- Miami already had one of the most potent offenses in the NFL.

"It seems like every year we load up on offense," Higgs said. "Hopefully we'll load up on defense like that one of these days."

Going into today's AFC East showdown at Buffalo, doubts persist as to whether the Dolphins can stop a good team. They ranked second-worst in the NFL last year in run defense. So why spend $ 6 million on Jackson?

"He's just a great football player," Marino said. "Any quarterback would want that addition to their offense."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

836 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


June 6, 1992, Saturday, City Edition


Sanchez Vicario wins 3 doubles matches


SOURCE: Compiled from Wire Reports


SECTION: SPORTS; FRENCH OPEN NOTEBOOK; Pg. 6C


LENGTH: 374 words


DATELINE: PARIS


 

Unfazed by her semifinal loss to Steffi Graf a day earlier, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario stormed back Friday to win three matches in one day at the French Open, one in women's doubles and two in mixed doubles.
 
    Today's schedule is almost as tough. She and Conchita Martinez are to play a women's semifinal in the early afternoon against Jana Novotna and Larisa Savchenko-Neiland. 
 
    Shortly afterward, Sanchez Vicario and Todd Woodbridge are to face Lori McNeil and Bryan Shelton in the mixed doubles final on center court.
 
    It's the second year in a row Sanchez Vicario has reached the  semifinals in three events.
Courier may have $ 24-million Nike deal

 
   Jim Courier reportedly has signed a six-year, $ 24-million clothing contract with Nike.
 
    Asked to confirm the deal, Courier's coach Jose Higueras said, "Well, if I were getting that much money, I'd wear anything."
 
    Higueras told reporters he didn't know about the contract, but he was wearing a Nike warmup suit.
 
    Courier has been under contract with the Italian clothing manufacturer Diadora.
Agassi's hats
hide balding head

 
   Andre Agassi wears caps, bandanas and other assorted headgear because he wants to hide his increasingly thinning hair, says the French sports daily L'Equipe.
 
    The paper reported Friday that Agassi doesn't take off his cap in the locker room and that his fellow pros tease him mercilessly.
Therapist helps French players

 
   Before losing to Petr Korda in Friday's semifinals, Henri Leconte seemed to be playing on a cloud. That's because he feels loved by the fans, said psychoanalyst Georges Ejzenberg, who has worked with many top French sports figures.
 
    Athletes call Ejzenberg a "motivational manager," who eases them  through winning and losing.
Making finals
satisfies hunger

 
   Jakob Hlasek was asked how it felt after he and fellow Swiss Marc Rosset reached the men's doubles final.
 
    Rosset: "This makes me very happy, even if you can't compare it to a Grand Slam singles final."
 
 

What does it compare to?
 
    "Well, let's say it's like a cheeseburger and fries."
