Times Publishing Company

 

839 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


November 28, 1992, Saturday, 1* EDITION


Paralysed driver barred from suing


BYLINE: LARRY STILL; VANSUN


SECTION: Pg. B3


LENGTH: 432 words


 

An impaired driver left paralysed by a highway crash after drinking beer supplied with dinner at his workplace has been barred from suing his employer for damages.

Michael Jacobsen, 19, claimed Nike Canada Ltd. breached its duty of care to him, an inexperienced drinker, when it provided him with alcohol as an incentive or reward to work overtime.

He said Nike, having allowed him to continue to consume alcohol after he became intoxicated, knew or ought to have known he was unable to drive his vehicle due to fatigue and alcohol consumption. 

Lawyers for Nike, citing a legal precedent that says no one can benefit from his or her own wrongdoing, argued in a pre-trial motion that Jacobsen's action should not be allowed to proceed.

B.C. Supreme Court Justice Richard Blair agreed, saying: "The conduct of the plaintiff (Jacobsen) is the type which society is trying to eradicate.

"The dangers of driving while impaired are great and devastating, particularly to the innocent users of the highway who have the misfortune to become involved in traffic accidents caused by persons who are driving while impaired.

"For this court to allow the plaintiff's claim to proceed would be to condone the actions of the plaintiff, who was clearly defying the law in driving while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol."

The court was told Jacobsen worked a 16-hour day on Sept. 6, 1991, part of it at B.C. Place Stadium, where he and other employees erected a trade show display for Nike.

When he finished work, Jacobsen was supplied with a dinner consisting of fried chicken and salad. A choice of beverages, including beer and soft drinks, was available.

Jacobsen consumed two bottles and four cans of beer supplied by Nike.

He then went with a co-worker to two nearby drinking establishments, where he drank another bottle of beer, part of a half pint of draft beer and a full pint of draft.

Driving home alone to Port Moody on the Trans Canada Highway at about 2:15 a.m., Jacobsen lost control of his vehicle, swerved across the nearside lane and crashed into a ditch. He was rendered a quadriplegic.

Expert evidence at the hearing indicated Jacobsen's blood-alcohol content at the time of the accident would have been between .17 and .20, substantially above the legal limit.

Blair, upholding the legal precedent cited by Nike, quoted an earlier judgment in which Justice Martin Taylor said: "It would be manifestly unacceptable to fair-minded, or right-thinking, people that a court should lend assistance to a plaintiff who has defied the law."


LOAD-DATE: November 29, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

842 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


October 10, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


New league out to motivate fans


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 522 words


The Greenville (S.C.) Spinners haven't played a game - or even finalized their roster.

But the Global Basketball Association team has a novel idea for sports teams looking for new revenues: Instead of just giving career counseling and motivational speeches to your players, make a business out of providing them to your fans.

By the time the GBA - a new pro league with 11 U.S. franchises - tips off in November, the Spinners hope to have signed up a number of local companies for motivational seminars. 

They won't be your typical corporate outings. Figuring there's a growing demand for corporate seminars that help develop teamwork and concern for quality, the club will work with a local technical college to provide motivational speakers and career and family counselors. After daytime seminars, workers will attend a Spinners game.

Spinners coach Joe Williams, who coached at Jacksonville, Furman and Florida State, says seminars will come with a range of options. Companies can opt to have their signs spread along the length of the court at the game that ends their motivational outing. Or let their key employee throw out the first ball at tipoff time.

But companies shouldn't get their hopes up too much. Seminar prices vary and are negotiable. But the Spinners top price, for their ''Grand Slam Outing,'' is close to what New York Knicks coach Pat Riley gets for a motivational speech: $ 15,000.

IT'S THE SHOES: Nike spent $ 178.8 million on advertising in 1990, says Advertising Age, which makes the shoemaker the USA's 58th-biggest advertiser. Last year, the trade magazine ranked it 99th.

But the Alliance for the Mentally Ill of New York State, an advocacy group, thinks Nike still has something to learn about marketing - at least about showing sensitivity to the mentally ill.

The group has criticized a Nike magazine ad, featuring San Francisco 49er Jerry Rice. Nike says the ad refers to Rice following the inspirations of his inner voice, with copy reading ''crazy people talk to themselves. And finally, you realize, only a madman doesn't listen.''

Nike says it won't drop the ad but will cancel billboards for cross- training shoes using athe tagline ''Multiple Personalities.''

CARD BEARER: Jack Nicklaus' Golden Bear International, along with Marine Midland Bank, is introducing a VISA affinity credit card. Along with various golf discounts, users get a Nicklaus golf tip on every monthly statement. ... Coming this Christmas: Cardboard cutouts of CNN sports anchors to help promote a sports video, part of a merchandising push that might result in watches and luggage with the cable network's logo. ... In its biggest promotion, Chrysler will team with K mart and CBS for promotions tied to the 1992 Winter Olympics. Chrysler, reportedly, will spend about $ 50 million for ads on CBS broadcasts. ... Changing times: A new $ 30 Cardillo Cross-Trainer spandex weightlifting belt hopes to compete with traditional leather belts made for heavy lifting. Also, Weslo Inc. of Logan, Utah, is introducing a home treadmill with a VCR hookup to show users Utah's red rock desert as they exercise.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SPORTS BUSINESS


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

845 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


December 28, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Remarkable ads sparkled


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 4B


LENGTH: 526 words


Reebok's heroes: Reebok's dueling-decathletes ad campaign hit its stride only when the athletes themselves faltered. When Dan O'Brienwashed out at the Olympic Trials, Reebok turned footage of his defeat - and rival Dave Johnson's sympathetic hug - into an ad that packed in as much drama as 16 days of the Games. Failure has never seemed so honorable. 

Agency: Chiat/Day/Mojo
 
 Nike's clowns: How could you go wrong with Michael Jordan and Bugs Bunny in one ad? They teamed up in this 60-second Super Bowl spot that ought to be running on the Cartoon Network - as programming. Bugs gets to run through his typical carrot-schtick, - including putting on a dress, - and Jordan does a good Porky Pig.

Agency: Wieden & Kennedy
 
Boomer humor: For those whose love beads have given way to love handles, Lee's funny ads for its Easy Riders made their point with a gentle poke rather than a pinch. In one, a jeans button pops and ricochets around the living room like a bullet in a Western. In another, a slightly smug shower singer goes from tenor to soprano when he zips his pants. The company's ads for women put female voices in men's mouths, without demeaning either sex. Not easy - and not very common.

Agency: Fallon McElligott
 
AT&T's split screen: Truly interesting long-distance company ads are rarer than a 10-cent pay phone. This one was visually glorious, -and bypassed the now-hackneyed special effect of transforming images on the screen, called morphing. Cliff Robertson was still droning away in the background about worldwide long-distance, but it was easy to get lost in admiring the smoothly flowing images and the ethereal soundtrack instead.

Agency: Young & Rubicam
 
Bud's fridge break: Amid all the sweaty hoopla of the summer Olympics, Budweiser rolled out an ad that relied on a clever idea instead of a celebrity endorsement. Babe-free, regular-Joe-free, the ad simply pictured a refrigerator and a caption telling viewers that, unlike other advertisers, Budweiser wouldn't mind if they skipped watching the commercial to grab a cold beer. Now that's a dry beer ad.

Agency: DMB&B

Planes, fashion and birds in best of rest
 
- United Airlines: ''Parrot'' - A Brazilian parrot pecks out the airline's theme song to push United's service to Rio. Not only can that bird play Gershwin, he can act.

- Saturn: ''Schoolteacher'' - The true story of a teacher who writes to the factory workers building her car. They tape her photo to the rearview mirror as the car goes down the assembly line. Sweet, not schmaltzy.

- US West: ''Voice messaging'' - Remember the geeky guy from Bud Dry's ''Why can't they love us for our minds'' ad? He redeemed himself here as a deadpan office assistant denying he broke the answering machine.

- Kmart: ''Fashion'' - Upscale women and sharp dialogue acknowledging Kmart and fashion aren't usually associated. If the clothes are as slick as the ads, they're the next Gap.

- Doritos: ''George Foreman I-V'' - Who taught those kids to act so cute? You did, Dad.

- Coca-Cola: New Times Square sign - a $ 3 million Broadway production. It was better than Cats.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO, color; PHOTOS, b/w (5)
 
CUTLINE: BUGS BUNNY: Takes it to the hoop with Michael Jordan in acclaimed Nike ad. CUTLINE: PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: AT&T's ad shows a London double-decker bus transform almost seamlessly into an Asian elephant. CUTLINE: REEBOK AD: Dave Johnson reacts as teammate Dan O'Brien fails to make U.S. Olympic Team. CUTLINE: THE FRIDGE: The ad Bud gave viewers permission to miss. CUTLINE: HOOPS AND HOCKS: Jordan and Porky Pig in Nike ad. CUTLINE: HIGH-SPEED PROJECTILE: In Lee ad, family escapes flying jeans button.


BEST AND WORST ADS OF 1992; See info box at end of text; The few, the proud, the ads you actually want to watch. Some you even want to see more than once. They're beautiful to look at, and they've got something to say. Here's a look at the best.

848 of 998 DOCUMENTS


South China Morning Post (Hong Kong)


September 24, 1992


Nike plan to shift China operations;
 Nike takes steps to shift part of production from mainland


BYLINE: By LOUISE LUCAS in Portland and CHRIS CHAPEL


SECTION: Business; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 719 words


SPORTS shoe giant Nike has drawn up plans to shift up to US$ 150 million worth of production out of China if the US acts on its Section 301 mainland hit list.

The multi-billion dollar group says it will be forced to raise the price of running and sports shoes by up to 15 per cent if the US refuses to back down on threats to double tariffs.

 Nike investor relations director Mr Ron Parham said: "We have put together very extensive contingency plans in the case of the sanctions being levied against China.

"We will shift products back to other bases. Every product built in China is also built in other countries, and it would take us only three to five months to fully transfer all our China volume into a variety of other countries." 

The US has imposed an October 10 deadline for the resolution of the acrimonious dispute over US access to the Chinese market.

 Nike has already mounted an intensive lobbying campaign in Congress to avoid the punitive measures, which it claims will damage the industry as a whole.

If no agreement is reached by midnight on October 10, the US will impose punitive tariffs of up to 100 per cent on up to $ 3.9 billion in annual Chinese exports to the US. China has said it has drawn up a list of its own covering a similar amount of US exports.

The National Retail Federation has told the Office of the US Trade Representative in the current public hearings in Washington that punitive tariffs against Chinese imports would strike a "severe blow to American consumers" and could cripple some retailers as they head into the Christmas season.

 Nike currently produces some 20 per cent of its shoes in China, representing about $ 300 million in turnover for fiscal 1993, shared among seven factories on the mainland.

Production vice-president Dave Taylor said: "In the first six months of this year over 40 per cent of all shoes imported into the US came from China, so if the Section 301 hit list is enacted there is serious, serious damage to the US retail industry. It's a huge deal.

"The idea behind 301 is to make it impossible to do business, so it punishes the importing country."

In Hongkong, a spokesman for Yue Yuen Holdings, one of Nike's main suppliers of Chinese-made shoes, said the threats applied mainly to domestic US consumption and were of no great concern to the company.

Yue Yuen executive director Steve Li I-nan said: "They are trying to convince the authorities not to act. We will take note of it for reference but they are being forced to say things to influence people in the US not to take action."

The US market accounted for about 69 per cent of Yue Yuen's turnover in the five months to February this year, but European sales had expanded strongly and were expected to increase as a proportion of total sales over the next few years, Mr Li said.

He added that Nike, one of Yue Yuen's four biggest customers, realised "China is the best place to make shoes" on a cost basis.

 Nike's Mr Taylor agreed, saying China offered "the lowest cost source; one of the best quality sources, and a huge labour pool".

According to Mr Parham, shifting production out of China to other Southeast Asian Markets would add around 10 to 15 per cent to manufacturing costs.

"To some extent shoes will become more expensive if the levies are enacted by Congress. Unfortunately that hits the consumer," he said.

 Nike and its competitors also face a squeeze from the other side of the Atlantic, with new EC quotas.

Mr Taylor said the EC-imposed quotas - originally scheduled to take place this year but postponed as member countries failed to agree on a package - had already prompted the company to adopt contingency plans.

"We have lobbyists in Europe monitoring the whole thing for us," he said. "We are using contingency plans right now, because some countries are not taking products in. France have got quotas, but we are working round them.

"It's a problem. We just need to know what the rules are to figure how we can work on them."

Europe is Nike's biggest market after the US. The group plans to do 50 per cent of total sales abroad by fiscal 1996.

It reckons the non-US market is worth between $ 8 billion and $ 10 billion, with around one-third coming from the Asia-Pacific region and half from Europe.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUB-TYPE: Newspaper


Copyright 1992 South China Morning Post Ltd.

 

850 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


January 16, 1992, Thursday, City Edition


Market hits new high


SECTION: BUSINESS; BUSINESS DIGEST; Pg. 1E


LENGTH: 549 words


 

MARKET HITS NEW HIGH. The stock market kept its recent rally rolling to new highs Wednesday, powered by mounting hopes for a sustained economic recovery. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 60.60 points on Tuesday, rose another 12.30 to 3,258.50. Volume on the Big Board came to an estimated 312.40 illion shares as of 4 p.m. EST, up from 264.55 illion on Tuesday. 
 Nation
Domestic production of oil falls sharply

 
   With oil companies focusing on foreign fields, U.S. crude oil production declined dramatically in the latter part of 1991, painting "a bleak picture" for domestic producers, industry officials said Wednesday.
 
    The American Petroleum Institute reported that domestic production dropped 2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1991 to the lowest fourth-quarter level in 30 years and continues to decline at an annual rate of 300,000 barrels a day.
 
    A year ago U.S. production had stabilized, said Edward Murphy, the institute's director of finance and statistics. But the decline resumed during 1991 when producers failed to get needed tax breaks and it became clear congressional efforts to enact a new energy plan would be unsuccessful, he said.

 
 BOOK CRITICAL OF NIKE. Steroid use by Nike-sponsored athletes and widespread under-the-table payments to amateur competitors are among the allegations in a book released this week that details the inner workings of the athletic shoe and apparel giant. Swoosh, The Story of Nike and the Men Who Played There was written by sisters Julie Strasser and Laurie Becklund. The authors write that competitors for Athletics West, the Nike-sponsored track club that operated from 1977-1985, used steroids and officials of the club were aware of the practice.
Tampa Bay/State

 
 WOLF BROTHERS CLOSING STORE. Wolf Brothers, an upscale clothing retailer founded in downtown Tampa 94 years ago, will close its location in the city's central business district on Friday, said Fred Wolf, the store's manager and a grandson of the founder. Wolf Brothers, owned by Chicago-based Hartmarx, was unable to renew its lease with the Lykes Co. that owns the old First National Bank building at Franklin and Madison streets. The retailer could not find another downtown location, Wolf said. He said the store's 15 employees either will retire or move to other Wolf Brothers locations.
Earnings

 
 WACHOVIA REPORTS LOSS. Wachovia Corp. reported a loss of $ 40.6-million, or 46 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1991, blaming the results on special charges arising from its merger with South Carolina National Corp. That compares with earnings of $ 84.4-million, or 98 cents a share, during the three months ended Dec. 31, 1990. For the full year, net income totaled $ 229.5-million, down 34 percent from $ 345.7-million in 1990. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., acquired South Carolina National on Dec. 6 in an $ 848-million stock swap, giving Wachovia combined assets of $ 33.1-billion.

853 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


March 14, 1991, Thursday, Final Edition


John Thompson's Nike Connection


Richard Cohen


SECTION: EDITORIAL; PAGE A25


LENGTH: 755 words


John Thompson, the renowned Georgetown University basketball coach, is good at what he does -- and that's not limited to coaching. He likes his players to be fine students as well as fine athletes, and in this and other ways he proves that he is a man of some values. One of them, unfortunately, is to sound like Adam Smith's parrot.

Capitalism, capitalism, Thompson squawks when asked about the $ 200,000 or so he gets annually from Nike shoes. In exchange, Thompson shoes his team in Nikes. He makes public appearances for the firm. He acts as one of their spokesmen, and he tried, without success, to broker a deal between Nike and Jesse Jackson over minority hiring and other such matters. Even Big John Thompson doesn't win them all. 

If patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel, then capitalism must run it a close second. It's often invoked as a lame excuse, an attempt to duck a moral argument by saying all ways of earning money are equal. But across town from Georgetown is the University of the District of Columbia. It's the city's public institution of higher learning, and many of its students are poor. On its basketball team is one Keith Goodie. He owns 56 pairs of sneakers.

Goodie is to sneakers what Imelda Marcos was to pumps. In his addiction, he is in no way typical, but he is representative. He told The Post he doesn't know anyone who doesn't own at least 25 pairs. To this, people in the sneaker business would only shrug their shoulders in cynical acknowledgment: What else is new? They know that athletic shoes make a major fashion and status statement in the inner city. Lots of poor kids have dozen of pairs, and they are the shoes of preference for drug dealers.

Jesse Jackson had his own differences with Nike. But when it comes to sneakers in general, what he says makes sense. These shoes, selling for as much as $ 135 a pair, are symbolic of an urge to showboat. They are worn by kids whose pride, whose entire self-esteem, is on their feet or on their backs. They spend recklessly because they think they have no future, and they have no future because, among other reasons, they have little self-discipline. Jackson to his credit says so.

It goes without saying that poor people have little money. But they often lack something else as well: a refusal to postpone gratification. Whether it's having a child when too young or squandering money on athletic shoes, this behavior is characteristic of the culture of poverty. So, too, in a way is basketball. It's a game of youth that promises an almost instant payoff for the extremely talented. But as a way out of poverty, it has the long odds of a lottery: just a handful win.

Thompson and the other coaches who have contracts with shoe firms surely understand the lure of basketball and the impact famous coaches have. But instead of acknowledging that their endorsements only reinforce a destructive mentality, they proclaim a mindless allegiance to the free-market system. "So all of a sudden it's a sin in this society for a person to be capitalistic?" Thompson said. "But as long as I live in America, that's exactly what I am going tobe."

Trouble is, Thompson's role as a capitalist is in direct conflict with his role as a mentor to young black athletes and, since basketball is king, to young black males in general. When his team takes the court with everyone wearing Nikes, not only do the people in the arena notice but so does everyone watching television. After all, Nike is paying him big bucks expecting a big payoff. Here is the ultimate in false values: a team wearing a certain shoe so that the coach can make a buck.

But what if Thompson allowed his players to wear any shoe they wanted? What if kids all over America could see that one sneaker is very little different from another and their obsession with name brands (at incredible profit margins) marks them as suckers? What if they gleaned the message that the shoes and their look didn't matter at all, but that performance was everything? Isn't that a lesson that transcends shoes?

Of all that ails the black underclass, a weakness for expensive sneakers is hardly the most serious. But as Jesse Jackson knows, it is representative of a larger problem, one personified by a college student who squanders his money on shoes -- making rich people even richer and himself a bit poorer. In this regard, John Thompson and other basketball coaches offer nothing in the way of rebuke. In perhaps the most important respect, the coach is not coaching.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: OPINION EDITORIAL


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

856 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


May 16, 1991, Thursday, Final Edition


John Carmody, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: STYLE; PAGE D6; THE TV COLUMN


LENGTH: 1558 words


C-SPAN will provide live coverage of Queen Elizabeth II's address to a joint meeting of Congress today, starting at 11:40 a.m... .

"Donahue" (Channel 9 at 9 a.m.) this morning asks, "Did Reagan and Bush Delay the Hostage Release to Win the (1980) Election?" Among the guests: Gary Sick, former National Security Council aide in the Carter administration ...

The Children's Television Workshop yesterday announced its "most exciting and innovative project since 'Sesame Street,' " an ambitious $ 20 million-a-year multimedia effort designed to help 7- to-10-year-olds understand what they read and to help them write clearly ...

Nike, the athletic footwear giant, will contribute $ 5 million, the largest single corporate grant ever made for a children's educational television project. CTW has also committed some $ 6 million of its own funds ...

Centerpiece of the project will be a weekly, half-hour action-adventure drama called "Ghostwriters," which is expected to premiere on PBS in the fall of 1992 ...

According to CTW president David Britt, "Ghostwriters" will feature "a gang of six youngsters -- including black, Latino, Asian as well as white -- plus an invisible seventh, a ghost" ...

The ghost, who is silent but whose words appear on the TV screen, will be the "motivator," explained Britt, "making the kids understand how important it is to express yourself well, to communicate, how reading and writing are relevant" ...

Britt expects that each program will also include a celebrity guest who will "read something" and "suggest a writing project -- maybe asking the kids to keep a diary for a week, things like that" ...

He predicted that " 'Ghostwriter' will capture the contemporary beat of MTV, the graphic look of print on screen, elements of the popular culture and a dramatic format to create the program and the excitement surrounding it" ...

Britt said current plans "hopefully" call for 48 new programs a year for three years, to be produced over perhaps a five-year period, and representing a potential outlay of some $ 60 million eventually ...

He said the bulk of the $ 20 million annual budget would be expended on a national campaign to reach children at home, in school and in community environments. Highlights of the campaign: 20 million copies of a mini-magazine to be distributed free in conjunction with the program; more than 200,000 copies of teachers' materials to be distributed through a variety of channels; a nationally syndicated weekly newspaper column; and two nationwide contests to be conducted during the show's first season ...

In addition to the funds provided by Nike and CTW, PBS is contributing $ 2.8 million; the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, $ 1 million; and the Mary Reynolds Babcock Foundation, $ 100,000 ...

Richard K. Donahue, president of Nike, said yesterday that his company's contribution is "a continuation of a lot of other things -- our participation in the Stay in School program last year, our work with the National Education Association. We saw it as an extremely high-quality opportunity that was difficult to pass up ...

"It is worthwhile making this kind of an investment because it lasts well beyond the period in which it's actually operating. The size of this project gives us a chance to focus on something that's needed -- and usually you can't identify the impact. We're very proud we can participate" ...

Now ThisAt the last minute, somebody up in New York forgot to tell him about the mandatory drug tests at ABC so it wasn't until yesterday -- a day late -- that ABC News could officially announce that Tom Bettag has been named executive producer of "Nightline" ...

By the afternoon, he was in Washington to introduce himself to the staff of 15 at the News bureau and discuss the night's program with anchor Ted Koppel ...

The former executive producer of "CBS Evening News With Dan Rather" is no stranger to Washington. He began his broadcasting career as an assignment editor at the CBS News Washington bureau 22 years ago ...

Bettag, 46, is only the fourth executive producer in the 11-year history of the very successful late-night show. Bill Lord, Rick Kaplan and Dorrance Smith preceded him ...

Bettag said an increased emphasis on investigative reporting can be expected. He said the program does so superbly during crises -- such as the Persian Gulf War -- that the trick will be to maintain that kind of momentum. "I think I've just got to remind them once in a while of just how good they are" ...

His predecessor, Smith, departed for the White House in March. Bettag said the fact that "Nightline" continued to operate without a glitch and without an executive producer for the next two months was another sign of "just how strong this program really is" ...

He will operate out of New York, where another 15-plus "Nightline" staffers work, at least for the time being. Manhattan-based ABC News president Roone Arledge likes to keep an eye on his executive producers ...

Bettag had been executive producer at "Evening News" for five years when he was replaced earlier this year by Erik Sorenson ...

Two more ABC notes: Arledge received an honorary doctorate in humane letters from Boston University this past weekend. According to BU President John Silber, Arledge's "programming innovations have transformed broadcast news reporting. You have increased the range of news coverage, developed new kinds of news programming such as 'Nightline' and dramatically increased the size of the television news audience. You are perhaps better known to the general public for your achievements in sports broadcasting, but we take particular note of your accomplishment in raising the industry standard for television news coverage; it is in this context that we propose to honor you" ...

And a video salute prepared by producer Rhonda Roberts and videotape editor Rick Watkins at the ABC News bureau here will be shown to guests tonight at the annual White House News Photographers Association dinner, which will be held at the Washington Hilton ...

The video uses footage shot at home and in the Middle East as a tribute to the men and women who served in the Persian Gulf War and the members of the media who covered it ...

The video is about eight minutes long and is set to the music of M.C. Hammer's "Can't Touch This" and Whitney Houston's version of "The Star-Spangled Banner" ...

The network premiere of " 'Crocodile' Dundee II" Tuesday night earned a 13.6 national Nielsen rating and a 23 percent audience share between 9 and 11 and enabled CBS to win the evening ...

Each national ratingzzzz point represents 931,000 TV homes ...

Over on ABC, the season finale of "Roseanne" averaged a 14.6/24, the penultimate episode of "STAT" did an 11.8/19 and an original "thirtysomething" -- during which Michael finally quit the agency!!! -- averaged a 9.4/16. If you're keeping track, the season finale (or worse!) of "thirtysomething" will be May 28 ...

On NBC, "Perry Mason: The Case of the Glass Coffin" averaged a 12.8/22. A very good "Shannon's Deal," which followed at 10, drew exactly the same number "thirtysomething" did for ABC. That is not good. Symmetrical, perhaps. But not good ...

"China Beach will fill that yawning "thirtysomething" slot next month, returning to temporary active duty after a fans' write-in protest campaign to ABC network officials ...

The Emmy-winning "China Beach" was suspended in December with seven episodes remaining to be aired. Those episodes will be shown on Tuesdays at 10 p.m. beginning June 4 ...

No word yet on the future of "CB." ABC is to announce its fall schedule next week ...

More HonorsChannel 9 was among the 24 winners of awards presented by Action for Children's Television (ACT) earlier this week at the National Press Club ...

Nine was the only network affiliate honored in the Commercial Television category. WUSA's "In Our Lives" series was tapped, said ACT, because of its "dramatic vignettes helping teens learn to cope" ...

The 10-year-old "In Our Lives" is the only regularly scheduled, locally produced TV show in this market that "provides a forum for teens to express their needs, problems and concerns," according to WUSA. Pauley Gwynn is host; Triona Mance-Lee, senior producer; Khalim Piankhi, executive producer; and Mike Mannarino, producer ...

Among the other honors distributed by ACT were two "stop, look & listen awards," which went to Turner Broadcasting System's "CNN Newsroom" for "delivering ad-free news daily to nearly 20,000 U.S. schools"; and ABC News for the special "War in the Gulf: Answering Children's Questions," cited as "a timely response to children's needs in a national crisis" ...

And a Washington production was among the winners of the 23rd annual Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards presented yesterday at a ceremony at the McLean home of Ethel Kennedy ...

The first prize in television went to a "Frontline" segment called "Throwaway People" that "examined how the once proud and successful black community of Shaw in Washington, D.C., has declined and become part of the black underclass" ...

Producer-director was Sherry Jones, whose Washington Media Associates has previously won two Du Pont/Columbia journalism awards. Roger Wilkins was correspondent and Foster Wiley was co-director ...


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: COLUMN


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

858 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 21, 1991, Thursday


Sporting goods firms expect OK year


BYLINE: By Jeffry Scott Staff writersports; equipment; industry; sales; economy; conditions


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION D; PAGE 07


LENGTH: 339 words


The sporting goods industry resembles Dominique Wilkins's missed slam-dunk in this year's NBA All-Star game: There's still plenty of spring in its legs, but maybe not what there used to be.

That was the message, in effect, that John D. Riddle, president of the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, deliverd to analysts Wednesday. They were gathered at the Georgia World Congress Center on the eve of the industry's annual Super Show mega-convention. 

Mr. Riddle said the $ 30 billion industry grew 6 percent last year - good, compared with the 2 percent overall growth of U.S. manufacturing, but sharply down from the double-digit growth in the 1980s.

"Manufacturers are prepared for a good, but by no means great, year," said Mr. Riddle, who attributed the slowdown to the recession and tight credit.

Sales growth this year will be driven by sports apparel and equipment for tennis, bowling and billiards, Mr. Riddle said, estimating 8 percent increases.

In previous years, athletic shoes put the bounce in the industry's step. But shoe sales may rise only 6 percent this year, he predicted.

Apparel sales, worth $ 13.6 billion, will eclipse total sales for all sporting equipment at $ 10.9 billion, he predicted.; Pumping it up

Athletic shoe manufacturers, meanwhile, have stepped up rivalries to increase their sales.

No. 2 Reebok three weeks ago launched its most agressive advertising effort yet, attacking No. 1 Nike with a $ 20 million campaign using the slogan "Pump up, and air out." Nike cried foul, claiming Reebok was abusing Nike endorsers by mentioning them in Reebok's ads.

Reebok Chairman Paul Fireman told analysts Wednesday the company plans to step up the attack, pumping an additional $ 15 million into its ad budget this year, for a total of $ 70 million.

Meanwhile, Reebok said it plans to buy up 21.3 percent of its outstanding common stock for $ 396 million. As part of the deal, Pentland Group PLC will reduce its stake in Reebok to 13 percent from 31.6 percent.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

862 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


July 31, 1992, Friday, 1* EDITION


COLUMN ONE


BYLINE: VANSUN


SECTION: SPORTS; COLUMN ONE; Pg. D1


LENGTH: 255 words


 

JUST when we thought the "Chicken Ryckman" saga had mercifully come to an end, we get a letter from B.C. Lions owner Murray Pezim.

"As you know," the letter begins, "I have recently been engaged in a war of words with (Calgary Stamps owner) Larry Ryckman about the Danny Barrett trade. In the heat of the moment, I referred to not only Larry Ryckman as a chicken but his father Claude as well.

"When I called Claude Ryckman a chicken, I meant it figuratively and I certainly didn't mean for anyone to take this literally. Mr. Ryckman is not a chicken, he is a hog farmer. I sincerely apologize to Claude Ryckman for any embarrassment I may have caused him by the fowl language."

We also received a copy of a letter sent to Pezim by Claude Ryckman, who asked that Pezim issue a retraction through the media. Contacted Thursday at his farm in Fort Assiniboine, Alta., Claude Ryckman said he hadn't yet received a copy of Pezim's letter and refused further comment.

We also promise to refuse further comment on this story.

JUST WEAR IT

What to wear? What to wear?

The U.S. Olympic Committee says it's got to be Reebok if the U.S. basketball team wins the gold and wants to attend the gold medal ceremony.

Charles Barkley, Michael Jordan and several other members of the U.S. basketball team under contract to Nike say that's a problem.

"Us Nike guys are loyal to Nike because they pay us a lot of money," Barkley said. "Nike pays us a ton of money. I have two-million reasons not to wear Reebok."


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

863 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Evening Standard (London)


June 24, 1992, Wednesday


£10BN BATTLE OF THE SPORTS SHOE STARS;
NIKE STILL LEADS THE FIELD BUT THERE ARE PLENTY OF OTHERS IN THE RUNNING AND THEY'RE HOT ON IT'S HEELS .SALLY WHITE GETS ON THE TRACKS OF THE FACTS


BYLINE: Sally White


SECTION: Pg. 34


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

ON WIMBLEDON'S elegant grass courts a grim multi-billion pound battle is being fought - but its takes a sharp eye to catch the action.

Slogging it out are the mega-stars of the sporting world - Nike, Reebok, Adidas, Asics, Puma and LA Gear. Nike is currently several sets ahead in the match for global market share. Wimbledon's cachet makes it the premier marketing event. 

The world sports shoe market is worth at least $ 18 billion (£10 million) in sales at wholesale level and tennis is probably 10% of that. Apparel sells for getting on for $ 30 billion and anything specifically tennis is hard to split out.

But the sports goods companies go for clothing because the brand names are easier to detect on TV screens.

Shoes are where the big money is made, however. Top-of-the-technology shoes cost at least $ 180 (£100) retail for those not lucky enough to be sponsored. Odds are those shoes left the factory gate in China, Taiwan or Indonesia for $ 18 - but there are lot of men in the middle including 10% for customs.

The US buys most, at around $ 6 billion wholesale, followed by Europe's $ 3 billion. Of that Britain takes $ 0.6 billion.

Rankings followed anxiously by the industry are those compiled by Pennsylvania-based John Horan's Sporting Goods Intelligence. He places Nike as number one seed with $ 2.3 billion sales of footwear, followed by Reebok with $ 1.8 billion. In the US Nike jumped from 28.6% to 29.8% in market share last year, while Reebok moved from 21.3% to 22.8%.

Tough marketing programmes run by these two are, according to John Horan, 'knocking the daylights out of Adidas'. Its clout has been shrinking.

Last year, says Horan, Adidas did well, gaining US market share, from 3.3% to 3.5% - although this was a slower rate of growth than the top two. Sales are now $ 1.1 billion.

This year Adidas, in the uncertain hands of French socialist millionaire Bernard Tapie, has been losing match points. With Tapie laden with debt, money for marketing seems to be missing.

'That is why everyone is waiting for Pentland to take all of Adidas,' says Horan, referring to market speculation that Pentland is just waiting in wings to add dramatically to its 20% stake with a bid for Tapie's 55% shareholding.

'That will really toughen the competition. At the moment it is all the smaller names that are benefiting from Adidas's struggles,' Horan adds.

Coming up are Puma, Keds, Ellesse, Fila and K-Swiss. Slipping down the league of smaller companies are LA Gear, New Balance, Etonic, Converse and British Knights and Pony.

But the scene has been changing rapidly this season.

Armed with £400 million from selling out of Reebok, Pentland boss Stephen Rubin has been able to pick and choose with whom he wants to do business.

The new alliances to watch are those with LA Gear (with whom Pentland does the sourcing and a 6% stake), and Ellesse (for whom Pentland sources all footwear). At the cheaper end of the market Pentland owns the Pony brand.

For the punters Nike has fallen from $ 77 this year to $ 56 on a profit warning. Reebok, too, has just issued a warning.

Pentland sold out at $ 26-5/8 - the price is now $ 22-5/8. It bought into LA Gear at $ 11, currently it is $ 13.

Pentland itself is still moving ahead - on hopes of a bargain bid for Adidas.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


PUB-TYPE: Paper


Copyright 1992 Associated Newspapers Ltd.

 

865 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Journal of Commerce


June 17, 1992, Wednesday


TRADE BRIEFS


BYLINE: From Wire and Staff Reports


SECTION: FOREIGN TRADE, Pg. 4A


LENGTH: 515 words


DATELINE: LONDON


 

MAJOR DENIES DECISION

BY UK TO BACK DELORS

The United Kingdom government has still not decided whether to back Jacques Delors for a second term as European Commission president, U.K. Prime Minister John Major said Tuesday.

Mr. Major denied newspaper reports the government had made a tacit agreement that Mr. Delors should be reappointed despite fierce opposition from many Conservative members of Parliament.

He confirmed that when the U.K. takes over the European Community's rotating presidency between July and December, it will promote an examination of the principle of "subsidiarity" - the idea that decisions in the EC should be made nationally or locally rather than at the EC center if this is more apt. 
 
CITIBANK BOMB THREATS

FUEL CONCERN IN TAIWAN

TAIPEI, Taiwan - Police searched Citibank's four Taiwan branches Tuesday in the latest in a series of bombings or threats involving U.S. companies and possibly related to trade tension with Washington.

Citibank's local headquarters received threatening telephone calls Saturday and again Monday, but a police search turned up nothing, a bank spokesman told The Journal of Commerce.

A series of explosions in several McDonald's restaurants in Taipei killed one person and injured four in late April. The bombings and subsequent threats to Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets forced both restaurants to close for several days.

The most recent threats may be related to anger over U.S. trade policy with Taiwan. Anti-American sentiment rose when the U.S. Trade Representative placed Taiwan on its priority watch list for inadequate protection of intellectual property rights.

Washington removed Taiwan from the list last month after Taipei agreed to U.S. demands to increase protection. Critics here assailed the government's move as a climb down, and several industries say they face ruin.
 
JAPANESE BEER, MADE

IN US, TO HIT MICH.

Ginjikomi, the new Japanese draft beer, will be available in Michigan by the end of the month. The beer, brewed by New York-based Sapporo USA, was introduced in the United States six months ago.
 
NIKE TO TAKE CONTROL

OF SWISS DISTRIBUTION

BEAVERTON, Ore. - NIKE Inc., the sports and fitness company, announced plans to add Switzerland to the list of countries where the company directly controls distribution rights to the NIKE brand.

NIKE, based here, will assume rights from the current independent distributor effective Jan. 1, 1993.

NIKE products have been sold in Switzerland since 1978 through Sevysa SA, an independent distributor based near Lausanne.
 
LIGHT-INDUSTRIAL PARK

SET FOR LHASA, TIBET
 
LHASA, Tibet - A small, light-industrial park, which will be open to overseas investors, is being constructed in Lhasa by the regional government and the Ministry of Light Industry, officials said.

Some 10 million yuan (US$ 1.8 million) will be spent this year on roads and water and electricity supply. Five factories to produce woolen carpets, packaging products, paper, plastics and beverages will be the first to be launched.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


EDITOR-NOTE: TRADE BRIEFS

867 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


January 3, 1991 Thursday


Reluctant hero gets points


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 474 words


ALAN Davidson is the first player to argue about being selected as the Herald-Sun Nike Air player-of-the-week.

His performance when Melbourne Croatia fought back from a goal down to beat Wollongong Macedonia 2-1 at the weekend earned rave reviews from the media and he was the automatic choice for the weekly award.

But the veteran Socceroo was reluctant to accept. 

"I felt I worked hard, but the game was marred by a strong wind and didn't lend itself to outstanding performances," he said.

"It was my first outing in midfield, but it turned into a game for defences having to cope with long balls. All we did in the middle of the park was battle."

Although the team won praise for its battling performance, new Melbourne Croatia coach Ken Worden was less than satisfied.

He says most of the players have to lift their game by 15 per cent.

Davidson was among those targeted. He was told he did an adequate job but more was expected of him because of his achievements and experience.

"He told me I've played at just about every level and expected more of me," Davidson said.

"If I accept the award, there'll be no end of ribbing in the dressing room this week." Worden might have been critical in the dressing room, but he agreed Davidson deserved the award.

"He was the orchestrator in a good team effort," Worden.

"He is not just a hard worker or marker, his experience and confidence and knowledge of the game allowed for a good steady job." As Davidson continues to produce on the field, he is already preparing for a post-playing career in the game.

He is doing coaching courses and enjoys being involved in the media with a column in the Sunday Sun.

"It has given me the chance to air my views, but it has also been a real education to find out how the press works," he said.

As the weekly winner, Davidson collects a pair of Nike Air runners valued at $280. He also collects votes towards the end of season award.

The season's winner collects $2000 from Nike.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot award.

Round 13 Votes: South Melb v Marconi: 3 Okon (m), 2 Petersen (sm), 1 Nastevski (m). Apia v Woll City: 2 Okon (al), 1 M.Brown (al), 1 Kuc (wc), 1 Bate (wc), 1 Hughes (al). Woll Mac v Melb Cro: 3 Davidson (mc), 2 Donnelly (mc), 1 Cavanah (wm). Adelaide C v Melita: 3 Cerro (me), 2 T.Vidmar (ac), 1 Callanan (me). Syd Oly v Preston: 3 Phillips (so), 2 Edwards (so), 1 Jackson (pm). Syd Cro v Heidelberg: 2 Herd (h), 2 Petkovic (scr), 1 Gibson (scr), 1 Rizopoulos (h). Sunshine v St Geo: 3 Clarkson (sgc), 2 Hasler (sgc), 1 O'Shea (stg).

Leaders: 17 Filan. 14 Petersen. 12 Petkovic. 11 Bundalo, Clarkson, Kindtner, P Okon, Stubbins.10 McCulloch. 9 Durakovic, Jackson, Krslovic, Lowe, Spink. 8 Blagojevic, Gimenez, Kuc, Tapai. 7 Davidson, C Foster, Ivanovic, McPherson, Yankos.

END OF STORY

870 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 9, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION


Black shoe sales lace up top spot


BYLINE: Mary McArdle


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 253 words


If it were up to him, Boston's Reggie Lewis would wear Celtic-green suede basketball sneakers on the court instead of black.

Then again, color is of little concern to the 6-7 swingman. 

''It's not the color of the shoe,'' says Lewis, who looks for comfort and fit, ''it's the individual that makes the shoe.''

If that individual is Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, then wearing black on the court has ramifications beyond basketball. It becomes a fashion statement.

Since Jordan and the Bulls started the trend three years ago in the playoffs, sales of black shoes have skyrocketed. Numerous college and high school teams wear them.

All the major companies - Nike, Reebok, Converse and adidas - report major increases in sales of black sneakers. At Nike, black shoes account for 75% of sales; at Converse, 60%.

''It's an all-time high,'' says Nike's Dusty Kidd.

Thirty of Converse's 54 models are offered in black, says spokesman Mickey Bell.

Black sneakers aren't limited to basketball. Even tennis, long stifled by ultraconservative dress codes, tolerates dark footwear on pros such as Andre Agassi.

Manufacturers have gone to great lengths to make black sneakers, long considered clunky-looking in basketball, sleeker.

''The thing that makes (today's black sneakers) look faster is the silhouette,'' says Kidd, adding that color accents and space-age designs make shoes appear ''more aggressive.''

Says Kidd: ''With some guys, they're so quick that no color is going to make them look slow.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w
 
CUTLINE: CLASSIC BLACK: Companies say sales are skyrocketing. Above, adidas' Streetball.


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

 

873 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 19, 1992, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


OUT THERE: CHICAGO;
Jock Citadel


BYLINE: By Marshall Sella


SECTION: Section 9; Page 3; Column 1; Styles of The Times


LENGTH: 969 words


IN the heart of Chicago's Michigan Avenue shopping district, the Nike Town building looks as tranquil as the Saks Fifth Avenue store it once housed.

Then you pass through the revolving doors. New Age music is playing, mixed with the tape-recorded clamor of playoff crowds. Banners hanging from the ceiling read: Performance, Technology, Innovation. 

And then, through a set of automated black doors (like any astronaut or aquanaut, one must enter this world gradually), you arrive in 68,000 square feet of museum exhibits, aquariums, video theaters and athletic photography. And half a basketball court.

This, you have to remind yourself, is a shoe store.

Nike Inc., the Beaverton, Ore., sport-shoe concern, can well afford its audacity. With annual revenues of $3.4 billion last year, the company has made its name with celebrity endorsements and irreverent ad campaigns. Three years ago, Nike executives decided to break from the company's history of modest retail outlets to gather all their wares under a single roof -- in effect, to jam every method of image enhancement into a box and see what happened.

The first experiment was a small-scale store in Portland, Ore., which opened in November 1990. The Chicago store, more than three times its size, is the concept's real test. It opened on July 2.

Walking along the manhole-dotted "streets" of Nike Town Chicago, you soon get lost between big design concepts and impressive details. Everything you see bears the mark of Nike's corporate mythology.

There are the Greek-style friezes of athletes in action on the facade, and life-size plaster statues of mountain bikers are suspended from wires in the three-story atrium. There are door handles in the shape of Nike's "swoosh" logo and museumlike placards that tell the legend of Bill Bowerman, a Nike founder. One day in 1971, so the story goes, Mr. Bowerman, a University of Oregon track coach, got it into his head during breakfast to pour latex into a waffle iron and thus discovered the waffle-soled shoe.

There's also the maple basketball court, where you can test sneakers (but not play ball) beneath a 35-foot picture of Michael Jordan and a quotation from William Blake.

Scattered around the entire store, in fact, are "inspiration boards" bearing abstract messages: "You get up in the morning, early. You think about your run. Anticipation is your first stretch. Then you go."

On the store's 12th day of operation, though, no one seemed to be doing much reading. There were shinier objects to examine, notably the nine-screen video floor in the aquatic apparel section, where crowds gathered to gaze down at a film of sharks, drifting seaweed and sand washing over conch shells.

"I am not sure I understand," said a Norwegian tourist. "Is this to be walked upon?"

A young salesman, Patrick Roach, stepped up to prove the floor's strength by holding an elderly woman's hand as she gingerly stepped onto the video sea. "You get the best effect if you're on top of it," Mr. Roach said, picking his way around customers who were trying on sandals. "It's really very safe."

While tourists stopped to pose with the octopuses in the video underfoot, Mr. Roach typed a stock number into a sober black computer terminal. Next to it stood a wide clear-plastic tube flooded with emerald-green light. Two minutes later, he opened the door of the tube and found a pair of sandals.

In Nike Town, you are never more than a few steps from these big tubes, which are actually miniature state-of-the-art elevator systems.. They run from every selling area to the stock area on the fourth floor, the functional heart of Nike Town. There, burly men sprint between shelves of orange and black boxes, pluck out the required shoes and feed them into the system.

"If those tubes remind you of 'The Jetsons,' it's no coincidence," said Gordon Thompson 3d, Nike's design director. "The transport system is actually a modified Spacely Sprockets idea."

Mr. Thompson's role in the project, he said, involved everything from devising floor layouts to color-coordinating the tropical fish in a 22-foot-long aquarium with the shoes that sit on the rack in front of it.

"My job is to be a sort of film director, and this store tells a story," he said. "It's a mythology, but one for a range of consumers, people who are 7, 27 and 67. What we've done is taken one theme, athletics, and pulled it in every conceivable direction. I like to think it's part 1939 World's Fair and part theater. But I guess the bottom line is, it's a store."

It's easy to lose sight of that fact. Still, to match the surfeit of design, there's a staggering amount of merchandise. There are all-condition jackets, Lycra shorts, beach shoes called aqua socks, running socks, trekking socks, cycling socks, aerobic socks, cross-training socks and every kind of sport shoe imaginable. Items are organized by sport so you can, for example, do all your tennis shopping in one feverish wave.

And how much did this store cost Nike? Executives declined to discuss the subject, commonly joking that it cost "more than Michael Jordan's championship ring," but one employee said the price tag was around $34 million.

In Nike Town's plush video theater, a few dozen people clustered to watch an endless loop of footwear commercials. Two young executives danced in the back of the room to John Lennon's "Instant Karma," but a Tulsa couple's eyes never left the screen.

Four towheaded children sat in a row on the floor. While two of them peeled off to buy posters of Andre Agassi, the two who remained cheered when a Spike Lee commercial for Nike came on. Then with the precision of a Gilbert and Sullivan patter song, they recited the words of the ad with Mr. Lee: "The mo' colors, the mo' better," they chanted. "Peace!"


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: At Nike Town Chicago, shoppers can test sneakers on a basketball court featuring a 35-foot photograph of Michael Jordan and a quotation from William Blake. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

876 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Sunday Mail (SA)


October 20, 1991 Sunday


Tipped to hit $400 mark MP calls for inquiry into shoe;
prices


LENGTH: 645 words


Sporting goods wholesalers and retailers have defended the

prices of recreation footwear despite some brands being tipped

to hit the $400 mark next year.

Liberal MP Dorothy Kotz claims the prices are an "exploitation

of the youth market".

But the Office of Fair Trading has said it has no control over

the multi-million-dollar industry.

The claims of exploitation come as the sports footwear war

intensifies between the two US-based giants Nike and Reebok,

Tipped to hit $400 mark

Three leading brands of sports shoes - Reebok (above), LA Gear

(below) and Puma (bottom) ... prices can vary as much as $40

from shop to shop, according to the Australian Consumers Association

which collectively account for $160 million in sporting gear

sales in Australia. 

The Office of Fair Trading said there was no price control

over sports footwear in a "free market where consumers can

shop around".

"Only if a situation arose where there was price-fixing by

agreement could any action be taken," an Office of Fair Trading

spokesman said.

Mrs Kotz said a Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry in to

the "exorbitant" price of sporting footwear should be launched

before prices went any higher.

"They have done it in the music industry in regard to tapes

and CDs and they should it with sports shoes," Mrs Kotz said.

Her complaints come as the recreation footwear pushes up through

the $300 mark with speculation a $400 pair of Nike shoes will

be released next year.

SA's leading sporting goods retailer, Rowe and Jarman, said

yesterday footwear now accounted for 50 per cent of its sales.

Store manager and ex-football star Paul Weston said the margin

on sporting footwear was "very small indeed."

He blamed government duty and quota charges on the high cost

of Reebok and Nike wear.

Top of the line Nike and Reebok sports shoes are between $179

and $280 a pair.

Both brands are made in Taiwan and Korea.

 Nike Australian distri- butor is John D Trading in Melbourne. Managing

director Mr

Tony Peddie said yesterday about 80 per cent was placed on the

cost of the shoes through government charges before they were

distributed to the retailer.

"There is a 100 per cent cost on the shoes by the time they

get to the stores," Mr Peddie said.

"That is due to $7 a pair in quota costs and 45 per cent in

duty. After that there is a freighting and administration costs."

'Monopolising

the market'

It was established yesterday a pair of Nikes in Britain costs

less than the wholesale price of a pair of the same shoes sold

in Australia. A pair of (original) Reebok sports shoes can be

bought in Seoul for $59 but will cost more than a $100 in Adelaide.

"This is the same situation we had in regard to taped and

CD music," Mrs Kotz said. "And the PSA looked in to that to

get the price down."

Mrs Kotz was highly critical of footwear companies targeting

youth "who already are under peer pressure to buy and wear

the best in sports shoes."

"They are being manipulated into buying high price products

with slick marketing and certain brands are monopolising the

market and pushing the prices higher." In a sampling taken yesterday at

three city stores Nike Air

Trainers were selling at $227, Reebok Court Victory Pump were

selling at $259, with Air Jordans - Nike's biggest seller -

on special at $199.

It was claimed by retailers profit margins were almost negligible.

However the Australian Consumers' Association in its running

shoes survey checked prices in all Australian capitals and found

variations, mark-downs and specials on both Nike and Reebok

to vary as much as $40 a pair.

"It is unilkely the retailers will sell these shoes at a loss

so there is a considerable mark-up," said ACA media spokesman

Mr Geoff Sirmai.


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: 3 photos: sport shoes; Three leading brands of sports shoes - Reebok (above), LAGear (below) and Puma (bottom) ... prices can vary as muchas $40 from shop to shop, according to the AustralianConsumers Association

880 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


September 17, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Hanson acquires construction group


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. B7


LENGTH: 689 words


 

Hanson PLC, Britain's largest industrial conglomerate, is buying British construction group Beazer PLC in a $ 609 million (U.S.) deal.

Hanson said yesterday it will offer $ 1.56 in cash and one new Hanson warrant for each Beazer ordinary share in Britain and $ 6.26 in cash and four Hanson warrants for each Beazer American Depositary Receipt. The ADRs represent four Beazer shares.

"Our long-term faith in the construction industry is bolstered by our belief that we have reached the bottom of its current cycle of recession, and we look forward to developing Beazer's well-established businesses alongside our own," Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson, said in a statement. 

Hanson, one of Britain's 10 biggest companies, is a trans-Atlantic conglomerate with interests ranging from Smith-Corona typewriters to Jacuzzi whirlpool baths.

Beazer is one of Britain's largest house builders, with interests in real estate development. The company also has interests in major building projects and open cast mining.

In the United States, Beazer is the largest producer of sand and gravel, with operations in hot mix asphalt, concrete products and ready-mixed concrete.

Nike sets record

Nike Inc., the worldwide athletic footwear and apparel maker, says its first-quarter profit of $ 114.4 million (U.S.) has set a world record in the sports and fitness industry.

It is the first time any company in the industry made more than $ 100 million in a single quarter, Nike executives said.

Chairman Phil Knight said in a news release, "We have built a global brand franchise and we believe that this quarter's results prove it is possible to be both the best and the biggest."

Earnings for the three months ended Aug. 31, which translated to $ 1.50 per share, were up 15 per cent from $ 99.6 million, or $ 1.31 per share, a year earlier, the Beaverton, Ore.-based company reported.

Nike's expansion in Europe led a 14 per cent growth in company revenues to a record $ 947.2 million from $ 833.6 million a year earlier.

Remarks hurt Ratners

Ratners Group PLC, owners in the United States of Kay and Sterling jewelry stores, has posted its first half-year loss in five years, blaming the poor results partly on disparaging comments made by the retailer's chairman about his company.

The company posted a pre-tax loss of $ 30.66 million (U.S.) in the six months ended Aug. 3, on sales of $ 780.7 million. That compares with profit of $ 16.1 million on sales of $ 642.4 million for the same period last year.

Chairman Gerald Ratner's widely publicized comment that some of his company's products were "crap" hurt his company's sales and its image in the marketplace, analysts said.

Delta deal cleared

The European Community's executive body has cleared Delta Air Lines' proposed takeover of Pan American World Airways' trans-Atlantic routes.

Under the deal, Atlanta-based Delta has proposed acquiring Pan Am assets that include routes between the United States and Europe and its hub in Frankfurt, Germany.

Pan Am, which is in bankruptcy court, hopes to sell the routes to get cash for creditors as part of a plan that would keep Pan Am alive as a smaller carrier based in Miami and focusing on Latin American routes.

The European Commission said it found that the asset sale would not create "a dominant position as a result of which effective competition would be significantly impeded in the common market or a substantial part of it."

Mercedes eyes Porsche

Mercedes-Benz AG chairman Werner Niefer says his company is "for now thinking about" taking a stake in German sportscar maker Porsche AG, but has not yet done so, an Austrian radio station official confirmed.

Niefer made the remark in response to a question by a reporter for the Austrian state radio, based in Vienna.

Porsche, a closely held German company based in Stuttgart, has said its group sales fell in the fiscal year ended July 31.

German media have circulated reports that potential partners, including Volkswagen AG and Mercedes-Benz, are prepared to buy stock in the company to help it overcome financial hurdles.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

881 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


September 17, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Hanson acquires construction group


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. B7


LENGTH: 696 words


 
   Hanson PLC, Britain's largest industrial conglomerate, is buying British construction group Beazer PLC in a $609 million (U.S.) deal.

Hanson said yesterday it will offer $1.56 in cash and one new Hanson warrant for each Beazer ordinary share in Britain and $6.26 in cash and four Hanson warrants for each Beazer American Depositary Receipt. The ADRs represent four Beazer shares.

"Our long-term faith in the construction industry is bolstered by our belief that we have reached the bottom of its current cycle of recession, and we look forward to developing Beazer's well-established businesses alongside our own," Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson, said in a statement. 

Hanson, one of Britain's 10 biggest companies, is a trans-Atlantic conglomerate with interests ranging from Smith-Corona typewriters to Jacuzzi whirlpool baths.

Beazer is one of Britain's largest house builders, with interests in real estate development. The company also has interests in major building projects and open cast mining.

In the United States, Beazer is the largest producer of sand and gravel, with operations in hot mix asphalt, concrete products and ready-mixed concrete.

It is the first time any company in the industry made more than $100 million in a single quarter, Nike executives said.

Nike's expansion in Europe led a 14 per cent growth in company revenues to a record $947.2 million from $833.6 million a year earlier.

Remarks hurt Ratners

Ratners Group PLC, owners in the United States of Kay and Sterling jewelry stores, has posted its first half-year loss in five years, blaming the poor results partly on disparaging comments made by the retailer's chairman about his company.

The company posted a pre-tax loss of $30.66 million (U.S.) in the six months ended Aug. 3, on sales of $780.7 million. That compares with profit of $16.1 million on sales of $642.4 million for the same period last year.

Chairman Gerald Ratner's widely publicized comment that some of his company's products were "crap" hurt his company's sales and its image in the marketplace, analysts said.

Delta deal cleared

The European Community's executive body has cleared Delta Air Lines' proposed takeover of Pan American World Airways' trans-Atlantic routes.

Under the deal, Atlanta-based Delta has proposed acquiring Pan Am assets that include routes between the United States and Europe and its hub in Frankfurt, Germany.

Pan Am, which is in bankruptcy court, hopes to sell the routes to get cash for creditors as part of a plan that would keep Pan Am alive as a smaller carrier based in Miami and focusing on Latin American routes.

The European Commission said it found that the asset sale would not create "a dominant position as a result of which effective competition would be significantly impeded in the common market or a substantial part of it."

Mercedes eyes Porsche

Mercedes-Benz AG chairman Werner Niefer says his company is "for now thinking about" taking a stake in German sportscar maker Porsche AG, but has not yet done so, an Austrian radio station official confirmed.

Niefer made the remark in response to a question by a reporter for the Austrian state radio, based in Vienna.

Porsche, a closely held German company based in Stuttgart, has said its group sales fell in the fiscal year ended July 31.

German media have circulated reports that potential partners, including Volkswagen AG and Mercedes-Benz, are prepared to buy stock in the company to help it overcome financial hurdles.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

884 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


May 27, 1991, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


DISTRICT WILL SEEK 48 TAX INCREASE


BYLINE: Linda Billingsly Post-Dispatch Special Correspondent


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 286 words


 

Voters in the Meramec Valley School District will be asked on June 4 to increase the district's tax rate by 48 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation. The money would be used for operating expenses and to pay for salary increases for teachers, said Superintendent Edward Hillhouse. The proposal needs a simple majority to pass. The district is mainly in eastern Franklin County, with small parts in St. Louis and Jefferson counties. The district's tax rate last year was $2.23. If passed, the increase would add $45.60 to the school tax bill of the owner of a house worth $50,000. Hillhouse said the increase is needed to hire two teachers at Coleman school and a part-time kindergarten teacher at Nike School. The district also wants to install a computer lab at Robertsville School and to buy new reading series for pupils in kindergarten through third grade. Hillhouse said the district is considering a bid of $69,000 for the series from Houghten and Mifflin Inc. Some of the money would be used for teacher salary increases. Teachers will not be getting a raise in the next school year, Hillhouse said. The district also wants to consider expanding counseling services, he said. Hillhouse said the district's last operating tax increase occurred 17 years ago. In that time, voters have approved two bond issues, one seven years ago for $3 million and the other three years ago for $3.1 million. Hillhouse said that money went to build Truman School and Nike School and for renovations at existing schools. Hillhouse said each school has been promoting the tax proposal. ''Everybody I've talked to has said they're with us,'' Hillhouse said. ''We've received no organized opposition.''


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

886 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)


January 25, 1991, Friday, DAILY EDITION


FITNESS IMPROVES FIRMS' FIGURES: Sponsorship ties products to health


BYLINE: Laura Fowlie


SECTION: SECTION 1, FOCUS ON EXECUTIVE FITNESS; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 718 words


Just like people, more companies are using physical fitness to stay in good shape.

The growing trend toward the sponsorship of fitness-related events points to a healthy desire by Canadian companies to raise their profiles among conscious consumers.

''The growth in sponsorship reflects a trend through the 1980s, when the public was becoming more aware of fitness,'' says Graham Fraser, owner of TriSport Promotions Inc. of Grimsby, Ont., a promoter of triathlon events across the country. ''Ten years ago, most of our sponsors wouldn't have talked to us. Now they like to sell the fact they're associated with a fitness-related event.'' 

In some cases, boosting exposure through spectator or participant sports is a natural.

Athletic-wear companies, such as Nike Inc., have developed multimillion-dollar advertising campaigns featuring professional athletes like football and baseball star Bo Jackson and basketball player Michael Jordan to win over aspiring athletes across the continent.

Regionally, smaller promotional events, such as community coaching clinics and local sporting events, bring the corporate message closer to consumers.

''The big, international sponsorships are well known, but we try to bring to make the brand more personal by sponsoring local events, too,'' says Roy Agostino, promotions co-ordinator for Nike Canada Ltd.'s Eastern region.

''This is the bread-and-butter of our business,'' says Murray Souter, vice-president of marketing at Toronto-based Reebok Canada, a division of Avrecan International Inc. ''It's much like automakers sponsoring pro car racing - we need to be involved.''

For such companies, athletic sponsorships take on a practical quality. By providing top-flight athletes with their product, the shoe companies get wear-testing data and free expert design input in return.

But for others, the connection isn't so apparent.

In 1990, for example, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd. spent more than $500,000 on sponsorship of a nationwide triathlon series in conjunction with Reebok, Toshiba and other sponsors, and plans to continue its association with the sport for another three years.

COMMON THEME

Moncton-based Cavendish Farms sponsors a junior ski-racing program at selected resorts across the country; McKenzie Financial Corp. in Toronto does the same at Ontario resorts.

And Crown Life Insurance Co. sponsors the Participaction Challenge, in which more than four million Canadians register 15 minutes of physical activity on a specified date each year.

Emphasizing their commitment to local communities is a common theme among corporate sponsors.

''As an insurance company, we like people to be well,'' says Barry Francis, assistant vice-president of corporate communications at Crown Life, which spends about $500,000 on the event annually. ''But it's also a great way to enhance the image of the company. Our representatives get a higher profile in the communities where they live and work.''

While the public-relations aspect of promoting a healthy clientele can'tbe underestimated, few sponsors would deny that they're cashing in on the high-profile nature of sports. In most cases, decision-makers look for well-advertised events with high attendance figures to get the most bang for their buck.

NOTHING IN STONE

And when considering a fitness-related sponsorship, few firms will take the initiative and organize an event on their own. In most cases, the sport's national association, or a promotional company like TriSport, takes care of the organization, advertising, and promotion, while the company provides the funding.

Though companies will often maintain an association with a particular event for several years, the value of their commitment is rarely written in stone, Fraser says. Given the current recession, therefore, some athletic events may see the level of sponsorship drop considerably over the next year.

''One of the first things to go when times get tough is usually discretionary spending, and sponsorship often fits into that category,'' Fraser points out. ''Some companies may find it hard to justify spending a lot of money on sponsorship, but they'll still want the exposure. It'll be a tough time for anyone just getting into the game.''


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

October 14, 1991


Robert Van Kampen closes deal for unit trust firm


BYLINE: Hal Lux


SECTION: FIRMS & EXCHANGES; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 200 words


Robert Van Kampen returned to the securities business two weeks ago with the purchase of the unit investment trust operation of Clayton Brown & Associates. Van Kampen, who built one of the top unit trust businesses at Van Kampen Merritt, is expected to quickly add other product lines to his new firm, Nike Securities. 

Van Kampen confirmed last month that he was holding advanced talks on the acquisition of the First Trust funds with his former partner, Clayton Brown (IDD 9/2).

In a written statement, Nike Securities said almost all Clayton Brown employees in that division would be moving over to Nike. James Bowen, head of Clayton Brown's unit investment trust business, will continue to run the group for Nike.

Clayton Brown has sponsored over $ 6 billion in First Trust funds, but that market share has slipped in recent years. Industry officials said Robert Van Kampen's extensive distribution contacts with regional broker-dealers will be the key to growing the business.

The purchase puts Mr. Van Kampen into direct competition with the firm that still bears hits name, Van Kampen Merritt. If the competition does heat up, both firms will be able to keep an eye on each other.

889 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


November 10, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Now Barbie has her own store


BYLINE: Ellen Neuborne


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 327 words


DATELINE: NEW YORK


Barbie heaven's come to Madison Avenue.

An all-Barbie shop, opening here today at FAO Schwarz, is the largest collection of Barbie-o-rama under one roof. The boutique packs 1,500 square feet of everything Barbie: dolls, doll outfits, children's clothes, books, pencils, backpacks, cosmetics, etc. 

Barbie on Madison is the latest in a string of one-brand retail stores, known in the trade as designer stores. Some are company-owned. Some have a retailing partner. Barbie on Madison is owned and operated by FAO Schwarz.

''Barbie has reached classic status,'' says Donna Gibbs of Mattel, maker of Barbie. ''One of the keys to Barbie's success has been the expansion beyond just dolls. We want to show just how much there is to Barbie.''
 
Other designer stores:

- Nike Town. Nike's second store opened this summer in Chicago. Inside: gear for 20 sports. ''The Chicago store, which is 60,000 square feet, lets us show our entire collection. No retail store has the space to do that,'' says Melinda Gable of Nike. Store No. 3 opens next year in Costa Mesa, Calif.

- Sony Gallery of Consumer Electronics. Sony's three-story museum like store in Chicago once housed a Saks Fifth Avenue department store. Now it's nothing but Sony. ''This store is almost educational. We want consumers to come in, see all that there is and walk away picturing it in their homes, their cars, their offices,'' says spokesman Rick Clancy.

- Levi's. Dropped by Gap stores last year, Levi's has been testing three of its own stores. Two more open this winter in New York and in the Mall of America in Minneapolis.

What's next? Any hot brand is a candidate, says Michael Gade, consultant at Coopers & Lybrand: ''Lego might be a good choice. Or Batman. Or maybe Dracula will turn into something big. If you have a strong brand, you can use a retail store to create more excitement. Seeing all the products displayed in one store can get a customer to say 'Wow.' ''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CUTLINE: BARBIES: Madison Ave., left, Empress Bride, Neptune's Fantasy.
