893 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 7, 1992, Friday, Late Edition - Final


BASKETBALL;
The Word From the Goat Park Legend: 'I'm Not into the Dream Team'


BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE


SECTION: Section B; Page 16; Column 1; Sports Desk


LENGTH: 838 words


Up in Goat Park, the legend picks glass off the concrete, chides a grown man for urinating against the fence, listens solemnly to an invitation to come to the Columbia University gym tonight and pick up an award.

"What for?" 

"You're a legend," says an older man. "We call it the Golden Hoops First Playground Legend Award."

"Who's the second?"

"That's next year, be somebody else."

The legend, Earl (the Goat) Manigault, sighs. He's 47 years old, broke and dying. He needs money for his tournament and a heart transplant for himself. He watches a covey of teen-age Michael Jordan clones, shaven heads, baggy shorts, Nike shoes, pad onto his court.

"You should ask Michael for money," I say.

"Ask him to look at my tape, read my proposal and help me," says Manigault. His eyes poke into distant corners of his park. "We're helping him, all these bald heads and Nikes. Look at me." He points down at his white Nikes. "Was looking for Converse, but all's I could find around here size 13."

"So, you gonna be there?" asks the Golden Hoops man.

Manigault shrugs. A second team of Michael clones arrives to play the first. The courts, officially in the Happy Warrior Park, are off Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan, between 98th and 99th streets, nestled among apartment buildings packed with players. This has been Goat Park since the early 1970's, when Manigault began his youth tournaments, first hustling drug dealers for shirts, trophies and referees, later soliciting foundation grants.

This year's tournament, 13 teams, something more than 100 youngsters, is one of the smallest because it began late, and tentatively; it seemed unlikely that Manigault, his heart irrevocably damaged by drugs, alcohol, street living, jail, would see summer. Last winter, after the Columbia-Presbyterian Transplant Unit rejected him as a poor medical and social risk, Manigault was weak and barely coherent. It seemed as though only the legend was left.

Uptown, it is still a powerful legend of a teen-age prodigy who could pick dimes off a backboard, who dunked over Kareem when Kareem was still Lew Alcindor; a 6-foot-1-inch guard who could control anything on the court and nothing off it. He didn't stay in college and he didn't make the pros. He became famous for failure, an easy metaphor for the dark side of the city game, where the best are often the most self-destructive.

"I'm not into the Dream Team," says Manigault. "It's not right. Should be amateur. I could pull one or two players off every block around here, go to the Olympics and win a gold medal."

"That's the urban myth," I say.

"That's the word," says Manigault.

He moves off to get the first game started and disappears into the late afternoon swirl of Goat Park, 12-year-old fans, old men, babies, winos, players, hustlers, a pulse that helped bring him back to life.

He has also had remarkable friends. A Princeton professor, Stephen F. Cohen, has been a fierce lobbyist for more than 20 years, and the foundation head, Walter Naegle, has fed and housed him. They found the city apartment he now shares with his two grown sons.

A young cardiology fellow at Bellevue, Dr. Mimi Guarneri, "tuned up" Manigault this year. He is now being seriously considered for a heart by the transplant unit at Mount Sinai, he says.

"This is his challenge now," says Ray Diaz, a 29-year-old record company executive who learned the game as a youngster in this tournament. "It's his second life. The future is not about keeping up the legend but about helping the kids."

The Golden Hoops man is getting impatient: "You gonna be there?"

"This is what he has to deal with all the time," says Diaz, who starred in high school, college, and the Puerto Rican pro leagues. He has his own tournament now. "How does one be a legend? He's worth a million dollars and he doesn't have a dime."

Manigault nods to the Golden Hoops man. He'll be there, he says. He turns back to the game to watch its star, Patrice Casimer of the nearby Franciscan Community Youth Center, a compact point guard with presence. Patrice is going into his senior year at Cardinal Hayes High School. He is being recruited by colleges and drug dealers.

"We're working on Patrice's game and head," says Alex Achille, the center's director and a former Goat tournament player. "A lot of drug dealers want him to play on their teams."

"Why is that bad?" I ask.

"What's the point of all this," says Achille, "if a 10-year-old kid is looking up to a dealer?"

Manigault drifts by. "The dealers I came up with are all dead or doing big time," he says. "I don't know these new kids."

"You wouldn't take their money?" I ask.

"I said I didn't know them; I didn't say I woudn't take their money." He smiles slyly. "I just wouldn't go ask 'em."

"Money from Michael is our next big move," says Diaz. "Spike Lee will get us to Michael, who's got to be thinking movies next, right? He needs that first credible role. We got the script. Who else should play Earl, but Michael, right?"

The legend nods.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

895 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


February 3, 1992 Monday


NEW RULES FOR JORDAN


BYLINE: RUCCI M


LENGTH: 372 words


IT IS understandable that Michael Jordan, the most identifiable man in American sport, would find it a little disconcerting to see his face slapped on the chest of almost every man, mother and child in the US.

So the emperor of US professional basketball has issued a new edict about clothing.

From March 31, no one, absolutely no one, will be able to put Jordan's face or name on any form of souvenir unless it is Nike, the world's largest manufacturer of sporting apparel. 

Not even the NBA, which will be restricted to selling Jordan's No.23 Chicago Bulls shirt because team uniforms are the property of the NBA and not the individual player.

It is not surprising that Jordan has finally called an end to the liberal use of his image and name which left Chicago in a sea of Jordan T-shirts after their title victory last year.

And if the personal reasons are not enough, the financial ones are certainly worth considering.

Jordan makes a mere $4.22 million from playing basketball. He collects more than $30 milllion selling a variety of products ranging from Wheaties, Hanes underwear to McDonald's food, Gatorade and the Illinois state lottery.

 Nike last year sold more than $300 million in goods featuring Jordan and will make a great deal more after March 31.

Now at the NBA, there are mutters of discontent. They say he has now "effectively separated" himself from the league, making himself bigger than the game.

Unlike the other US professional sports - ice hockey, football and baseball - the NBA does not give a player a percentage of the profits made from souvenirs.

The NBA made $90 million in profits from souvenirs last season and returned the favor by handing just $A680,000 to the player pension fund.

But Nike makes a financial promise to Jordan.

"Every piece we sell," says Nike president Dick Donahue, "Jordan gets a piece of.

"This is not a Jordan issue; it's a persona issue."

NBA lawyer Gary Bettman says: "I suppose we'll feel an economic impact from this." "Our primary business is the sale of uniforms," he said. "And our best seller has been and will continue to be the Bulls jersey with (Jordan's) No. 23 on it." - MICHELANGELO RUCCI

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Deadline . . . Micheal Jordan and Nike are tightening their grip onthe star's line of clothing.

USA TODAY


December 18, 1992, Friday, FINAL EDITION


TIME TO GO


BYLINE: Jack Carey


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 339 words


Bob Devaney, one of the most recognized figures at the University of Nebraska since his arrival as football coach in 1962, says he is bitter with the manner in which he was led to retirement after 31 years of service to the state. Devaney, who will step down Jan. 5 as athletic director, said he also feels bitter about the manner in which his replacement, Bill Byrne, was selected. ''I was hoping I could work a little longer,'' Devaney said. 
 
 GOOD NEWS: Jockey Kent Desormeaux was released from Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif., Wednesday - five days after sustaining several small skull fractures in a fall at Hollywood Park. After his release, Desormeaux headed to Arcadia Methodist Hospital, where his wife, Sonya, gave birth to the couple's first child, 4-pound, 1-ounce Joshua Jason. Desormeaux could be back riding in 4-6 weeks.
 
SHOE WARS: A patent infringement lawsuit has been settled by Nike Inc. and Avia Group International, the shoe makers announced Thursday. Avia filed the lawsuit in 1991, charging that Nike's ''Air 180'' and ''Air Force 180'' running and basketball shoes infringed on Avia patents. Nike responded that one of its patents was infringed by several Avia athletic shoes. Neither company would discuss terms of the settlement.
 
GREEN FEES: Charitable contributions from the PGA Tour, Senior PGA Tour and Ben Hogan Tour reached a record $ 29 million this year, it was announced Thursday by the PGA Tour.
 
DOWN UNDER: Three Australians led the way Thursday in the first round of the $ 2.7 million World Championship of golf at Montego Bay, Jamaica. Craig Parry shot 2-under-par 68 for the lead. Greg Norman and Peter O'Malley shared second at 71.
 
DURAN WINS: Four-time world champion Roberto Duran (87-9) stopped journeyman Ken Hulsey (16-8) with a hard left to the ribs Thursday in the second round of a scheduled 10-round middleweight fight in Cleveland.
 
BOUNCED: From Vermont to Nevada, college basketball underwent changes in 1992.

901 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


June 24, 1992, Wednesday, City Edition


Imprint on victim's throat linked to shoe


BYLINE: ELIZABETH CLARKE


SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; Pg. 8B


LENGTH: 328 words


DATELINE: GAINESVILLE


 

A Nike tennis shoe found in a garbage can days after the slayings of two University of Florida students could have made the imprints found on one victim's neck, an expert witness testified Tuesday.
 
    The marks left on the neck of Eleanor Anne Grace, 20, indicate the shoe was repositioned at least once, said Florida Department of Law Enforcement crime lab analyst supervisor Ernest Hamm.
 
    Carpet cleaner Alan Robert Davis, charged with killing Grace and her roommate Carla Marie McKishnie, 22, last June in their Casablanca West apartment, told investigators less than 48 hours after the killings that he knocked Grace unconscious after she sprayed him with Mace. 
 
    He said he strangled McKishnie before returning to Grace, who was found on the floor of an upstairs bathroom. McKishnie's body was found under a bed.
 
    Dollar General cashier Debbie Hutchins said the Nike shoes seemed to be the ones she put in a bag for Davis, 30, after he bought a new pair of shoes June 6, 1991, the day the women were killed.
 
    "He had the new shoes on. He had the old shoes in his hand," Hutchins said. "He asked me if I would put the shoes in a bag."
 
    Alachua County sheriff's detective Robert Gaff said he and another detective retrieved those shoes from a garbage can outside the Dollar General on June 9, 1991.
 
    Hamm, the crime lab analyst, said that although the Nike shoes could have made the marks, he couldn't guarantee the imprints came from that shoe.
 
    Hamm told Circuit Judge Robert P. Cates that three fingerprints found in the bathroom sink match Davis' fingerprints and a palm print from the counter around the sink matched Davis' right palm print.
 
    Assistant State Attorney Ralph Grabel said Davis' confession, along with testimony from the medical examiner who performed the autopsies, will be introduced as evidence today. He expects to complete his case today.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


DISTRIBUTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE


Times Publishing Company

 

902 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


July 14, 1991, SUNDAY, THREE STAR Edition


BO'S LATEST NIKE COMMERCIAL DELIVERS A MIXED MESSAGE


BYLINE: Bill Modoono Scripps Howard News Service


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 4F


LENGTH: 475 words


 

Random observations from the wide, wide world of television sports: - Bo Jackson came through a television the other night. Walked right through the sucker in an effort to express his utter disgust with the medium, one supposes. Of course, it wasn't real. It was merely another in a seemingly endless series of clever (and somewhat disturbing) Nike television commercials. Do we know Bo in any other way? Anyway, in this one Jackson spoofs his image (created in previous commercials, naturally) that he can do anything. In the middle of the spot, Bo walks off a lavish stage set, complete with musicians and beautiful back-up singers. He walks right through a TV set into a living room, where he chides a little boy who is sitting there for watching too much television. He then heads to a gym where he is shown going about the difficult business of rehabilitating his career. The career that exists outside of commercials, that is. The message, presumably, is that what Bo is really all about is hard work and sweat, which is not exactly what Nike was saying in its earlier ''Bo knows'' commercials. No, those implied that everything from hockey to rocket science came naturally to this wondrous athlete. This time, there's work involved and since the product being advertised is something worn in weight rooms and gymnasiums, it makes sense to finally put Jackson in such a setting. The message about hard work was equally welcome and Tuesday's All-Star game was a great place for the spot to make its debut. But let's pause here for a healthy dose of cynicism. Bo Jackson chastising a kid for watching too much television? Bo Jackson telling us that image is not everything? Who's kidding who? Not that it is Jackson's fault, but no athlete has been dominated by his TV image more than Jackson. Jackson's pro sports career, as spectacular as it was in brief spurts, could not compete with Jackson's TV image. Most athletes need to be at or near the top of their games to sustain a career in commercial endorsements. All Jackson had to do w as be Bo. This advertisement is proof of that. Jackson has yet to play an inning - and may never play an inning - in a Chicago White Sox uniform, and yet his Sox uniform (stylishly black, of course) is featured prominently in this advertisement. Bo does not have any White Sox RBIs, but he does have a White Sox image. Thanks to Nike. Of course, image is what Nike is selling, every bit as much as sneakers. Images perpetrated by TV commercials. Images consumed willingly by little kids (and big ones, too) who watch too much TV. Should we listen to Bo and not watch so much TV and go out and ''just do it''? Or, should we just sit back and be overwhelmed by the amazing and attractive image of Bo? Nike is telling us to do the former while cleverly enticing us to do the latter.


LOAD-DATE: October 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

904 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


June 20, 1992


EXTRA TIME: SIXTH COLUMN


BYLINE: EDITED BY JEREMY ALEXANDER, MATTHEW ENGEL, NEIL ROBINSON


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 622 words


 

THERE are two works on tennis at the Royal Academy's Summer Exhibition. Turbo Tennis is a bronze girl with pigtails, racket and roller-skates. The other is a naive painting called Centre Court which bears no relation to Wimbledon.

The same hand is responsible for the only rugby offering, World Cup Final, which has no sense of occasion or Twickenham - making two impostors, treated just the same. Perhaps the Kipling quote, reproduced at the entrance to the Centre Court, went to the artist's head. 

The exhibition also includes three works on football, two on cricket, one each on boxing and the London Marathon and, in the architectural section, the National Hockey Stadium at Milton Keynes. And that is all.

It is uncertain which is more naive, the work or the hanging committee. But, when it comes to hanging, the committee is more deserving. There should be no surprise that sport is ill-represented. So is art. This is evidently the age of infant daub and abstract artifice.

Yet Britain has a noble heritage in sporting art and now a minister of both and more. If the Summer Exhibition has sunk beyond the pale, where junk enough is hung in Piccadilly on Sundays, David Mellor has a clear opportunity to relax the tug-of-war between grant-seeking factions by setting up an exhibition of sporting art. He has only himself to persuade.

SPAIN's peculiar trademark law is threatening to put a sock in Nike's sponsorship of the United States Olympic track and field team. An attorney owns the Nike name in Spain, registered 60 years ago by a Barcelona sock maker. Without his permission - and he shows no hurry to grant it for nothing - athletes cannot use the name. Nike (US) talk of "trademark piracy".

Spanish laws used to permit anyone to register and renew a name simply by paying a fee, even without ever producing anything. Though the statutes were changed in 1988, registrants still do not have to prove they have an on-going business or product when filing an application. If the brand is not used in five years, a challenger must sue the trademark's owner, who then has three months to begin using the mark.

In July 1990 Nike (US) were issued a registration for their name but two Spanish courts have since upheld the earlier trademark. Though this applies only to sports apparel, not shoes, Nike (US) put potential sales losses at pounds 11 1/2 million in Spain and many times that worldwide. It does not help that their adversary is called Amigo.

THERE may be something in rainbow sunglasses after all. Judging by appearances they fail wretchedly. But Richard Blakey, the first wicketkeeper to follow the fashion, is guarding against further migraine attacks. Several times previously he had been forced from the field. With the glasses he has had no trouble.

On the other hand Martin McCague of Kent, trying them at Canterbury, failed to see the benefits or, apparently, the ball. After two misfields and the fumble of a simple catch, he sheepishly handed the things to the umpire John Holder.

GOAL celebrations know no bounds in Brazil. After scoring the winner for Botafogo against Cruzeiro at the Maracana stadium Carlos Alberto Dias jumped on to a telephone booth behind goal, where he was mobbed by team-mates. The referee was not amused. He took Diaz's name, not to mention address and 'phone number.

PRISONERS at Spain's Ocana jail near Toledo have been getting into the Olympic spirit by staging their own games. Nine nationalities are represented although Spain, with the largest team, are favourites to top the medals table.

A prison official said that "sports incompatible with an enclosed area" were not in the programme. There is no pole vault.


LOAD-DATE: May 7, 1993


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Guardian Newspapers Limited

 

908 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


February 2, 1992, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


They Just Did It


BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques;  Diana B. Henriques, a financial reporter at The New York Times, is the author of "The Machinery of Greed: Public Authority Abuse and What to Do About It."


SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk


LENGTH: 1146 words



SWOOSH
The Unauthorized Story of Nike
and the Men Who Played There.
By J. B. Strasser and Laurie Becklund.
Illustrated. 682 pp. New York:
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95. 

ONCE upon a time, people did not jog. The very notion of lacing up hideously expensive sneakers to trot along the roadside at a sweat-breaking pace would simply never have occurred to the ordinary person.

There were sports shoes, of course, manufactured by a handful of low-profile companies catering to professional and amateur athletes who ran track or played team sports. But for typical middle-class Americans, a complete sports-shoe wardrobe comprised a pair of tennis shoes, some golf shoes with parquet-marring cleats, and a pair of high-top sneakers for shooting baskets with the guys.

Then, in the mid-1960's, something happened. Almost overnight, the loneliness of the long-distance runner was invaded by hordes of health-conscious converts to the runner's religion. Fad became frenzy: if you weren't jogging, you should have been jogging. And for the shoe business, the world turned upside down.

Suddenly the sports footwear market became an arena worth fighting for. And fight the shoemakers did -- across national borders, with shifting alliances, by fair means and foul. Despite its inane title -- the "Swoosh" is the fat, lopsided chevron that is Nike's trademark -- this is a lively and engrossing account of that battle, as told from the perspective of the men who fought to push Nike from nowhere to the front ranks of its industry.

A raucous crew they were, too. A more accurate subtitle for the book would have been " 'Chariots of Fire' Meets 'Animal House.' " Nike executives routinely punished themselves with grueling international travel, impossible production deadlines, constant financial anxiety -- and used alcohol as an ever-present anodyne. Marriages fell apart. People fell apart. Sometimes even the shoes fell apart. But the bombardment of the competition -- chiefly Adidas, the German running-shoe giant -- continued without so much as an occasional cease-fire. Ultimately, it was a war with few heroes and many, many casualties.

The silent, implacable general in the fight was Philip H. (Buck) Knight, the enigmatic Oregonian who willed Nike into existence and who is still chairman of the $3 billion public company that his brainchild has become. At the University of Oregon in the late 50's, Buck Knight -- a shy, monkish accounting student -- was a competent but unspectacular runner for Bill Bowerman, the school's legendary track coach. In late 1963, when Mr. Knight decided to go into the shoe business, Mr. Bowerman agreed to help him -- for a half-interest in Blue Ribbon Sports, the company that would become Nike.

For Mr. Bowerman, the perfect running shoe was the Holy Grail. Years before he teamed up with Mr. Knight, he had been cobbling together his own experimental versions for his top runners. But those were amateur endeavors; when he sealed the Nike partnership with a handshake, Mr. Bowerman went pro. He put Mr. Knight's shoes on the feet of his own hero athletes -- an endorsement from Olympus in the runner's world -- and he contributed to the research process. He quietly sold his cachet, his influence with young athletes, to Nike. In return, he eventually became very rich.

It was on just such alliances that the Nike empire was built. The Bowerman connection was perhaps more noble than some of the later cash-for-cachet deals Nike entered into with amateur and professional athletes and coaches. And it was certainly less crass than the liaisons already forged by a few of Nike's rivals. But it was the first step in a process that ultimately came to define the company and, indeed, the entire industry.

That process reached its fullest development in Nike's dealing with Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, the electrifying athlete whose association with Nike put the term "Air Jordans" into the sports lexicon -- and burned a desire for fancy footwear into the minds of countless impoverished city youths. At the peak of the Air Jordan frenzy in 1985, the $65 shoes were being resold on the street for $100 a pair. "I can't wear them around here," one National Basketball Association executive said at the time. "I'm afraid they'd be taken away from me on the way to work by some kid with a gun."

For some of the men who built Nike, this commercialization of the sports they cherished and the athletes they idealized felt like heartbreak, or like betrayal. But for most of them, it felt like a war -- against richer, more powerful European adversaries like Adidas and Puma, against Asian factories and finance companies who wanted more of the action, against the pushy agents who handled the star athletes, and even -- sadly, too often -- against one another.

The book's major flaw is its failure to illuminate the man who started it all -- a shortcoming that perhaps cannot be entirely attributed to its authors, J. B. Strasser, a former Nike employee (whose husband, Rob Strasser, is one of the company's founding executives and now part owner of a consulting firm that works for a Nike rival), and her sister, Laurie Becklund, a reporter for The Los Angeles Times. Phil Knight remains, after hundreds of pages, the same indistinct and enigmatic figure he was when the story opened. A "black hole," one of his subordinates once called him. The "masked man," pronounced another. Mr. Knight offered little cooperation with this book, its authors concede in their preface, and he emerges mostly as a mosaic of images: Buck Knight as seen by the other actors on the stage. There is little sense of what drove him, what inspired him, why he did what he did -- except for a poignant suggestion, as the story is ending, that he might, just possibly, have done it for the money.

Certainly Nike made enormous amounts of money for the people who built it. When the company went public in 1980, Mr. Knight joined the ranks of the very rich. The ruinous effect of success on an entrepreneurial company is a threadbare cliche in business, of course, but in "Swoosh" it is transformed into an exciting, intimate adventure that gives the old tale a fresh gloss.

The fundamental wonder of the Nike story is that so much emotion and effort and imagination have been expended on behalf of a slab of rubber and a few scraps of nylon mesh. However, the authors of "Swoosh" are occasionally able to lift the running shoe to the level of cultural icon. At those moments, Nike's story begins to echo that of an entire generation -- those newborns of the baby boom who rebelled in the 60's, jogged through the 70's, memorized aerobic pulse levels in the 80's and have arrived at the 90's with tender joints and at least three pairs of athletic shoes on the floor of the closet.

Odds are, at least some of those shoes are Nikes.


LOAD-DATE: February 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Philip (Buck) Knight in 1962, before he founded Nike Inc., breaking the tape in a pair of Adidas shoes. (Jeff Johnson/From "Swoosh")


TYPE: Review


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

911 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


March 31, 1991, SUNDAY, THREE STAR Edition


ADVERTISING WORLD SNUBS THE STARS OF OLD RELIABLE - BASEBALL


BYLINE: Mike Littwin The Baltimore Sun


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 3F


LENGTH: 658 words


 

If Bo Jackson's sporting career is over, that would make him the last of the great baseball stars, and even he didn't exactly qualify. He was a hybrid, a baseball-football freak whose like we hadn't seen since Jim Thorpe. And it took a shoe commercial to make him really famous anyway. Where are the great baseball stars? I mean real stars, Ruthian stars, where-have-you-gone-Joe-DiMaggio stars? Mickey Mantle, Willie Mays, Hammerin' Hank stars? As far as I can tell, there aren't any, even though baseball, as a game, is bigger, grander, more popular than ever, or haven't you tried pricing baseball cards lately? And even though we live in an era where anyone - picture your name here - can be a celebrity. It isn't as if the games we play aren't yielding heroes. Michael Jordan is the only man in America whose popularity rivals Stormin' Norman (take note: he drinks Diet Pepsi) Schwarzkopf. He is On-The-Air Jordan. Talk about hang time, Jordan has true staying power, from your shoes to your breakfast table to your soft drink to who knows where it will end. It doesn't stop with Jordan, either. Old people get Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer. Young people get Boris Becker and John McEnroe. Magic Johnson, Mr. Robinson. And Joe Montana, he's everywhere now. Even Mike Tyson. Greg Lemond - who rides a bicycle - gets Taco Bell. Basketball, football, boxing, cycling, golf, tennis. Baseball, anyone? Maybe it's the criteria we set for stardom these days. In the modern era, stardom has come to mean endorsements, commercials, TV time. Nike made Bo; Bo didn't make Nike. Nike did as much for Bo as Miller Lite did for Marv Throneberry. It's all an advertising game. Let's take the case of David Robinson, who is a fine basketball player but no better than Patrick Ewing or Hakeem Olajuwon. Somebody in advertising picked out Robinson, who is bright and articulate, but the ad boys didn't trade on that, either. They made Robinson into the stereotypical 7-foot mean guy whose path you had better cross only with caution, in comic juxtaposition with the numbing calmness of Mr. Rogers. It's a media creation, and Mr. Robinson, although he performs in a small market, is now a media star. Why didn't somebody pick Rickey Henderson instead? There is one easy explanation, and that's shoes. Basketball players wear shoes that people buy by the millions, pumping up the volume. People don't kick back in cleats, if only for safety reasons. The shoe industry and the National Basketball Association have fed nicely on each other in classic economic symbiosis, and they've both grown apace. And there's the crossover effect. Minute Maid is coming out with a commercial starring Isiah Thomas, Dominique Wilkins and Ewing, who are hot because basketball is hot because Nike commercials are hot. But Boomer Esiason just got a Reebok commercial. Why not Don Mattingly? Why not Eric Davis? Why not Ryne Sandberg? Why not Dwight Gooden? Nolan Ryan is getting work these days, but, gosh, is there a better story anywhere in sports? This guy is a biological phenomenon who, by any logic, ought to be a megastar - but who isn't, at least on Madison Avenue. Even the experts are stumped. If the time is ripe for anti-heroes - McEnroe, Jim McMahon, Brian Bosworth, Charles Barkley - why not Jose Canseco, who has fame, personality and all the bad, bad boy you could ask for? Go figure. There are actually more stars, in the old sense, in baseball than in any other sport. There are names that people who follow baseball know. But as it was explained to me, baseball, in advertising jargon, is an ''old reliable brand'' and therefore possesses limited sex appeal. And it's a regional brand. Cal Ripken is big in Baltimore, Andre Dawson in Chicago and Michael Jordan everywhere. But could there be more to it? Has baseball somehow become a faceless sport? Or is it that the real heroes, say Pete Rose, have shown themselves to be flawed?


LOAD-DATE: October 8, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

913 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 13, 1992, Tuesday


Sanders loyal only to himself, Nike


BYLINE: By Terence Moorepersonalities; business; finances; earnings


SECTION: SPORTS; Section D; Page 5


LENGTH: 631 words


The Atlanta Braves are a victory away from reaching the World Series tonight at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, but everybody is engrossed with the guy who isn't here. We're talking about Deion Sanders, whose mind is elsewhere.

Maybe it's in Buckhead.

Maybe it's in Miami. 

Maybe it's in Beavertown, Ore., where Nike makes enough money to make Sanders do goofy things.

There was Sanders's latest silliness that began Saturday night after Game 4 of the National League Championship Series in Pittsburgh. First, he took a limo to the airport. Then he caught a charter to Miami for Sunday's Falcons game against the Dolphins. Then he swam the English Channel. Then he shot deer in Alaska. Then he sauntered into the Braves' clubhouse for Sunday's Game 5 against the Pirates.

Braves president Stan Kasten isn't pleased these days. After all, Kasten is o ne of the few sports executives who was forced to phone one of his players to ask that player what his plans were for the next day.

"The details were a little sketchy," said Kasten, hours after he dialed Sanders in his hotel room Saturday. Witnesses said the conversation between Kasten and Sanders was rather loud. Anyway, somebody asked Kasten if Sanders would do what he was rumored to do after flying to the Falcons' game and hustle back to town to continue his role as the most overpublicized bench player in baseball history.

"He didn't say," said Kasten, grinning, with eyebrows raised. "I'm just assuming that he's coming back."

Braves general manager John Schuerholz isn't pleased with Sanders, either. Schuerholz says he wouldn't have placed Sanders on the Braves' playoff roster if he knew Sanders would renege on his agreement to stay exclusively with the Braves throughout the postseason.

"I'll discuss the situation after the playoffs," said Schuerholz, his words toasting Pittsburgh's chilly air. As for Braves manager Bobby Cox, when asked if Sanders's latest silliness would have been worse if Sanders weren't just another guy on the roster, "If he were a starter doing this, it would be a huge issue. Now it's just an issue."

No, this is just Deion Sanders, the ego that both the Braves and the Falcons can do without. Sanders's ego is the size of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and the Georgia Dome. Sanders's ego is out of control. Fortunately, for Atlanta sports fans, Sanders's ego can become somebody else's problem in 1993, since neither the Braves nor the Falcons are contractually obligated to the guy after their respective seasons.

The sad thing is that it has taken the ultimate of silliness from Sanders to make the Braves see what they should have seen all along, and that is Deion Sanders cares only about Deion Sanders. Well, that and his three-year, $ 3 million contract with Nike. In fact, Nike is making a commercial of Sanders's latest silliness. Nike runs Sanders. If he plays only one sport someday, Nike says it will cut his payroll by $ 900,000 per year.

That "someday" for Sanders might come soon within these city limits, hopefully in regard to the Braves and the Falcons.

Sanders stopped talking to the local media, by the way, because of your afternoon columnist. I wrote last month that Sanders was embarrassing himself by saying the Falcons were using a "plantation" mentality during negotiations that gave him a $ 2 million salary with the team this season.

I wrote that Sanders should "shut up," and he did. He said he was doing so because of me.

Well, I blew it. If I'd known that Sanders follows my advice, I'd have asked for a piece of his Nike contract. I can't ask now, because Sanders told author John Feinstein in regards to why he doesn't talk to the local media, "They had the privilege, they abused the privilege, and now they've lost the privilege."

Darn.


LOAD-DATE: October 17, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922910130


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

915 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Sunday Times (London)


September 6, 1992, Sunday


Adidas plans $30m boost


BYLINE: Rufus Olins


SECTION: Business


LENGTH: 282 words


PENTLAND GROUP, which recently acquired Adidas, the sports goods company, is launching a $30m (Pounds 15.4m) advertising campaign, in an effort to fight off its American rivals, Nike and Reebok. It also wants to introduce a series of top-of-the-range products. 

Adidas has sacked its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, and appointed Leagas Delaney, whose clients include Porsche cars and Timberland shoes, to help protect the market-leading position of Adidas in Europe. The Nuremberg company, which used to have 50% of Germany's sports-shoe market, has seen its share slip to 40%. Adidas also plans to take on Reebok and Nike in America, where it has 3% of the market.

Frank Farrant, Pentland's finance director, said: ''The brand is so powerful it doesn't have a problem once we've put some momentum behind it.''

Pentland, which entered a conditional agreement to buy control of Adidas two months ago, is expected to report interim profits of about Pounds 19m tomorrow, and a dividend increase.

Results from the deal, which is scheduled to be completed in November, will not be included in this week's figures. In 1991, however, under the control of Bernard Tapie, Adidas made only Pounds 7.6m profit on turnover of Pounds 1.1billion.

Stephen Rubin, chairman of Pentland, who netted Pounds 390m last year by selling his stake in Reebok, believes he can now resurrect Adidas with improved marketing, sourcing, distribution and product innovation. A key task is to improve margins at the company.

Beefeater Gin is attacking its arch-rival Gordon's for reducing its alcohol strength from 40% to 37.5% by volume in an advertising campaign by Abbott Mead starting today.


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Times Newspapers Limited

 

916 of 998 DOCUMENTS


MTI Econews


August 26, 1991


Hungarian-Italian ammunition manufacturing JV - development plans


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 453 words


    Budapest, August 26, 1991 (MTI-ECONEWS) - Nike-Fiocchi,
a Hungarian-Italian JV which manufactures ammunition,
recently embarked on a 250-million-forint (3.33-million-USD)
capacity expansion project. 
     The JV, which operates on the premises of Nitrokemia
Industrial Works at Balatonfuzfo, Western Hungary, was set
up on January 1, 1991, with an initial capital of 662
million forints (8.82 million USD).
     The partners -- Nitrokemia, and Fiocchi of Lecco, Italy,
share the capital 50:50.
     Nike-Fiocchi manufactures ammunition mainly for hunting
and sports guns, as well as for special weapons.
     The company expects to put out products worth 450
million forints (5.92 million USD) this year, 80 per cent of
which will go for export.
     Main markets are Denmark, Germany, The Netherlands and
Canada.
     About 15 per cent of the JV's output is made up of
pyrotechnical products.
     As well as manufacturing cartridges for fireworks,
 Nike-Fiocchi has just started a trial production run of its
own patent, a rocket used for braking hang-gliders.
     A variety of cartridges for power nail-punches is
another of the company's own developments: these are used
primarily in the building industry. The majority of these
products will similarly be exported, mainly to Western
Europe.
     The Hungarian-Italian JV reckons that the
250-million-forint development project it recently
implemented will be complete by 1993.
     New production lines with capacities larger than the
present equipment will be put into service via this project.
     As a result of the investment, overall capacities will
be increased by 50 per cent.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 MTI Hungarian News Agency

 

918 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 30, 1992, Thursday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS Mercenary athletes use hard-sell on soft shoes


BYLINE: Steve Hummerolympics; advertising; equipment; behavior; business; trends; results


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 5


LENGTH: 681 words


Barcelona - We have seen early in these Games clues to future Olympics, when athletes no longer will align themselves by nation and heritage, but rather by how they are shod. No more flags. No more anthems. Only the drumbeats of commerce.

In the opening ceremonies of tomorrow, competitors will march into the stadium behind the corporate logo of their choosing. Teammates may not speak a common language, but they will be on a common payroll. 

Stirring medal ceremonies will consist of some 30-second spot flashed on a big screen - no doubt directed by Spike Lee - while the theme of the gold medal winner's sponsor blares over the sound system.

It's honestly not that far away.

Some U.S. track and field performers already have shown us how difficult it is to keep a team together on the flimsy basis of pride-in- country.

Tuesday, Danny Everett of the 1,600-meter relay went to the media with complaints that his choice, Andrew Valmon, was excluded from the four-man team in favor of Michael Johnson because of shoe politics. He charged that coach Mel Rosen and Johnson were solemates - both Nike guys - and they conspired to keep Valmon off the team because he does not have the proper insignia on his shoe. Never mind that Johnson is probably the more capable 400-meter man.

You can see bad things coming for this relay team. Maybe a baton gets dropped because somebody's contract prohibits contact with another athlete from a different company.

This team doesn't need training, it requires a corporate merger.

Europe has broken up or recombined because of politics and age-old ethnic divisions. The United States is breaking up over footwear.

The lines already have blurred concerning who is competing for whom. Track's biggest stars have been independent agents for a long time, collecting beneath the U.S. flag once every four years. The arrangement has never seemed more transparent than here.

If you wanted to interview Carl Lewis at the start of the Games, that would not be arranged by the United States Olympic Committee, but rather by the athletics-wear company, Mizuno. You would be directed by helpful Mizuno employees to a cramped, steamy atrium where Lewis would meet the world's media and discuss the current state of business. Another giant in the world of overpriced sneakers, Asics, was proud to announce its news conference Wednesday with 100-meter contender Leroy Burrell. Also on hand would be company chairman Kihachico Onitsuka. Used to be, athletes appeared with their coaches. Now they tow foreign CEOs.

Undisputed champion of redesigning the Olympics is Nike, which is running almost daily orchestrated media events at a theater it rented in downtown Barcelona. It has claimed outright many of the most popular athletes here as its own, ignoring whatever other insignia they may bear. The only differentiation it makes between people is in size and width.

Michael Jordan and Commonwealth of Independent States pole-vaulter Sergei Bubka appeared almost as teammates together on the Nike stage, the conference moderated by NBC's Ahmad Rashad. Call it a seminar on hang time.

Charles Barkley stopped by. Scheduled to follow were members of the Croatian basketball team. Most ambitious yet is the "Nike International Track and Field Team" - Nike's title, not mine. Consisting of such diverse members as the previously maligned Michael Johnson, Chinese hurdler Tong Li, Nigerian sprinter Mary Onyali and middle-distance runner Letitia Vriesde of Suriname, they are supposed to appear today as one big, happy, nylon-upper coalition.

I like the chances of the Nike International Track and Field Team to do well in the medal count in these Games. The Nike machine should be a force for Olympics to come.

For all this time, idealists have dreamed about weaning the Olympics from its nationalism, the unseemly flag-waving and jingoism. That is being steadily attended to by the makers of fine leisure wear. In the near future, the worst chant you'll hear at the Olympic Stadium will go something like:

"Your shoe stinks! Your shoe stinks!"


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922180166


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

Herald Sun


April 4, 1991 Thursday


Biskic's win may result in a career extension


BYLINE: DESIRA P


LENGTH: 350 words


JOE BISKIC, captain of Melbourne Croatia, has been named player-of-the-year in the Herald-Sun-Nike Air Golden Boot award.

The midfielder overtook the three joint leaders - John Filan, Anthony Franken and Mike Petersen - with three votes in the postponed match against Marconi in Sydney.

Biskic was the only one of seven players with award-winning chances to poll votes. 

He said last night it had been easy to play well in a Melbourne Croatia team full of good players.

He conceded the win may force him to change his retirement plans.

As the Golden Boot winner, Biskic will receive $2000 cash from Nike Air.

Biskic is hopeful it will turn into a double celebration with Melbourne Croatia winning the league title.

Fixture details for the first round of the NSL championhip finals series: Sunday April 14. Elimination semi (4th vs 5th): Marconi v Melita Eagles at Parramatta Stadium, 3pm. Preliminary semi (2nd v 3rd): South Melbourne v Adelaide City at Olympic Park, 3pm.

Herald-Sun Nike Air Golden Boot Award.

Round 26. Votes. Marconi v Melb Croatia: 3 Biskic (mc), 2 Miller (mc), 1 Lowe (m). Adelaide City v Melb Cro: 3 Veart (ac), 2 T.Vidmar (ac), 1 Ivanovic (ac).Apia v Preston Mak: 3 Ellem (al), 2 Poimer (al), 1 Jolevski (pm). Melita v Syd Oly: 3 Cerro (me), 1 Genc (me), 1 Hunter (me), 1 Bernal (so). South Melb v Heidelberg: 3 Wright (sm), 1 Trimboli (sm), 1 McDowall (h), 1 Postecoglou (sm). Sunshine v Woll City: 3 Roodhouse (sgc), 2 Yankos (wc), 1 Hunter (sgc). Syd Cro v St George: 3 Harper (stg), 2 El Ali (stg), 1 Koczka (stg).Woll Mac v Marconi: 3 Seal (m), 2 Georgakis (m), 1 Young (wm).

Leaders: 20 Biskic. 18 Filan, Franken, Petersen. 17 Clarkson, P.Okon.16 Blagojevic, Durakovic, 15 Ivanovic, Petkovic, Stubbins. 14 Bundalo, Herd, Kindtner, Phillips, Stewart, Yankos. 13 Cerro, Gimenez, Katholos, Kuc, we, A.Vidmar, 12 Davidson, 11 El Ali, Jackson, Kupresak, McCulloch, Parton, Soper, Spink, Tsolakis, T.Vidmar. 10 Catlin, C.Foster, Harper, Krslovic, Marth, Nowicki, Olver, Soper, Wade, Player of the week. Rd 26: Danny Wright (sm).
