922 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


July 15, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


College basketball coaches mostly unhappy campers


BYLINE: Pat Forde


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 10C


LENGTH: 778 words


DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS


The Nike/ABCD Basketball Camp, the swoosh-stripe fashion show that doubles as a showcase for the USA's most dazzling high school boys basketball talent, concluded last week.

Participants hailed it as one of the best ever. Although the camp stresses academics, featuring five hours of classwork daily, its dribbles might be numbered.

A controversial piece of legislation from the National Association of Basketball Coaches is aimed at reining in summer camps. 

The NABC says the current system fails in several areas:

- It allows third parties to exert influence over prospects in recruiting or act as middlemen between players and college coaches.

- It forces coaches to crisscross the country for all of July to put in appearances watching prospects; such appearances are believed to be essential in wooing recruits.

That runs at odds with cost-cutting measures the NCAA is trying to enforce.

''It's an area that's totally unregulated,'' said University of Southern California coach George Raveling, chairman of the NABC Recruiting Committee.

The committee recommends that the NCAA start regulating. Its suggestion: nine NCAA-sponsored regional camps.

The recommendation goes before the NCAA Council July 31. If it passes, it will be forwarded to the NCAA convention in January, where university presidents will vote on it as a two-year pilot program to be implemented in summer 1993.

''I think it has a real good chance of passing,'' said Rick Evrard, NCAA director of legislative services.

According to the NABC plan, only high school seniors-to-be (not other underclassmen) would be invited to its camps, at a cost of $ 75, and only high school coaches would work at the camps.

Most important, these would be the only camps college coaches are permitted to attend, which presumably would put talent shows like Nike in the shoebox.

''I think it's ludicrous,'' said Nike coordinator Sonny Vaccaro, the man who outfits his 120 campers in shoes, shirts and shorts - and the man whom some call the most powerful in college basketball because of his shoe deals with dozens of the game's top coaches.

''I think it's blind. And the reasons aren't good enough for me to believe that what they're trying to do is for the best interests of the kids.''
Raveling stressed he is merely the chairman of the NABC's Recruiting Committee, not a lone firebrand.

''I'm interested in who these people are who think it's a slim chance,'' he said. ''They're certainly not the people who vote on it. ... A lot of coaches want to demonstrate to adminstrators they're on the same page.''

Raveling said he has been banned from three camps for his advocacy of a new summer system.

The only camp Raveling would name that he said has banned him is Dave Krider's All-American camp in Cincinnati. Krider also is sports editor for the La Porte (Ind.) Herald-Argus and picks all-USA teams for USA TODAY.

Raveling said players are saying they feel pressured to attend Krider's camp in order to boost chances of being all-USA.

''We don't promise kids anything,'' Krider said. ''I have never, ever told kids anything as far as my position at USA TODAY helping them in any way.''

Krider's camp made its debut last year. He and partner Bobby Kortsen charged coaches $ 200 for Kortsen's scouting service - which they had to buy in order to gain access to floor seating at the University of Cincinnati's Shoemaker Center.

Krider, who will charge only $ 15 this year, claims some schools spend more than $ 20,000 on recruiting, ''so how much is $ 200 really?'' Krider also alleges that at their camps, Bill Cronauer (BC Camp) and Howard Garfinkel (Five Star) have sold private information on prospects. Garfinkel could not be reached, but Cronauer denies the charge.

The divisiveness among camps, Raveling said, keeps them from presenting a united front to discuss the issue with the NABC.

''Everyone is pointing his finger at the other guy,'' he said. ''There's a need for regulation. You can't even get five of them in the same room to arbitrate.''

Several college coaches scouting Vaccaro's camp had reservations about the new proposal.

''It's mixed, I think,'' Georgetown's John Thompson said of the coaches' reaction. ''I think a lot of guys are for it because of what they perceive it to be: They perceive it to be something where the NCAA will take total supervision and there will be no influences at all.

''. ... But is the NCAA capable of administering a camp? Let's stop and think about that. They can't even administer enforcement services; they don't have enough people. Where's the (camp) staff going to come from? Where's the funding going to come from?''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w, Porter Binks, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: GEORGE RAVELING: USC coach banned from three camps because of stance.


Pat Forde writes for the Louisville Courier-Journal.


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

925 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Straits Times


The right fit


November 19, 1992


Mary Rose Gasmier


With so many types of sports shoes in the market, how do you pick the right one? MARY ROSE GASMIER asks a man who should know.

WHETHER you are a big-foot, small-foot, thin-foot or fat-foot, the point of buying sports shoes is to get a pair that fits your particular needs. And one man who should know how to go about doing this is James Spiro Davis, 49, chairman of New Balance.

New Balance's American sales of US$ 95 million (S$ 153 million) last year limp far behind Nike's US$ 1.7 billion and Reebok's US$ 1.3 billion in the same period. Nike holds 29.8 per cent of the United States market, Reebok 22.8 per cent. New Balance trails with just 1.8 per cent. 

Given these figures, and as Mr Davis was on a selling mission here last week, some sales talk is perhaps understandable.

"We don't have the promotional budget that Nike has but I just believe that ours is a far superior product," he says, sunk in an armchair in the lobby of the Shangri-la Hotel.

To his credit, though, when asked for advice on what the Singapore consumer should look for in a pair of athletic shoes, he immediately sits up to give clear, detailed instructions, then stands up to demonstrate how to test your shoe.

He suggests several factors one should bear in mind when selecting athletic shoes:

<> The most important factor is correct fit: Most shoes are produced in lengths but European feet are longer and narrower, whereas Asian feet are shorter and broader. So the best-fitting shoes are those that offer the width and length appropriate to your foot. A shoe that looks good but does not fit may cause blisters.

<> When shopping for a shoe, first decide what you will use it for: This is where product performance comes in.

<> Shoes are designed differently for men and women because women have narrower heels, so when selecting a model, make sure that it is also the correct "gender".

A shoe usually has two soles. The outer outsole is made of durable high-carbon rubbers mixed with chemicals and pigments. It is glued with a urethane-based cement onto the inner midsole.

The midsole consists of ethylene-vinylacetate or high-density polyurethane which is usually thicker from the heel to mid-foot to give stability and shock-absorption for the "heel strike", the hard landing on the heel when one runs or jumps.

The midsole is usually made of softer, lower-density polyurethane for the upper part of the foot, which lands more gently during exercise.

If the materials are of poor quality, a shoe that appears to have a lot of spring and offers a good cushioning effect when you walk up and down in the store may, over time, lose resiliency.

<> So, in buying running shoes, a "hard-heel lander" whose heel normally hits the ground very hard, should look for a running shoe with a reinforced heel -this may be an extra rubber pad that runs in a horseshoe shape round the outer edge of the shoe heel.

Those who tend to run more on the balls of their feet should look for extra reinforcement in this area.

Pick a shoe that offers more forward-backward stability and less torque (sideways wobble). These are usually found in shoes which have a fairly high midsole.

Shoes like this are also good for heavy people who need stable shoes that can take their weight and will not wobble with each stride. They also offer better grip for cross-country runs or rock-climbing.

<> Running shoes for track and field use and for competitive sports should be lighter, with thinner midsoles and outsoles made of lower-density ethylene-vinylacetate.

The lightness is important for running speed, and the heels are better designed to take the lighter weight of athletes who are generally slim-built. Such shoes should have little torque and more forward-backward stability.

<> For court games like tennis or squash, choose shoes that allow easy sideways movement. Running shoes like those described above do not fit this purpose as they are not designed for sideways jumps and leaps: The midsole is too high and there is not enough build-up of the sole around the edges.

When testing the shoes in the shop, move as you would on a court to test flexibility.

Knowledgeable salesmen can tell you which model offers a better grip on a wood surface, such as a squash court, and which on hard ground or artificial surfaces.

<> If you engage in very strenuous activity, you should check for uppers with nylon-mesh which allow air circulation and easy evaporation of sweat. All-leather uppers will retain heat and cause discomfort.


SECTION: Life; Society; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 1374 words


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: James Spiro Davis ... bought New Balance in 1972 with US$ 20,000 when he was 27.


Copyright 1992 The Straits Times Press Limited

 

927 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


June 28, 1991, Friday, METRO EDITION


Agasssi still quite a sight in white at Wimbledon


BYLINE: By Nora McCabe Toronto Star


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. B6


LENGTH: 671 words


Leave it to Andre Agassi.

Or perhaps, to be more accurate, Nike.

First, the swashbuckling Las Vegan turns the stuffy tennis world on its ear with his tousled tie-dyed hair and stone-washed denim shorts. Not satisfied with this tradition-flaunting attire, he then - with the blessing of Nike, his clothier of record - adds Day-Glo cycling shorts and crop-topped shirts. 

Then, just when purists have reluctantly started to resign themselves to this godawful apparition, the born-again Agassi embraces . . . tradition.

In keeping with his image as a creature of extremes, for his maiden appearance yesterday at centre court at the All England Club the clean-shaven Agassi wore (gasp) white.

White warmup suit. White crop-topped shirt. White shorts with white lycra cycling shorts. White socks. White tennis shoes. White headband.

A contrast was Grant Connell, Agassi's Canadian-born opponent who was also dressed by Nike. He looked like a peacock - even though he conformed to Wimbledon's "predominantly white" clothing rules. That is to say, the Vancouver southpaw's shoes had jade green markings and his first shirt was splashed with blue and hot pink.

At 3:45 p.m., Agassi, swathed in a white nylon warmup suit, arrived on centre court to a swell of applause from a gallery that included the Duchess of Kent.

Milking the occasion for all it was worth, Agassi went over to his chair and slowly, like a stripper, began to disrobe. As he took off his pants, revealing his white look, there were wolf whistles, cheers, applause.

When rain began again at 5:08 p.m., washing out play for the rest of the day with but a meager six matches completed, Agassi and Connell were level at one set each and 1-1 in games in the third. The No. 73-ranked Connell took the first 6-4 and the fifth-seeded Agassi the second 6-1.

In what had to be most distracting and intimidating circumstances, Connell did himself proud. He kept his poise, served and volleyed well and moved confidently on the slippery grass. He broke Agassi in the seventh game, then conceded just three more points on his own serve en route to claiming the first set.

Agassi, who had not played a grass court match since losing in the first round here in 1987, started out looking uncomfortable on the unfamiliar turf but grew increasingly comfortable and aggressive as the match progressed. By the second set, he'd harnessed his errant first serve and begun whaling his returns of serve, racking up 16 winners, and broke Connell twice to build a 5-0 lead. When Agassi is firing at that level, no one can blunt his attack.

But while Agassi had the momentum when play stopped, he is vulnerable on grass. There is no evidence that his volleying has improved. He still tends to wind up and take a big swing in midcourt, rarely comes in to crowd the net, rarely opts to come in to volley off his serve. In other words, he has made few adjustments to his normal hard-hitting style to accommodate the vagaries of grass.

He might beat Connell. But he's won't be a serious contender for the men's title.

Connell is not throwing in the towel. Having put to rest his prematch jitters and having had some time to assess the match, he's not pessimistic that he can come back and win - weather permitting.

"It was a great feeling. I loved it. But he's damn good, so I have to get in my first serves and then it's down to two out of three."

In other matches, top-seeded defending champion Stefan Edberg finally finished the match he started Tuesday, defeating Swiss Marc Rosset 6-4, 6-4, 6-4. Eightseeded U.S. Open champion Pete Sampras won his first Wimbledon match - 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 over Brazilian Danilo Marcelino - and sixth-seeded German Michael Stich removed American Dan Goldie 6-4, 6-1, 6-2.

None of the other Canadians finished. Montreal's Martin Laurendeau is leading 6-3, 7-6 (7-4), 3-6, 2-2 in his match with Briton Danny Sapsford. Patricia Hy of Richmond Hill won the first set 6-2 against veteran South African Ros Fairbank-Nideffer.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP photo Stefan Edberg


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

929 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


January 31, 1992, Friday


SPORTING STYLE Show highlights a $ 21 billion industry


BYLINE: By Jeffry Scott STAFF WRITER


SECTION: BUSINESS; Section G; Page 1


LENGTH: 502 words


Among the great moments in athletic apparel history, 1985 will be recorded as the year that changed us forever.

It was the year Cybill Shepherd showed up at the Emmy Awards wearing a black strapless gown and high-top orange Reeboks.

And it was the year Nike signed an NBA rookie named Michael Jordan to a $ 5 million, five-year endorsement contract to launch a shoe called Air Jordan. 

Since then, America has had a hard time deciding whether $ 80 sneakers are for show or for function. Along the way, sports apparel has become an estimated $ 21 billion-a-year industry in this country - and shoes are just the jumping-off point.

As about 88,000 representatives of the nation's sporting goods industry converge on Atlanta this weekend for the Super Show, they will be looking at an industry that, if not recession-proof, is certainly in better shape than most of the economy.

According to the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, the industry's retail sales, including equipment, hit $ 31.56 billion in 1991 - up 4.4 percent from 1990. And they're expected to accelerate again this year, climbing 5 percent to $ 33.14 billion.

The industry's fiscal health, however, has little to do with the nation's physical health. According to a study by Kurt Salmon Associates, 80 percent of the sports apparel sold in this country is purchased by "non-participants": those who buy for fashion, not function.

Remember the Billy Crystal/Fernando gag, "Better to look good than feel good"? America takes it to heart.

Reebok understood that appeal in 1985 when it sold its aerobic shoes in 27 colors and shifted the emphasis of its advertising from performance to high fashion. But when Nike's Air Jordan sales hit $ 107 million nine months after it was launched, sneaker chic suddenly turned hard core: Americans wanted "serious" athletic apparel first - even if they were just wearing it for fashion.

Reebok's sales slumped, and Nike's soared.

Reebok has since rebounded, introducing its "Pump" line of performance sneakers, selling $ 750 million worth, for up to $ 160 a pair, in two years. Still, 70 percent of Pump sales are for "street use," according to the company. And Nike estimates 50 percent of its Air Jordans, at up to $ 130 a pair, aren't worn for basketball.

The companies have come under fire for allegedly marketing the shoes to youths who can't afford them. Some youths reportedly have been killed for the shoes.

Reebok now is introducing a line of Pumps for under $ 100. And a Nike spokesman says the company recognizes the problem, but denies it has aimed its ads at inner-city youth.

"Our target market is people who actually want to use the shoe for athletic purposes," says company spokeswoman Melinda Gable. "We don't segment our advertising. It's national in scope."

The performance appeal has since, like top athletes themselves, made the transition from amateur to pro. The big boom in apparel these days is in licensed merchandise with professional team logos and colors.


LOAD-DATE: March 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

931 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


February 28, 1992 Friday


Lisa close to signing up for AOC


LENGTH: 446 words


AUSTRALIAN runner Lisa Ondieki is close to signing a controversial sponsorship contract which will allow her to chase marathon gold at the Olympic Games in Barcelona.

Ondieki is one of several athletes, including Rob de Castella and Kerry Junna-Saxby, yet to agree to a contract.

She said yesterday she was likely to sign next week after changes agreed to by the Australian Olympic Committee. 

When Australian team members were first handed the contract, it stipulated they must support the AOC's sponsors from the time of selection until arrival back in Australia after the Games.

They were also expected to endorse AOC sponsors, even if they were personally sponsored by opposition companies.

The AOC this week altered the contract, making the support start when teams arrive in the Olympic village, rather than during the preparation.

And no athletes will have to endorse sponsors in competition against their own.

Ondieki said it was a victory for the athletes and the concessions were "worth fighting for".

The 1988 Olympic silver medallist has been sponsored by Nike for 10 years while the Australian team is sponsored by adidas.

Ondieki leaves for the US on Tuesday to continue her Barcelona build-up and will meet Nike officials to discuss the contra discuss it again with Nike, who have sponsored me for 10 years now," she said.

Ondieki said athletes she had spoken to from other nations had not received the pressure imposed on Australians and officials here were more "bureacratic" than elsewhere.

Ondieki said the contract dispute had unsettled her.

"It's been unpleasantness and stress that you can do without," she said.

"It's sad to say but it's another reason I'm glad I'm leaving Australia - so I can leave this all behind." Ondieki will be based in Phoenix, Arizona until it becomes too hot, and in May will head to Europe.

She will run in the San Fransisco Bay to Breakers race, then a 10km event in Central Park, New York.

Barcelona will be Ondieki's 15th marathon and she admitted the pressure would be on her.

"It's a strange situation going back to the Olympics again when I've won silver because it means I can only do one thing to do better, and that's win the gold," she said.

The Olympic marathon course is different from anything Ondieki has tackled before, with a wicked hill at the end.

"It's a unique course because it's the only marathon course that increases in elevation - most race directors want a fast race so they have a decrease," she explained.

"I don't think it'll give anyone an advantage but it's so bad that you have to change your training to take it into account." AAP

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Lisa Ondieki . . . "worth fighting for".


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1992 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

932 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


June 28, 1991, Friday, ME2


Agasssi still quite a sight in white at Wimbledon


BYLINE: By Nora McCabe Toronto Star


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. B6


LENGTH: 675 words


 
   WIMBLEDON - Leave it to Andre Agassi.

Or perhaps, to be more accurate, Nike.

First, the swashbuckling Las Vegan turns the stuffy tennis world on its ear with his tousled tie-dyed hair and stone-washed denim shorts. Not satisfied with this tradition-flaunting attire, he then - with the blessing of Nike, his clothier of record - adds Day-Glo cycling shorts and crop-topped shirts. 

Then, just when purists have reluctantly started to resign themselves to this godawful apparition, the born-again Agassi embraces . . . tradition.

In keeping with his image as a creature of extremes, for his maiden appearance yesterday at centre court at the All England Club the clean-shaven Agassi wore (gasp) white.

White warmup suit. White crop-topped shirt. White shorts with white lycra cycling shorts. White socks. White tennis shoes. White headband.

A contrast was Grant Connell, Agassi's Canadian-born opponent who was also dressed by Nike. He looked like a peacock - even though he conformed to Wimbledon's "predominantly white" clothing rules. That is to say, the Vancouver southpaw's shoes had jade green markings and his first shirt was splashed with blue and hot pink.

At 3:45 p.m., Agassi, swathed in a white nylon warmup suit, arrived on centre court to a swell of applause from a gallery that included the Duchess of Kent.

Milking the occasion for all it was worth, Agassi went over to his chair and slowly, like a stripper, began to disrobe. As he took off his pants, revealing his white look, there were wolf whistles, cheers, applause.

When rain began again at 5:08 p.m., washing out play for the rest of the day with but a meager six matches completed, Agassi and Connell were level at one set each and 1-1 in games in the third. The No. 73-ranked Connell took the first 6-4 and the fifth-seeded Agassi the second 6-1.

In what had to be most distracting and intimidating circumstances, Connell did himself proud. He kept his poise, served and volleyed well and moved confidently on the slippery grass. He broke Agassi in the seventh game, then conceded just three more points on his own serve en route to claiming the first set.

Agassi, who had not played a grass court match since losing in the first round here in 1987, started out looking uncomfortable on the unfamiliar turf but grew increasingly comfortable and aggressive as the match progressed. By the second set, he'd harnessed his errant first serve and begun whaling his returns of serve, racking up 16 winners, and broke Connell twice to build a 5-0 lead. When Agassi is firing at that level, no one can blunt his attack.

But while Agassi had the momentum when play stopped, he is vulnerable on grass. There is no evidence that his volleying has improved. He still tends to wind up and take a big swing in mid-court, rarely comes in to crowd the net, rarely opts to come in to volley off his serve. In other words, he has made few adjustments to his normal hard-hitting style to accommodate the vagaries of grass.

He might beat Connell. But he's won't be a serious contender for the men's title.

Connell is not throwing in the towel. Having put to rest his pre- match jitters and having had some time to assess the match, he's not pessimistic that he can come back and win - weather permitting.

"It was a great feeling. I loved it. But he's damn good, so I have to get in my first serves and then it's down to two out of three."

In other matches, top-seeded defending champion Stefan Edberg finally finished the match he started Tuesday, defeating Swiss Marc Rosset 6-4, 6-4, 6-4. Eight- seeded U.S. Open champion Pete Sampras won his first Wimbledon match - 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 over Brazilian Danilo Marcelino - and sixth-seeded German Michael Stich removed American Dan Goldie 6-4, 6-1, 6-2.

None of the other Canadians finished. Montreal's Martin Laurendeau is leading 6-3, 7-6 (7-4), 3-6, 2-2 in his match with Briton Danny Sapsford. Patricia Hy of Richmond Hill won the first set 6-2 against veteran South African Ros Fairbank-Nideffer.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP photo Stefan EdbergTennis


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

935 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


May 25, 1991, Saturday, Final Edition


SECTION: FINANCIAL; PAGE C1; DIGEST


LENGTH: 408 words


The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is missing work safety violations because it rarely reinspects targeted work sites and relies on information voluntarily supplied by employers, according to a report by the GAO.

Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.47 percent this week, down from 9.50 percent last week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. One-year adjustable rate mortgages were at an average initial rate of 7.22 percent, down from 7.23 percent last week.

Nine soybean traders convicted of fraud and racketeering at the Chicago Board of Trade were sentenced to jail terms of up to three years and ordered to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines and restitution. 

NEC, one of the world's biggest computer chipmakers, said earnings fell 36.2 percent in 1990.

Greyhound Lines said its chairman and chief executive, Fred Currey, has agreed to resign. Currey would not confirm or deny whether the resignation is tied to the company's plans to emerge from bankruptcy protection this summer.

Britain cut interest rates by a half percentage point in an effort to speed an economic recovery promised by the ruling Conservative Party before the next general election. It was the fifth half-point cut since February.

Nike counter sued Avia Group International, contending that the rival shoemaker is making shoes that use Nike's sole cushioning technology. In a suit last week, Avia accused Nike of infringing on patents for its Cantilever sole -- a system that directs the shock of impact away from ankles and knees.

Germany is expected to name Bundesbank Deputy President Helmut Schlesinger as successor to outgoing central bank president Karl Otto Poehl, Reuter quoted government sources as saying.

Canada reports that the number of its bankruptcies has soared 77 percent in April from a year ago as a slump in consumer spending hit the retail sector.

TRW named Timothy W. Hannemann general manager of the company's Space & Defense Sector. The company's Systems Integration Group, which has headquarters in Fairfax, will report to Hannemann.

Polly Peck International's creditors agreed to a rescue plan that hinges on the continued operation of the company rather than the sale of its Del Monte fresh fruit and Sansui electronics operations to repay outstanding debt.

Carter-Wallace withdrew its letter of intent to buy Procter & Gamble's Dramamine motion sickness brand of medication.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


TYPE: COLUMN


Copyright 1991 The Washington Post

 

936 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 23, 1991, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


L.A. Gear aims Catapult at competitors


BYLINE: Stuart Elliott


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 4B


LENGTH: 274 words


L.A. Gear Inc. is gearing up to introduce a line of shoes intended to catapult the company into the ranks of performance-sneaker leadership.

The high-tech line, called Catapult, features an ''anti-fatigue rebound system'' designed to give the wearer added lift for jumping higher. 

Teaser TV ads now airing - by the BBDO Los Angeles agency - call Catapult The Machine. They urge viewers to watch the shoe's launch in an ad to run during Super Bowl XXV on Sunday.
Starring in the launch ad: Karl Malone, power forward for the Utah Jazz basketball team. It ends with a slogan referring to rival shoes as hot air - a dig at sneaker giant Nike Inc.'s best-selling Air line.

''It's directed at certain people, obviously,'' says Sandy Saemann, exec VP of L.A. Gear. Coincidentally, Nike also will run a Super Bowl ad to launch a shoe, -the Air 180.

L.A. Gear became the USA's No. 3 sneakers firm, behind Nike and Reebok International Ltd., by marketing fashion-oriented shoes that women loved. But the market turned more performance-oriented, -leaving L.A. Gear at a disadvantage. L.A. Gear surprised Wall Street on Monday with a fourth-quarter loss from selling leftover shoes at reduced prices. The stock fell 2 7/8 Monday, then dropped 1 Tuesday to $ 9 1/2.

With Catapult, L.A. Gear will have feet in both markets. ''Why can't shoe companies be both?'' Saemann says. ''Ford makes the Explorer, a slick little muscle truck for young men, and makes the Thunderbird for young women.''

Catapult will make its debut in a basketball version. Scheduled to follow this year: versions for sports such as tennis, running and cross-training.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO; color, AP; PHOTO; b/w
 
CUTLINE: KARL MALONE: Utah Jazz star to help launch Catapult. CUTLINE: IN ACTION: Catapult prepares for liftoff.


TYPE: Advertising and Marketing


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

939 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)


April 26, 1992, Sunday, FINAL EDITION


Fun & Games


BYLINE: HERALD NEWS SERVICES


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. F1


LENGTH: 256 words


 

DIAMOND JUBILATION How strong have the Toronto Blue Jays been in recent years, even though the club has never gone all the way? Consider this statistic: If the period from 1983 to 1991 had been one endless nine-year season, the Blue Jays would have had an outrageous 37-game lead over the next-best team in the American League.

GOOD NEWS AND BAD NEWS

When he won the Masters, Fred Couples' earnings for the golf season reached $ 1,008,162. This made him the sixth player in PGA Tour history to get to the seven-figure mark for a year, but he did it in the shortest amount of time. On the other hand, it has to be a bit deflating for Couples to know his record surge put him just a little ahead of the average major league baseball salary.

THAT'S SHOE BUSINESS Consumer Reports is out with ratings of 32 brands of running shoes and the Nike Air 180 model was ranked No. 2 for men. "Toe box was like a slipper," said one runner.

There's one catch to that lofty rating, though. The report notes that Nike's No. 2 shoe costs nearly twice as much as the No. 1 rated shoe, Saucony Jazz 3000, and the No. 3 regarded shoe for men, Avia ARC 2040MZ.

You don't suppose Nike having all those high-priced athletes on the advertising payroll has something to do with that? A ROYAL PAIN Wiseguy of the week award goes to ESPN's Dan Patrick, who broadcast this report about the 1-16 Kansas City Royals: "The Royals have optioned second baseman Terry Shumpert to (triple-A) Omaha," he said, "and that's a promotion."

Ouch.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 CanWest Interactive, a division of
CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved

 

942 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


 July 3, 1991


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.
 
  

What makes it so cool?
 
    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.
 
    And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, the Nike Air Jordan and the Nike Quantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.
 
    According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.
 
    It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.
- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Times Publishing Company

 

943 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


July 3, 1991, Wednesday, City Edition


Pumped up


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


SECTION: FLORIDIAN; AFTER A FASHION; Pg. 3D


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.
 
  

What makes it so cool?
 
    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.
 
    And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, the Nike Air Jordan and the Nike Quantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.
 
    According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.
 
    It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.
- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO, Philadelphia Inquirer MICHAEL S. WIRTZ; Child wearing pair of Reeboks jumps


Times Publishing Company

 

944 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


 July 3, 1991


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.

    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.

He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Times Publishing Company

 

946 of 998 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


 July 3, 1991


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.
 
  

What makes it so cool?
 
    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.
 
    And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, the Nike Air Jordan and the Nike Quantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.
 
    According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.
 
    It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.
- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Times Publishing Company

 

948 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 16, 1991, Saturday


SPORTS BUSINESS: DAVID DAVIDSON; Renovations for Omni would cost $ 3 million-plus


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION C; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 717 words


Omni president/general manager Bob Dhue, citing competition from the Lakewood Amphitheater and the impending opening of the Georgia Dome in 1992, has proposed a major renovation of the 18-year-old arena.

In a presentation to the Atlanta-Fulton County Recreation Authority this week, Dhue outlined improvements and suggested bonds be approved to finance construction, since The Omni stands on public property. He emphasized The Omni would be responsible for the debt service and estimated the cost at between $ 3 million and $ 5 million.

With recreation authority approval, construction could start as early as this summer and be complete well before the Georgia Dome opens. 

Among the proposals:

- Convert interior concession stands to box suites, increasing the number from 12 to 32;

- Knock out segments of the exterior walls and rebuild affected concession stands;

- Double the restroom area;

- Widen the concourse.

Dhue said expansion of seating capacity from the current 16,600 was considered, but it was deemed unnecessary because the average attendance for 180 to 200 events per year is 11,000.

"To be competitive, we need to update," Dhue said. "The Georgia Dome people have said they'd like to host college basketball games, SEC, ACC and NCAA tournaments, and as many as 12 rock concerts per year. Those aren't new events. We've hosted all those events, so we'd like to be at speed when the Dome opens."

BON APPETIT: The Braves haven't wasted any time formulating plans under new

general manager John Schuerholz's orders to improve food quality at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium this season. A new food court to be located along the gates nearest home plate will feature for the first time fried and grilled chicken, french fries, grilled hamburgers and Italian sausage. There also will be a Beers of the World stand featuring imports in addition to the domestics available elsewhere in the stadium. . . . "Being a Braves fan isn't the toughest thing about living in Atlanta," says Ron Snyder, vice president for sports sales and marketing for TBS. "Selling advertising to Braves games is tougher."

FOOTING THE BILL: Georgia's Andy Landers was the nation's first women's basketball coach to get a shoe contract after the Lady Bulldogs won the NIT in 1981. Previously, Nike - acting on a suggestion from men's basketball coach Hugh Durham - provided Landers's team with 48 pairs of shoes annually. When Converse offered Landers $ 2,000 plus shoes for the season following the NIT, Nike matched it. Landers now receives over more than $ 12,000 per year, FROM from Nike, including $ 2,000 in merchandise, from Nike, plus shoes for his team. . . . Anheuser-Busch has reached a $ 5 million agreement with the U.S. Olympic Committee to serve as the organization's exclusive "malt beverage" - not beer - sponsor.

HIGH ON SPORTS: The High Museum is seeking a $ 125,000 sponsor for "The Sporting Life," an exhibition of 155 sports images spanning 125 years scheduled for May 16-Sept. 13, 1992. It's the first major exhibit surveying the relationships between photography, sports and culture in the U.S., Europe and the Soviet Union. The exhibit also is scheduled for Springfield, Mass., Wilmington, Del., Buffalo and, tentatively, Indianapolis.

BLOCKBUSTER DEALS: "A lot of people thought we were crazy to create what was then the 19th bowl game," says Richard Giannini, president of the Raycom Management Group. But the numbers are in and Raycom is certifiably sane: The Blockbuster Bowl will pay $ 1.6 million each to Florida State and Penn State, sixth-largest per-team payout this year. It had the seventh-highest TV rating, beating three New Year's Day games, and the fourth-largest crowd among all bowls. The crowd also was the second-largest ever at Joe Robbie Stadium behind the 1989 Super Bowl. . . . Blockbuster Video CEO Wayne Huizenga recently completed a stock manuever with Merrill Lynch geared toward raising capital to bring a major league baseball franchise to the Miami area. If, as Huizenga expects, Tampa-St. Petersburg and Denver get the two expansion franchises now up for grabs, he would like to buy the Pittsburgh Pirates - at a price of $ 100 million to $ 140 million, including as much as $ 50 million in


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

950 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Ottawa Citizen


July 26, 1992, Sunday, FINAL EDITION


Bubka casts shadow over Jordan; Pole vaulter's star shines as bright as Dream Team's guiding light


BYLINE: BILL UTTERBACK; SCRIPPS HOWARD NEWS SERVICE


SECTION: SPORTS PLUS; (SPORTS); Pg. D2


DATELINE: BARCELONA


A press conference featuring Michael Jordan and Sergei Bubka may have amplified global opinion, or at least the global media's opinion, of the athletes' prominence.

Jordan and Bubka are part of the Air Nike promotional campaigns which have taken over the top floor of the hotel Torre Catalunya where daily media gatherings monitor the progress of some of their 100-plus U.S. track athletes and 12 or so from many of the other countries.

There were 39 television cameras in the auditorium, giving the news conference the look of a presidential news conference. Only some of these cameras were from Finland and Austria and Japan. 

But Saturday's press conference took place at the Palacio Balana cinema. In front of the theatre a six-metre-long balloon of an Air Nike sneaker sat atop of a parked bus. The theatre marquee that only days before had advertised The Hand that Rocks the Cradle now had huge red letters proclaiming JORDAN-BUBKA.

When Jordan and Bubka landed in a residential district of Barcelona on Saturday, they confounded the neighbors and the regulars at the Bar Felipe.

People stared from balconies of 10-storey brick apartment houses, where yellow and red Catalan flags were draped next to laundry. They looked with wonder at the scene below, where a Nike bus blared rock 'n' roll and workers handed out hundreds of caps.

The first six questions at the press conference were directed at Bubka. The voices spoke with varied accents. They asked about his health, his training, his goals, his homeland. The reporters were clearly intrigued by the Ukranian pole vaulter.

Jordan, the American basketball/marketing superstar, sat quietly and listened. He is the star of "The Dream Team," but he may not be the brightest star in the 1992 Olympic Games.

Bubka has earned his place next to Jordan. Earlier this year, he set the world record at 20 feet, one-half inch. It was his 30th world record, indoors and outdoors. He won the Olympic gold medal in 1988. He has won six world titles.

Bubka is so dominant that he rarely concerns himself with other competitors.

"When I was younger, the other competitors made me go higher . now, my main competition is the height."

Bubka said he has two sources of motivation in Barcelona.

First, because of the political changes of recent years, he is competing for his native Ukraine instead of the Soviet Union.

"When an athlete wins the gold medal, they must play the anthem of his native country and raise the flag of his native country. For me, it must be Ukraine. That will be very satisfying."

Bubka is also driven by the Olympic stage.

"This is my second Olympics. In Seoul (1988), it was not a very good competition for me. The weather was very bad. The wind was bad. I won the gold medal, but I did not reach the world record. In Barcelona, the weather will be better and it is my dream to win the gold medal and set a world record."

The key to Bubka's success is his athleticism. He long jumps, high jumps and sprints in practice.

"My coach wanted me to move from the pole vault to the decathlon, but I love the pole vault."

Bubka also employs a gymnastics coach.

"There are many elements of gymnastics in the pole vault."

Combine the speed of a sprinter, the burst of a jumper and the body control of a gymnast and the possibilities have Bubka thinking about 20-8 or 21-0.

"(21-0) is possible, but it would be difficult," he said. "But by improving my body and improving my technique, I think it is possible to jump higher."

The only flaw in the plan is a foot injury that forced him to withdraw from a meet earlier this month.

"Right now, there is just a little bit of pain."

Falling from a height of 19 or 20 feet, year and year, could break down a man's body. But Bubka feels he is strong enough to persist.

"I know people think it will be difficult to keep jumping until I'm 32, but I think I will be jump in Atlanta (in the 1996 Olympics)."

There is also a financial motivation to keep jumping. The money he earns from endorsements and competition will take care of his family in the future. The political changes in the former Soviet Union have allowed him to bank more of his earnings.

"For many years when I was jumping, I did not make good money. Most of it went to the country. Now I can make some money, but that's not why I jump. I jump for love of sports. Money is second."

Aside from his goals of world records, gold medals and financial security, he has another objective. He has two sons and he wants to get their attention.

"One day they want to play basketball. The next they want to golf. I keep hoping they will try the pole vault. Maybe it will happen some day."

(Bill Utterback is a sportswriter for The Pittsburgh Press.)

(With files from the Canadian Press and Southam News)


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1992


LENGTH: 808 words


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

951 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Newsweek


August 10, 1992 , UNITED STATES EDITION


The Money Games


BYLINE: BY FRANK DEFORD


SECTION: OLYMPICS; Summer Olympics 92; Pg. 18


LENGTH: 1321 words


HIGHLIGHT: Barcelona was a great show, lacking only a villain. The sponsors smiled.


All in all, we see now that there was a place for Communism in this world, and it was at the Olympics.

So, for two lousy weeks, couldn't we at least revive Communism, make it another official Worldwide Olympic Sponsor and get the juices flowing here again? But no, we've traded a wonderful dramatic conflict between Good and Evil, Capitalism and Socialism, for what? For Nike vs. Reebok. That's for what.

The best we can do for a villain is Charles Barkley and maybe some heady little Chinese children. (A billion Chinese may wonder when Communism ever left, but hey, we're talking about television here.) The whole earth's economy is going to hell, and the only issue in Barcelona is how rich is the International Olympic Committee getting. The most popular competition in tow is to watch the Dream Tam pick wings off flies. For the first time since '72, there aren't any boycotts. Even South Africa is back. Even Castro dropped in. This Olympics is so fat and happy, the Klingons could get in team handball. 

Oh, to be sure, there are always a few nit-pickers in any crowd that is only allowed to use Visa cards. Spoilsports. Speaking more or less on behalf of Juan Antonio Samaranch, the hometown Barcelona boy who is president pro eternity of The Games, Barkley -- El Gordo, The Fat One -- answered Olympic critics thusly one day: "Why don't they take their ass-whipping-like people and go home?"

Why indeed not? Well, as much as the Dream Teamers may seem to NBC to be like those starlets who make folks happy by removing their tops at the Cannes Film Festival, others see the NBA heroes as representative of all that is rotten with the Kodak Olympics. "They may be your Dream Team," said Mike Moran of the U.S. Olympic Committee, "but they're my nightmare." Where is the old Olympic spirit? What became of yesteryear's noble amateurs? Why can't these multimillionaires live in the Bausch & Lomb Olympic Village instead of their fancy "palacio hotel" and learn love and fellowship there? Well, answered Dreamer John Stockton: "the Olympic spirit to me is to beat your opponents, not live with them."

And so the Dreamers outscored Angola 46-1 over one stretch, winning 116-48, and next coasted over Croatia, its most formidable opponent, 103-70, and then whipped Germany and Brazil by other similar scores that read like what happens to a stock when the market crashes.

Magic Johnson, Magia, was magnificent. He said all the right things and did all the best things. He was like Olga Korbut and Jesse Owens and Eleanor Holm and Jim Thorpe all rolled into one. It was telling. He strained his right knee early in the Croatian game and missed the balance of that game and all of the next two. And although this left America without a point guard, the wheel kept right on turning. In fact, the first 15 minutes of the German game was quite possibly the most surgically brilliant exhibition of team sport ever put on display. But somehow it was different without Earvin Johnson.

The fans understood that. Barkley was the heavy, and the other Dreamers were admired artists. Yet from the moment the great team arrived, Magic was the only one who really connected with the people. The NBA's critics couldn't see past that irony, that for all the obvious gross excess of Team Dream, when No. 15 was on the court, only then did The Games come closest to the exuberant joy that we always hope they will be. Then they truly have been the Magic Olympics; it's the rest of the time they've been only the Philips Olympics or the 3M Olympics.

Michael Jordan was representative in his own way, too. Ever since Peter Ueberroth instructed the IOC in how to obtain strength through sponsorship, everything at the Time/Sports Illustrated Olympics has been up for sale. Reebok bought the rights to the United State's victory uniforms. Jordan then declared his allegiance to Nike, saying he would not go to the victory stand if forced to be garbed in the hated Reebok attire.

The USOC countered with an ultimatum forcing all American winners to dress properly Reebokian, which was just as well with Nike officials, who had, privately, cringed that Jordan could have been so obtuse. But the company is such a huge international sporting power that soon it found itself mired in another money mess.

Michael Johnson, the odds-on favorite to win the 200-meter gold, did not even try to qualify in the 400. Johnson remains, however, Nike's biggest U.S. star, and when Mel Rosen, the U.S.-team coach, and long on the Nike payroll, suddenly named Johnson to the four-by-400-meter relay team, suspicions were everywhere voiced that Nike man Rosen had been pressured by Nike to put the Nike star -- and Nike track shoes -- in another event.

Although Steve Miller, Nike's "athletic director," lustily denied any such allegations, the other 400 runners had a mean screaming match with coach Rosen. Worse, those American track-team members who don't enjoy dual citizenship with Nike were then furious to find Michael Johnson Nike T shirts distributed by the USOC itself to everyone on the team. Steve Lewis, Johnson's relay teammate, threw his gift shirt on the floor, screaming: "Shoot, I'd rather put Homey the Clown on my shirt than Michael Johnson."

This is the kind of stuff that becomes important at the Olympics after nationalism, terrorism and Communism cease to matter. And, says Steve Miller of Nike: "I think it'll get worse before it gets better." Money will do this to the Panasonic Olympics.

Money has not, of course, been de facto evil for The Games. But Barcelona shows all the more how, even, a split-level Olympics has emerged, with the few glamour sports getting all the attention and all the dough, while the other sports go begging.

Then, too, nobody has the foggiest idea where all that money goes. The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, struggling manfully to find out what its city was getting in bed with for the next four years, finally gave up and designed a computer analysis to seek some inkling of Olympic finances. The computer estimates $ 2.4 billion revenue in this Olympiad, $ 3 billion the next. Hundreds of millions are left over somewhere after The Games are put on. Samaranch loves to refer to the Olympics, grandly, as a "movement," but what it surely is is the most powerful and unaccountable private organization to have existed since the Roman church on the day before Luther tacked up some of his thoughts at Wittenberg.

Samaranch, 72, just had his arm twisted to seek another term as president -- although he expects to be called His Excellency. He is a schooled politician, who co-opts any internal opposition -- most recently, say, from the likes of the heads of the track and skating federations --- by railroading them onto the IOC and smothering them thereafter.

As the first week at Barcelona showed, Samaranch is absolutely in the saddle, and the American presence is everywhere declining. As recently as 1968, 20 percent of medals went to Americans. By Seoul it was 13 percent, and the gold diffusion should continue here. Money from Western corporations is flowing in to help the athletes in former Soviet-bloc countries. Even poorer countries have increased funding for training. That's not bad.

Once, not so long ago, the Olympics were a model for the battle of military superpowers. Today, for all the emphasis on money in the United States Postal Service Olympics, it's only appropriate that The Games seem to pattern themselves after the economic world, with the United States only first among equals. Still, for all that historical symmetry, it'd be more fun if Fortress America yet had The Evil Empire left to try and beat on the Coca-Cola Olympic field of play.
 
BASKETBALL
The Dream Team took no prisoners. In the first four games, the average margin for the U.S. was 47 points.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo 1, Jordan soars and scores; Photo 2, The Dream Team's bad-boy Barkley leans on an Angolan opponent; Photos 1 and 2, BY JOHN McDERMOTT


Copyright 1992 Newsweek

 

953 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


July 10, 1992, Friday, Late Edition - Final
Correction Appended


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
CBS Knows Bo Knows Its Viewers


BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott


SECTION: Section D; Page 9; Column 1; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 792 words


BO knew football, alas. Bo has known baseball, and vows to know it again. And, of course, Bo knows advertising. Now, CBS is audaciously trying to convince viewers that Bo also knows enough about television to serve as a sort of critic.

"Bo Knows Shows" is the theme of what CBS executives say is their first on-the-air promotional campaign featuring a celebrity spokesman who endorses the network's programming. The campaign, which will be introduced with teaser commercials tomorrow, stars Bo Jackson, the professional athlete who has been sidelined in his dual-sport career by a serious hip injury. 

The commercials, which will run on CBS through the fall, will begin in earnest on Tuesday, during CBS's telecast of the 1992 baseball All-Star Game. They are the latest in a flock of ads from the television networks to sell their series in the same manner that television advertisers sell soup, soap and soft drinks.

CBS, which during the 1991-92 season leaped from third to first place in prime-time ratings, has been the most aggressive in adapting the tactics of packaged-goods marketing to broadcasting.

"Part of what we're selling is not CBS, but an attitude of leadership," George F. Schweitzer, senior vice president of CBS marketing and communications, said yesterday during an interview at CBS's headquarters in midtown Manhattan. "And promotion plays a big role in that."

He added: "We have a saying, 'You are what you air.' People watch programs, not networks. But networks do have personalities."

Joseph Abruzzese, senior vice president of network sales, said the campaign would enable CBS to tap into consumers' avid interest in Mr. Jackson's comeback attempts.

"People want to see him succeed," he said. And in advertising and media, as in sports, nothing succeeds like success.

In its humorous tone and fast-paced style, the CBS campaign is evocative of, and derived from, Mr. Jackson's award-winning "Bo Knows" advertising for Nike Inc., created by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. CBS sought, and received, the blessings of Nike and Wieden to follow in their footsteps; they even lent CBS Joe Pytka, the director of many of Nike's best-known spots. Nike and Wieden also approved a commercial in the "Bo Knows" style, starring Mr. Jackson, that Ogilvy & Mather Direct in New York created in 1990 for A.T.& T.

Such authorized homages are a shrewd strategy, according to Brian T. Murphy, editor and publisher of The Sports Marketing Letter in Westport, Conn.

"Nike has a big investment in Bo," he said, "so they have a real interest in trying to get value out of that relationship."

Mr. Murphy believes Mr. Jackson is "still a star" in terms of endorsements, despite his inactivity.

"The potential is still there," he added. "And one thing that must be remembered is that if he makes a comeback, and he excels, that would be one of the greatest comeback stories in the history of sports.

"And that would make him torridly hot."

Torrid was an apt word for Mr. Jackson's ad career, which had soared since he appeared in his first "Bo knows" Nike commercial in 1989. He then divided his ad work between Nike and other marketers like A.T.& T. and Pepsi-Cola.

After Mr. Jackson was injured playing football for the Los Angeles Raiders last year, there was speculation that his career as an endorser would be over. Instead, he has remained in the spotlight, in large part because of a hilarious Nike commercial last summer about his rehabilitation regimen to recover from his injury.

That premise is also used by CBS. If Mr. Jackson is not playing sports, what is he doing? Working out in a bid to return to the Chicago White Sox -- and watching television.

"It'll be quite a while before Bo can hit or run or field like he used to," Mr. Jackson says in a teaser spot, using his characteristic third-person references to himself.

Holding up a sign that says, "Watch the All-Star Game on CBS," he adds, "But Bo can still pitch."

The funniest of the spots shows Mr. Jackson in his training room, doing one-armed push-ups as "60 Minutes" plays on a giant television set.

"Bo loves working out during '60 Minutes,' " he says. "When the show's over, Bo knows it's time to do push-ups with his other arm."

The arrangement between CBS and Nike to use Mr. Jackson has no quid pro quo involving advertising, Mr. Abruzzese said, adding that CBS "already has a big share of their sports advertising."

Indeed, Mr. Jackson's CBS spots will share air time during the All-Star Game with Wieden's latest "Bo Knows" commercial for Nike. Called "Bo's Hip," it will contrast his active life with that of a typical viewer.

"What are you and your good hip doing right now?" the spot asks. The answer: "Watching commercials."


LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1992, Monday


CORRECTION:

A picture caption with the Advertising column in Business Day on Friday about the new CBS promotion "Bo Knows Shows," referred to it incorrectly. It involves television commercials, not a television show.


GRAPHIC: Photo: The logo for Bo Jackson's new television show on CBS. (CBS)


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

956 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)


September 21, 1991, Saturday, 1* EDITION


Nike Town is retail theatre U.S.A.: A running start: NIKE: store aimed at middle and upper-income campers


BYLINE: DAVID SMITH VANSUN


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C1


LENGTH: 1722 words


DATELINE: Portland, Ore.


There's the rhythmic thump of a basketball on a gym floor and the whack . . . whack . . . whack of a tennis match. Tropical fish glide behind a clear wall while, elsewhere, a tennis racket personally ruined by John McEnroe is displayed.

Then, of course, the shoes. Running shoes. Tennis shoes. Basketball shoes. Golf shoes. Hiking shoes. Wrestling shoes. Soccer shoes. Shoes that bristle with static energy, shoes that gleam under spotlights, flanked by racks of lycra clothing in neon and black.

Sounds, sights - and products.

Just Do It. 

This is Nike Town, America's new kid on the retailing block that blends '70s Disco decor, straight-up '80s consumerism with '90s marketing savvy into a virtual reality shopping experience aimed at people with bucks who like to hum when they cruise the aisles.

Sounds, images, colors and computers converge here in a store devoted exclusively to sports and an atmosphere that puts the shopper in the starting block, on the 14th tee or slam-dunking with the scoreboard showing 112-111.

Or reaching for their wallets and purses.

Just Do It.

"A lot of people do like to shop and when they shop, atmosphere is important," says store manager Mary Burns, a mid-Westerner with a strong merchandising resume.

Nearby, Tom and Donna Sunderland, up from Stockton, Calif., flip through the racks, their tanned faces glowing at the goods.

"This store," says Tom, "is just the greatest."

Adds Donna: "I felt like jogging after being in here for only a few seconds. It really pumps you up."

Nike Town, opened last November by Nike Inc., is retail theatre, one of those things only the U.S. of A. would do, or want to do - meaning it's risky and expensive.

But doubts that the entire exercise is just a doomed, dippy marketing balloon dissolve, somewhat, when Burns pulls out some figures.

On a recent Saturday in August, 5,000 people went through the store. It has a capacity for 350 shoppers.

She calculates Nike Town draws at least 30,000 customers a week, or about 150,000 people a month.

It opened Nov. 21, so let's say 1.5 million people to date have trooped through Town.

That's 1.5 million through a store that is only 4,570 square metres (15,000 square feet).

Lineups to get in here are not uncommon and the store has become a major tourist attraction for the city.

"It's finally put Portland on the map," declares Sandy Macomber, librarian at the Oregonian newspaper a few blocks away.

Yesssssss!

*

Nike Inc. was founded by Phil Knight (a middle distance runner) and Bill Bowerman (his coach). It is the biggest sports and fitness company in the U.S. with net profits in 1989 reaching $ 167 million. They've sold five million pairs of Air Pegasus, a Nike running shoe, alone.

Nike Inc.'s world headquarters were established in the nearby Portland suburb of Beaverton in 1979. Nike (rhymes with Mikey) is the Greek goddess of victory. The Swoosh curve in the trademark was designed by a Portland State University student.

Jimmie Connors won the Wimbledon and the U.S. Open wearing Nikes. In 1983, Jean Benoit shattered the women's world marathon time wearing Nikes. Chicago Bulls superstar Michael Jordan made them a cult shoe.

Nike, it follows, treats sports and shoes very, very seriously.

"A couple of years ago Nike decided that it wanted to build a store that would represent their collections or their sports categories the way they designed and developed them," says Burns.

From the concept emerged the town - resist the temptation to call it Smelly Runnerville - a two-storey, 4,570-square-metre store in downtown Portland. For Lower Mainlanders, it is about a seven-hour drive south down the I-5.

The idea of Nike Town was to merchandise footwear, apparel and accessories - 95 per cent of what is in the Nike catalogue is on display in the store - not just to consumers, but to retailers as well.

Nike Town, Burns said, was supposed to be fun and so unique in retail, "that it was more than just a store."

More than just a store.

Let's say you want to buy a wet suit for sailboarding. At Nike Town you stroll to the Aqua Gear pavilion, the name for each area selling a different sports product.

Here, you see the tropical fish. At your feet, a multi-screen image - on the floor! you can walk on it! - depicts scenes of rippling water. The background music is the sound of rushing water, virtually real. You can hear the water, if not the cash register.

"The uniqueness of the atmos-phere of each sports category is felt when you walk in," says Burns.

The products sit on a surfboard shelf. The salesperson will be a sailboarder, dressed in sports gear, who will push a few IBM computer buttons to check the inventory and order your purchase, which is delivered smoothly via large acrylic tubes from the basement.

There is no disappearing act by the salesman to find the goods. They remain with the customer, discussing the product, signing them up for the next sailboarding competition or just chatting about the latest sports scores. It's called schmoozing.

*

Gordon Thompson was hired by Nike Inc. as creative director of Nike Town. For inspiration, he visited the stage set of the movie Back to the Future, which based a lot of its action around a town square. He'd also visited many older European towns. Ditto, town squares.

Thus, Nike Town includes maybe a dozen pavilions linked by a common area, an elevator and a catwalk. A two-storey town was born. The entrance and passageway lighting was kept Nightclub Dark, with each pavilion becoming an oasis of bright lights, a palette of color and products - moving the shopper from dark to light. Get it?

In addition to the merchandise, the layout and the sound track, a museum element was introduced to entice shoppers.

They can gaze at a basketball signed by Michael Jordan or Nolan "Tex" Ryan's shoes and hat. Sports heros like Bo Jackson or the Portland Blazers visit the store to autograph equipment or offer advice, all adding to the sports aura, all bringing shoppers through the door.

Developing Nike Town as an "event" rather than a retail centre carried the risk that people will look, rather than buy. It was a risk that Nike, competing with the likes of Adidas, Reeboks, LA Gear and Brooks, could accept.

Says Burns: "We didn't know on day one when we opened if there would be a line of people at the door. We didn't know if people would find it interesting. But the first two weeks we had lines a block long to get in the store. We couldn't get everybody in.

"Right now I would say that every Sunday morning now, there are at least 70 people outside the front door, waiting to get in. It's amazing. We are a tourist attraction, people bring their cameras to take pictures."

Nike won't release any sales or dollar figures, but Burns says, "we are definitely meeting our expectations in that area."

One indication that Nike Town is approaching black ink came when the company announced it will open another Nike Town in Chicago, a 50,000-square-foot store, next May and plans additional Nike Towns for New York and Europe.

Less enthusiastic about such retail theatre is Toronto retailing analyst John Winter.

"You have to realize that the sports shoe market has become very competitive. If Nike can get an edge by selling through an attractive outlet. That's fine. If you can get an edge, it's fine for a year or two. Concept retailers have a very short shelf life.

"There's a lot of distractions, from salesgirls wearing shorts to music and atmosphere and all that. They all detract from the fact that it's $ 150 US you're paying for shoes made in the Phillipines by someone paid 75 cents an hour.

"But it's merchandising. Brilliant merchandising."

*

Nike Town is also aimed at retailers who visit the store to draw ideas from the racking, the presentation and the concept they can then apply to their own stores.

Nike doesn't advertise Nike Town, relying on word-of-mouth and media stories to do the rest after it trumpeted the official opening.

"The main reason is other retailers sell Nike products too and our intention is not to compete with them but to help and enhance the business totally. If Footlocker or Nordstrom wants to run the same product we have at 20 (per cent) off, that's good, that's okay, that's their business. We're here just to enhance what Nike is all about," says Burns.

"Is this the wave of the future? Well, it's a combination of design and merchandising, but also service. We've heard that over and over again. We went from a very service-oriented retail environment many years ago to self- service to 'wait a minute, people still really want service' especially with price points and technical products, they deserve to know why this costs what it costs and in order to do that, you have to service the customer."

Make no mistake, Nike Town is aimed squarely at middle and upper-income campers who don't flinch at a $ 360 US price tag for a Goretex running suit or at $ 225 US Air Super Dome AC6 hiking boots or $ 150 US Air Force 180 basketball runners.

Nike continues to operate a factory outlet seven kilometres away from Nike Town, where prices are 20 to 30 per cent lower.

Nike Town, says Burns, is for the customer, "who wants the atmosphere, wants the design and wants to be able to say, 'I bought it at Nike Town.' "

Heather Shannon, director of retailing for Ernst Young in Vancouver, observes that Nike Town typifies the polarization of retail stores in North America into either discount, bare bones-type stores or high end, service-oriented, experience-oriented outlets.

"It fits in well with that as an over-all trend," Shannon said. "And as far as demographics are concerned, people are demanding more from retailers and expecting more. As we age we get crankier and more demanding."

*

If you buy it at Nike Town, you may buy it from Ethan Egan, a twentysomething salesman and former Nordstrom salesman who jumped at the chance to work at Nike.

"I went to Nike classes in product knowledge before the store opened so we were all primed for opening day," says Egan, who pointed out the store's features during a stroll through each pavilion.

He jogs and plays soccer, skills that he uses daily in talking to customers. "I love it here," he says.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH



GRAPHIC: CONCEPT RETAILERS: 'There's lots of distractions'
PUMPED UP: Sounds, images, colors converge in total-sports store

Nike running shoe
