The New York Times


August 6, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final


Market Place;
Athletic Shoes Without the Fads


BYLINE: By Stephanie Strom


SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 3; Financial Desk


LENGTH: 859 words


WHILE the rest of the world is watching the Olympics, Steven Nichols has his sights on the United States Open tennis tournament later this summer.

As president and chief executive of K-Swiss Inc., maker of classic white-on-white leather tennis shoes favored by preppies and college freshmen, Mr. Nichols is sitting the Olympics out, determined not to stage a footwear industry version of the basketball game between the United States Dream Team and Angola. 

"We'll probably sell twice as many shoes in our booth at the U.S. Open as either Nike or Reebok," Mr. Nichols said. "That's our territory. That's what we're good at."

K-Swiss is a company known for sticking to its knitting. Between 1966, when the company was founded by Swiss brothers who were World Cup skiers, and 1987, K-Swiss made only that classic white tennis shoe, crafted from three pieces of leather, metal rings for lacing and a heavy, durable rubber sole.

Although Mr. Nichols has been introducing canvas shoes, children's shoes, and shoes for walking, hiking and basketball since he and some investors bought K-Swiss in a leveraged buyout in 1987, it has never developed the sexy image cultivated by most growth companies hyped by Wall Street.

Even its double-digit increases in earnings fail to impress the analysts, who use Nike and Reebok as yardsticks. "Over all, they're up about 18 percent in the second quarter," said Gary M. Jacobson, a footwear analyst at Kidder, Peabody. "That's O.K., but it's not anything to get excited about."

In comparison, he noted, Nike's second-quarter profits rose 20 percent. K-Swiss closed yesterday at $18.00, down 75 cents, in over-the-counter trading. Its price-earnings ratio is about 12; Nike's is about 17.

While most analysts expect K-Swiss to earn about $1.50 a share this year, a 12 percent increase over last year, much of the gain will come from a more favorable tax rate and lower interest payments. The company's minuscule size in comparison to a Nike or an L.A. Gear can present problems in its dealing with overseas factories, which may produce for all three companies.

K-Swiss's relative lack of clout with its suppliers, in fact, has hampered distribution recently, according to analysts.

"At a slightly lower price, this is an attractive growth company," said Alice A. Ruth, a footwear analyst with Montgomery Securities. "But they're small, and that has great disadvantages in this business."

The comparisons are frustrating to Mr. Nichols. With an advertising and promotional budget this year that is less than one-tenth the size of Nike's and one-twentieth that of Reebok, K-Swiss does not even try to contend with the industry's Goliaths. Together the two shoe giants control more than 50 percent of the $5.5 billion-plus domestic market for athletic shoes; K-Swiss has about 1.7 percent.

Instead, the company's sit-it-out strategy is a textbook example of niche marketing.

"The world doesn't need another Nike or Reebok," Mr. Nichols said. "It has two spectacular ones already."

K-Swiss deliberately aims at the blue-blooded end of the athletic shoe market, leaving Nike and Reebok to contend for the huge -- and fickle -- teen-age and fashion set. K-Swiss's Surf and Turf nautical shoe, a canvas version of its classic leather tennis shoe that sells for about $35, was the official shoe for the America's Cup this year.

Its first television advertising was shot in gritty black-and-white film with arias from "Madame Butterfly" as background music. And at $75 and $85 a pair its Si-18 tennis shoe is a best seller, thanks in part to tennis-playing matrons in places like Greenwich, Conn.; La Jolla, Calif., and Chicago's North Shore. "If it's upscale and snooty, that's just where we want to be," Mr. Nichols said.

While the company's refusal to get into high-tech, neon-encrusted athletic shoes frustrates many analysts, it protects K-Swiss and its retailers from the vicissitudes of fashion. Nike and Reebok change styles every few months, dictating demand by building in obsolescence.

That strategy means retailers may have to cut prices on old inventory, which puts pressure on their profit margins. K-Swiss's shoes rarely change, which, Mr. Nichols contends, means shoppers and retailers get a better value because K-Swiss prices are rarely marked down. A pair of men's Classics sells for about $55.

"Every once in a while we'll miss a little trend like neon or buckles and Velcro on the uppers," he concedes. "But our retailers know there's not a new innovation coming down the pike that is going to make their inventory worthless."

Eschewing fashion also means a smoother manufacturing cycle. In the first month of production of a newly designed shoe, about 25 percent of the output is defective, Mr. Nichols said. It takes about three months for a factory to get the process right.

Sales of K-Swiss shoes abroad grew 57 percent last year, and Mr. Nichols sees good growth opportunities in Europe and Japan, where the Classic has become a best seller.

"We're putting down stakes in territory we can be very good on," Mr. Nichols said. "Someday, we'll have a stake at the Olympics, too."


LOAD-DATE: August 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company

 

961 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 2, 1991, Sunday


A good role model isn't perfect; Black kids need more than big stars


SECTION: PERSPECTIVE; SECTION G; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 924 words


Reprinted from The Economist, a magazine published by Economist Newspaper Ltd. of London.

New York, it was once said, has Jews, Italians and Irish, so New York is manic, brassy and exciting. Chicago has Poles, Croats and Slovaks, so Chicago is sullen, defeated and oppressed.

But that was before Eastern Europe won its freedom; and before Michael Jordan, too. 

Jordan, 28, is the City of Broad Shoulders' latest hero. Even in the intense, slightly unbelievable athleticism of professional basketball, he does things that make you gasp.

Many knowledgeable judges reckon he is the most thrilling player ever to grace the court. George Will, a conservative columnist, has suggested, tongue only half in cheek, that (along with such luminaries as Frank Lloyd Wright and Aaron Copland) Jordan's face should grace high- denomination bank notes.

In previous years, Jordan has had to play on a Chicago Bulls team that collapsed when the going got tough - and in the National Basketball Association's playoffs, the going gets very tough indeed.

This year, however, the Bulls have swept all before them. Last week they completed a four-game rout of the Detroit Pistons - champions the past two years - in the NBA semifinals. This week they will play for the championship. Winning a championship ring would be the culmination of Jordan's career.

Professional basketball, more than any other American sport, is dominated by blacks. Since to play professional basketball at all you need great discipline, and to play it at Jordan's level you need extraordinary flair and imagination, it is hardly surprising that the great search for "role models" for black children should have fastened on the Bulls' star. Since Jordan is intelligent and articulate, notable for good sportsmanship and devoted to charitable work (though without ever seeming cloyingly goody-goody about it), he is an obvious choice.

There is, however, a catch - two catches, actually. The first is Jordan's association with Nike, America's leading maker of sneakers. Jordan has been endorsing Nike products since 1984: The Air Jordan shoe is Nike's best-selling line. He is not alone; other black heroes, like filmmaker Spike Lee and John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown University, also endorse Nike products.

What is wrong with that? According to Jesse Jackson, black America's most popular politician and a basketball fan, a lot. Nike, he argues, is promoting an "ethos of mindless materialism" by encouraging black children to buy sneakers (the latest Air Jordans cost $ 125) that they cannot afford. That sounds like killjoyism taken to the limit, but Jackson has a point.

It is not as if inner-city children buy just one pair of sneakers; the pressure from the street is to keep up with the latest fashions. Some youngsters own as many as 50 pairs of sneakers; one 14-year-old boy told The Washington Post that he spent $ 2,000 a year on shoes.; Sneakers used as lure

You do not need to be a genius to work out one of the most likely ways in which some inner-city youngsters come by such sums: It is by selling drugs. Some drug dealers use sneakers as a way of recruiting youngsters to their gangs; some gangs identify themselves by the sneakers they wear, or accept stolen sneakers as payment for drugs. There have even been incidents in which people have been murdered for their high- fashion basketball shoes.

Nike, to be fair, makes sure that its role-model endorsers like Jordan appear in advertisements warning kids off drugs and encouraging them to stay in school. But Jackson is entitled to wonder whether those messages are as strong as the ones coming from the street.

The bigger catch is in the very idea of role models. Behind the search for role models lies the assumption that only great men such as Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X or Jordan himself are worthy of emulation. When those idols are found to have feet of clay - and everyone who draws breath does - the pain of disenchantment can be profound.; Parents best role models

Jordan knows the pressure that role-modeling puts on him: "I'm not a perfect person," he has said. He agrees with Charles Barkley, another NBA star, that the most useful role models for children are not heroes like himself but their parents.

There is another drawback to role models. The majority of children have no chance of fame on the basketball court, or anywhere else. The veneration of sportsmen subtly denigrates more mundane but realistic goals - like getting a steady job.

What blacks need is not supermen but economic opportunity; and, as two recent sets of studies by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute have shown (as if the point needed laboring), anyone who thinks that they have such opportunity in the same measure as whites is deluding himself.

None of this should be taken as an excuse to denigrate Jordan's talent. But it is a shame that America's obsession with sports means that his kind of talent is celebrated more than that of other men and women.

As the city prepared for the NBA Finals, Chicago magazine ran an article on Cyrus Colter, who in his long life has been one of Chicago's leading black lawyers, academics and public servants, and who, when most men would have put on the slippers, took to writing award-winning novels, short stories and poems. His has been an extraordinary tale; it is probably known to fewer than 1 percent of the young blacks who worship Michael Jordan.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Color photo: Chicago Bulls' Michael Jordan goes for the basket / file


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

963 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


February 13, 1991, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


Bo knows he's a hit with kids


BYLINE: AP


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. C6


LENGTH: 370 words


DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.


 
   PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - Baseball and football star Bo Jackson delighted a group of high school journalists yesterday stories about his rise to fame and comments on his career.

Jackson held a news conference for the students at Nike Town, the new shoe store opened last fall by Nike Inc., one of Jackson's advertising employers. 

Jackson continually spoke with wonder about how a poor boy from rural Alabama could grow up and become a rich, famous man. "A nappy-headed kid who threw rocks better than some people could shoot a gun," is how Jackson described himself then, and a family man who loves children is how he sees himself now.

A charmer

With two of his own children watching from a balcony above, Jackson charmed the group with an easy demeanor - a contrast to his sometimes shy and surly dealings with professional media.

Jackson walked in to Nike Town wearing an earring and a sweatsuit. As soon as he started joking about the "nice, sunny city of Portland," he put the students at ease.

When asked to introduce his family, Jackson said his oldest son was nicknamed "Spud," his younger son was "a human tornado," and his infant daughter decided herself not to fly to Portland because of an ear infection.

Jackson's humor continually broke through a deadpan delivery and a grave expression. A student asked what Jackson wanted to be remembered for, and the response was a furrowed brow, a glare and a mock-serious:

"Am I going anywhere I should know about?"

Some of the questions were facile:

Which is Jackson's favorite TV commercial?

"The last one I did, the multisport Jackson. They wedged me in that sports car, and it took three people to pull me out. The Indy 500 is not in my future."

Some were serious:

What about the use of steroids in sports?

"I don't know anything about that. I would not know what a steroid is if you came up here and smacked me in the face with it. Go ask (sprinter) Ben Johnson about that. Bo don't know steroids."

Enjoys his work

And some were obvious:

Which sport do you enjoy more, football or baseball?

"You wouldn't believe how many times I've been asked that. I enjoy my work as far as the business aspect goes. It's my job."


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

965 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The New York Times


August 11, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final


Flashy New Swimwear for Feet as Well as Bodies


BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN


SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 50; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page


LENGTH: 498 words


In recent summers, men have headed to the beach clad in snug bikini trunks, feet bare or shod in loose-fitting flip-flops. But in the summer of 1991, snug trunks are outnumbered by loose-fitting briefs. And it's the new beach shoes of choice that are worn snug.

Nike's Aqua Gear collection of coordinated swimwear and water sport shoes has kept fashion and sales pace with the increased popularity of sports like wind surfing and wave running (the latter refers to riding a water vehicle that looks like a snowmobile). These sports call for steady footing and, of course, the pulled-together bearing that matching shorts and shoes imply. 

 Nike's Aqua Socks, actually slip-on shoes, consist of neoprene soles with treads, built-in arch support and reinforced toes and molded heels, with ankle-high uppers of an airy spandex mesh in flashy neon colors.

This summer, they're not worn just by the sports-minded.

Aqua Socks protect feet from hot sand, sharp shells and glass, and give traction on mucky lake bottoms and slippery rocks. In Central Park, they're worn by young men scaling the outcroppings on mountain bikes.

They have caught on at health clubs, especially in aqua aerobics classes, and in locker rooms, to prevent foot infections. And they're comfortable. A man in a business suit was recently spotted wearing a pair while walking along Park Avenue.

"I am constantly sold out," Robert Ottofaro, owner of Panda Sport, 311 77th Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, said of Aqua Socks. "The foot can't breathe in most activewear shoes," he said, adding that "your feet do not get fatigued, as in flip-flops, where there is no support."

Baby Aqua Socks, in sizes 2 through 8, and youth and junior sizes are $25; adult Aqua Socks are $29; Aqua Socks, Too -- with a Velcro closure over the instep for extra support -- are $35. All come in vivid color combinations that complement Nike's equally colorful Aqua Shorts, in wave-textured nylon taffeta, $36. A Du Pont Coolmax liner wicks away perspiration, and mesh pockets allow drainage. Aqua Gear is sold at Paragon Sporting Goods, 867 Broadway (18th Street) and at Foot Locker stores around the New York region.

Speedo America also makes a popular beach shoe and nylon swim shorts. The shorts come in 15-, 16- and 17-inch lengths, with mesh pockets and drawstring waistbands, in a variety of colors and prints. All are $36 at Paragon, Macy's, A. & S., Bloomingdale's and the six Herman's World of Sporting Goods stores in Manhattan.

Speedo's Surf Walker comes in high- and low-top versions, for children and adults. The high top comes in black or turquoise, $40. The ankle-high slipper comes in two-tone black and turquoise or black and yellow, $34. Children's sizes start at 12.

The high-top Surf Walker is somewhat denser and more structured than Aqua Socks and offers less ventilation. A popular boating shoe, it offers support and durability. The molded insole is removable for easy cleaning.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 1991


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photos: Speedo's Surf Walker, with spandex mesh upper, nubbed sole and ankle and instep support, $40.; Nike Aqua Shorts, $36, come in colors to complement their Aqua Socks.; Aqua Socks, $25-$35, come in neon-colored spandex mesh, with treaded neoprene soles. (Martin Jacobs; Nike Aqua Gear)


Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

971 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


July 30, 1992, Thursday


BARCELONA OLYMPICS OLYMPIC GAMES Basketball points News and notes on the basketball competition Barkley: Support women


SECTION: SPORTS; Section F; Page 4


LENGTH: 483 words


Charles Barkley, who behaved himself relatively well during the U.S. men's basketball game against Germany on Wednesday night (he only confronted a referee once), said he plans to attend some of the women's games in a show of support. A frequent spectator at the women's games at St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia, where the 76ers have practiced for years, Barkley planned to urge several of his teammates to accompany him.

"It's so typical," Barkley said. "They don't support women's sports enough in America. They support the men, but not the women." 

Asked whether he planned to attend the women's 11 a.m. opener against Czechoslovakia, he hedged. "Uh, I heard Czechoslovakia's not too good. I may wait until they get farther along."

They hate four-year waits

Of the 12 U.S. women's players, 11 play professionally overseas. The 12th, Suzie McConnell, retired to have a baby. Women's pro basketball has failed in the United States and the American women aren't thrilled about having to wait every four years for an American audience. "I don't know what's special, besides wearing the red, white and blue," says three-time Olympian Teresa Edwards, who plays in Japan. "We go overseas to make our living and we come back and represent the country for nothing, you know? We don't get enough credit for that. The Japanese people feed me. Nobody in the U.S. feeds me. I don't make a penny here."

Needed: ideal scrimmages

Lynn Barry, vice-president of USA Basketball, said an ideal scrimmaging opponent for the women's Olympic team would be a boys' high school team - if they could check their egos at the gym entrance. "The problem is that they can't handle being beaten by the girls," said Barry, "and if they start playing too hard, we could get hurt. A perfect combination would be high school boys with college players' mentalities."

Warmup war continues

Both sides are taking hard-line positions in a dispute between the U.S. Olympic Committee and the U.S. basketball team over what to wear at medal ceremonies. Reebok has a contract with the USOC that all medal winners will wear a specially designed Reebok warmup suit after winning an Olympic medal. But Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley, both of whom are under contract to Nike, are outspoken in their desire not to wear the Reebok suit. Scottie Pippen, Chris Mullin, John Stockton and David Robinson also are U.S. players under contract to Nike. The USOC said no athlete who is not wearing this suit will appear in a ceremony. Some of the players say they must follow their contracts. "Us Nike guys are loyal to Nike because they pay us a lot of money," Barkley said Wednesday.

He's tops at table tennis

According to one member of USA Basketball's traveling delegation, Christian Laettner is holding his own. At table tennis. "He's the best player on the team," said the official, "so he's contributing something."


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922180174


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

973 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


August 15, 1991 Thursday


VFA dash revived


BYLINE: BARRETT D


LENGTH: 244 words


THE time-honored VFA half-time dash will be revived on Saturday at Coburg's City Oval.

Formerly known as the Dandy Dollar Dash, this year's series will be sponsored by Nike. 

Heats are to be held during the final two home-and-away matches and the first three weeks of the finals.

The 10 runners with the most points will take part in the final at Princes Park on grand final day on September 22.

President of the Victorian Runners and Trainers Association, John Evans, said the dash was a long-standing part of the VFA competition.

"It was a shame to see it go," Evans said.

"It's a prestigious race and one the pro runners really like to win." Evans had been seeking sponsorship for the race for much of the year after losing backing at the end of last season.

"Times are tough . . . the economy's tight," he said.

"We were pretty fortunate Nike came to the party."

He said the series would be a good stepping stone for the upcoming professional racing calendar.

Backmarker for the series will be Victorian hurdles champion Kevin Oakey.

The evergreen Doug Howey, a perennial finalist, is also competing.

Other runners of note include Chris Pegg, last season's Bendigo 5000 winner Tim Mason, and runner-up to Dean Capobianco in the 1990 Stawell Gift and the 1991 Melton Gift winner Perry Hannah.

Veteran NBL basketballer Al Green is a past winner of the VFA dash.

Bookmakers are expected to field on the final.

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Back in running . . . Nike representative George Lawlor (right) handsJohn Evans a sponsorship cheque for the reborn VFA dash yesterday.


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

975 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Strategy


November 02, 1992


Editorial One man's view


SECTION: Pg.4


LENGTH: 542 words


It is a rare bird these days who will talk about advertising without cant or pseudo-profundity, but they do exist. And when they speak, as British adman Tim Delaney did recently to Strategy, it is wise to pay attention.

Delaney, in Toronto recently to speak during the Newspaper Marketing Bureau's Extra Awards gala, is no seer, as he would be the first to admit. But he does have clearly thought out opinions about where he thinks advertising is heading and where this half-art, half-science will end up. 

The venerable British creative director and founder of his own shop, Leagas Delaney, is convinced massive change is coming to the advertising business, whether in Europe, North America or elsewhere. And so massive is this change, Delaney sees parallels between that and the crumbling of the state regimes in the former Soviet Union and its satellites. The communist-militarist dictatorships of Eastern Europe could no longer sustain their bureaucracies, their superstructures, Delaney says. So, too, with multinational advertising agencies and their enormous fixed overheads.

Delaney predicts the globe-girdling juggernauts of the business will falter and bring down with them their various adjuncts such as media shops and research houses. When or where this will occur remains problematic, Delaney says, but it is coming and could return advertising to the three-people-to-a-shop cottage industry it once was. Clients, Delaney says to emphasize his point, will only pay agencies to make advertising.

Delaney's outlook is not simplistic, nor is it apocalyptic. A cursory examination of business in Canada today reveals the companies that are surviving the second economic depression in 60 years are mostly small, nimble and fat-free. Why should advertising be any different?

Delaney is on equally stimulating, but less firm, ground with his tacit approval of what he calls the coming of "neo-imperialism" in advertising. As an illustration, Delaney uses the example of the Nike athletic equipment trademark. Advertising creative is approved in Oregon, Nike's headquarters, and used around the world. If consumers in France or Germany or Australia respond to it then they are "Nike people" and may buy the company's products. But if other consumers in Sweden or Spain or Brazil do not respond to the same ad they are not Nike people and so beyond this athletic shoe's pale.

Canadian ad agencies might find Delaney's prediction of a coming neo-imperialism at odds with his earlier suggestion that small shops are the future. His reasonable views on the breakup of the multinationals might leave them wondering where the power to back this neo-imperialism will come from if not from the multinational agencies. Delaney would counter that technology has levelled the playing field, giving even the smallest of agencies ready access to the new neo-imperialist market.

Whether Delaney's predictions are right or wrong, time, of course, will tell. But for those agencies blinking out at North America and beyond from agency centres across Canada, it is heartening to be reminded once again that new opportunities are unfolding, and that the basis for successful advertising continues to be nothing more complicated than clear thinking.


LOAD-DATE: April 21, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 Brunico Communications, Inc.

 

976 of 998 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


February 13, 1991, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


COMMENTARY;
New shoe motto: Don't tread on me


BYLINE: Tom Weir


SECTION: SPORTS; Tom Weir; Pg. 3C


LENGTH: 633 words


Michael Jordan was talking about Dominique Wilkins, and the words weren't friendly.

''I know what he's doing,'' Jordan said suspiciously before the NBA All- Star Game. ''When someone's on top of you, you try to knock him off. But I'm going to take a Carolina approach, and keep it clean, and stay on top.'' 

What exactly had 'Nique been doing to Jordan? Body slams in the lane? Submarining him on layups?

No, Wilkins had committed the sin that has been forbidden since Elvis warned the world not to step on his blue suede shoes.

Wilkins is among the Reebok crew of ''pump up'' endorsers who have been needling Nike on television ads. Air bags vs. Air Jordan. Nike has threatened to take legal action against Reebok's leapers, a case made for a kangaroo court if ever there was one.

What is it about shoes that breeds such hostility?

They have been a source of easily injured pride dating to when ''Your mother wears combat boots'' still was an insult. For all her faults, what really bugged us about Imelda Marcos was her warehouse full of shoes. And those who like to tweak Nevada-Las Vegas about its courtside seats filled with high-rollers always snidely refer to it as ''Gucci Row.''

Boston's Dee Brown kicked the shoe confrontation up a notch Saturday, when he paused before each of his attempts in the dunk contest to pump up his Reeboks. Dee-bok swears it was his idea, and maybe so, but somewhere a commercial is being filmed of the newly crowned slam champ.

But maybe Reebok should be worried. Playgrounds are on the verge of becoming pumpatoriums. The inevitable peer pressure could lead to a new kind of game of chicken, to see who can take the most pumps. Watch out for the injury of the '90s: ankle strangulation.

It's amazing how far we've come from the days when there truly was only one shoe a dignified athlete could wear. The Converse Chuck Taylor model came only in white and black. Why they bothered to have the black model was a mystery, because only the Celtics wore them and they made even the world champs look dorky.

Then came the major breakthrough in the '60s. Someone in the back shop let a pair of scissors slip, and thus the low-cut was born. Wow. Two styles. This is like when Baskin-Robbins served only chocolate and vanilla.

Today Nike and Reebok are at the same kind of odds as Coke and Pepsi. One wonders how much of Nike's jealousy has to do with the Laker Girls' collective bustline being turned into a Reebok billboard. Or that infamous but quickly pulled ad with the bungee-cord jumpers, where the Reebok-shorn guy survives but the kid clad in Nikes disappears into the abyss (kind of like going to the Sacramento Kings).

Shoe battles aren't new. The first two companies to go at it - adidas and Puma - were run by German brothers named Dassler who carried on a lifelong feud.

And the stakes are high, as L.A. Gear learned when it suffered a public relations disaster in December. Marquette freshman Robb Logterman drove the lane at Kansas, only to suffer a blowout the likes of which even Goodyear seldom sees. His shoe simply fell apart, and left behind in the paint was Logterman's filet of sole.

It turned out Marquette was going through its L.A. Gear (Joe Montana's brand) by the gross, and within the month the Warriors switched to Nike.

Nike also got the last word before All-Star weekend ended, as Jordan got a foothold on revenge.

In Sunday's All-Star Game, Wilkins blew the opportunity to become the all- time ham of slam. With no defender near, Wilkins went up for one of the from- the-hip, over-the-shoulder power dunks that he invented, only to miss. This is what's called an air dunk.

After seeing Wilkins suffer the ultimate showtime embarrassment, Jordan issued an epitaph for the times: ''He forgot to pump up.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w; PHOTO; b/w, H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY
 
CUTLINE: DEE BROWN: Dunk contest champ gets in some air time.


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

980 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 15, 1992, Friday


NOTEBOOK Cox will spread around save chances in bullpen


BYLINE: By I.J. Rosenberg STAFF WRITERsports; baseball; football; competition


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 4


LENGTH: 255 words


Until Alejandro Pena works out his problems on the mound, the Atlanta Braves will turn to Marvin Freeman and Mike Stanton more often in the closer's role, despite Freeman's blown save Thursday night.

Pena has blown two save opportunities and given up the winning run three times in his last four appearances. 

"We'll move it around until some things straighten out," said manager Bobby Cox.

Freeman inherited a 3-2 lead and a base-loaded situation in the ninth Thursday, then gave up a two-run single to Pittsburgh's Jeff King as the Pirates rallied for a 4-3 win.

That won't change his plan, Cox said. "I thought Marvin pitched well. His pitch to King was a jam shot and it found the right hole. Then he comes back and strikes out the next two guys."

Freeman had two saves in his previous two opportunities. Stanton was out of uniform Tuesday and Wednesday because of a viral infection and was available Thursday night only for one inning.

FOOTBALL NOT A MUST: The new shoe deal Deion Sanders signed with Nike does not require him to play football, according to Sanders's agent, Eugene Parker. Sanders will help endorse Nike's cross-trainer shoe and his first commercial is expected to air in July around the All-Star Game. . . . First baseman Sid Bream is bothered by a hamstring pull, but it is not expected to keep him out of the lineup. He will have a few days to rest because the Braves faced a lefthander Thursday night and are scheduled to go against another one tonight, meaning Brian Hunter starts at first.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

981 of 998 DOCUMENTS


Business Times (Singapore)


Fels' US subsidiary completes US$ 2.7m rig conversion job


September 23, 1992


SINGAPORE -Amfels Inc, Far East Levingston Shipbuilding's US subsidiary, has completed a US$ 2.75 million (S$ 4.4 million) contract to convert a jack-up rig to a shallow water-drilling unit for Houston's Western Oceanic Inc.

Amfels designed, constructed and installed additional quarters and two side sponsons -- box-like structures which adjust the rig's buoyancy -on the Nike I. The contract was unique because the quarters and the sponsons were retractable, allowing the rig to be returned to its original class of jack-up rig if necessary, a Fels statement said.

The two sponsons were added to increase Nike I's buoyancy, enabling the rig to operate in waters as shallow as eight feet. They match the hull's 20-foot depth and add 20 feet on each side of the hull, providing sufficient deck space for the additional accomodation unit.

Following the conversion, oil company Chevron Nigeria will use the rig for shallow water drilling in Nigeria.

Under the contract, Amfels also relocated cranes and upgraded the Nike I. Work on the rig was completed in less than 12 weeks. Meanwhile, Fels has completed the acquisition of the remaining 23 per cent stake in Amfels.


SECTION: Shipping Times; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 374 words

984 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)


March 14, 1992, Saturday, FINAL EDITION


Oceanographer tracks the great Nike shoe spill


BYLINE: KEAY DAVIDSON; SAN FRANCISCO EXAMINER


SECTION: SCIENCE: EARTH MATTERS; ENVIROLINE; Pg. J6/BREAK


LENGTH: 444 words


DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO


For some beachcombers, it was a gift from the sea: hundreds of pairs of Nike shoes that floated on to Pacific Northwest beaches.

But for oceanographer Curtis Ebbesmeyer, the veritable school of shoes offers a chance to study a scientific wonder: the circulation of the Pacific Ocean - circulation that, over thousands of years, has influenced climate, tribal migration, oil spills and where drowning victims wash ashore.

It was one of the oddest marine mishaps of the decade. On May 27, 1990, a freighter in the North Pacific encountered a storm. Numerous containers fell overboard and broke open, dumping 80,000 athletic shoes, boots and golf shoes into the drink. 

Seven months later, the first shoes drifted on to North American beaches. Beachcombers recovered about 100 shoes on the western side of Vancouver Island. On March 26, 1991, 250 were found on the coast of southern Alaska. By May, hundreds more had been found as far south as Oregon.

About 1,300 shoes have been recovered to date, says Ebbesmeyer, of Evans-Hamilton Inc., a consulting-oceanography firm in Seattle.

"I wouldn't be surprised if more start to come to shore. But some might drift in different directions - say, to Hawaii or Indonesia. They might continue floating out there for years," said Ebbesmeyer.

Many beachcombers scrubbed salt and barnacles off the shoes, dried them out and discovered them to be snug fits. They held swap meets to exchange shoe sizes.

"I got about 140 pairs of Nikes and another 60 pairs of golf shoes by Etonic," said Steve McLeod, 47, of Cannon Beach, Ore. "I have about 16 pairs that fit me, and I've shoed my entire family."

The shoe spill intrigued Ebbesmeyer, who tracks ocean debris to better understand Pacific circulation.

The Pacific isn't simply a big basin of salt water - it's a realm of constantly circulating "rivers" of water. Some spiral endlessly; others slosh back and forth from the chill waters of the north to the warmer waters of the south. Changes of temperature, season, salinity and tides influence ocean circulation.

Using information gathered from coastal dwellers, Ebbesmeyer is developing a map showing where and when shoes reached land. So far, his findings pretty well match the accepted behavior of Pacific currents.

Based on the movements, he calculates the shoes could have moved eastward at an average speed of 6.5 km a day, assuming they moved in a straight line.

However, they probably first travelled in a loop in the Gulf of Alaska, then moved toward North America. The "loop" would have added 2,900 km to their journey. Hence, their true speed of travel could be closer to 16 km a day.


LOAD-DATE: March 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 CanWest Interactive, a division of
CanWest Global Communications Corp.
All Rights Reserved

 

986 of 998 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


October 12, 1992 Monday  
FINAL EDITION


DEION STRETCHES DUAL ROLE TO THE LIMIT


BYLINE: Tim Rosaforte


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 7C


LENGTH: 1125 words


DATELINE: MIAMI


The white stretch Lincoln was a 10-yard completion, the front bumper to its open trunk. It was a prime-time kind of ride waiting in front of the Atlanta

Falcons team buses on a hot October afternoon at Joe Robbie Stadium. A

security man wearing a headset guarded the limo.

Inside the Falcons' locker room, Deion Sanders was stretched out on a

training table, lying flat on his back, with a needle stuck in his arm and an intravenous bottle hanging from the ceiling over his head. 

This is what it had come to. Deion with a doctor squeezing the last drops from the plastic bag into his arm.

"He just wants to make that game," said team physician Charles Harrison.

At 4:50 p.m., Deion got up off the training table, put on his Nike hat and Nike T-shirt and Nike sandals, threw on a pair of black shades, and started

making his way to the limo, limping every step of the way. It wasn't that he

was too tired to talk. He had a plane to catch.

Actually he had a limo to catch.

And then a helicopter to catch.

And then a plane to catch out of Opa-locka Airport for a 2 hour, 20-minute flight to Pittsburgh for Game 5 of the National League Championship Series.

The door closed on his limo at 4:52. The helicopter was waiting in the

parking lot on the west side of JRS. It was airborne a little after 5 o'clock, approximately 12 hours after Sanders checked into the Falcons' team hotel in Fort Lauderdale Sunday morning.

"You have to really look at, if it was you in that situation, what would you do?" said Bobby Butler, the 12-year veteran from Delray Beach and Florida State. "Every athlete here would do the same thing."

GETTING HIS PROPERS

If you think this sideshow distracted the Falcons in their pursuit of

victory against the Dolphins, you're wrong. Sanders hasn't set foot on the

team's training facility in Suwanee, Ga., since the Monday after the Green Bay game. That was Sept. 28-- 14 days ago.

Yet he has enough natural ability to go out on a field where the head

index was in triple digits and play every down at cornerback, two at wide

receiver, and seven as a kick returner. He made three tackles, all of them

after pass completions to Mark Duper.

"I have a new-found respect for the guy pulling something like that

off," said Tim McKyer, the former Dolphin who plays on the opposite corner.

"It says a lot about Deion. It says a lot about how he feels about the

game.

"We really appreciate him coming out here and doing it for us."

Was Sanders doing it for "us"-- the Falcons? Or was he doing it for

Deion-- and Nike? Those are the big questions surrounding this "Play Two"

circus that redefined the old Ernie Banks quote.

Sanders made $118,000 in Falcons' pay by showing up for Game 6 of their

NFL season. It also was a made-for-TV publicity stunt that is camera-ready for a Nike commercial. The only character missing was Spike Lee.

"He asked us to help him," said Anne Scearce of Nike Sports Management.

"We'd do anything we can to help Deion with his career goals."

And just what are those? It's hard to tell because one day Sanders wants to be a pro baseball player, the next day he wants to be a pro football

player, and on Sunday, he wanted to be both.

It doesn't seem to bother the Falcons. It's the Braves who are calling it a "distraction."

"What goes unnoticed about him?" wondered coach Jerry Glanville in the

Falcons locker room. "Everyone notices his athletic ability, everyone notices his God-given talent. But what's inside of him, how much he cares, is even

bigger than his ability."

NOTHING SPECTACULAR

His heart may be the size of his ego, but Sanders' game was just

average. He didn't strike out twice on six pitches, which he's done in the

NLCS. But he was flagged for one pass interference penalty and he had a second flag put back in the back judge's pocket when it was ruled that Dan Marino's

pass to Duper was not catchable.

"They went out of their way to call it on Deion," Andre Rison said.

The Dolphins went out of their way to test Sanders early. Marino's first play of the game was a deep out to Duper that sailed incomplete. Sanders was

never burned, other than the 47-yard pass interference penalty, which didn't

cost the Falcons any points.

On offense, he caught a flanker screen and ran for a 9-yard gain in the

second quarter. On the last play before the half, he ran down the field under Chris Miller's Hail Mary pass that landed out of bounds.

By the second half, it was obvious the heat was getting to him. He

stopped going to the Falcons' defensive huddles and his limp became more

noticeable. No plays from this game will make any of Deion's highlight films. Yet it was a statement not only to Deion's marketability, but his ability as

an athlete.

Bo may know, but Deion is the show.

DEION'S DAY

Some of the highlights of Deion Sanders' same-day, different-city, two-

sport doubleheader.

* 12:18 a.m. Sunday in Pittsburgh-- Sanders, wearing sunglasses and

outlined by the klieg lights of a dozen TV cameras, climbs into a stretch

limousine outside Three Rivers Stadium after playing two innings in left field and striking out in his only at-bat in the Atlanta Braves' 6-4 win over the

Pittsburgh Pirates in Game 4 of the National League playoffs.

* 12:58 a.m. in West Mifflin, Pa.-- Sanders and his entourage board a

chartered Canadair CL601 jet at Allegheny County Airport in nearby West

Mifflin, Pa., for 2-hour, 20-minute flight to Fort Lauderdale. Aboard are his girlfriend, Carolyn Chambers, their 2-year-old daughter, Diondra, his

attorney, Eugene Parker, and a CBS camera crew.

* 3:52 a.m. in Dania, Fla.-- Sanders, in a stretch limo again, arrives at the hotel where his Atlanta Falcons teammates are staying.

* 12:14 p.m. in Miami-- Sanders emerges from the tunnel at Joe Robbie

Stadium for the Falcons' 1 p.m. start against the Dolphins.

* 4:06 p.m.-- Walks off field of Joe Robbie Stadium, helmet in hand, head down following the Falcons' 21-17 loss.

* 4:48 p.m.-- Sanders walks from training room to a waiting limousine.

* 4:55 p.m.-- Limousine leaves stadium en route to helicopter pad, where a helicopter waits to take him to Opa-locka Airport, where a private jet waits

to take him to Pittsburgh.

* 5:19 p.m.-- Private jet leaves Opa-locka Airport.

* 7:45 p.m., (estimated) in West Mifflin, Pa.-- Sanders' chartered jet

lands. Sanders, Parker and an aide board a helicopter for the short flight

downtown.

* 8:01 p.m. in Pittsburgh-- Atop the Channel 11 building in downtown

Pittsburgh, Sanders lands and heads downstairs for a waiting limousine.

* 8:26 p.m.-- At a side entrance to Three Rivers Stadium, Sanders slips

out of a black limousine, wearing a baseball cap, sunglasses, windbreaker,

shorts and flip-flop sandals. Sanders brushes past waiting camera crews and

reporters without saying a word.

* 8:43 p.m.-- First pitch of Game 5. Sanders is not in the starting

lineup.


LOAD-DATE: June 6, 2011


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LOREN G. HOSACK/Staff Photographer Atlanta's Deion Sanders (21) leaves the field with Charles Washington and team personnel headed for the locker room, a limo, a helicopter, a jet and Pittsburgh for the Braves' Game 5 of the NLCS.

988 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Washington Post


July 23, 1992, Thursday, Final Edition


A Sneaker Maker Loses Its Magic;
Star's Parting Shot as Converse Endorser Underscores Firm's Troubles in Ad Race


Paul Farhi, Washington Post Staff Writer


SECTION: STYLE; PAGE D10


LENGTH: 944 words


In the never-ending race for the sneaker-buying public's hearts and feet, Converse Inc. has just been left flat-footed.

Earvin "Magic" Johnson, the basketball megastar, ubiquitous pitchman and AIDS activist, said yesterday that he was walking away from Converse, the athletic-shoe company that he has served as an endorser for the past 13 years. His departure was accompanied by a parting shot: Converse, Magic Johnson admonished, had misunderstood the rules of modern sneaker salesmanship by failing to make the most of ... Magic Johnson.

"Converse is still living in the 1960s and '70s," Johnson told the Associated Press after a U.S. Olympic basketball team practice in Monaco yesterday. "They haven't arrived in the '80s and '90s where advertising and marketing are the keys." 

Johnson's announcement was a bombshell to those involved in the $ 12 billion-a-year sneaker business -- including Converse, which expressed "surprise and shock" at the news. The reaction underscored a basic tenet of the business: Athletic shoes, and basketball shoes in particular, live and die on the strength of superstar endorsers like Johnson, Michael Jordan and David Robinson.

Several sports marketing specialists said yesterday that Johnson's criticism was on target. They said Converse, in a battle for basketball-shoe supremacy with Nike Inc., Reebok International Ltd. and L.A. Gear Inc., had booted an opportunity to raise its profile by boosting Johnson's.

"When you get an athlete on his level, it's not just dollars alone that's important," said Stephen Disson, president of the D&F Group, a Washington firm that develops sports events for corporate sponsors. "It's extremely critical to them how they are used in TV and print advertising. I'm sure Magic sees what Nike is doing with Michael Jordan. [Johnson] isn't jealous, he's just saying, 'This is how [a corporation] should use an athlete.' "

Once the preeminent basketball shoe marketer with its classic-but-clunky Chuck Taylor All-Star line, Converse has been under siege in recent years. Nike and Reebok, in particular, have waged high-profile ad campaigns for their Air Jordan and Pump models, respectively, and have poured money into developing sleek, albeit pricey, new lines.

Converse, meanwhile, has labored to keep pace. It has been criticized for being slow to introduce a line of "Magic" shoes and sportswear; it didn't get around to that until last year, long after Nike and others had flooded the market with their own "signature" products.

Moreover, Converse's ads built around its association with Johnson are dimly remembered at best, even within the industry. The company has had more luck with another Johnson, Charlotte Hornets rookie Larry Johnson, who has starred in a well-received series of commercials dressed like his grandmother (the ads' conceit is that even a senior citizen can beat an NBA player in Converse shoes).

"One thing that has driven Nike is their creativity and their ability to use the strengths of their [endorsers] in their ads," said Bill Strickland, president of the basketball division of International Management Group, the nation's largest sports agents' firm. "You don't see any of that from Converse. ... For the association with Converse not to be stronger would suggest that [Johnson's criticism] is on point."

Yet another shoe could drop soon for Converse. Sources said yesterday that tennis star and Converse endorser Jimmy Connors will end his association with the company shortly. (Converse has issued a statement repudiating press reports that Johnson's fellow basketball star, Larry Bird, was considering bolting from the company's employ too.)

In Monaco yesterday, Johnson indicated that his unhappiness with Converse began when he first signed with the company. Then, Converse boasted an all-star lineup of endorsers -- Johnson, Bird, Julius "Dr. J" Erving, Kevin McHale of Boston and Isiah Thomas of Detroit. "I kept telling them they weren't taking advantage of that situation," Johnson told the AP.

"At that time, everybody was calling Converse shoes 'Docs' on the playground because of Doctor J. [Erving's nickname]. I said they should just call the shoes 'Docs.' But they told me a player will never sell shoes. Then Michael Jordan came along and he proved them wrong, but they're still saying it."

Johnson added that Converse "got tired of me complaining and I got tired of them not listening."

Converse President Gilbert "Gib" Ford called Johnson's comments "surprising," especially since Johnson is under contract with Converse for two more years. That could limit Johnson's ability to seek another shoe endorsement deal.

The company issued a statement saying that it has spent more than $ 35 million on advertising and marketing programs featuring Johnson, including a special public-service campaign called "Magic's Athletes Against AIDS" last fall after Johnson announced that he has the virus that leads to AIDS. It said it would launch a second AIDS campaign with Johnson later this summer, and it is currently airing an ad with an Olympics theme featuring him, Bird and Larry Johnson.

Converse, however, may not have had the financial muscle to play with the big boys recently. Its parent company, Interco Inc., a conglomerate that also owns the London Fog raincoat brand, has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since the beginning of last year.

Although Converse's ad budget isn't known, observers said the company has cut back on media advertising to conserve cash, concentrating instead on "grass roots" marketing, building its brand by supplying shoes to amateur and pro teams.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


SERIES: Occasional


GRAPHIC: PHOTO, EARVIN "MAGIC" JOHNSON AS HE INTRODUCED A NEW LINE OF SPORTSWEAR IN 1990. YESTERDAY, THE STAR SAID HE WAS DEPARTING THE FIRM AS ENDORSER. UPI


TYPE: FEATURE


Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

 

992 of 998 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


September 9, 1992 Wednesday


CANADIAN OPEN Sparks flying off the greens


BYLINE: LORNE RUBENSTEIN; GAM


LENGTH: 776 words


DATELINE: Oakville, Ont.


LORNE RUBENSTEIN
Oakville, Ont.
THE lush green fairways of the Glen Abbey Golf Club will be full of some
of the top players in the world when the Canadian Open begins tomorrow.
But last evening at a player"Tour meeting a series of issues concerning
the Tour were paramount, and they will continue to be so until they are
resolved.

The meeting apparently concerned a number of related issues. One
central item concerns the number of players exempt for the following
season. Currently the top 125 money-winners are exempt. Other criteria
also admit more players, but that number is the most significant. 

Some players, Tom Watson for one, have long felt that too many players
get in by virtue of finishing in the top 125. The argument is that a
player can go along making $30,000 or $40,000 for the season and then
break through with a late-season second or third place. Bingo, he's
exempt.

Limiting exemptions to perhaps 110 or 115 makes many players
uncomfortable. Jeff Sluman is one of four player directors on the 10-man
tournament policy board, and said yesterday that it's not easy to think
about reducing opportunities. That would be one inevitable result of
changes to the all-exempt list.

But the question of the number of exempt players does not exist in
isolation. PGA Tour commissioner Deane Beman pointed out at the Abbey that
it's related to the persistent problem of slow play, and also to the
question of stocking what was the Ben Hogan Tour and is now the Nike Tour.

The Nike Tour is a secondary series of 30 tournaments that the PGA Tour
will run next season, as it has the Hogan Tour. It's a breeding ground for
future PGA Tour players. Tom Lehman is one such player. He led the Hogan
Tour in winnings last year and has won $424,378 on the PGA Tour this year
for 25th place.

The PGA Tour wants more players on the Nike Tour. That can be seen
either as a benevolent notion that would give players some experience
before they reach the PGA Tour. A cynic might argue that moving the
golfers who finish from 110th to 125th from the PGA Tour to the Nike Tour
is a lazy and harsh way of ridding the big circuit of unwanted players.

There's also the vexing problem of slow play. Some players said it
would be the main issue on last night's agenda. Any reduction in exempt
players would feed into the number of contestants in PGA Tour events.
There's talk that the number should go from 156 players in summer's full
fields to 132.

Beman said that slow play is indeed a serious concern. He mentioned
that there are too many players on the course before the field is cut
after 36 holes.

Have fewer exempt players, then. Drop some sponsor exemptions. Erase
local qualifying each Monday that admits four players. So go some of the
ideas.

Paul Azinger, like other golfers, believes Tour officials should simply
get tougher on slow play. A player is currently warned that he is being
timed. If he is timed twice as playing slowly then he is fined $500. Four
bad times gets him a $1,500 penalty, with two shots added to his score.

But PGA Tour officials are reluctant to impose slow play penalties.

"I'll tell you what," Azinger said. "Our officials would have trouble
giving me two shots, or fining me for slow play. They know me, and all of
them but one like me. It's harder to fine a player you know and like. It
may not be so hard for an official to fine a player he doesn't like."

Azinger mentioned Scott Hoch as one player who might fall into the
latter category. His point was that personal attachments get in the way of
assessing penalties.

Player director Peter Jacobsen had something of the same idea. He
called slow play a "joke," said "there are too many bodies out here," and
suggested that rules officals are too important to be speed cops.

"The best way to deal with slow play is with peer pressure," Jacobsen
said.

Who knows? Maybe he will name the slow players in a book he has written
for spring publication. It's called Buried Lies: Tall Tales and True
Stories from the PGA Tour. Azinger mentioned that one of Jacobsen's ideas
is to fine a slow player 10 per cent of his earnings at an event.

PGA Championship winner and defending Canadian Open champion Nick Price
argued slightly differently.

"We know who the slow players are out here," Price said. "We should be
dealing with them."

Players wouldn't say for publication who the slow players are. But many
could take lessons from fast players Price, Daly, Watson and Lanny
Wadkins.

It all amounts to plenty of important issues on the PGA Tour. Careers
could be at stake. It remains to be seen what will emerge from last
night's meeting. One thing was certain as night settled on Glen Abbey: The
meeting was going to be well-attended, and sparks would fly.


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1992 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

 

994 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Toronto Star


June 30, 1991, Sunday, SUNDAY SECOND EDITION


Ailing Bo Jackson still working in TV ads


BYLINE: By SKIP WOLLENBERG (AP)


SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. F1


LENGTH: 1087 words


DATELINE: CULVER CITY, Calif.


 
   CULVER CITY, Calif. (AP) - Bo Jackson's hip injury put his professional baseball and football careers on hold, but hasn't cost him a step in his other high-paying job - commercial pitchman.

Ad makers for Pepsi-Cola Co. and Nike Inc. have even turned Bo's injury to their advantage, pressing him into service in new advertising.

"What else have I got to do this summer?," Jackson says as he sits in a beach chair in a cameo appearance in Pepsi's summer ad campaign. 

He does everything but relax in the latest and probably the last edition of his "Bo Knows . . ." commercials for Nike.

In a commercial filmed at the Culver City Studios, Jackson abruptly walks out on his own Las Vegas-style show to start some serious rehabilitation in the gym. That leaves the door open for that burger-eating boxer George Foreman and others who jump at the chance to fill Bo's shoes in the lounge act.

The new Nike ads begin running July 9 during the All-Star baseball game telecast, the same occasion Nike used two years ago to launch the series with a commercial that also featured another famous Bo, bluesman Bo Diddley.

That commercial and a 1990 ad that showed Jackson ready to compete in a dozen different sports made him one of the best-known athlete endorsers in the business and added a phrase to the American vernacular.

As the rare athlete who successfully competes in two professional sports, Jackson was a natural fit for Nike's cross-training shoe, designed for multiple uses - running, shooting baskets, lifting weights, riding a bike.

Helped by Jackson's commercials, Nike says sales of the shoes have climbed from nothing in 1987 to about $400 million (U.S.) this year, making them second only to basketball shoes among top-ranked Nike's best-selling models.

Consumer surveys by the research firm Video Storyboard Tests Inc. indicated Jackson was the best-known endorser from sports in 1989 and ranked him second only to football's Joe Montana in 1990. The 1991 results aren't in yet.

Sports Marketing Letter rated Jackson as the 10th most sought-after sports figure by marketers this year despite the hip injury. The newsletter's publisher, Brian Murphy, estimated Jackson will make $5 million this year from advertising, several million more than he will likely make from sports.

The injury Jackson suffered while playing football for the Los Angeles Raiders has prevented him from playing baseball this year. The Kansas City Royals dropped him after doctors said he might never play again, but he was signed by the Chicago White Sox.

His doctors say Jackson is making progress and will be re-evaluated over the All-Star break to see if he can play baseball this season.

But his injury raised questions about Jackson's commercial career. Some marketing experts said Jackson would likely fade from view as many retired athletes have if he were unable to play again. Others said his struggle back would keep people interested.

Jackson's agent, Richard Woods, said Jackson remains in demand.

Besides the extra work for Pepsi and Nike, Woods said, Jackson is promoting lines of sports medicine and fitness products and is considering two major endorsement offers that wouldn't have been made without the injury. Woods declined to identify them.

Even before Jackson was injured, Nike's ad makers had been seeking a way to give the "Bo Knows" series of ads a big

sendoff.

"The whole 'Bo Knows' thing had been overexposed," said Jim Riswold, the Wieden & Kennedy ad writer who created the series three years ago. "The time to end 'Bo knows' has come."

Scott Bedbury, Nike's advertising director, agreed that he would be "very surprised" to see any more variations on the theme next year although Nike will probably use Jackson in other commercials.

Riswold came up with a stylish sendoff.

Jackson is the star of the "Bo Show," a garish act with 20 chorus girls in White Sox or Raiders jerseys, a 30- piece orchestra and Bo's name in lights.

"Bo knows it's got that air thing," the chorus girls sing as they dance around Jackson, who is wearing a tuxedo and has a microphone in hand.

But after a few choruses, Jackson has second thoughts. He yells for the band to stop. "This is ridiculous," he says, walking off the stage.

The camera then moves to a living room where the TV set is tuned to the Bo show. Mom is shocked and Dad looks perplexed as Bo crawls through the set.

"I've got rehab to do," Jackson mutters as he reaches back into the set for his cross-trainers.

"Nice shoes," a boy sitting on the floor says as Jackson passes through the living room.

"You watch too much TV, kid," Jackson shoots back.

In the gym, Jackson lifts weights, pedals a stationary bike and works out in the pool. He can't shake that irritating "air thing" song, though.

"You know I don't have time for this," he yells at the Nike logo.

After Jackson walks away, the logo rolls up, revealing the same glitzy set where the backlights have been changed to read, "Not Bo."

"But I do," says Foreman, dressed in a tux and surrounded by the chorus girls now dressed in boxer shorts and orange boxing gloves.

"Hit it," Foreman orders, as the band plays again and the girls sing "George knows . . ."

Nike has three other endings for use later in the year.

In one version, Los Angeles Kings star Wayne Gretzky takes over from Bo, a throwback to the original "Bo knows . . ." ad where Gretzky was the only athlete unable to attest that Jackson could play his sport - ice hockey.

The other versions end with pairs of athletes - Darryl Strawberry of baseball's Los Angeles Dodgers and Jerry Rice of football's San Francisco 49ers in one; Eric Davis of baseball's Cincinnati Reds and Randall Cunningham of football's Philadelphia Eagles in the other.

The "Bo knows . . . " campaign may provide the grist for trivia games a few years from now. Jackson may turn up in nostalgic beer or credit card ads.

Or the ads may have sent Jackson on the road to a long career as a celebrity spokesperson.

"He represents not only a versatile athlete but the whole fad of being fit," said David Vadehra, head of Video Storyboard Tests, the firm that quizzes thousands of people each year on what commercials they liked best.

Sports Marketing Letter's Murphy envisions Jackson effectively pitching recreational sports such as golf, weight training or tennis.

"The idea has already been established in the public's mind that this is a guy who does everything," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photos TV STAR: Bo Jackson has made new TV commercials that will debut during the All-Star game and appeared on Sesame Street.Bo; Jackson; advertising; sports; marketing


Copyright 1991 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

 

996 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 3, 1992, Monday


Defections like Jordan's could sap NBA's financial strength


BYLINE: Ailene Voisinbasketball; personalities; advertising; finances; business


SECTION: SPORTS; Section E; Page 2


LENGTH: 704 words


Michael Jordan stuck his tongue out at the NBA and its Players Association last week. Stuck it in their faces big time. No longer, he informed them, could they place his tongue or his ears or his nose - in essence, his likeness - on league-licensed apparel.

Michael chose to withdraw from the league-union group licensing agreement because the players' share of the approximately $ 45 million-$ 50 million annual revenue is a mere $ 500,000, all of which is placed in a pension fund. He broke ranks - as was his right - and gave exclusive rights to his mug to Nike. 

The reaction has been swift, though not certain. This is rarefied Air, yet to be fully navigated or comprehended. Jordan thus is perceived as greedy by some, while others accuse the league of being exploitative and the union ill-advised.

There is some truth in all of this. But in all of this is a much larger issue. Namely, what becomes of the once-powerful union that forged a unique revenue-sharing alliance with management to resurrect an economically crippled league and ensure prosperity for all? How quickly all is threatened.

How quickly all is forgotten.

While Jordan was enrolling in North Carolina and Nike was in its infancy during the early 1980s, the league's owners and players sacrificed, they shared, and together they savored. Failing franchises were revived. Insolvent owners were displaced. Television contracts and marketing revenues soared. (Players share 53 percent of the gross.) And the league once perceived as that of drug users and deviates became a glitzy rock-and-roll road show featuring Doc, Magic, Larry.

No one wants the show to end. Yet many foresee Jordan's defection as potentially disastrous, with other premier Nike endorsers sure to follow, and other, similar developments equally sure to threaten the collective fiber of the union-league relationship.

Strange alliances once again are quickly forming. NBA commissioner David Stern - ever cognizant that his league has never had a strike - is monitoring the situation closely, perhaps to intervene at some point. The union's executive director, Charles Grantham, who inherited the current agreement from Larry Fleisher, is anxious, concerned. Union president Isiah Thomas is both disheartened and fearful.

Though quick to concede the group licensing agreement is inadequate in today's market, Thomas believes the matter will be resolved during the next collective bargaining session in 1993-94. Or, if Jordan was so dissatisfied, why didn't he form his own apparel company - as did Magic - and become one of the NBA's authorized licensees?

"None of us can say that what Michael is doing is wrong," said Thomas, "but would I do it? No. I've always tried to do what's best for the league, without forgetting that it was a group approach that made us strong."

Several of Thomas's friends say he is so disheartened by recent developments that he considered resigning, then reconsidered. The timing, he felt, was not right.

The timing, in fact, could hardly be worse.

The league is still reeling from the news that Magic has the HIV virus. Bird is fast nearing retirement, and even Jordan and Charles Barkley are closing in on the end. Their successors - those stars or characters with charisma - are yet to be named. Yet to be sighted.

Economically, the next big television contract appears to be a thing of the past, with networks feeling the pinch. The union and league already are embroiled in a legal debate over defined gross revenue. Other skirmishes await. And just outside the arenas, the homeless, the unemployed, the many without quality health care illustrate how Americans are continuing to suffer from the me-first mistakes and fiscal foibles of decades past.

Is there perhaps a lesson to be learned here? Just a few.

Jordan is a good guy, a bright guy. Magic likes him immensely and is quick to acknowledge that he has every right to capitalize in a capitalistic society. "But I do want to talk to him about this," said Magic. "I want to hear his motives. Is he mad at the union? Something else? I want to find out."

But not lost on Magic is the irony of the 1992 NBA Finals.

Jordan agreed to share the wealth.

And look who won.


LOAD-DATE: March 5, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

 

998 of 998 DOCUMENTS


The Independent (London)


August 28, 1991, Wednesday


Column Eight: SNC beats rivals to Albania


BYLINE: By PATRICK HOSKING


SECTION: BUSINESS AND CITY PAGE; Page 29 


LENGTH: 395 words


Smith New Court is claiming a first in Eastern Europe. While rival advisers are fighting for hotel rooms in Prague and Budapest, it has ventured into Tirana, capital of Albania.

Alexander Duma, director of SNC Corporate Finance, has introduced the South African firm Samancor to the Albanian government, an introduction which may lead to a joint venture to mine chrome ore. 

Mr Duma, who first set foot in Albania three weeks ago, admits to one advantage over rival advisers: ''I'm Albanian.'' His father Dervish was secretary of the Albanian legation in London before Mussolini invaded Albania.

Joggers, do not remove your plimsolls. ADT, the car auctions firm which is axing its dividend, may have run out of puff. But it will still sponsor next year's marathon, director David Hammond promises.

The American sports clothes group Nike is having a run of bad luck. It has already had to fork out repeatedly to the Russian pole-vaulter Sergei Bubka. It pays him a $ 50,000 bonus every time he breaks the world record. Mr Bubka breaks it often, half-inch by half-inch.

Now, who should be ignominiously knocked out of the first round of the US Tennis Open than Nike's champion clothes horse Andre Agassi.

Upper lip stiff, Don Wood, Nike's marketing manager for tennis, sums up admirably: ''Last year Andre got into the finals, getting us a great deal of invaluable exposure for our products. . . Er, this year we weren't so lucky.''

An Asda Group annual report thumps on to the desk. No mention of compensation for John Hardman and Graham Stow, the directors ousted in June. Their packages are almost finalised, according to finance director Ron Scott, and will appear in the next report.

There's been less progress, it seems, on finding a new chief executive. ''Candidates are being seen,'' is all Mr Scott will volunteer.

One piece of good news is that chairman Sir Godfrey Messervy, 66, is back in the saddle after his heart attack and will chair the annual meeting next month. ''He's proving pretty robust,'' says Mr Scott.

With no chief executive to share the work, he 'Asda be (to borrow a slogan).

Timothy Dewhirst, chief executive of clothing supplier Dewhirst Group, is ambiguous about second-half prospects: ''If Christmas doesn't happen, then we are all in trouble. But then Christmas always happens, doesn't it?''

On 25 December, they say.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Independent Print Ltd
